Title: “Looking good is like plating well”
Content: Fashion is... Functional and multi-dimensional. I opt for attire that carries me through a multi-faceted schedule, which is almost every day!5 essentials of a man’s wardrobe- A good pair of jeans and joggers, crisp white shirt and shirt-style kurtas, scarves in versatile colours, a well-fitted tailored jacket and semi-formal shoes.My everyday outfit- Easy, breezy kurtas or shirts in breathable, sustainable fabrics with comfortable trousers and a jacket on reserve – for any unexpected meetings.My shopping strategy- Call my designer friends, tell them what I am looking for and wait for them to interpret that into clothes.A grooming tip- Skincare is a must – something men take for granted. A good vitamin C serum is a must-do routine.A style trick- Wear Punjabi juttis – they are a statement and yet can be muted.A fashion trend I hate- I am not really a big fan of accessorising with beads, a good watch is all you need.A fashion trend I love- The whole idea of athleisure and also cropped and short trousers. They are lazy yet functional, crisp and effective.Fashion blunder- Long socks with cropped pants.Style philosophy- Keeping it casual and effortless. And respecting and wearing natural fabrics and helping Indian artisans and farmers.My grooming essential- My beard-trimmer – taking good care of my beard is important to me.A fashion advice someone gave me- Looking good is like plating well. Put too much in the composition, and nothing stands out. Think effortless yet effective.A skincare advice that my mom passed on- Ubtan. As kids we used to get in line to get a good scrub. Even now, whenever I get a chance I do the ubtan routine.My airport look- It has to be comfortable, typically athleisure. I do formals only when I am flying straight into a meeting.My guilty indulgence- Clothes and shoes definitely."At times, I come back from a shopping spree to realise I picked up what I already have"One word for me- Crazy cookMy workout- KalaripayattuUltimate fashion destination- TokyoWhat makes me feel sexy- Intelligent conversationsMost stylish person- Ranveer Singh

Title: Bangalore Nagarathnamma’s life story needed to be narrated: Nagabharana
Content: Veteran filmmaker and theatreperson TS Nagabharana is known to bring alive interesting personalities either on screen or on the stage — be it Allama Prabhu or Shishunala Sharifa. His latest play, Vidya Sundari Bengaluru Nagarathnamma, is about the life of courtesan, artiste and activist Bangalore Nagarathnamma . He reveals how this play came into existence.Nagabharana says, “I always wanted to do a musical on stage, especially one that would have Carnatic music . This has always been on the back of my mind and I was searching for a relevant play. In the meantime, I got an offer to do a biopic on Bangalore Nagarathnamma, based on a book on her. So, I began working on the script. However, while doing so, I realised that it was very hard to capture her life in a film. That’s when I decided to begin by doing a play on her,” he explains. He further says, “I was intrigued by the way she pursued music. The research for the play took almost a year. It was only after I successfully staged the play that I had the confidence to make a film based on her life.”Nagabharana also says that his research led him to see how two facets of her — a cultural icon and an activist — that were intrinsic the narrative. He also explains that her feminism and activism was much ahead of her times. “Before all the ‘isms’ came into existence, she held her ground for so many things. While she was an activist, she also held a just temperament. One can identify her in two ways. If she was an activist on one side, she was an artiste, who made a difference to the cultural ethos, on the other. One cannot take away her accomplishments as a musician and dancer. I must stress on her contribution, especially to harikathe, as she trained devadasi girls in the form,” he explains.Nagabharana does not discount the possibility of a film on Nagarathnamma’s life. He says, “The film on her is definitely on the cards. I do not know when it will happen, as it will mean another year of research and other intricacies. Once we have that perfect script in place, this film will go on floors.” The play, though, is slated to be staged sooner. “Our next performance is at Gayana Samaja on February 19,” he signs off.

Title: The New Boudoir Pin-up!
Content: There’s a new sensuality at play in the countdown to Valentine’s Day 2020 – boudoir photoshoots. Women are heating up social media with risqué shoots. For the uninitiated, a boudoir is a woman’s private sitting room or salon, usually between the dining room and bedroom. On Instagram, these sensuous shoots are the new tease in #couplegoals, with hashtag #somethingboudoir getting 4.2 million posts, #boudoir getting 4.6 million posts. Photographer Sarika Gangwal believes social media has helped create a demand for boudoir shoots. “Boudoir photography is all about loving yourself and feeling good in your body. It’s an experience of discovering your sensuality,” she says. Her tip: expression is everything as there is a thin line between sensuality and vulgarity. Gangwal adds that camera anxiety is a real thing. A reason why she tells her models to relax, and creates a mood where they feel comfortable. “I always play some music in the background. I’ve done sexy boudoir shoots of women in sarees – it highlights the curves. The big change is people are opening up their desires to feel good about themselves and their body,” she adds.The photographer is officially now in the bedroom. Pre-wedding shoots are passé as to-be brides are preparing to gift their fiancés a little ‘secret’ shoot. Or it could be couples trying to spice things up. Even single women are resorting to it to express their love for their bodies. Photographer Priyanka Sachar notes that people do boudoir shoots for various reasons: to preserve their youthful looks, to surprise their partner, improve their body image – as a couple or single person. People of all ages, shapes, sizes and sexual orientation like to try out boudoir photography. “The mood at these shoots is casual yet glamorous. It is a special day for the person(s) getting the shoot done. I go with an all-women team of make-up artist, hair stylist and photographer (me). The participants are made to feel comfortable. Music is played to keep the atmosphere lively. Boudoir photography can be artistic as well as elegant. It is not titillating or crude.”Boudoir photography emphasises the power and sensuality of ordinary individuals — primarily women — at an extraordinary point in their lives, notes photographer Pratik Sanghi, and adds, “The pictures express their feeling about their own relationships and, done well, depict them at their most desirable and powerful.” Sanghi likes to shoot high contrast black and whites images, usually in their homes where they are most comfortable. “My main goal is to visually convey heavy romance and intimacy and not shoot erotic portraits. In boudoir shoots, we limit the intimacy maximum to kissing. It takes a few minutes for them to get in the zone especially when it comes to getting comfortable with their bodies. I show them every image we shoot to make them feel completely at ease.”Thanks to Instagram, the interest in boudoir photography is showing a revival. Brides-to-be are stripping down either partially or completely and paying to have soft-sensual photos taken of themselves as a gift for their grooms. The job of boudoir photographers is to be “very discreet”; and most photographers are under strict contract. The favourite outfit is lingerie, but women often choose to wear what they feel most comfortable in – be it a saree, dress, shirt, garter belts, etc. The common misconception is that boudoir photography is nude or borderline pornographic. This is not true at all as these photos can range from intimate and sweet to straight-up provocative. They can also feature themes like popular pin-ups, burlesque or something trendy such as steampunk. Photographer Noopur says that it’s being fuelled by women who want to showcase their confidence. She says, “They are not shy and very comfortable in their own skin. Social media has made women (and men) own their sensuality. They have shed their inhibitions and are lovingly flaunting their bodies.” It’s like your bedroom is no longer off limits.The favourite outfit is lingerie, but women choose to wear what they feel most comfortable in – be it a saree, dress, a shirt, garter beltsCouples are hiring photographers to shoot intimate portraits in their bedrooms to celebrate their relationship – and also feel empowered and sexy. They want to create something memorable other than a pre-wedding shoot. Last year, we had a bride gift her fiancé a boudoir shoot. It is the new sexy.- Pratik Sanghi, photographerThe favourite outfit is lingerie, but women choose to wear what they feel most comfortable in – be it a saree, dress, a shirt, garter belts- Relax and be comfy in your own skin. It’s important to trust your photographer- Your images have to evoke emotions. Boudoir photos shouldn’t be cold- Consider the outfits you’d like to wear. Be creative with your outfit choices and styling- Create a mood board. Dark and moody? Cheeky and flirty? Girly and sassy? Black and white? Have a clear idea of the vibe you want- Figure out your poses. Some of the common ones include sitting on knees, lying on your back, putting legs up against a wall, lying on your side, sitting on a stool, etc. Arched backs, leg lifts and torso twists are used to achieve sexy poses- You can use interesting props, such as stools, canopy beds, pillows, furry throws, sexy shoes and classy lingerieThumb image: Instagram/Sarika Gangwal

Title: Fan moment: I was totally dumbstruck, says Chandrashekar
Content: I watched Dheena when I was in Class 8, bunking my school. I remember not being able to take my eyes off Thala. I couldn’t understand what that magic was. From then on, I haven’t missed catching his movies on the first day, except for once in 2013. During my school days, I thought my craze for him would come down once I joined college, but it only intensified as years went by. Travelling to Chennai from Bengaluru has become a norm over the last few years, mainly to catch the FDFS of his movies.I got to know that Ajith sir was shooting for Viswasam in Hyderabad. I booked a room in the same hotel where he was staying in. I took a flight to Hyderabad from Bengaluru at 6am and reached there by around 8am. I kept waiting in the lobby till 4pm without having food hoping to meet him. The staff kept asking me who I was waiting for and I gave them one reason or the other. I befriended a Bengaluru-based staff there, and he informed me Ajith sir would return to his room from the shoot only by 11pm. So, I went to my room, freshened up and waited in the lobby again till 1am. Then, I got to know that Thala would be in only by 4am. So, I went back to my room, slept for a couple of hours and returned to the lobby, only to get disappointed again. Later, I got to know that he was staying on the seventh floor. I was also told that he usually went to his floor through a service lift directly from the basement. So, at around 12pm, I checked out my room and booked a suite on the seventh floor, which cost `24,000.This time, I was more hopeful because the service lift was right opposite my room. At around 9.40pm, I finally met him! I went near him and said, ‘Hi sir’. He asked me who I was and enquired how I had managed to meet him. I was totally dumbstruck and couldn’t utter a word for some time. He then asked me to be calm and invited me to his room. He said he doesn’t expect his fans to visit him through such means because that would disturb the production. He gave me water and asked me about my family and advised me to take care of them and my health.I showed him a few photos of his birthday celebration, which we had organised in Melbourne a few days earlier. And I also spoke about how I had enjoyed watching some of his films. I then gifted him a branded watch that I had bought in Singapore. I had bought it because I had read somewhere that he loved that particular brand. But he refused to accept it as he felt that would send out a wrong message. Instead, he tied it on my hand, saying, ‘This is AK’s present for you’. I didn’t know what to say when he said ‘sorry’ for making me wait for so long.

Title: Vivek Simha is back to doing a daily soap
Content: After participating in the dance reality show, Dance Karnataka Dance Family War season 2, Vivek Simha has signed up for the new serial, Mathe Vasantha, directed by Madhusudhan . Vivek, who had earlier done Mahadevi and Sowbagyavathi, says, “I play Vasanth a rugged, straight-forward guy who wants things to happen according to his wishes. But he is a nice guy to people who know him. The shoot will predominantly take place in Mysuru .”After his stint on the dance show, Vivek had lost a few kilos. “I have become lean because of the rigorous training sessions. The show helped me better my dance skills, which will be helpful once I start doing films again. I have now started hitting the gym to regain the weight for the serial, as well as the films that I will be doing later this year,” says the actor.

Title: The Magic of Omega 3
Content: For the longest time fats have got a bad reputation and are considered artery-clogging and fattening. However just like there are good carbohydrates and bad carbohydrates, there are good fats and bad fats too. There is a reason why fat is classified as a macronutrient and nearly every single cell in our body needs fats to function the right way. Our brain is largely composed of fat, hormones are made from fat, certain key vitamins like A, D, E, K are absorbed by the body in the presence of fat, so chasing a fat-free diet can be downright dangerous for our health – right from skin and hair health, ageing process, hormonal imbalance, lack of satiety from meals, energy and much more. Amongst all kinds of fats, there is one in particular that is of great nutritive as well as therapeutic value. That is omega 3 fatty acid (FA). There are three kinds of Omega 3 FA – ALA, EPA and DHA. While ALA comes mostly from plants, nuts and seeds, DHA and EPA come from fatty fish.Your brain is almost 60 per cent fat and half of that comprises the Omega 3 kinds. This nutrient is used to build brain and nerve cells, and is responsible for cognitive memory and overall brain function. It also helps keep brain inflammation in check thereby being one of the necessary nutrients in managing and preventing cases of Parkinson’s, Alzheimer’s, autism, ADHD, cerebral palsy. A deficiency of this nutrient is linked to learning impairment, depression and poor memory and is even associated with depression and anxiety cases. It is also used in cases of schizophrenia and other mental disorders because it is nutrition for the brain and nervous system. Omega 3 holds the potential to protect nerve damage and helps them regenerate.Omega 3 plays a big role in healing our heart and the cardiovascular system. It helps boost HDL (good cholesterol), lowers LDL and triglycerides (bad cholesterol) and helps reduce chances of heart stroke and inflammation in the heart. It helps repair the endothelial linings of artery walls that are damaged due to various lifestyle factors, especially smoking.Chronic inflammation can contribute to almost any illness known today, right from obesity to cancer. Omega 3 plays a vital role in calming down the body’s inflammatory responses and oxidative stress.A fat-deprived diet can play havoc on our hormonal health. Hence all fad diets that ask you to go fat-free can be dangerous for your hormonal health because they lack the key nutrient that helps manufacture hormones.Omega 3, specifically DHA, helps form the structural component of the retina in our eyes and hence its deficiency can affect vision and possibly cause macular degeneration and other vision impairment issues. It is also responsible for a healthy skin and gives it the soft, moist, supple, wrinkle-free appearance. It works as a natural sunblock as it safeguards the skin from damage due to excessive and inappropriate exposure.Omega 3 is crucial when it comes to cellular health and energy. It is what makes up the cell membrane and its deficit can affect the overall functioning of a cell. As for energy levels, even a one per cent decrease in Omega 3 in your body can cause tiredness and continual low energy levels.Consult your health care provider before introducing any of the discussed foods into your lifestyleOmega 3 can be obtained from both vegetarian as well as non-vegetarian sources, however the primary source is fatty fish like salmon, tuna, trout, mackerel, sardines and herring. In veg food, it is found mostly in nuts and seeds like flaxseeds, chia seeds, walnuts, hemp seeds. Marine algae also provides Omega 3, especially DHA and that is how fish get them too. There is also an option of a good quality Omega 3 or a fish oil supplement in case food sources don’t sufficeOils rich in Omega 3 like flaxseed are not suitable for high heat cooking as they are extremely sensitive to heat exposure. They are best consumed raw.

Title: Milana Prakash: Darshan’s next film has a political backdrop
Content: Sandalwood star Darshan is back with the team of Taarak . Director Milana Prakash has confirmed that they are working on a new film, the script of which has been finalised. They are chalking out schedules before they go on floors. Giving us an insight into the upcoming movie, Prakash says, “The storyline is built on a political backdrop — something that I have never worked on before. The narrative revolves around two political families and what they do to gain power. It also focuses on how their next generation deals with it. While politics is the backdrop, the story still qualifies as a typical Darshan film.”The filmmaker adds that they are looking at an ensemble cast, which they will put together once the shooting schedule is fixed. “Darshan will first start work on the Madakari Nayaka biopic, and then on this new film. We are planning to shoot both the films simultaneously, and are looking at going on floors this summer,” Prakash sums up.

Title: Red carpet leads the way
Content: Even as an Indian award function substituted the red-colour carpet for green, international awards, red carpets are going green – in spirit. Best actor nominee (in all major awards) for Joker, Joaquin Phoenix announced that he’s planning to wear the same tuxedo for awards season 2020 – in an attempt to reduce waste. Trust the Joker to be disruptive.Phoenix has joined hands with British designer and sustainability activist Stella McCartney to make better choices for the “future of the planet”. His fiancé Rooney Mara too wore a Givenchy 2019 for the Globes.As is the same in every industry, even awards shows are facing questions over their environmental footprint. The Baftas asked all attendees to consider rewearing an outfit they own or choose a sustainable option. They aim to make the show carbon neutral. In addition, the Globes served a plant-based menu.Even the Academy awards, served a 100 per cent plant-based menu at the annual luncheon for nominees. The menu for the Governor’s Ball, held immediately after the Oscar ceremony (today), will be 70% plant-based. Plastic bottles and beverages in plastic containers will be eliminated from all Oscar events. It’s time for some red carpet activism in India too.Phoebe Waller-Bridge auctioned her Globes’ tux to raise money for Australian bushfire relief; Joaquin Phoenix plans to wear this tux to all awards this year.

Title: Flavours of Italy and Mexico come to Bengaluru
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Quattro, a newly-opened restaurant near Residency Road, hosted an extravagant dinner party recently. Influenced by flavours of Italy and Mexico , this is a fusion restaurant, combining these cuisines with gastronomical elements for a culinary experience like no other. Guests were seen enjoying a variety of dishes like Watermelon and Feta Salad, Enchiladas and Tres Leches.

Title: Dainty charms is all you need to add whimsy to your trinkets
Content: That fashion is in the midst of the 90s revival is common knowledge. From bell bottoms to ruffles to polka dots, everything is trendy once again. While clothes are going back in time, jewellery trends are no less. Cue in drumroll for the return of the 90s staple: charm jewellery. Popularised as ‘the’ cool thing to wear by Madonna, charms have come a long way from being dainty baubles to chunky leather and beaded variants. The popularity of the evil-eye has added a new talisman to the trinkets.Charms — earlier common in bracelets — can now be added to anything from anklets to necklaces and earrings. In fact, at the Met Gala 2019, Elle Fanning added kitschy charms to her nail art! Evidence of charms in jewellery dates back to prehistoric times when they were made from shells and animal bones. Credit goes to Queen Victoria (who ruled from 1876-1901) to fashion the modern-day charm bracelet. She not only liked wearing the bracelets but also gifted them, taking care to personalise the charms to fit the recipient. In fact, she had a “mourning” bracelet made to mourn Prince Albert’s death. Among the charms on this bracelet was a locket with his miniature photograph, locket of his hair, and mementos of their life together.The nostalgic jewellery trend by way of charms, engraved ornaments or refurbishing heirloom pieces is officially cool again. Today, you can express yourself with the bracelet itself, and not just its charms. Pick charms that hold a special meaning to you. Designers like Alexander McQueen, Gucci, Oscar de la Renta gave it high-fashion cred. The pendants can vary from symbols for hobbies, travels, a child or grandchild’s name, a birthday age or timeless hearts and flowers. Charms are unique and meaningful – find yours today.l Charms can be added to any jewellery from necklaces to bracelets to ankletsl You can use the standard open-link chain or go for leather, bead, crystal, chunky silverl Pick and choose charms that speak to youl Mix and match charm sizes from chunky to dainty as per your personal tastel Pack in various charms or space them out – again, you get to decidel Leather has a hip vibe

Title: Churchill Brothers face defending champions Chennai City
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Panaji: The goals are back, so are the smiles, and confidence too. But Churchill Brothers FC coach Bernardo Tavares is waiting for more proof that his squad can go all the way in the I-League .

For a club that doesn’t appreciate second-placed finishes and consolation prizes, the top spot remains the goal. It looked like they were on the right track when they won three matches in a row at the start, but an unexpected drop in performance that saw them lose points against comparatively weaker teams, even at home, raised doubts.

Thanks to a 4-1 demolition of Neroca FC in the previous game, those doubts have somewhat disappeared. Churchill’s credentials will be put to the test again as they face defending champions Chennai City FC at the Nehru Stadium in Fatorda on Sunday.

“The victory (against Neroca) came after a difficult week when we lost against TRAU (at home) and Gokulam Kerala. The TRAU game was bad. We couldn’t convert our chances, and everyone wondered how could we lose? Against Gokulam, we were good in the second half, but everyone remembers the result and nothing else,” said Tavares.

Churchill are sixth in the table with 13 points from eight matches. Even if they win their two remaining matches in hand, both at home, they would still remain four points behind leaders Mohun Bagan, although crucially they would have overtaken everyone else.

“We have many games to play and anything can happen. I cannot say whether team A or B will become champions. We must think about the next game. Step by step, if we win games, we will be nearer to our goal,” said Tavares.

Midfielder Quan Gomes was more forthright. “This team can become champions. We have to keep winning,” said Quan, singling out leaders Mohun Bagan as the team to watch out for this season.

Churchill’s immediate worry is Chennai City. The defending champions are a far cry from the team that had a band of experienced Spaniards and young Indian players, winning a tightly contested league last season. Akbar Nawas’s side have lost players and, possibly, the spark too. But what they have retained is their philosophy and style of play.

“Chennai love to have the ball. They have good quality in the middle. If they have the ball, they are happy. We must deny them ball possession. We must keep the ball away from them,” said Tavares.

With just 11 points from their first nine matches, no team will be happy while defending their title. Understandably, Nawas doesn’t like his teams position as well, as they are much closer to the relegation zone than the title which they won so majestically last season.

“We must still aim to be champions, sure. I mean, if the goal has changed, that’s not the way how we proceed. We still aim to collect three points in every game. Definitely, we don’t wish to be where we are. We wish we had more points. Eleven points, I am not happy, for sure. I don’t think any coach will be happy. We still want to go out there and give a good fight,” said Nawas.

Title: Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan cast shoots with Bappi Lahiri for retro track
Content: The cast of Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan got into retro mode when they shot for the recreated version of the 80s hit track Yaar Bina Chain Kaha Re from Saaheb (1985). This time around, however, the title of the song is Arrey Pyaar Kar Le . To recreate the 80s, a set was erected at a studio in Mumbai, which had all the elements of that era, including an illuminated, colourful dance floor, a shiny disco ball and dancers wearing bell-bottom pants. The highlight on the day of the shoot was Bappi Lahiri ’s arrival on the set to shoot for his guest appearance in the song. Along with Ayushmann Khurrana and Jitendra Kumar, who are the film’s lead actors, Neena Gupta, Gajraj Rao and Maanvi Gagroo will also be featuring in the film.Speaking about choosing this track for the film, director Hitesh Kewalya says, “We wanted to show that same-sex love has been existing since a long time. We picked this 80s hit dance number as we felt that it celebrated the emotion of love very well.” Recreated by Tanishk Bagchi, the song, which releases tomorrow, has a rap portion penned by Vayu with vocals by Ayushmann. The team has retained Bappi Lahiri’s composition and voice from the original in the new version. Bappi Lahiri says, “I am happy that the film is keeping disco music from the 80s alive. The switch from seeing Anil Kapoor and Amrita Singh dancing in the original to Ayushmann Khurrana and Jitendra Kumar romancing each other in this redux version, is just phenomenal.”

Title: Padma Shri: It feels great to be honoured with a prestigious award like the Padma Shri: Yogesh Praveen
Content:
Yogesh Praveen (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Yogesh Praveen (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Overwhelmed on being awarded the fourth highest civilian award, Padma Shri for his outstanding contribution in the field of Literature and Education, Lucknowite and historian Dr Yogesh Praveen has been busy with congratulatory calls and messages ever since the news came out. “It feels great to be honoured with such a prestigious award like the Padma Shri. I would like to specially mention my mother because she contributed immensely in winning this award as she kept me going and always motivated me, unhone mujhe kabhi tootne nahi diya,” says Praveen.An expert in the history and culture of Avadh, specifically Lucknow, Dr Yogesh has written over two dozen books. “Rang laati hai henna patthar pe pis jaane ke baad. This quotation is apt for me as I have been working constantly without any kind of desire or expectations. And this award proves ki sacche mann se ki hui tapasya kabhi vyarth nahi jaati. Anvarat kaam karta raha aur yeh kabhi socha nahi ki raasta asaan hoga, thokre bahut khaayi hain maine.” Quoting Mirza Ghalib, he adds, “Once Mirza Ghalib was asked who is your ustaad, he replied ‘thokren hi meri ustaad rahin’, so for me also my failures have been my teacher, my mentor.”Yogesh Praveen (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Because of his expertise in the history and culture of Avadh, he has been part of several films based on it. He has also written the lyrics for the Shyam Benegal directed film Junoon. His inputs were also taken for the film Umraao Jaan. “I always got respect from everyone, even many filmmakers approached me for films based on Avadh. Humein nawaazne waale film industry se bhi bahut aaye. Shyam Benegal, Shashi Kapoor, Farooque Sheikh, Rekha, Satyajit Ray, Shabana Azmi to name a few,” he says.Sharing his concern for the city Praveen says, “Lucknow has become hotch-potch and uski rooh bhi tabah ho rahi hai. The city has joined the mad race like other cities without knowing where it is heading. With the government changing names of places, many people come to me and ask ki Lucknow ko Lakshmanpur kiya jaye toh kaisa rahega. So I request them to divide the city into two parts with Gomti river at the centre because it is a state capital and needs to have a proper development. Making twin cities like Hyderabad and Secunderabad will have two nagar nigams which will facilitate better development. And then rename the old city as Lucknow and the other one as Lakshmanpur. It feels insulting when people say naya Lucknow and purana Lucknow as purana feels like a waste so I think this renaming and division should be done.”

Title: I am elated to get this recognition: Pt Chhannulal Mishra on Padma Vibhushan
Content:
Pt Chhannulal Mishra (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

Pt Chhannulal Mishra (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

Flooded with congratulatory messages, noted vocalist Pt Chhannulal Mishra , who has recently been conferred with Padma Vibhushan award, says, “I am really elated to get this recognition. It is an honour to be selected for this award. Though I feel that I should have received this award a trifle earlier, at the same time, as the popular adage goes, der aye durust aaye. I am happy that it has eventually happened,” says the artist who is already a recipient of Padma Bhushan award.However, Pt Mishra believes that classical music needs to adapt itself to the changed times in order to attract the younger audiences. “In this fast-paced world, the artistes should perform accordingly. Pehle ek dhun se doosare dhun tak jane mein ek din beet jata tha, which is not acceptable now. Audience no longer have the patience for this. Raag utna hi gayein jab tak usme anurag rahe. Raag se logon ko bairag ho jaye, kalakar ko aisa nahi gaana chaiye,” he says.Pt Chhannulal Mishra (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)Having lent his voice in films like the Prakash Jha directed Aarakshan and Dr Chandra Prakash Dwivedi ’s Mohalla Assi , Pt Chhannulal says, “I have turned down several film offers on account of bad poetry in the songs. The level of film music has gone down. Music is just being created to mint money,” he says.He even has a piece of advice for the various singing reality shows on television. “To bring out the real talent, more focus should be on raag-based singing. The participants should be selected on the basis of their knowledge of ragas rather than their high pitched singing,” he says.

Title: Masks are must-carry accessory for visitors at Auto Expo this year
Content:
The 15th edition of Auto Expo kicked off amid coronavirus fears as hundreds of people were spotted wearing fac... Read More

Visitors wear masks as they look at cars on display at the Auto Expo in Greater Noida

Visitors wear masks as they look at cars on display at the Auto Expo in Greater Noida

Over the last few years, spotting people in masks has become common in Delhi-NCR. However, that happens outdoors, so it was quite a surprise spotting hundreds of people wearing face masks at the ongoing Auto Expo in Greater Noida . The cause, however, isn't pollution but the coronavirus scare. The mega automobile show sees exhibitors and visitors from across India and a lot of South East Asian countries. Although exhibitors from China – the epicentre of the coronavirus pandemic – are not at the expo this year, visitors are still wary. Raman Awasthi, a Noida student, who came to the expo with his friends, told us, "All of us bought masks to wear here. There are so many people coming from all over, particularly the countries hit by the virus, that we did not want to take chances. We would have cancelled our visit had we not booked the tickets in advance."Not just visitors, many working at the expo also admitted that they were nervous. Zumur, who works at the stall of a leading automobile manufacturer, says, "My father was not too pleased with me coming here because he felt I was walking into the lion's den. I wasn't that perturbed but seeing so many people with masks makes me wonder if I should get one, too, tomorrow." The 2018 edition of the Auto Expo saw six lakh visitors across the six days and this year, the number is expected to rise.

Title: Gaurav, Ashutosh & Bidita shoot for film in Lucknow
Content: The shooting of the film titled Lakeerien, starring Ashutosh Rana Bidita Bag and Gaurav Chopra is going on in Lucknow these days. Directed by Lucknowite Durgesh Pathak , the film has been written by another Lucknowite Dilip Shukla , acclaimed writer of films Dabangg, Ghayal and Damini, to name a few.Ashutosh Rana (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)The film also stars Aman Verma and has several actors from the city including Tia Bajpai of Haunted fame, and Saharsh Kumar Shukla of Chhichhore fame. The film, in its second shoot schedule in the city, will be capturing the main areas including Gomti Nagar for the silver screen.Bidita Bag (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)Durgesh, who is making his debut as a director with this film, has also done cinematography for various commercials and short films in the past. “The film deals with women-centric issues and has local artistes as well as a local production team. The story deals with issues like marital rape and how women deal with such things in real life. It highlights not only the problems women face when they go out of their homes but also what happens with them behind closed doors,” shares Durgesh.

Title: Bollywood ka tadka at this do in Kanpur
Content:
Akshay and Khushboo Trihan (BCCL/ IB Singh)

(L) Chhavi Saraf and Neha Gupta (R) Deepesh and Sweta Gupta (BCCL/ IB Singh)

(L) Karuna Gupta, Sushila Singh and Sapna Jaiswal (R) ML Agarwal and Rama Agarwal (BCCL/ IB Singh)

(L) Laxmi Makhija and Balwant Makhija (R) Neha and Amit Gupta (BCCL/ IB Singh)

Friends and family members of ML Agarwal had a blast when he threw an Amitabh Bachchan theme party, recently. Going by the theme, the venue was beautifully decorated with cut-outs of the actor.(L) Chhavi Saraf and Neha Gupta (R) Deepesh and Sweta Gupta (BCCL/ IB Singh)“Big B is my favourite actor. This party has been organised to pay respect to his work,” said Agarwal. Akshay and Khushboo Trihan made an early entry at the do and were soon joined by Riya and Sumit Agarwal .(L) Karuna Gupta, Sushila Singh and Sapna Jaiswal (R) ML Agarwal and Rama Agarwal (BCCL/ IB Singh)The highlight of the evening was the dance of the guests on some hits songs of the Bollywood actor. We spotted Kanchan Gupta Chhavi Saraf, Raja Saraf and Nitin Gupta dancing on songs like Samundar Mein Nahake, Main Hoon Don and Khaike Pan Banaraswala.(L) Laxmi Makhija and Balwant Makhija (R) Neha and Amit Gupta (BCCL/ IB Singh)Guests were highly entertained when they played antakshari with a twist. During the antakshari the participants were only allowed to sing Amitabh’s songs which made it a bit tricky and difficult for them. Title: Artists recreate Delhi, London at Auto Expo
Content: For Auto Expo regulars, India Expo Mart will be a whole new place as this year, Delhi Street Art Group has joined hands with exhibitors at the expo. The members of the art group have painted the temporary wall-like structures at the venue.The group's members tell us that since the expo is for automobile enthusiasts, they decided to keep the theme as 'automobiles in cityscapes '. Yogesh Saini, founder, Delhi Street Art, says,"We have been commissioned this work by one of the exhibitors and we have completed two wall arts which show different aspects of Delhi and London. To establish Delhi, we have chosen Lotus Temple, Red Fort India Gate etc. Similarly, for London, we're showcasing the London Tower Bridge. Now we are working on our third wall art at the expo."The wall art at the expo also serves as a selfie-spot for the visitors. Saini says, "The wall art is quite popular among visitors , and we're expecting a good response." It will be on display till February 9.

Title: Kartik Aaryan gears up for his first action thriller
Content: After making a mark in the rom-com genre with films like the Pyaar Ka Punchnama 1 and 2, Sonu Ke Titu Ki Sweety (SKTKS) and Pati Patni Aur Woh (PPAW), Kartik Aaryan is all set to move into a new zone. The actor will be packing in a punch with his first action thriller. The movie will be helmed by Om Raut , who made his directorial debut in Bollywood with Tanhaji : The Unsung Warrior, and backed by T-Series. Talking about stepping into a completely new arena, Kartik says, “I have been keen to do an out-and-out action film for a while now, and Bhushan Kumar knew about it. Recently, I watched Tanhaji and was completely blown away, not just by the spectacular visuals, but also the narrative. Om Raut’s vision, when it comes to storytelling using 3D, is amazing. I am excited to be a part of his next and can’t wait to start work on my first action film.”Bhushan Kumar who is keen to make this into a franchise, adds, “Right from SKTKS and PPAW to Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2, it’s been a long, successful association with Kartik. Though he has been successful in the romance and comedy space, he has always wanted to diversify and do an action film.” The producer reveals that like Om’s previous film, this one, too, will be made in 3D, but they will take it notches higher. He explains, “Om’s vision and passion for cinema, which I saw in Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior, made me want to back his next project as well. The action in that film was in a different zone, while this one will be more on the lines of movies like Dhoom and War. It’s our first film of this kind and will be a fast-paced movie revolving around a heist. The film will be made on a huge scale and will be Kartik’s biggest budget film so far.”The pre-production of the film is underway, and it will go on the floors around August 2020. The remaining cast of the movie, which will be shot in India and at various foreign locations, is yet to be finalised. Om Raut says, “Bhushanji supports my vision completely. In the initial stages of the project itself, I knew that Kartik would fit the character well, and I am glad to have him on board.”

Title: This Valentine's Day, give your better half the gift of not being a cliche!
Content: Stuffed toys? A big no! Flowers? They will perish in no time. A dinner date? It's not unique. If you are planning gifts for your better half for Valentine's Day, stay away from the cliches. They will definitely fail to impress your partner and will only make you look brain deadValentine's Day is right around the corner and so is the anxiety of what to get your significant others. But perhaps this year, you might want to do your relationships and yourself a favour by actually putting some thought into the gifts for your Valentines. Instead of gifting the same ghisa pita combo of flowers, teddy bears and chocolates to your girlfriend or boyfriend, maybe 2020 is the year you step away from the whole 'it's the thought that counts' concept. And no, a jar full of personalised messages detailing how much your BF/GF means to you isn't the solution either (even Beyonce said 'crazy in love' and not lazy in love). Love is love and of course, materialistic and expensive gifts aren't always the alternative, but surely some cliches can be discarded. FOREVER! So, to help you stay clear from the cliche trap this Valentine's Day, here’s a few tried, tested and now trashed gift ideas you'd want to stay away from this year and those to come.Just getting a table at one of those'always busy, hours of waiting' restaurants cannot be considered as a feat. What could possibly be so special about dinner on Valentine's Day? A celebrity guest at the table? Unlikely. It's just like any other dinner date, with perhaps a higher bill and a more romantic ambience. Maybe even some nice cutlery. But that's about it. And where exactly are you going to go on a long drive in this city where even flyovers are choked with traffic? You are just going to add to the air pollution. Might as well gift each other the commitment to be more eco-friendly, at least it will present a challenge beyond the Delhi roads. Plus, you'd be doing something for the greater good, so you have that to boast about.Clever or a sure shot way to convey to your significant other that you just can't get a Valentine's gift right? Everyone deserves a decent, if not a grand proposal. But by killing one bird with two stones, you are not only taking away Valentine's Day from them forever but also making sure that every year, they have one less day to celebrate. Unless your pandit ji has told you that it's this day or never, try to make Valentine's Day about celebrating your relationship.The coming years are all about going eco-friendly, so flowers shouldn't even be on your list. They will add to the waste and no matter how beautiful the bouquet, a rose can only do so much in its short lifespan. Whether you swap the roses with the fanciest orchids or the prettiest tulips and lilies, this gift will always have an expiration date.Okay, yes, everyone loves to hear how much they are adored, respected and appreciated, but why should they just get to hear this on Valentine's Day? Do you not feel the same during the rest of the year? This might work on your first Valentine's as a couple, but there's only so much love you can express as time passes. Reserving Valentine's Day to let your significant other know how much they mean to you doesn't just reek of laziness, it's also very basic. And if you were planning on plagiarising or typing these instead of hand-writing them, abort mission now.This is a big no. First of all, even kids have moved beyond soft toys. Second, when was the last time you looked at a stuffed toy and thought 'wow, that's something I need to get for myself'? Exactly. Don't do to others, what you wouldn't do to yourself. Stuffed toys, no matter which species, eventually just become dust collectors, hidden away at some corner of the room. Is that really the symbol of your love?If you simply want to remind your BF/GF about all the fun and romantic moments you have had together, you can definitely do this on any other day. While this one needs more time and patience, the only hard work and thought that goes into this is going through your archives. And while this may be a cute throwback idea (for some), not just your significant other, even your social media followers deserve a better post for Valentine's Day. Even though a video or a customised cup with your pictures on it might seem like a unique/cute idea, this year, let it stay unique in theory and not in reality.

Title: Decentralise Isro powers, set up space regulator & tribunal, says New Space Policy by think tank
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

NEW DELHI: A new Space Policy 2020 drafted by Takshashila Institution, a think tank and public policy school, proposed decoupling the regulatory and service delivery roles of Indian Space Research Organisation ( Isro ) to create a level-playing field for new entrants.

The policy said the present space ecosystem is centralised around Isro, which is a research organisation, service delivery establishment, regulatory, licensing and compliance agency as well as a disputes settlement body. Therefore, it proposed establishment of an independent Space Regulatory of India (SRAI), which will be responsible for setting standards, licensing space activities and compliance of these activities, and Space Disputes Settlement Appellate Tribunal to adjudicate disputes and settle appeals to protect the interest of service providers.

It also mulled setting up of space PSU Bharat Space Corporation (BSC), which will provide a whole range of space services, directly or through subsidiaries and will be under the ambit of SRAI.

In an interview to TOI, Nitin Pai, co-founder and director of Takshashila, said, “The recommendations were drafted by a task force consisting of myself & Utkarsh Narain from Takshashila, and Siddhey Shinde (Astrome, space technology co) and Yashas Karanam (Bellatrix, space company). They are derived from the outcome of Takshashila’s space policy conclave where a number of experts from the government and private sector came together to discuss the future of the space industry.”

On proposing a regulator and a tribunal, Nitin Pai said, “One of the most basic principles of governance and fair play is that the same entity (Isro) cannot be the player, umpire and rule-maker. So the first step in the opening of any industry sector is the structural separation of these roles: in telecom, we used to have telecom department in the 1980s providing the service, regulating the industry as well as making policy. Today those functions are split between BSNL , TRAI, TDSAT and DoT. The space regulatory authority and dispute settlements tribunals can create a level-playing field for private industry to operate in the space sector. They will be neutral umpires.”

On the fate of Isro’s existing commercial arms Antrix Corporation and NewSpace India Ltd, the Takashashila founder told TOI, “Policy proposed that existing arms will become subsidiaries of the space PSU.” BSC shall explore public-private partnership (PPP) models for building satellites and launch vehicles, etc. This will help drive private capital and solving some capacity constraints, the policy said.

Nitin Pai said, “Even after liberalisation, Isro will have an important role to play. As the national space agency, it will conduct missions like Chandrayaan, Mangalyaan etc that push the frontiers of science, and drive national space exploration. It will also engage in the development of strategic technologies.”

The policy proposed that SRAI, in consultation with the Space Commission, shall come up with a comprehensive framework for licensing and regulation of private human space flights in a year.

The regulations shall delineate safety and technical requirements of the space vehicle, liability and insurance requirements for the company as well as participants.

Title: I’m a desigineer. All my work is about how machines can become more like us, says inventor Pranav Mistry
Content:
Pranav Mistry

How do you look back on your journey from Palanpur to US?

From a gaze-and-blink robot to an invisible mouse, from a smart watch to SixthSense, you are credited with many inventions. Which ones are you most proud of and which ones do you use at present?

Why are the Artificial Humans called ‘

’?

So, how different is a NEON from an Alexa?

Some reviews have called the innovation “overhyped”. Your reaction?

How do you react to the commonly expressed fear of AI overriding human intelligence in the future?

What about things like augmented reality and virtual reality? Are these making life easier for people?

You could argue that the world has enough artificial humans as it is but then Pranav Mistry would most likely dismiss it as a terrible joke. The kind of artificial humans that Mistry, president and CEO of Samsung STAR Labs , unveiled at the recent Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas are spelt with capital letters. The 38-year-old computer scientist and inventor talks to Sharmila Ganesan Ram about a future in which humans are humans and machines are humane.I am a small-town boy aiming to change the world we are living in. I could not speak English before I came to the US over 15 years ago. Today, I do not want to be known for the money I make. I am inspired by legends like Michelangelo and Walt Disney. We don’t care how rich they were, what matters is what they gave the world and billions of people — dreams.I would not like to single out any one invention. As I grew up in a small village in India, I used to ask: can we make technology more human? I worked with the India Incubation Centre to make Gujarati keyboards. Also, my exposure to fields like design, technology, art and psychology have given me a very unique perspective of the world. I love to see technology from a design perspective and vice versa. This vision reflects in almost all of my projects and research work as well. In short, I do what I love and I love what I do. I am a ‘Desigineer’. All my work has been about how machines can become more and more like us, rather than we becoming more like machines.The word NEON derives from NEO (new) + humaN. The naming of NEON is also inspired from the properties of Neon as a noble gas . Neon (Ne), the tenth element on the periodic table, is an inert gas that glows orange-red when electrically charged.Unlike AI assistants, NEONs are not an interface to the Internet to ask for weather updates or play your favourite music. Rather, they are more like virtual living beings who can show emotions and learn from experiences. NEONs are more like our friends and companions with whom you share your experiences and build memories. Since NEONs are Artificial Humans that are capable of understanding, conversing and sympathising just like real humans, they can serve as an individualised teacher, a personal financial advisor, a healthcare provider, or a concierge. A NEON can also be an actor, a spokesperson, or a TV anchor.We believe much of the confusion arose since some people thought this was the fully-finished product. At CES 2020, we previewed NEON to the world for the first time. We were showcasing the prowess and capabilities of our CORE R3 engine, and not the fully-finished Artificial Human that will look real and be responsive in real-time.Any new technology generates a lot of fears and concerns too, many of which are genuine and understandable. Here are some ways we hope to address these concerns. First, privacy is at NEON’s core by design. This means, NEON will never share your private data without your permission. Second, the creation of NEON was never about replacing humans, but in fact to make us more human. It is a new medium of expression, compassion, learning and love. NEONs are neither some know-it-all bots nor are they androids, surrogates or copies of real humans. Third, though Artificial Humans’ look may be based on the likeness of a real person, CORE R3 and the technology behind NEON is fundamentally different from deepfake or other facial reanimation techniques. CORE R3 does not manipulate an individual scene, videos or sequences. Instead, it creates unique behaviours and interactions of NEONs in real-time that never happened before. Thus, CORE R3 creates new realities.AR, VR, and many other such new technologies are not making tech easier for people. These are simply providing newer ways to connect to the same data. However, all these technologies are making us more and more disconnected. I grew up with Mickey Mouse as a kid. These cartoon characters are not just in our movies, they are in our dreams too. My daughter, for instance, becomes sad when she sees that Princess Fiona is sad. It’s the human connection that strengthens bonds.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Exit polls predict another big mandate for AAP; BJP to make gains
Content:
File photo

NEW DELHI: Exit polls on Saturday predicted another big win for AAP in the Delhi assembly elections, with one giving it up to 68 seats in the 70-member house, a figure that would be higher than the 67 it won during its 2015 sweep. None of the polls gave the party less than 44 seats, which would still leave it comfortably placed to form a hat-trick of governments.All polls gave AAP a vote share of over 50%, which if correct, would mean that for the second time running, the party would have won a majority of votes cast. The polls also forecast another wipeout for Congress and in most cases, some improvement in BJP ’s tally, though the magnitude of the increase varied from poll to poll. BJP’s vote share was also projected to increase in each of the polls.If the polls are correct, that would suggest that BJP’s bid to focus on issues like Shaheen Bagh had at best limited success while AAP’s strategy of focusing mainly on the work it had done paid off. Senior BJP functionaries, however, claimed that the exit polls would fail when votes are counted on February 11.The Times Now-IPSOS poll was the most conservative in projecting an AAP victory, giving the party between 44 and 50 seats with a vote share of 52.5%, a slight decline from its 2015 figure of 54.3%. It gave BJP between 20 and 26 seats compared with the three it won in 2015.Even the BJP’s vote share was estimated to rise from 32.8% in 2015 to 39% now. At the other end of the spectrum, the India Today-My Axis poll gave AAP between 59 and 68 seats with a vote share of 56%, which would be even higher than the 2015 figure. This poll saw the BJP finishing with anywhere between two and 11 seats with its vote share up only by a little to 35%.Somewhere between these two polls was the ABP News CVoter poll, which suggested AAP would win between 51 and 65 seats and a vote share of 50.8%. BJP was estimated to end up with anywhere between three and 17 seats with a vote share of 36%. The ABP News poll was one of the few that suggested that the Congress could win seats, projecting a range of one to three seats for the party with a vote share of 8.8%, just a little below the 2015 level.The other two polls mentioned here gave the Congress no seats and vote share in the 5-6% range. Other polls suggested AAP winning over three-fourths of the seats despite BJP increasing its tally significantly from the three seats it won in 2015.In Video: AAP set to retain Delhi, third term for Kejriwal, predict exit polls unanimously

Title: Delhi Election: Delhi falls well short of 2015 record with turnout of 61.5%
Content: NEW DELHI: The turnout in Delhi for the assembly election fell short of its record in 2015 when AAP had bagged 67 seats out of 70. It was a sunny Saturday but voting was sluggish till afternoon. According to the latest figure available with the EC, which is subject to revision, the turnout stood at 61.5%, against 67.1% in 2015 when AAP recorded a spectacular victory.The voter turnout in the capital had been consistently going up since 1998 when just about 49% of the electorate had stepped out to cast votes. In the 2019 Lok Sabha polls, 60.6% voters had exercised their franchise. Delhi election officials said though the voter turnout had crossed the 2019 parliamentary election figure, it won't reach anywhere close to the 2015 one.Interestingly, in absolute terms, some 1.62 lakh more people voted on Saturday as compared with the 2015 polls.Accepting that the voter turnout was less than expected, election officials said it was too early to look for reasons. "Several factors contribute to the voter turnout. We are still waiting for the final numbers and won't comment on it yet," said chief electoral officer of Delhi Ranbir Singh.While final numbers are still being computed, Seelampur in northest Delhi reported the largest turnout of 71.4% followed by 70.6% in Mustafabad assembly segment. Delhi Cantonment witnessed the least number of people coming out to vote at 41.3% followed by Chhattarpur with 46.5%.Though it was a triangular contest in most seats, the battle was essentially between AAP and BJP. AAP had sought votes on the work its government had done in health, education, water and other sectors, including giving free power, water and bus rides to women. BJP made it essentially an election on national security and nationalism. It highlighted the protests against the amended citizenship law, abrogation of Article 370 and 35A, the SC judgment in the Ram temple case and surgical strikes on Pakistan.

We are still waiting for the final numbers and won't comment on it yet," said chief electoral officer of Delhi Ranbir Singh.While final numbers are still being computed, Seelampur in northest Delhi reported the largest turnout of 71.4% followed by 70.6% in Mustafabad assembly segment. Delhi Cantonment witnessed the least number of people coming out to vote at 41.3% followed by Chhattarpur with 46.5%.Though it was a triangular contest in most seats, the battle was essentially between AAP and BJP. AAP had sought votes on the work its government had done in health, education, water and other sectors, including giving free power, water and bus rides to women. BJP made it essentially an election on national security and nationalism. It highlighted the protests against the amended citizenship law, abrogation of Article 370 and 35A, the SC judgment in the Ram temple case and surgical strikes on Pakistan.

Title: Exit Poll Results Delhi: BJP will win 48 seats, says Manoj Tiwari; AAP stays guarded
Content:
ये सभी एग्ज़िट पोल होंगे fail.. मेरी ये ट्वीट सम्भाल के रखियेगा.. भाजपा दिल्ली में ४८ सीट ले कर सरकार बनायेगी ..… https://t.co/29uKTTx6X3 — Manoj Tiwari (@ManojTiwariMP) 1581170685000

चुनाव आयोग इस घटना का संज्ञान ले ये किस जगह EVM उतारी जा रही है आस पास तो कोई सेंटर है नही। https://t.co/zQz7Ibaoe7 — Sanjay Singh AAP (@SanjayAzadSln) 1581178400000

NEW DELHI: Senior Bharatiya Janata Party functionaries, including Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari , on Saturday claimed that the exit polls, which predicted a clean sweep for the Aam Aadmi Party, would fail when the votes were counted on February 11. An average of the exit polls predicted that the broom ( AAP ’s symbol) would sweep Delhi on February 11.Some of the exit polls even predicted that AAP would repeat its 2015 landslide victory when it bagged 67 out of 70 seats. Putting up a brace face, Tiwari claimed that BJP would win 48 seats and form the government in the capital.“All of these exit polls will fail. Save my tweet carefully. BJP will win 48 seats and form the government in Delhi... Please do not search for excuses to blame EVMs,” he tweeted.Delhi BJP MP Parvesh Sahib Singh Verma claimed that BJP would win 50 seats, while 16 seats would go to AAP and four to Congress. Union home minister Amit Shah held a review meeting with Delhi MPs and other party functionaries at the end of polling to analyse the performance of the party at the booth level and get a feedback.The meeting was also attended by party national president Jagat Prakash Nadda. In the extensive election campaign, both Shah and Nadda had claimed that BJP would win more than 45 seats in Delhi. The exit polls boosted AAP’s confidence, which was already hoping to form the next government.“People voted on the basis of work done by AAP even as BJP kept calling chief minister Arvind Kejriwal names and tried to communalise the election. BJP functionaries didn’t discuss the vision of the party and focused on communal politics. I feel that the people of Delhi have given their verdict. It will be out on February 11. I am confident that the results will be better than 2015,” AAP Rajya Sabha MP Sanjay Singh said.AAP functionaries, however, are not letting their guards down about electronic voting machines. Kejriwal called a meeting to review AAP’s performance in the election and directed party functionaries to keep a vigil outside the strong rooms where the EVMs have been stored.AAP workers were also following the movement of EVMs from the polling booths to the strong rooms.Tweeting a video of a DTC bus carrying EVMs standing in the middle of the road, Sanjay Singh urged the Election Commission to take cognisance. The location of the bus was, however, not clear. Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra also rejected the exit polls and said they would turn out to be wrong.“Congress will surprise everyone with its performance,” he said.In Video: Times Now Delhi Exit Poll 2020: 44 seats for AAP and 26 for BJP

Title: Coronavirus: Japan to send army to ship, Indian crew pleads for help
Content:
Inputs by Subhro Maitra Shreyas & Saurabh Sinha

NEW DELHI: Japan is likely to deploy its army to Diamond Princess, a luxury cruise liner that has remained quarantined near Yokohama port for several days and is now the largest known cluster of coronavirus infection outside China, crew members told TOI on Saturday.A total of 138 Indians — 132 staff and six passengers — are among the 3,700 passengers on board the ship which was quarantined after a man who had disembarked in Hong Kong was diagnosed with the novel coronavirus.With two more on board testing positive, the number of confirmed cases has climbed to 63, but none of them are Indians. The army was either being called to “manage” things on the Diamond Princess or for evacuation, a staffer said.The army was either being called to “manage” things on the Diamond Princess or for evacuation, a staffer said, adding, “The army is probably being called to manage things and to ensure safety protocols are followed.” He spoke on the condition of anonymity.The news came even as yet another Indian on board the ship appealed for help on Saturday. A 26-year-old employed as a steward on the ship made a desperate call to his family in Karwar ( Karnataka ), urging them to seek help from the government. “I’m scared as people are being quarantined. Please contact government officials to help us evacuate the ship,” he said in a video call to his father. Carnival Corporation & plc, the company which owns the ship, has assured his parents there was no need to panic and the Indian embassy also emailed a statement to them that it was in constant touch with local Japanese authorities. A majority of Indian crew members on the ship are from Mumbai, Kerala and Goa.On Thursday, another crew member, Binay Kumar Sarkar’s call for help on Facebook had gone viral. He told TOI that it’s all hands on deck now. “We’re all chipping in — in the kitchen, with supplies, cleaning. Then there are always people who have specific requests about their food. We try and do as much as possible,” he said. Sarkar added that "speaking out of turn" may not have been prudent. “By talking about our fears, I broke protocol. But this is about the safety of so many people. I don’t know what will happen when I leave this ship, but I had to say something,” he said. Till Friday, he was a chef. As of Saturday, he is a phone operator.But back home in Kolkata, his appeal led to a flurry of activity. West Bengal minister of state for labour, Golam Rabbani, sent a team to his house in North Dinajpur to gather details. His elder brother Shyamal said that their mother was spending sleepless nights. “The longer he is on the ship, the higher his chances of catching the infection. We are worried," he told TOI.While there is a definite end in sight — February 19 — when the quarantine period ends and they can disembark, people on board are worried. “This quarantine protocol, by putting potential carriers together, is what is worrying me. Why should we be on the ship when we know it is an infected zone?” said an Indian chef who hails from Jammu. “Japan has all the resources. Why has it docked us here?”For those on board, waiting is the only option. “No one is allowed to step out. Two days ago, people were allowed to come out for fresh air and stand a metre apart from each other. But that’s about it,” said Sarkar. Anyone with a temperature higher than 37.5°C has to be “taken away”. Medicines and masks are in good supply though."Water and food is now free of cost, as is the internet. Though usually the internet is the most expensive thing on the cruise”, a crew member said.

Title: Expedite reconciliation with Lankan Tamils, PM Modi tells Rajapaksa
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

PTI photo

NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi said the Tamil issue was discussed with an open mind with his Sri Lankan counterpart Mahinda Rajapaksa , who is on his first visit outside the island nation after assuming office.

Security and counter-terrorism dominated talks between India and Sri Lanka, as the Modi government hosted Rajapaksa even as India also asked Sri Lanka to expedite reconciliation process for the Tamils in the north and northeast of the island. The emphasis was significant given India's stake in the welfare of the Tamil population, which has shared ethnic bonds across the Palk Strait in Tamil Nadu.

In his statement to the media, Modi said, "I am confident that the Government of Sri Lanka will realise the expectations of the Tamil people for equality, justice, peace and respect within a united Sri Lanka."

In his statement to the media, Modi said, "I am confident that the Government of Sri Lanka will realise the expectations of the Tamil people for equality, justice, peace and respect within a united Sri Lanka. For this, it will be necessary to carry forward the process of reconciliation with the implementation of the 13th amendment to the Constitution of Sri Lanka."

The two sides held delegation-level talks, restricted talks (with external affairs minister S Jaishankar and NSA Ajit Doval ) and a one-on-one conversation between Modi and Rajapaksa on Saturday.

Title: SC: States not bound to give quotas in jobs, promotions
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

NEW DELHI: Busting a constitutional myth about reservation being intrinsic to public employment, the Supreme Court has ruled that states are not bound to provide quotas for SCs, STs or OBCs in government jobs and that there is no fundamental right to claim reservation in promotion.

“There is no doubt that the state government is not bound to make reservations. There is no fundamental right which inheres in an individual to claim reservation in promotions. No mandamus can be issued by the court directing the state government to provide reservations,” said a bench of Justices L Nageswara Rao and Hemant Gupta on Friday.

The ruling came in a case regarding the validity of the Uttarakhand government’s September 5, 2012 decision to fill up all posts in government services in the state without providing reservations to Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. The Uttarakhand HC had struck down the notification and had directed the government to provide quota to the specified categories.

Uttarakhand’s legal team argued that Article 16(4) and 16 (4-A) of the Constitution are merely enabling provisions and there is no fundamental right to claim reservation. The SC agreed the articles empower the state to make reservation in jobs and promotion in favour of SCs and STs “if in the opinion of the state they are not adequately represented”.

The bench upheld the September 5 notification and reversed the HC judgement. Writing the judgement for the bench, Justice Rao said, “It is settled law that the state government cannot be directed to provide reservations for appointments in public posts. Similarly, the state is not bound to make reservation for SCs and STs in matters of promotions. However, if they (the states) wish to exercise their discretion and make such a provision, the state has to collect quantifiable data showing inadequacy of representation of that class in public services.”

It also faulted the HC direction to the state to collect quantifiable data for providing reservation in promotion.

The SC said, “Not being bound to provide reservations, the state is not required to justify its decision... Even if under-representation of SCs and STs is brought to the notice of the Supreme Court, no mandamus can be issued by this court to the state government to provide reservation.”

Senior advocates Ranjit Kumar, Mukul Rohatgi and P S Narasimha, appearing for Uttarakhand, had argued there is no fundamental right to claim reservation in appointments or promotions to public posts and that there was no constitutional duty on states to provide reservations.

Appearing for people seeking quota in promotion, senior advocates Kapil Sibal , Dushyant Dave and Colin Gonsalves argued that states had a constitutional obligation to provide reservation for upliftment of members of SC and ST communities as mandated under Articles 16(4) and 16(4-A). Justices Rao and Gupta said, “It is for the state government to decide whether reservations are required in the matter of appointment and promotions to public posts.”

The bench said when a state forms an opinion that reservation is not required to be provided, all that is needed is that there must be some material to support its decision.

“The court should show due deference to the opinion of the state which does not, however, mean that that the opinion so formed is beyond judicial scrutiny altogether,” it said.

Title: Better roads, buses luring railway short-haul passengers?
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Better roads connecting major cities and more availability of luxury buses seem to have impacted the railways’ revenue.

The number of passengers travelling in AC chair car and executive class, meant primarily for inter-city travel on trains such as Shatabdi and Tejas, is estimated to decrease from nearly 35 million passengers in 2018-19 to about 33.8 million during the current fiscal ending March.

On the other hand, the number of passengers travelling AC 1, 2 and 3 is estimated to increase during this period. While the railways has projected a minor increase in the number of passengers in the AC first class, rise in the number of passengers is estimated to be significantly higher in the other two classes.

According to the Budget document, during 2018-19, nearly 138 million passengers travelled in AC-1, 2 and 3 compartments; the corresponding figure for this fiscal is estimated to be just over 143 million. The ministry has projected this cumulative number will increase to about 144 million passengers during 2020-21.

Though the railways has projected moderate increase in the number of passengers travelling in executive class and AC chair car for the next financial year — 35.3 million — officials said achieving that would be a tough task. “This is because now better roads and high quality bus service between cities like Delhi-Jaipur, Delhi-Chandigarh, Delhi-Lucknow and Pune-Mumbai have emerged as perfect alternative for people. It’s a challenge for us how to bring back passengers for this segment. Increase in number of passengers in AC-1 and 2 is an indicator that people prefer a more relaxed journey,” said a railway official.

He cited how the railways has now offered a Humsafar Express , which is a fully premium service with AC-3 tier and 3-tier sleeper class accommodation with modern facilities, to IRCTC to run between Varanasi and Indore under its initiative to give 150 trains to “private players” to run them. Till now it has given two Tejas trains with only seating facility to IRCTC, which operate on Delhi-Lucknow and Ahmedabad-Mumbai routes.

According to the Budget documents, the railways has targeted to increase the earnings from passenger segment to Rs 61,000 crore in 2020-21 as compared to Rs 56,000 crore during this fiscal. Nearly Rs 2,000 crore of this increase will come from hike in fare. It has projected freight earnings at Rs 1.47 lakh crore for 2020-21 as compared to Rs 1.43 lakh crore during this fiscal.

Title: Crackdown on pharma companies trying to dodge price controls?
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Drug-makers trying to circumvent price control will face stringent regulatory action and penalty with the drug price regulator revising its guidelines to monitor overpricing.

The National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority is considering a proposal to bring under the scanner cases where firms are not following pricing norms and refusing to submit data related to production and pricing or responding to showcause notices.

Such defaulters will be issued notice and their cases will be referred to the collector for recovering the overcharged amount along with a penalty, an official source said.

The proposal suggesting changes in the overcharging guidelines was taken up at a recent meeting of NPPA and it was decided to incorporate necessary changes in the guidelines, he said.

The move comes in the wake of many pharmaceutical companies not submitting data – especially verified data— or not responding to showcause notices issued by the regulator while pricing their products at prices determined on their own. The regulator has recently examined over 200 cases and found such aberrations. NPPA has also asked to validate data submitted by the companies with reference to excise or GST records and returns filed by the company under the statutes.

Currently, cases of overcharging beyond a particular amount are automatically referred to district collectors/magistrates administering the region where the defaulting company has assets. The district authority then recovers the amount as land revenue arrears.

The existing guidelines mandate companies to submit detailed information and data about their manufacturing as well as pricing.

The Drugs Price Control Order (DPCO) empowers the regulator to recover from the company any amount accrued due to charging of prices higher than those fixed or notified by the government.

Apart from the overcharged amount, the regulator also imposes an interest as penalty from the date of overcharging. Contravention of provisions of the DPCO is also punishable in accordance with provisions of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.

Title: PMC bags Rs 1.4cr in Lok Adalat, 456 plaints resolved
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Pune: The civic body added Rs1.4 crore to its coffers after amicably solving 456 cases of legal dispute pertaining to municipal properties, property tax and water charge defaults, among others, in the Lok Adalat on Saturday.

Civic officials said the PMC was trying out such an initiative for the second time in the last two months. The first such initiative was in December 2019.

As per the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) records, 409 cases of the water department were resolved in the drive where the recovery amounted to Rs1.33 crore and the 47 other cases pertaining to the establishment department raked in Rs7 lakh in this drive.

"The initiative has received a good response from citizens after notices were issued in this regard," said Manjusha Idhate, a senior official of PMC's legal department.

The civic officials said the administration was focused on recovery of tax dues and pending rents of properties, such as shops, public parking places and residential properties, under its jurisdiction.

“It is tough to recover all the dues with issues like manpower crunch which make recovery hard. It has led to long pending dues as many defaulters have not paid tax in decades,” said a senior PMC official.

He said even if some issues were of a personal nature, but they were indirectly impacting the revenue collection of the PMC. Family disputes over property ownership were leading to delays in payment of property tax. A few such problems were addressed in the Lok Adalat on Saturday.

As per the National Legal Services Authority, Lok Adalat is an alternative dispute redressal mechanism, it is a forum where disputes/cases pending in the court of law or at pre-litigation stage are settled/compromised amicably. It has got statutory status under the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987. Under the said Act, the award (decision) made by the Lok Adalats is deemed to be a decree of a civil court and is final and binding on all parties and no appeal against such an award lies before any court of law. There is no court fee payable when a matter is filed in a Lok Adalat.

Title: Jeweller arrested for cooking up loot story in Patna
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Police arrested Sujit Kumar, owner of Shivam Jewellers at Jai Ram Bazaar in Khagaul for cooking up a story of jewellery loot worth Rs60-70 lakh from his shop on February 4 to claim insurance money.

Patna SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma said on Saturday that Sujit had concocted the robbery story to claim insurance amount of Rs60-70 lakh. Upendra said Sujit himself cut the wires of CCTV cameras and dumped the wires into the garbage. “At that time there was only 50 grams of gold and silver jewellery in his shop, which is still there. Later, he called the police and alleged that jewellery worth Rs60-70 lakh were stolen from his shop,” he said.

“After three consecutive days of intensive investigation, the police did not find any evidence related to the robbery. Later, we also checked several footages of the CCTV cameras installed in the vicinity, but could not see anyone entering the shop during the period mentioned by him,” he said.

The SSP said Khagaul police got to know from reliable sources that Sujit had taken huge loan and couldn’t repay the debt. “When the police quizzed him, he kept changing his statement about the robbery. After the police showed the evidence, the shopowner accepted that he faked the jewellery loot story,” Upendra said.

A case under Sections 420 (cheating), 466 (forgery) and 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating) of IPC has been lodged against the jeweller.

Title: 16-year-old raped by kin in Patna
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

Title: Hindutva neta’s assailant hired by wife’s lover held after encounter
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Jitendra lies injured after the encounter on Saturday

LUCKNOW: Less than a week after Hindutva leader Ranjeet Bachchan was shot dead in the heart of the city, the gunman who pumped a bullet in his forehead was arrested after a brief encounter, minutes after midnight on Friday.

Police said, the shooter, Jitendra , 28, had come to collect cash from a relative’s house at Charbagh before fleeing to Nepal. A .32 bore pistol was seized from his possession, which was also the murder weapon. Bachchan was shot outside Globe Park in Hazratganj area on February 2, while he was out on a morning walk.

Jitendra’s name surfaced as an accused after masterminds — Bachchan’s second wife Smriti Srivastava , Smriti’s paramour Deependra Srivastava and the latter’s driver Sanjeet Gautam were nabbed on Thursday. Jitendra, who carried a cash reward of Rs 75,000 on his head, was Deependra’s cousin. He worked as a contractor in Mumbai and later shifted to Lucknow after his business floundered. Jitendra owed an obligation to Deependra as his stay in the city was sponsored by him, said police.

Lucknow police commissioner Sujeet Pandey told TOI five teams were tasked with tracking down Jitendra after he was caught on CCTV camera, stalking Ranjeet during his morning walk in Hazratganj on the fateful day. “Police teams began tracing his whereabouts after arrest of key plotters provided vital clues. Cops swooped down on Jitendra’s residence and enquired about his relatives and friends,” said Pandey.

Local intelligence unit along with police teams were asked to keep vigil on his relatives. On Friday night, Jitendra came to meet a relative in Charbagh and police teams were pressed into action.
