Title: nCoV outbreak in China can spur textile sector biz in India
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Coimbatore: With China reeling under the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) outbreak, Indian textile sector could potentially use the situation to its advantage, said industry representatives on Saturday. Pointing out that cargo movement in and out of China has been hit heavily, they said the global textile supply chain that was dependent on China would have to rely on other countries for import. “And India could tap into this opportunity.”

According to Rajkumar, chairman, Confederation of Indian Textile Industry, stakeholders, who were importing textiles from China, especially Southeast Asian countries, would look for alternatives, and India, with its capacity, could capitalize on the situation.

Speaking to reporters in the city, he said the opportunity could push up export of finished textile goods, clothing and fabrics by at least 20%-30%, providing an immediate relief from the drop in exports last year.

Rajkumar said the slump in China was a good opportunity for India. “Ships are not going there, and the number of flights has come down. This might take another 30 to 60 days to set things right. This would directly impact the world supply chain, which would at any time have 30 to 60 days stock.

If China doesn’t produce for 30 days, he said, orders might come to India. “It might come to Tirupur or Ludhiana. The possibilities of exporting cotton yarn, polyester yarn and viscose yarn from here also would go up. We have to wake up and work quickly to tap the opportunity.”

China's main clients in Vietnam, Cambodia, Thailand, Korea and in the European Union could possibly turn to India for buying finished gods, clothing and fabrics, he said. “This is a big opportunity to Indian textile sector. Inquiries have started pouring in. It would take another week to pick up,” he said.

With textile export falling in the past couple of years, this surge would help the industry become buoyant, he said. In the past two years, the export had come down from 100 million kilo per month to 60 million kilo and then 40 million kilo, he said. As the industry’s capacity was not utilized fully because of the fall, he said, the facilities were ready to meet the possible demand.

However, the situation also has a flipside. With the slowdown down due to the virus outbreak, yarn exports to China, which has been picking up, would take a hit, Rajkumar said.

Title: Rajasthan: Man falls off fourth floor while talking on phone, dies
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

KOTA: A 50-year-old man died after falling off the fourth floor of a hospital building while talking on his phone , in Jhalawar district on Saturday morning.

The man had gone to Jhalawar district government hospital for a heart ailment along with his wife and brother-in-law late on Friday night. Jhalawar city police handed over the body to family members after postmortem and lodged a case under Section 174 of CrPC for further investigation.

The deceased was identified as Rayees Khan (50), a resident of Suket town of Kota district, who was currently living at his in-laws’ place with his wife in Shyamgarh town of Mandsour district in Madhya Pradesh, said a police personnel at police check post of Jhalawar district hospital Bhupendra Hada.

While the man was talking on his mobile phone at around 5am on Saturday, moving to and fro on the fourth floor of the hospital, he accidentally fell over the stairs railing onto the third floor and died on the spot, the police personnel said.

Title: Priyanka Gandhi Vadra to visit Ravidas temple on seer’s birth anniversary
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Followers of Sant Ravidas in Seer Gowardhanpur on Saturday

VARANASI: Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra will visit Ravidas temple in Seer Gowardhanpur area on Sunday and attend celebrations on the occasion of birth anniversary of Sant Ravidas .

Thousands of followers of Sant Ravidas attend celebrations organised at his birthplace Seer Gowardhanpur every year. The district administration and police are working on arrangements to ensure a comfortable stay for the pilgrims.

Senior Congress leader Ajay Rai said that Priyanka Gandhi Vadra will reach LBS International Airport at 12.10pm. “She will head to Ravidas Temple from the airport to offer prayers. She would also meet Mahant Niranjan Das.”

She would return to Delhi the same day.

Before Priyanka, her brother and former Congress chief Rahul Gandhi had also visited Ravidas temple in November 2011. In 2016, Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal had offered prayers at the same temple on the occasion of Ravidas Jayanti .

Meanwhile, followers of the Sant Ravidas continued to pour in the city till late Saturday. Devotees had started arriving in the city a week ago from states like Punjab and even other countries.

A number of such pilgrims are staying in giant tents put up near the temple, while langars (community feasts) were also organised throughout the day on Saturday.

ADG (Varanasi zone) Brij Bhushan, IG (Varanasi range) VS Mina and other officials took stock of the security arrangements. District magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma visted the temple again on Saturday to inspect the arrangements. He directed officials to ensure uninterrupted power and water supply to the area.

Title: After armoury, work to open Khasbagh Palace’s strong room starts
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Rampur: The onerous task to throw open the locks of strong room of Khasbagh Palace in Rampur kick-started in presence of court-appointed commissioners and family members of erstwhile Rampur Nawab on Friday. It comes eight months after the Supreme Court passed judgment for the division of the property among the family members of the erstwhile Nawab.

The locks of armoury were opened on Monday to count the weapons. Carved vintage guns, gem-studded swords, knives with handles made of precious stones were found there.

On Friday, workers tried to cut open one of the iron sheets shielding the strong room. There are several such irons sheets and locks protecting the “treasure” inside the strong room.

One of the heirs, Nawab Kazim Ali Khan, alleged that the lock of the strong room was found “unlocked”.

The process to open the strong room will resume soon. “On February 10, the armoury of Khasbagh Palace will again be reopened for the counting of the weapons," Ali said.

Khasbagh Palace is under the possession of Nawab Muhammad Ali Khan alias Murad Mian and his elder sister Shahzadi Naghat Abedi, both son and daughters of the late Nawab Murtuza Ali Khan.

Title: Rs 1k cr more to be mobilized from market
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: In yet another bid to mobilize funds from market, the state government has notified the sale of Kerala Government Stocks (securities) of 10-year tenure for an aggregate amount of Rs 1,000 crore. The proceedings will be utilized for financing productive development programmes and projects to be implemented in the state. Auction of the stocks will be held on February 11 through E-Kuber at RBI’s Mumbai Fort office, an official statement said here on Saturday. Last time the state government went for fund mobilization from open market was on January 10 for an aggregate amount of Rs 500 crore. tnn

Title: I-T dept carries out searches on 10 premises of five jewellers
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Ahmedabad: A search operation carried out by the income tax (I-T) department on Friday covering five city-based jewellers continued on Saturday at 10 locations. While the officials did not disclose the finds, sources close to development said that the primary purpose of the action was to identify unaccounted cash and cash transactions which were not getting reflected in official books of account.

According to sources, various teams carried out the search at Om Jewellers, Manek Chowk; Ashtmangal Chains, Manek Chowk and CG Road; Shyam Bullion, CG Road; Suvarna Samriddhi, CG Road; RH Zaveri, Shivranjani Crossroads; and Rajeshkumar Mandaliya, Ratanpol.

“Impounding of the books of account, digital records and transaction details were conducted by the teams. Excess stock of both stock and cash were found at several of the premises. The search was on for almost entire day and the tabulation of what’s been found is being done,” said an official.

In December, a large number of firms associated with bullion trade and jewellery business had received notices over alleged non-disclosure of cash transactions post demonetization. The trade bodies had also protested against the move, terming the action ‘harassment.’ The officials however mentioned that the move is to identify the transactions where the demonetized currency was used for purchase of gold bars and jewellery.

“The transactions carried out in past three years, the stock taken and sold and the cash, digital and cheque payments are under scanner. Further probe is on,” said the official.

Title: Tamil Nadu nursing students register for jobs abroad
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Earlier, T Meena, a final-year nursing student from Dharapuram in Tirupur, had no idea that she could become a nurse in a hospital in the United Kingdom (UK). However, after attending the Overseas Manpower Corporation Limited (OMCL)’s registration drive on Saturday she said she was now hopeful of becoming a nurse in the UK. “I think the prospects have widened,” she said.

Like Meena, around 200 final-year nursing students from Coimbatore, Ooty, Tirupur and Erode had gathered to enroll themselves with the OMCL, a state government undertaking, at the drive that it conducted at the district employment office on Mettupalayam Road in the city. They were seeking an opportunity to become nurses in England and Ireland, with a monthly pay of Rs 2 lakh to Rs 2.5 lakh.

Representatives of OMCL said they had been facilitating jobseekers from the state to find jobs abroad for more than 40 years. B Somasundaram, recruitment coordinator, OMCL, said they have signed a memorandum of understanding with the Health Education England in the UK for sending 500 nurses from India to that country every year. “We would be offering the nurses free coaching for taking up the International English Language Testing System (IELTS) exam, which is a requisite for getting a job in the UK. We have tied up with the British Council for that.”

He said the first batch of candidates, around 15 people, have started training for the IELTS exam. “We would start sending nursing candidates to the UK in six months.”

Speaking about the process, Somasundaram said OMCL would register the candidates and upload their details online. After they take up the IELTS exam, their score would get uploaded on the portal. “Candidates would be tracked through an online application system. Following this, personnel from the UK would come down to interview and recruit them.”

A Jothimani, deputy director of employment, Coimbatore, said they have been planning to bring personnel from the British Council to the district employment office to train candidates. “This is the second registration drive after the one that we held last November. We had asked the nursing colleges in the region to send their students to the drive,” she said.

Candidates who were seeking skilled jobs such as electricians, technicians, plumbers and carpenters in the Middle East also took part in the drive.

Title: ‘Agri expo violation of civic body’s resolution’
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Kolhapur: MLA Chandrakant Jadhav alleged on Saturday that the agriculture exhibition on the Merry Weather Ground was a strict violation of the civic administration’s decision to reserve the ground exclusively for sports activites.

Jadhav’s claims come in the wake of the allegations raised by BJP functionary Dhananjay Mahadik. During the inauguration ceremony of the agriculture exhibition on Friday, Mahadik alleged that based on the instructions of guardian minister Satej Patil, Jadhav was obstructing the smooth conduct of the expo. The exhibition is being held at the same ground for the last 13 years.

“Those obstructing the exhibition are against the welfare of the farmers, who come from the rural areas to see the various breeds of animals as well as the new technologies available for farming,” said the former MP. Mahadik also refuted the allegations that money from Gokul dairy was being siphoned to hold the exhibition.

Jadhav said, “The grounds are the lungs of the city. I myself have remained a football player and as an MLA, it is my duty to protect the rights of the players. I had requested the organisers to shift the location, but they did not pay heed to the request. When the exhibition is held, the ground is not just blocked for a week but also undergoes extensive damage.”

“KMC had passed a resolution to allow only sports activities on the ground. The state government had also given its approval to the resolution. The exhibition is still being held,” he said.

“Earlier, the BJP-led government used to bypass KMC’s objections while approving permission for the exhibition. The organisers even failed to allocate space for the citizens so they atleast can take a walk in the morning and evening,” said Jadhav.

Title: Chitale Dairy’s Kakasaheb passes away
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Kolhapur: Dattatray Bhaskar Chitale, the man responsible for many modernising efforts in the dairy business, passed away on Saturday at Miraj in Sangli district. He died of a heart attack at the age of 78.

As per Chitale Dairy’s management, Kakasaheb — as Dattatray Bhaskar Chitale was fondly called — had inherited the Chitale Dairy business started by his father at Bhilawadi, which was located along a rail route in Sangli district, in 1939.

After graduation, he, along with his brothers, looked after the dairy which then was limited to just one village. At that time, even as the co-operative sector was growing, he and his brothers managed to run and expand the private business successfully. While he looked after the dairy, his brother Bhausaheb started the famous Chitale Bandhu Mithaiwale at Pune in 1950.

Kakasaheb was a household name among the farmer community. He connected with most of the dairy farmers in three talukas of the district. Chitale’s small milk collection centres helped the youth in the villages earn money. Under his watch, the farmers were provided with the high milk yielding buffaloes and cows. In recent years, he took a keen interest in the breeding of cows with the help of advanced technology.

He also set up library and schools in the region apart from being associated with several social organisations in the district.

Title: Upgrade of Candolim PHC to begin soon
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

CANDOLIM: The upgradation of the Candolim primary health centre ( PHC ) will begin after almost three years of its announcement.

Soon after the last assembly elections, health minister Vishwajit Rane had inspected the health centre in May 2017 and announced that the government had made a budgetary provision of Rs 10 crore for a new PHC, work on which, was to start in September that year. “This is a prime tourist area and we need to have a modern health centre here with a stress on trauma and emergency relief. This PHC has outlived its time,” Rane had said during the visit.

Soon after making the announcement, the old Mangalore roof tiles of the health centre had been replaced with galvanised sheets at a cost of Rs 10 lakh to stop the water leakage during monsoon. However, work on the new PHC had been stalled. Sources said that work was also delayed due to lack of funds.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: 'Bareilly ka bazaar' finally gets its famed jhumka
Content:
The 14-foot-high jhumka has been installed at the 'zero-point' on NH-24 in Parsakhera

BAREILLY: City’s long wait for a ‘jhumka’ (dome or bell-shaped chandelier earring) finally got over on Saturday, with Union minister of state (independent charge) and local MP Santosh Gangwar unveiling nearly 14-foot-high and two quintals heavy jhumka at the ‘zero-point’ on the National Highway 24 in Parsakhera area.Although the city has no direct link with jhumka, taking a cue from the song ‘Jhumka Gira Re Bareilly Ke Bazaar Main’ from the 1966 blockbuster ‘Mera Saaya’, which inadvertently associated Bareilly with jhumka, three years ago, the Bareilly Development Authority (BDA) conceived the project of installing a jhumka as an attraction for the tourists visiting the city. The project, however, hit roadblocks several times before taking a concrete shape.Bareilly division commissioner Ranvir Prasad, local MLA Arun Kumar and Bollywood actor Mukesh Bharti were among prominent chief guests who lit the traditional lamp before Gangwar inaugurated the jhumka — embedded with colourful stones and decorated by city’s famous ‘zari’ embroidery.Praising the BDA, MoS for labour and employment Gangwar said, “The collaborative effort made by the authority, various organisations and local residents in setting up of the ambitious jhumka in Bareilly is commendable. It looks beautiful and unique. Visitors will finally be able to associate the landmark jhumka in Bareilly with the evergreen song.”The project costs BDA around Rs 18 lakh — Rs 8 lakh for the jhumka and Rs 10 lakh for the beautification of the landscape surrounding the main structure. Notably, no government money was used for the project, even as it faced fund crunch several times, said BDA officials.Speaking to TOI, BDA vice-chairperson Divya Mittal said, “The jhumka was supposed to be inaugurated on the New Year eve, but it got delayed for some unavoidable reasons. The beautiful project is a collaborative effort among Rohilkhand Medical College, Bareilly International University and few other organisations, and local residents who helped BDA with funds in giving the shape to the ambitious project that would be considered a landmark.“The location, design, decoration and several other things were decided by the authority, which employed skilled artisans who worked diligently ensuring that the jhumka becomes a major attraction for the tourists.”BDA secretary AK Singh said, “Once the inauguration ceremony was over, people throng the venue to have a glimpse of the jhumka and were seen taking selfies and group photographs with the jhumka in their background.”Bareilly district magistrate Nitish Kumar, DIG (Bareilly range) Rajesh Kumar Pandey, SSP Shailesh Kumar Pandey, prominent physician Dr Keshav Agarwal and senior BDA officers, including Mittal, were also present on the occasion.

Title: Centenary church to mark 100 yrs of Gunadala shrine
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Vijayawada: A new church, with a seating capacity of over 3,500 devotees, is being envisioned at the foot of the Gunadala hill in the city on the occasion of the centenary year celebrations of the holy shrine of Mother Mary . Work on the structure has already begun and is planned to be completed within the next three years, in time for the 100-year celebrations of the shrine.

What started as a small prayer service for inmates of St Joseph’s orphanage in 1923, is now the second biggest pilgrimage for Christians in south India, next only to Velankkani in Tamil Nadu. Lakhs of devotees have already converged in the city from across the country for the three-day annual Mary Matha fest, which begins on Sunday.

Though the centenary year is still three years away, the management of the shrine, headed by bishop Joseph Raja Rao, has already begun preparations for the celebrations. While the existing church at the foot of the hill would continue to provide religious services to visiting devotees, a new and bigger church is being planned keeping in view the increasing number of pilgrims visiting the shrine year after year. The annual festival has been gaining in popularity over the years, with lakhs of devotees from across the country visiting the shrine during the three-day fest. Special train services by Indian railways and bus services by APSRTC are run during before and after the festival to cater to pilgrims’ rush.

A statue of Mother Mary, weighing 300 kgs, was brought to the city from Italy in 1951 and was installed in the cave, replacing the one that was initially installed in 1924. “The city (Vijayawada) is blessed with deities presiding over it on two sides. While goddess Kanakadurga sits atop Indrakeeladri hill on one side, Mother Mary is there on Gunadala hill on the other side,” says Fr EW Jaya Rajuthe, the shrine’s rector.

“We see a lot of non-Catholics visiting the shrine regularly. Hindus and Muslims perform their own style of rituals here, which we welcome,” he added.

The church had improvised direct access to the main road from the foot of the hill in the last two years, thus making the shrine visible from far. With the festival set to begin with the celebration of Holy Eucharist on Sunday, city police have provided elaborate security arrangements all through, including atop the hill.

Title: South Indian players to give inputs for national textile policy
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Coimbatore: The Southern India Mills Association (Sima) would organize an interaction session for textile industry stakeholders from South India with Union textile secretary Ravi Capoor in the city on Wednesday (February 12).

Stakeholders could use the platform to provide their inputs for the national textile policy to the Union textile secretary, said T Rajkumar, chair of the Confederation of Indian Textile Industry (CITI), here on Saturday. He said they have invited representatives of textile associations from Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka to participate in the interaction session.

Speaking of the announcements for the textile sector in the Union budget, he said abolition of anti-dumping duty on Purified Terephthalic Acid (PTA), a raw material for producing polyester, would enable the Indian textile industry to become globally competitive in the manmade fibre market. Indian polyester and other man-made fibres could not be sold for globally competitive rates due to the anti-dumping duty on PTA, which prevailed from 1996 to 2000 and from 2014 to 2020. “There wasa difference of Rs 15 between the international rates and Indian rates. Because of this, we couldn’t venture into making polyester products such as swimsuits or winter wear,” he said.

Rajkumar said on December 26 last year, representatives from various sections of the textile sector had met prime minister Narendra Modi in New Delhi and presented him their demands for the Union budget. “Half of our demands has been met in the budget.” tnn

Title: Varanasi: Traffic diversions along several routes
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

VARANASI: The traffic police department will introduce restrictions and diversions along several routes in the city in view of Sri Lankan Prime Minister Mahina Rajpaksa ’s visit, Maghi Purnima and Ravidas Jayanti on Sunday.

Expecting rush of devotees from Allahabad on the occasion of Maghi Purnimam, SP (traffic) Shrawan Kumar Singh said, “Vehicles heading to Dashashwamedh Ghat from various roads will be diverted towards from Maidagin, Luxa, Beniabagh and Sonarpura. Vehicles heading towards Lanka from Cantonment railway station will be diverted to Mahmoorganj via Kakarmatta .”

Commuters heading towards Bhaisasur Ghat and Rajghat will be diverted from Bhadauchungi, Visheshwarganj and Padao. The entry of heavy vehicles into the city from highways will be prohibited on Sunday. The restriction will be effective since early morning and will continue till the crowds thin.

In view of the religious processions organised on Ravidas Jayanti, no vehicular movement will be allowed between Maidagin and Gowdowlia after 8am. When the processions will cross Godolia on Maidagin route, traffic restrictions will be imposed on Godowlia-Lanka road via Shivala.

Title: Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation wipes out tricolour-themed rangoli
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

The revamped version of the 64-year-old ‘Khau Gali’ at Law Garden on Saturday

AHMEDABAD: The Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation wiped out the rangoli themed on the Indian tricolour, on Saturday morning, following a report published by TOI.

On Friday, the revamped version of the 64-year-old ‘Khau Gali’ at Law Garden was inaugurated by chief minister Vijay Rupani. The inauguration served up a controversy after people were seen walking on a footpath over the rangoli. The rangoli also featured an image of Patang hotel.

Enraged netizens reacted strongly on various social media platforms to videos which showed many people walking over the rangoli late on Friday evening. Early on Saturday, the AMC ordered all rangolis to be removed.

An AMC official said: “But when we reached the spot, there was not much of the rangoli left as many people had walked over it.”

On social media platforms, many citizens had red-flagged the offence on Friday, tagging municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra and mayor Bijal Patel. A twitter user, C Shekhar Dave (CShekharDave1), had tweeted: “Insult of National Flag By People. Flag created at Happy Street Law Garden by municipal corporation”. Another citizen, Muzammil Memon (muzammilmemon3), had tweeted: “This photo from law garden new happy street way. This is an insult to our national flag. Please order the dismantling of the tiles.”

Title: Citizens asked to provide info on rented properties
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Kolhapur: Officials of the civic administration have appealed to citizens to come forward and render information about the rented properties in their localities on the assurance that their identities would remain confidential.

Several discrepancies have been reported in the property tax collection. Officials from the property tax department said that many owners had been evading taxes on their rented properties for several years. Complaints have poured in from several quarters stating that the evasion was taking place at the behest of property tax officials. Recently, a couple of rented properties were found, for which property tax assessed was much less than the actual tax.

Senior officials from the property tax department said that since there was a nexus between the local authorities and the property owners, it was difficult to find out the actual number of rented properties and that only the information from citizens could be relied upon.

Chief superintendent of the property tax department Sanjay Bhosale said, “We have appealed to the citizens to provide details of the rented properties in their localities. Owners may rent out properties for commercial or residential purposes. Many times, owners hide the details of their rented properties. We have observed that such properties are registered differently in our system. As of now, we have received the details of over 60 rented properties from citizens and we are randomly scrutinising by visiting these properties.”

Sources in the civic administration said that if unearthed properly, a huge scam may likely surface from the property tax department.

“A couple of years ago, a firm that was roped in to identify and register new properties in the city also came under scanner. Many activists and corporators had raised allegations stating that the surveyors of the firm were bribed by owners to either not register their rented properties or tax them with lesser assessment,” said souces in the civic administration.

Meanwhile, municipal commissioner Mallinath Kalshetti decided to transfer some staff from other departments to the property tax department on Saturday and initiated the recovery of property tax. A team of officials will be set up at the divisional-ward level for sealing properties, which have not paid tax for several years.

Title: Annual bird race to be conducted today
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Coimbatore: The ninth edition of Coimbatore Bird Race will be held on Sunday. With sponsors like HSBC Bank and 23 teams, including teams of schoolchildren and experienced bird watchers, registering for the event, it is expected to bigger than last year.

The key aim of the event, which is organized by the Salim Ali Naturalist Forum (SANF), is to popularize the hobby of bird watching in urban areas. The participants will spot and identify different bird species from dawn to dusk. Though the race is not a competition, participants will exchange notes and have discussions based on their findings, from which children and beginners will gain knowledge from experienced bird watchers.

“The bird races are conceptualized to help study lives of birds in urban areas and to understand various aspects of biodiversity and environment around them,” said an official organizing the event. “Birds are often the foremost attraction for people trying to understand urban biodiversity.”

The race, which is coordinated by the Yuhina Canopy, is part of the India Bird Races conducted across 12 Indian cities usually between December and early March. “Important data that reflects positive and negative impacts of urban areas on natural scheme of things has been gathered so far in the races by about 3,000 participants,” said the official.

Title: Mumbai: Reel life woman cop chases, nabs mobile thief in real life
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Anita Kashyam’s photograph on her retrieved mobile phone

MUMBAI: A junior television artiste from Virar , who dons the police uniform for her role in a series, turned “cop” in real life when she chased and nabbed a thief who had snatched her mobile phone .

The incident took place in the densely populated Sainath Nagar in Virar (East) on Wednesday night.

Around 10.30pm, Anita Kashyam (29) had stepped out to buy some food items. As she was paying the money for her purchases, a youth approached her from the rear, snatched her phone and fled.

Leaving behind her purchases in the shop, she ran behind the youth and kept calling out to passersby to catch the thief. As she ran behind the youth through the busy road, her screams helped her nab the thief.

She retrieved her phone, valued around Rs 10,000, from the accused who was identified as Jogai Yadav (20). A huge crowd gathered at the spot and thrashed the youth before handing him over to the Virar police station. Kashyam registered a complaint against Yadav who was formally arrested on Thursday.

She told the police wearing the uniform in the series gave her the courage to chase the thief, who was “too fast”. Yadav has been booked under IPC Section 392 for robbery.

Title: Rajasthan: Carcasses of 7 peacocks found in Bundi fields, 1 held
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

KOTA: Carcasses of at least seven peacocks were recovered from the fields in Jajawar area of Nainwa forest range in Bundi district on Saturday early morning. One person was arrested in this connection while two others succeeded to flee from the spot.

Bundi district topped in poaching of the national bird in Rajasthan with as many as 200 peacocks reportedly killed in 2016. However, incidents of poaching of the national bird had declined in the district in last few years. The fresh killing of the bird has again alarmed the authorities. Peacock is protected under schedule-I of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972.

Carcasses of at least seven peacocks were found in the fields of Jajawar area of Nainwa forest range early on Saturday morning and they are likely to have been poisoned to death, however the exact reason of death would be clear only after the postmortem report, said deputy conservator of forest ( DCF ) Suresh Misra. One person was arrested in this connection and was produced before the court that ordered to send him to jail under judicial custody, while two others involved in poaching of the birds fled from the spot, he added. Carcasses of the bird have been sent for postmortem by medical board, he further added.

A particular tribal community is generally found involved in poaching of the national bird in the district and awareness activities to stop such poaching would soon be initiated, Misra said.

“Mogia tribal community was mainly involved in poaching of national bird but they stopped the bird and wild animals’ poaching after the community members along with their leaders were administered oath to shun the poaching in the district,” said ex honorary wildlife warden Prithvi Singh Rajawat and added that the Kanjar tribal community in the district is still involved in the poaching of the national bird. The accused in the recent poaching of seven peacocks also belonged to the same Kanjar community from Shankarpura village under Dablana police station of the district. Mogia community fines a penalty of Rs 21,000 if someone from the community is found involved in poaching of the national bird or wildlife in the district, he further said.

Title: GHMC News: GHMC’s Rs 5,380 crore budget gets green signal, likely to get more funds later
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

GHMC commissioner DS Lokesh Kumar during the budget speech.

HYDERABAD: Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation ( GHMC ) on Saturday unanimously approved Rs 5,380 crore budget for 2020-21. Similarly, Rs 1,593.64 was allocated for Road Development Corporation and houses being built under two BHK housing scheme of the state government, the overall budget for the three was pegged at Rs 6973.64 crore.

Of the approved GHMC budget , capital expenditure, which takes care of big-ticket infrastructure projects like flyovers and underpasses, was pegged at Rs 2,630 crore.

On the other hand, revenue expenditure stood at Rs 2,750 crore, leaving a revenue surplus of Rs 917 crore. Payment of salaries, maintenance works (roads and sanitation) except construction of projects like bridges and flyover fall under revenue expenditure.

The civic body hopes to garner Rs 3,667 crore revenue income, mostly from property tax. The capital receipts stood at Rs 2,630 crore.

The corporation has allocated Rs 98.45 crore for bridges, flyovers and subways, while roads and pavement improvement would get Rs 1,639.80 crore and Rs 170 crore for storm water drains.

GHMC has also allocated Rs 41.50 crore for greenery development (urban forestry and horticulture), Rs 121 crore for buildings, primarily for construction and renovation of markets, shopping complexes and community halls and Rs 345.79 for land acquisition, garbage dump yards and playgrounds.

Members urged the council for Rs 4 crore corporator fund. Hyderabad mayor Bonthu Rammohan said corporators could take up works up to Rs 50 lakh immediately and sanctions would be made accordingly.

“GHMC is likely to get more funds in the future as per the State Finance Commission,” said GHMC commissioner DS Lokesh Kumar.

Title: Azamgarh lawyer shoots himself dead in chamber
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative Image

VARANASI: A senior lawyer and woman police constable allegedly shot themselves dead in Azamgarh between Friday evening and Saturday morning.

In the first case, Surendra Nath Singh — a lawyer by profession — shot himself dead in his chamber around 8am on Saturday morning. The lawyer practised in a chamber, which was a located on the same premises as his residence, in Sidhari area of the district.

The incident came to light when his family heard a gunshot and they rushed towards his chamber. They found him lying in a pool of blood. He died on the spot.

Singh was also the former secretary of the Azamgarh District Bar Association .

SP (city) Pankaj Pandey said the lawyer shot himself with a licensed gun. Police have seized the gun and sent the body for postmortem examination. “It is not clear why Singh might have killed himself, but an investigation is underway.”

Late Friday evening, a constable posted at Phoolpur Kotwali, Puja Singh , was found hanging at her residence. The incident came to light when another constable went to her residence as Puja hadn’t reported for duty till late evening on Friday.

When Puja’s colleague reached her home, she found the doors locked. When she knocked, there was no response from inside.

In the meantime, the vendor who delivered milk at the house daily also reached the spot. When the two looked inside the room through a window, they found Puja hanging from the ceiling fan.

SP (Azamgarh) Triveni Singh said Puja was a constable of the 2018 batch and was native to Shahmadpur village in Chakia area of Chandauli district.

She lived in a rented house in Phoolpur and had been posted at the Kotwali since February 2019. “The police are trying to find out the cause of death,” the SP added.

Title: Civic body hopes to improve citizen perception ranking
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Vijayawada: After Swachh Survekshan 2020, Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) has shifted its focus to improving the city’s rank in Citizen Perception Survey , which is a part of Ease of Living Index assessment. The city which ranked 9th in 2018 is eyeing to break into the top five.

VMC commissioner Prasanna Venkatesh said that Ease of Living Index is assessed based on four major pillars — institutional, economical, educational and physical — and 15 key indicators which include safety and security, education, governance, health and public open spaces. The survey is conducted to achieve an evidence-based approach for future interventions and investments to deliver easy living outcomes, Venkatesh said.

“This is a prestigious survey and feedback given by the citizens will help us identify the core issues in the city. We have streamlined door-to-door garbage collection and street cleaning. We are using central government schemes like AMRUT, Housing for All and others to develop infrastructure,” Venkatesh said.

The civic body has started encouraging people to give their feedback in the survey. Around 114 cities across the country are competing in this survey and most of them are Smart Cities. Although Vijayawada is not a smart city, it was given a chance considering the initiatives of the urban local body, said additional commissioner U Sarada Devi.

Each city is given a score between 0 and 100. A core indicator carries 70% weightage while a supporting indicator carries 30% weightage. Institutional (25 points), social (25 points), economy and employment (5 points), and physical (45 points). Citizens are requested to answer the questionnaire in the online portal https://eol2019.org/CitizenFeedback or mobile application.

Title: KMC to install new light poles, shift existing ones
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Kolhapur: To improve the lighting across the city, the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) is all set to install new street light poles and shift some existing ones.

The civic administration had earlier received flak from corporators for using low-wattage LED bulbs, which created many ‘dark zones’ in the city. The KMC’s move to install more powerful bulbs was also slammed by the corporators, who said that the new bulbs were simply not powerful enough and that the dark zones were causing accidents along certain stretches.

The civic administration recently surveyed with the help of the electricity department staff and concluded that many neighborhoods, especially the ones in the suburbs and extended colonies in Ward E, need more street light poles. The survey also showed that some of these poles need to be realigned to spread the lighting uniformly.

Netradip Sarnobat, chief city engineer of the KMC said: “We have decided to take up short-term and long-term measures to get rid of these dark zones. The installation of the new poles and shifting of the existing ones are part of the long-term measures, which will take us a month to complete after the work order has been issued. Also, newly developed colonies do not have a proper network of street lights. We aim to start the work of shifting and installing poles in two wards. Our survey has shown that there are many roads with dark zones.”

Corporators had demanded that 70-watt bulbs will be installed along major roads. They had also asked that the wattage of the bulbs be decided based on the width of a road and if the distance between poles on one side of the road should be taken into consideration. Ideally, poles should not be located on both sides of a road, but this is not the case of the many city roads.

Sarnobat said that though the deadline for correcting flaws in the LED street lighting project ends on February 28, the work of shifting and installing light poles will continue post that too. He added that the same agency, which had executed the the project will be asked to fit LED bulbs of adequate wattage on the new poles.

Title: Govt launches chopper services from Doon to Chinyalisaur and Gauchar in Garhwal hills
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Dehradun: In a major boost to connectivity for people living in the hills of Garhwal region, chopper services to two important hill towns of Garhwal —Chinyalisaur in Uttarkashi district and Gauchar in Chamoli — were started by the state government on Saturday.

In a function at Sahastradhara helipad, CM Rawat flagged off the chopper services to the two towns. The helicopter service has beenstarted under the Centre’s UDAN (Ude Desh ka Aam Naagrik) scheme.

Speaking on the occasion, CM Rawat said, “This service will immensely benefit people living in the hills and it will play an important role in the progress of our state.”

The CM said the chopper services will prove crucial in emergency situations as well. “The government is making efforts to connect other districts of the state with the helicopter service. Air connectivity will boost tourism in districts and support the efforts of the state government to have a new tourist destination in each of the districts,” he added.

While Uttarkashi has two dhams, Gangotri and Yamunotri, Chamoli has the Badrinath shrine and is also famous for the Gauchar Mela. A fare of Rs 4,120 has been fixed from Doon to Gauchar while Rs 3,350 would be the fare for Chinyalisaur. Helicopters for Gauchar and Chinyalisaur will fly twice a day from Doon.

Title: One-day water cuts across city on Monday
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Kolhapur: The entire city is again going to face one-day water cut on Monday.

The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) is going to take up the remaining work of electrical installations at the Balinga pumping station, which is claimed to be a part of the upgradation process for the pumping station on Monday. Water supply to A, B, C, D wards and some parts of the E ward along with the suburbs will be cut off for the entire day.

Last week, the city had two-day water cuts. The works involved repair of leakage to a pipeline and the electrical installations, which could not be completed. Pressure from citizens and corporators had forced the KMC to resume the pumping.

“The work of electrical feeder and isolator, which are part of the pumping station, will be carried out now. We have requested the engineers of the electricity board to assist us in the work. We expect the work to be completed in one day. The water supply will resume immediately, unlike last time, when the supply was delayed due to hydraulic testing of the repaired pipeline,” said a senior official of the water supply department on condition of anonymity.

The rural fringe of the city, which depends on the Balinga pumping station for the water supply, too is going to face water cuts on Monday. The officials claim that the water supply may be at low pressure in some of the areas, especially in the D ward, which receives water a little late from the pumping station in comparison to other areas.

The localities that will face water cuts are Lakshtirth Vasahat, Sane Guruji Vasahat, Aptenagar, Rajopadhyenagar, Kanerkar Nagar, Krantisinha Nana Patil Nagar, Devkar Panand and Shivaji University.

The interior parts of the city such as Dudhali, Mangalwar Peth, Gangavesh, Uttareshwar Peth, Shukrawar Peth, Budhwar Peth, Somvar Peth, Bindu Chowk, Mahalaxmi temple area and Udyamnagar too will face water cuts. The water supply department is going to deploy water tankers. The tankers will be kept ready from Sunday evening onwards.

Title: Elamkulam plant finding it hard to shed its dry-sewage manure
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

The sewage treatment plant at Elamkulam

KOCHI: With virtually no takers, the Elamkulam treatment plant has been stacking up on manure made from the dry sludge of sewage.

The organic matter is piled up in a single-storey storehouse — for which an acre of land has been set apart on the plant’s premises. “Earlier, people from Tamil Nadu used to source the manure and have it transported by lorry for use on farmlands. But, there have been no takers for the past five to 10 years. Farmers here are not interested in using it. So we have been storing the manure in cake form. We have intimated the authorities about lack of takers for the manure, but to no avail,” said an official.

The plant employs the aeration method, in which sewage is collected in a primary tank where sludge is deposited and screening done to separate napkins. The overflowing water is collected in a secondary tank and fanned. The effluent is then moved to a third tank where air is again passed before the effluent is discharged into the nearby waterbody. The sludge which settles in the tank is then treated with anaerobic bacteria for 40 days in two steps before the final dry product is produced. This product is moulded to cake form and dried in sunlight on a drying bed, which covers 40% of the four-acre plot on which the plant is situated.

Authorities said the manure is odourless, unlike the sewage which is piped to the primary tank from the pump houses in Kadavanthra and near the Maharaja’s College Ground.

Moreover, Kerala Water Authority officials have sought an action plan on recycling the effluent. “The effluent water can be used for gardening and landscaping. Along with the action plan, we sent a report on the manure piled up at the store. We are looking forward to anybody buying the manure,” said the official.

Title: 7 arrested for duping people of Rs 5cr, hunt launched for 3
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Kolhapur: The Economic Offences Wing (EOW), Kolhapur, has booked 10 suspects and arrested seven of them for duping several people to the tune of Rs 5 crore on the pretext of high returns on their investment. A manhunt has been launched to nab the remaining three suspects, said police.

The suspects have been booked under sections 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property), 409 (criminal breach of trust by public servant, or by banker, merchant or agent) and 406 (punishment for criminal breach of trust) of the Indian Penal Code. The arrested suspects were produced before a local court on Saturday and remanded in police custody till February 12.

Police said that the suspects had launched ‘Success Life and Developers’ in 2012 with their main office located near the Central Bus Stand. They had developed their network in the district through a web of agents.

The suspects, along with other staff of their office, used to lure people by promising good returns on their investments. The suspects offered 12% returns to people on various investments in their company.

The complainant, in December 2012, had invested Rs 19 lakh in the company after the prime suspect offered him good returns. He said that he was promised a hefty sum of Rs 5 crore after five years. In 2019, when he approached the company and demanded the promised returns, he was asked to wait for sometime and was assured that his amount will be cleared soon. However, despite repeated visits to the company, the he did not get any money. Realising that he was duped, he lodged a complaint with the Shahupuri police station.

“We have registered a case against 10 members of the company, including directors and other officials, and have forwarded the case to the EOW for further investigation,” said a police officer from the Shahupuri police station.

Police said that they are investigating the case and are gathering information about the transactions carried out by the company so far. “We suspect that they (suspects) might have cheated thousands of people from Kolhapur district to the tune of hundreds of crores,” said an official from the EOW.

“We appeal to people to come forward and register complaints with us if they have been cheated by anyone from this company. We will take note of the complaint and act accordingly, “added the official.

Title: Mana Krishna campaign to be launched in rurals areas
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Vijayawada: After the success of ‘Mana Vijayawada ’ campaign, which imposed a complete ban on single-use plastic, Krishna district administration is now set to take up Mana Krishna campaign to educate the public in rural areas about the harmful impacts of single-use plastic.

Krishna district collector A Mohammad Imtiaz said, “Continuing the spirit of ‘Mana Vijayawada’ we have decided to takeup ‘Mana Krishna’ campaign in 304 villages in 18 mandals in Krishna district.” Officials from the panchayat, health, and revenue departments along with village volunteers and secretaries, will go door-to-door and explain the harmful impacts of single-use plastic and urge the public in use alternatives such as jute and cloth.

Imtiaz said he is happy with the state government’s decision to establish a special board to clean canals in Krishna and Godavari delta. “ We have started a campaign ‘Nenu Saitham Krishnamma Suddhi Sevalo’ and cleaned garbage piled on the canal bunds. Students and government officials joined the campaign. Even chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy appreciated our efforts and directed officials to constitute a special board to clean canals. We have prepared a detailed project report (DPR) with an estimated cost of Rs 400 crore to establish around 350 mini sewerage treatment plants (STP) in Vijayawada that will prevent sewage water entering directly into canals,” Imtiaz added.

Title: City hospital gets gold seal accreditation
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Guntur: The city branch of Ramesh hospitals has bagged the prestigious gold seal of approval from US-based global accrediting agency Joint Commission International (JCI). Gold seal badge is given to healthcare organisations for demonstrating continuous compliance with internationally-recognized standards. The private hospital , which was set up in 1988, is the only healthcare institution from AP in the list of 34 hospitals in India to get the JCI gold certification.

Dr P Ramesh Babu, chief cardiologist and MD of Ramesh hospitals group, said the facility went through a rigorous on-site survey by JCI experts, who evaluated its compliance with 1,199 hospital standards related to a variety of areas. “We are happy to receive the JCI accreditation. It puts our hospital on the global map. We scored 9.8 out of 10 on JCI’s quality scale, which is the highest in the country,” he said.

Potluri Gopikrishna, chief operating officer of the healthcare group, said Ramesh hospitals has many firsts to its credit. “We entered the Limca book of records in 1998 for 99.8% success rate in cardiac surgeries. In November last year, we made it to Guinness book of world records for our high success rate. The JCI accreditation is the latest addition to several other signature accreditations we received before,” he said. tnn

Title: Acquittal for man in ex-wife rape case
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative Image

COLVA: Additional sessions judge Dvijple Patkar on Friday acquitted a man charged with raping a woman whom he had divorced.

According to the Colva police, accused had divorced his wife in 2012. In January 2013, under the pretext of taking her back into his home, had forced sexual intercourse on three occasions, due to which she conceived and delivered a child.

Upon filing a complaint, the police arrested the accused and was later released on bail in November 2013.

Title: Action against Gorakhpur cop for his dharna
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative Image

GORAKHPUR: The sub-inspector, who staged a protest in front of Dr BR Ambedkar ’s statue in Gorakhpur on Friday alleging harassment at the hands of land sharks and demanding safety of his family in Jaunpur , has been sent to Police Lines and will face departmental action.

Sub-inspector Rahul Rao staged a demonstration holding a poster with an appeal to CM Yogi Adityanath to ensure safety of his family in Jaunpur from land mafia who, he claimed, were trying to grab his land.

SSP Sunil Kumar Gupta said, “Prima facie, we found that the land was not being encroached by any land mafia but the work of metering was on following the orders of SDM. He took the wrong platform to air his grievance. He has been sent to Police Lines and strict disciplinary action will be taken against him.”

When contacted, the S-I refused to comment on the matter claiming that he had some health issue and would not be able to talk.

Title: RTO suspends 522 licences in April-Dec period in 2019
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Regional Transport Office (RTO), between April and December last year, suspended the driving licences of as many as 522 motorists for different violations. The data emerged as city, highway and rural police stepped up their campaigns against drunk drivers and those found talking on the phone while driving.

Police authorities send proposals to the Nashik RTO whenever motorists are caught driving under the influence, speeding and using phones while behind the wheel. Subsequently, the RTO moves to suspend licences for a period of three months.

A senior RTO official said that the police have been getting more stern with motorists, given the rising number of accidents in the region. Last year, there were 1,853 accidents across the district in which 960 people lost their lives and 1,757 people ended up with grievous and minor injuries.

Between April and December 2019, the Nashik RTO received 548 proposals to suspend licences. Out of that number, it moved to suspend 522. The remaining 26, officials said, are in the process of being suspended. Offences such as overloading of vehicles, illegal transport of school students, signal jumping, speaking on the phone and drunk driving featured prominently in the list of proposals sent by the police to the RTO.

The transport officer said suspension of driving licences was a major deterrent.

City and rural police have been conducting awareness programmes to ensure minimal traffic violations. The police have also received high-tech vans to check speeding and driving under the influence alcohol. The RTO officials said the proposals to suspend licences will only increase, given the renewed drives and new equipment.

Title: Try your luck to win Rs 25,000 by taking up ease of living survey
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Coimbatore: People who participate in the ease of living index assessment could win a cash prize of Rs 25,000. All one has to do is to follow @easeofliving 2019, participate in the survey by clicking on the link in the profile description, share it and nominate five more people for participation.

Even as municipal corporations are racing against each other and time to achieve their target number of voters, as on Friday, the city corporation has achieved 58% of its target. Data shows that the civic body has managed to get 6,375 people to take up the survey, against its target of 10,919 people.

Meanwhile, the government has decided to award 25 people from each of the 114 smart cities a cash prize of Rs 1,000 each and an opportunity to interact with the city mayor or commissioner on critical issues as a reward for taking their time off to participate in the survey and share their feedback. Out of this, three national winners will be awarded Rs 25,000 and felicitated in the 4th apex conference of smart cities that would be held in Surat in June. They would also get a chance share their opinions at the event.

The ease of living index and municipal performance index were launched to assess the quality of life of citizens in smart cities. People have been asked to rate performance of the city based on 24 parameters such as women’s safety, health services, affordability of health services, cleanliness, pollution, transportation and electricity services, among others.

The city corporation has been creating awareness on the survey among the public by constantly posting it on its Facebook page and Twitter handles, and displaying it on LED boards.

Title: 4 held for attacking forest official
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Kolhapur: Shahuwadi police have booked four suspects for allegedly attacking a forest official, who obstructed them from cutting and smuggling ‘khair’ (scientific name: Senegalia catechu) tree in the forest area of Perid and Shirgaon villages adjacent to the Western Ghats.

The suspects have been booked under sections 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty), 323 (punishment for voluntarily causing hurt), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace) and 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation) of the IPC.

According to police, Rajaram Bapu Rajigire (43), a resident of Chuye, works with the forest department at Shahuwadi division. During his routine patrolling in the forest area of Perid village on Friday afternoon, Rajigire spotted four suspects allegedly cutting khair tree. He immediately rushed to the spot and obstructed them.

The four suspects allegedly attacked Rajigire with the equipment they were carrying and fled the spot in their vehicle with a part of the khair tree they had managed to cut. Though Rajigire gave the suspects a chase, they managed to disappear from the road. Later, Rajigire lodged a complaint at Shahuwadi police station.

“We are gathering information about the suspects involved in the crime and have launched search operation to nab them. Arresting the suspects will help us in reaching out to the illegal trade nexus from forest to other areas of the state,” said a police officer attached with Shahuwadi police station.

Khair is a medicinal tree found in abundance in the Sahyadri ranges of the Western Ghats and is a cure for several diseases.

Title: Mahipalgad: A 16th century fort & ancient Shiva temple atop hill
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Mahipalgad, an ancient fort located in Kolhapur district, stands tall on a hill adjacent to the Maharashtra-Karnataka border. The fort dates back to the 16th century and has got its name listed among 111 forts built by Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. The fort also hosts the Vaijnath temple that dates back to the 11th century. The huge fort and the ancient temple surrounded by dense forest certainly calls for a weekend outing.

How to reach

Mahipalgad is located in Chandgad taluka and is about 126 km away from Kolhapur city. Reaching Mahipalgad from the city is nearly a two-hour drive. Although Mahipalgad is located in Kolhapur district, one will have to travel to Belagavi first and then head towards Mahipalgad by taking Belgavi-Chandgad route. One has to take a right deviation at Shinoli village and then proceed towards Mahipalgad. One can visit the Vaijnath temple en route fort on the uphill road.

Legend has it

The Vaijnath temple was built using Hemadpanti style of architecture. A lot of changes have taken place in its architecture over the years and it can be easily seen by looking at various architecture styles in the sanctum. Jangam Swami, priest at the Vaijnath temple, said, “The temple is built using Hemadpanti architecture. The pillars of the temple are beautifully carved and have two sections, of which one is for Lord Vaijnath (Shiva) and the other one is for Goddess Arogya Bhawani. There is a small stone-carved water pond behind the temple..”

One can find a lot of things from Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj’s era in the fort premises. They include ‘Nishani Buruj,’ a fort tower, a huge 70ft x 40 ft well, temples of Lord Ambabai and Mahadev, a statue of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. The area is commonly known as Mahipalgad village. The villagers, believe that this fort was built sometime in the 11th or the 12th century by a ruler named Mahipal, but was established only when it came under Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj’s rule.

Flora and fauna

Mahipalgad offers lush green surroundings with a stunning view from all directions. Umakant Chavan, a researcher and nature lover, said, “This is one of the best places in Chandgad taluka and is full of natural beauty . It is famous as an ecological hotspot among nature researchers. One can spot many reptiles and Indian Gaur in the vicinity.”

Title: New dump yard poses health risks to Malumichampatty folk
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Coimbatore: The residents of Malumichampatty on Saturday said the stench and smoke emanating from the dump yard in their locality have been making their lives miserable. Owned by Malumichampatty town panchayat, the dump yard is located off the Chettipalayam Road.

Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) officials, who received photographic proof of decomposed waste and burning of garbage there on Friday, said they have issued a notice to the panchayat board.

According to residents, every few days around five to six trucks full of waste is dumped in the yard. The waste is then burned at least twice a week.

Meena, a resident of Sion Nagar, said, “Smoke envelopes the house every time they burn the garbage. Because of this, our eyes start burning due to the irritation. It feels like we can’t breathe. Our children also get respiratory infections due to this.”

Durai Rafeal, another resident of Sion Nagar, said the area was stuck in between Vellalore dump yard and the new dump yard that was set up by the panchayat around six months ago. “Every other day, one of the dump yards start stinking or burning. In fact, two weeks ago, we had caught a group of North Indian boys trying to set the garbage on fire one night and staged a protest the next morning, but to no avail. It feels like we can’t breathe in clean air at any point in our own houses.”

Manimaran, district environment engineer attached to TNPCB, said it was the second notice that they have issued to the town panchayat on Saturday. “Dumping unsegregated waste and burning it is against the rules and law, because when you burn food waste it decomposes, emanating a stench and causing air pollution. If it seeps underground, it can cause pollution of water sources too. If they don’t reply or don’t start complying with the rules, we will take up the issue with Chennai headquarters for further action,” the officer said.

Title: HCBA celebrates ex-BCI chief’s birthday as Lawyers Unity Day
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

ALLAHABAD: The Allahabad High Court Bar Association (HCBA) on Monday celebrated 91st birthday of former chairman of Bar Council of India (BCI) VC Mishra as Lawyers Unity Day .

Speaking at the programme, HCBA president Rakesh Pandey said huge gathering of lawyers showed that they had immense respect for legendary figure VC Mishra who always stood for the cause of lawyers.

The programme was conducted by HCBA secretary JB Singh.

VC Mishra, who has also served as former advocate general of the state, urged the legal fraternity to remain united to make a strong bar. He expressed happiness that his services were recognized by the legal fraternity.

Recalling the services rendered by Mishra, senior advocate TP Singh said, “Despite differences with him, I respect him for his devotion for the lawyers’ cause.”

Others who addressed the programme included former presidents of HCBA CL Pandey, RK Ojha and Anil Tiwari, former chairman of Bar Council of UP Amrendra Nath Singh, former secretary Ashok Singh, former additional advocate general Kamal Singh Yadav , and former secretary Pranesh Dutt Tripathi.

Title: Jhansi: 7 Bangladeshis held from hotel
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative Image

JHANSI: Police arrested seven Bangladeshis from a hotel in Babina area of Jhansi district on Saturday. The seven, aged between 24-40 years, were caught from a hotel after someone tipped police about their presence.

Police officials said that the seven arrested men have been identified as Mamoon Sheikh , Milan Sheikh, Mukul Sheikh, Monu Ved , Sijer Sheikh , Aslam Sheikh and Pallav Sheikh , all hailing from Dhakha , Bangladesh. None of them had passport or any other valid document in their possession.

Police recovered fish oil they claimed they were selling.

An ATS team rushed for interrogation as Babina is a sensitive area due to Army presence. Later, a case was lodged against the the seven under Section 14 of Foreigner’s Act and they were sent to jail.

SO Babina police station, Ishwar Singh, said, “The preliminary investigations reveal that they had come illegally to trade fish oil and were living here for past 7-8 days. We interrogated them on suspicion of any spying but nothing has been revealed so far.”

Title: Denied money for booze, man kills elderly parents
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Coimbatore: An elderly couple were hacked to death by their 31-year-old son at Vellimalaipattinam on the outskirts of the city in the early hours of Saturday after they refused to provide him money to buy liquor. The Alandurai police have arrested the murderer.

A police officer identified the deceased as 75-year-old P Sundaram and his 70-year-old wife S Thulasi, of Indira Colony at Vellimalaipattinam near Viraliyur. They are survived by four daughters, who have been married off and settled in various parts of the district, and a son. According to the officer, the couple made a living by grazing goats.

He said their son Karthikeyan was an alcoholic and used to fight with his wife often. “Unable to bear his torture, she had left him a few months ago and moved to her parents’ house at Kaliyapuram village near Madukkarai. A daily wage labourer, he also stopped going for work properly,” the officer said.

Karthikeyan, the officer said, then started to fight with his elderly parents and assault them in drunken state. At one stage, his parents lodged a complaint against Karthikeyan and police warned him severely. “On Thursday (Feb 6) night, he consumed alcohol and assaulted his parents. They again lodged a police complaint against their son. Police picked him up for questioning and he was let off later,” the officer said.

On Friday night, Karthikeyan consumed liquor and fought with his parents, before going to bed. On Saturday around 2am, he hacked his parents, who were asleep, to death with a sickle and left the house.

As the couple didn’t come out of the house in the morning, neighbours went to their house and found them lay dead in a pool of blood. They alerted the Alandurai police, who sent the bodies to the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital for postmortem. They also registered a case against Karthikeyan under Section 302 (murder) of the Indian Penal Code and formed a special team, which arrested him near Narasipuram. Further investigation is on.

Title: Chinese man, two others test negative
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Pune: Thirty-one-year-old Chinese man and two other persons quarantined at civic-run Naidu hospital tested negative for the novel coronavirus infection even as one more person was isolated on Saturday.

All of them were admitted to the Naidu hospital on Friday. While the Chinese national vomited in a Delhi-Pune flight, the other two complained of flu-like symptoms after their recent return from China. “The Chinese national has no other symptoms. Two other travellers have cold and cough. All of them have tested negative for the virus. They will be discharged soon,” Ramchandra Hankare, the chief of the Pune Municipal Corporation’s health department, said.

A 26-year-old traveller with a travel history to Hong Kong was quarantined at Naidu hospital on Saturday evening after he complained of flu-like symptoms. “His throat swab samples will be sent to the NIV,” health officials said.

Title: Amaravati protesters take complaint to goddesses
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Amaravati’s protesting farmers visit Medaram Sammakka Saralamma Jatara on Saturday.

VIJAYAWADA: Amaravati’s protesting farmers knocked on the highest doors for justice, that of god’s, on Saturday. On the 53rd day of protests opposing trifurcation of capital, a group of farmers visited Medaram Sammakka Saralamma Jatara, Asia’s largest tribal festival, accompanied with Dhanasari Anasuya (Seethakka), the present Mulugu MLA, and offered prayers to the goddesses.

It is not new that the protesting farmers sought divine intervention . From its very inception, Amaravati had had a divine connect. It had started with the laying of the foundation stone. The then TDP government had brought holy soil and water from all divine places cutting across religious lines to the region. Seethakka, who was with the TDP then, had brought soil and water from Medaram.

On Saturday, she helped the farmers gain darshan of Sammakka and Saralamma. She said the decision to change the capital will not yield any results.

Speaking to reporters after the darshan, she said, “We have given holy soil and water from Medaram and goddess Sammakka will shower blessings on the farmers of Amaravati who came all the way to Medaram to offer prayers.”

Earlier, the farmers had offered prayers to goddess Kanaka Durga atop of Indrakeeladri in Vijayawada.

In fact, it was the time when the Save Amaravati protests had gained national attention. Police had refused permission to women marching to Indrakeeladri carrying ‘Pongallu’ to goddess Kanaka Durga and had taken them into custody.

Later, they had also prayed at Amaralingeswara Swamy temple in Amaravati, Meesala Venkateswara Swamy temple at Anantavaram and Lakshmi Narasimha Swamy temple at Mangalagiri.

Since the beginning of the protests, farmers, especially the women, of the capital villages belonging to all faiths have been praying and seeking god’s divine intervention, hoping that the government would change the decision.

Title: DMC to fine residents who don’t pay property tax by Mar 31
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Dehradun: The Dehradun Municipal Corporation has said that it will penalise residents who don’t pay their property tax by March 31. Officials of the corporation said that residents living in the old wards of the city must pay residential and commercial property taxes by the end of March and those living in 32 new wards of the city should pay the tax of any commercial property that they own there by the same date.

The officials added that if the residents fail to pay their property taxes by the set deadline, a penalty of up to Rs 15,000 is likely to be imposed. DMC officials also pointed out that very few residents of the new wards have paid commercial property tax so far.

“Out of over 14,000 commercial properties in the 32 new wards, owners of only 300 such properties have paid their property taxes in this fiscal. To encourage tax payers, the DMC is also giving 20% rebate to all city residents who submit their property tax by February 15,” said an official of the civic body. The officials of the civic body have confirmed that the last date for availing this rebate won’t be extended any further. Last date to avail the 20% rebate was earlier revised from January 15 to February 15.

Title: Civil hosp gets microwave disinfection device to treat biomedical waste
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nashik: Member secretary of the Maharashtra Pollution Control Board (MPCB), E Ravindran, inaugurated a microwave disinfection system at the Nashik civil hospital on Saturday.

MPCB’s regional Manager J B Sangewal, member Amar Supate, district civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale and additional civil surgeon Nikhil Saindane were among others who were present at the inauguration ceremony.

Saindane said that the machine, manufactured by Meteka GmbH, Austria, has been jointly set up by the Global Environment Facility (GEF), United Nations Industrial Development Organisation (UNIDO), ministry of environment, forest and climate change (MoEFCC) and MPCB at a cost of Rs 80 lakh.

Jagdale said that the purpose of setting up the device was to provide an ideal facility for bio-medical waste management. Senior officials at the civil hospital said that the microwave disinfection device was the first such machine installed at a government hospital in Nashik.

Jagdale said that since Nashik civil hospital was one of the largest civil hospitals in the state,the hospital had a huge inflow of patients throughout the year. Hence, the volune of medical waste produced was also massive.

On any given day, around 700 to 800 intravenous (IV) bottles are used at the hospital, besides other plastic waste. Of the total bio-medical waste produced, 80% is plastic waste and the remaining 20% are shards of glasses, cotton used for cleaning blood stains, etc.

The aim of installing the system is to disinfect the plastic waste, which can be sent for recycling. It will eventually help in generating revenue and also in controlling pollution.

Senior officials said that the staff at the hospital would soon be imparted training on how to use the microwave disinfection devise.

Senior officials at Nashik civil hospital expressed their gratitude to the MPCB for selecting the hospital for setting up the microwave disinfection device. The Nashik civil hospital has twice won the first prize of Kayakap Award in the state, under the guidance of civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale.

Title: Budget would help take forward devpt agenda: Pinarayi Vijayan
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said the proposals in the state budget would help the state to take forward its development agenda through alternative plans.

The budget would help Kerala to tide over the acute financial crisis the country has slipped into. While doing so, the budget proposals would be able to give the much needed help to common man. “Consolidating the achievements the government was able to establish in the last three and a half years, the budget proposes plans to make further lofty achievements in agriculture, industrial and health sectors,” Vijayan said.

The budget, claimed the chief minister, reiterated the government’s focus on social welfare. Proposals for women, children and disabled people proved the same, he said.

“The alternative and people-centric policies of the state budget would appear clearer in the background of the worsening financial slowdown in the country and the defiant attitude of the Centre towards Kerala,” he said. The chief minister claimed that the coastal development package, Kuttanad, Wayanad and Idukki packages would help to narrow down the imbalances in development.

Vijayan also said the budget reflected the concern his government maintained towards the welfare of expatriates.

Title: Amaravati protesters take complaint to goddesses
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Amaravati’s protesting farmers visit Medaram Sammakka Saralamma Jatara on Saturday.

VIJAYAWADA: Amaravati’s protesting farmers knocked on the highest doors for justice, that of god’s, on Saturday. On the 53rd day of protests opposing trifurcation of capital, a group of farmers visited Medaram Sammakka Saralamma Jatara, Asia’s largest tribal festival, accompanied with Dhanasari Anasuya (Seethakka), the present Mulugu MLA, and offered prayers to the goddesses.

It is not new that the protesting farmers sought divine intervention . From its very inception, Amaravati had had a divine connect. It had started with the laying of the foundation stone. The then TDP government had brought holy soil and water from all divine places cutting across religious lines to the region. Seethakka, who was with the TDP then, had brought soil and water from Medaram.

On Saturday, she helped the farmers gain darshan of Sammakka and Saralamma. She said the decision to change the capital will not yield any results.

Speaking to reporters after the darshan, she said, “We have given holy soil and water from Medaram and goddess Sammakka will shower blessings on the farmers of Amaravati who came all the way to Medaram to offer prayers.”

Earlier, the farmers had offered prayers to goddess Kanaka Durga atop of Indrakeeladri in Vijayawada.

In fact, it was the time when the Save Amaravati protests had gained national attention. Police had refused permission to women marching to Indrakeeladri carrying ‘Pongallu’ to goddess Kanaka Durga and had taken them into custody.

Later, they had also prayed at Amaralingeswara Swamy temple in Amaravati, Meesala Venkateswara Swamy temple at Anantavaram and Lakshmi Narasimha Swamy temple at Mangalagiri.

Since the beginning of the protests, farmers, especially the women, of the capital villages belonging to all faiths have been praying and seeking god’s divine intervention, hoping that the government would change the decision.

Title: Rural cops seize gutka worth Rs 22.5L
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nashik: The rural police arrested two people from Madhya Pradesh for allegedly transporting gutka worth Rs 22.5 lakh in a truck on the Mumbai-Agra highway on the intervening night between Thursday and Friday.

Based on the instructions issued by superintendent of rural police Arti Singh, the personnel of the Local Crime Branch (LCB) were patrolling Kokangaon Phata near Ozar on the Mumbai-Agra highway from 11pm on Thursday and 5pm on Friday. While patrolling, the LCB personnel received a tip-off that a truck carrying a huge quantity of gutka was coming from Mumbai towards Nashik .

Subsequently, the police laid a trap at Kokantgaon Phata and intercepted the truck. On searching, police found 72 bags of gutka and banned tobacco products worth Rs 22.5 lakh. Police also seized the truck. The seized tobacco products have been handed over to the Food and Drugs Administration (FDA).

Meanwhile, based on a tip-off, police also raided a shop on the Chinchked road in Pimpalgaon city on Thursday and seized banned tobacco products worth Rs 62,000 found hidden in 10 bags.

Police said that the total banned products was estimated to be around Rs 22.87 lakh.

Title: 4.7 magnitude quake in Kumaon, 2 hurt
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Bageshwar: An earthquake of magnitude 4.7 on Richter scale struck Kumaon hills on Saturday morning leaving two persons injured.

The epicentre of the quake was Gogina area in Bageshwar district and tremors were felt across Bageshwar, Almora, Pithoragarh, Champawat and Nainital districts. The district disaster management authorities in Bageshwar said that two persons —Basanti Devi, 41, and her daughter Reeta, 11 — were injured when the wall of their house in Kidai village collapsed in the impact of the quake. Bageshwar district disaster management officer Shikha Suyal said, “Both of them suffered minor injuries. They were rushed to the district hospital where they were provided first-aid, Rs 3,800, two blankets and a disaster relief kit.”
