Police have sent the body to the postmortem and launched a further investigation into the matter.

Superintendent of police (city) Satpal Antil said, “Investigation is being conducted on every point of view, CCTV footages are also being examined. Once we get some clues, we will disclose the details soon.”

Title: Vadodara courts dispose of 9k cases during Lok Adalat
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Vadodara: Courts in Vadodara district disposed of 9,796 during the day-long National Lok Adalat held on Saturday.

Courts in the district court complex at Diwalipura and at different talukas in Vadodara district took up 20,203 cases for hearing. These cases included pending civil and criminal cases like motor accident claims, matrimonial disputes, land acquisition cases, service benefit disputes, bank recovery suits, labour disputes, cheque bounce cases and electricity and water bill disputes. Of the disposed of cases, 301 cases were at pre-litigation stage and 9,435 cases were pending in different courts.

Along with the disposal of cases, amount of over Rs 60 crores was also awarded as compensation or settlement money.

“Lok Adalat is not at a substitute to the present justice dispensation system, but rather a complimentary component to achieve speedy justice and a binding resolution,” said Dr A C Joshi, principal district judge and chairman of district legal services authority.

Title: MSEZ stares down barrel with steep hike in water tariff
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

A file pic of MSEZ.

MANGALURU: Mangalore Special Economic Zone (MSEZ) is staring at closure . With industrial offtake in MSEZ limited to ONGC Mangalore Petrochemicals Ltd, five other units and more than 300 acres yet to be allotted, a recent move by the state government to hike water tariff for industrial use 100 times has come as a body blow to MSEZ. Tariff that was Rs 1,800/mcft was hiked to Rs 1.5-lakh/mcft and after protestations pared to Rs 1lakh/mcft.

Following a May 28, 2018 order for water drawn from dams and reservoirs, the tariff has been revised from the previous Rs 3,200/mcft to Rs 300,000/mcft across industries. For water drawn from natural sources, it has been revised to Rs 150,000/mcft across industries from Rs 1,800/mcft earlier.

A top MSEZ source, privy to the development, told STOI that the tariff for the latter category on which it is dependent has since been reduced to Rs 1 lakh/mcft.

Saying that this hike will make operations at MSEZ unviable, the sources said the annual water bill that MSEZ used to foot was Rs 28 lakh, which has now jumped to Rs 24 crore.

Wondering how industries in the present economic scenario of slowdown and with bank lending too having come to a standstill, will cope with the situation, the sources said, “MSEZ has borrowed to create infrastructure in the SEZ. How can we repay this amount unless industries set shop?”

Existing units at MSEZ – four fish surmi units, Cardolite and OMPL are yet to fully establish themselves. Against 1,620 acres notified for MSEZ and only 1,000 acres available for commercial exploitation, the source pointed out that MSEZ is yet to lease out 300 acres.

OMPL alone accounts for 450 acres allotted, and the remaining units are set on 250 acres. These units will not be able to sustain this steep hike in water tariff, the source said.

The source pointed out that with power tariff too set for revision as Mescom tariff filing for 2020-21 is coming up for hearing on February 13, this will effectively kill any entrepreneurship that one expected to thrive at MSEZ.

“MSEZ has distribution license inside the zone, but KERC decides at what price we must purchase power from Mescom. This even though MSEZ is the single biggest customer for the electricity distribution company,” the source said.

Incidentally, it is not just the MSEZ that has raised red flags on this water tariff issue. Even Karnataka Iron and Steel Association as well as other affected manufacturers have appealed to the state government for an immediate rollback of the tariff revision. In Tamil Nadu or a drought-stricken state like Rajasthan, the rates are Rs 14,000-Rs 20,000/mcft, the source said, assailing the tariff order that Krishna Bhagya Jala Nigam Ltd mooted.

Title: DPC takes up rainwater harvest at collectorate premises
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nashik: The district planning committee ( DPC ), Nashik, has undertaken the rainwater harvesting exercise at the district planning office which falls under the district collectorate premises.

“As part of the exercise to harvest rainwater falling on the roof top at government buildings, the DPC decided to construct the apparatus on the collectorate premises that can collect the water,” a senior officer from the district administration said.

The work will be carried out by the public works department (PWD) estimated at Rs 2.5 lakh. The PWD official said the water falling on the terrace will be drawn in the pit that has layers of metals and substances to purify the water.

Title: Rajkot woman admitted with suspected coronavirus infection
Content:
Representative image

RAJKOT: A 21-year-old medical student from Jetpur was admitted to the isolation ward of Rajkot civil hospital following suspicion of coronavirus infection late on Friday night.The woman, who studies medicine at Nanchang University in China’s Jianxi city, has been suffering from cough and throat pain ever since she returned to India on February 1 following the outbreak of the deadly virus.The hospital administration has sent her blood sample to B J Medical College in Ahmedabad for testing and results are expected on Sunday. Besides her, 62 others from Rajkot district, who have returned from China in the past 15-20 days, have been kept under observation.Giving details of the woman’s medical history, district development officer A R Ranavasia said, “She had arrived in India on February 1 and has been under observation since then. However, after she told us that she was suffering from cough since January 25, we advised her home quarantine.“But her condition did not improve and coughing continued along with throat pain. We, therefore, advised her family to shift her to the isolation ward of Rajkot civil hospital.”The woman had landed at Mumbai airport on February 1 and thereafter she went to Surat for a day before coming to her hometown Jetpur.Rajkot district medical officer Manish Bhanderi said, “We don’t want to take any risk. She has mild symptoms of the deadly virus as she is continuously coughing with no improvement. We had to convince her family members to get her admitted in the isolation ward.”The district administration has received list of persons returning from China or those who came to India via China from the union health ministry and the ministry of external affairs. The majority of arrivals from China are students and businessmen.Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC) health officer Dr Pankaj Rathod said, “We have 53 people in Rajkot city under observation. We will observe them for 14 days and ask their family members to maintain social isolation.”

Title: Teen boy, girl end lives on railway tracks in Gujarat
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: Two teenagers ended their lives by throwing themselves in front of a train near Dahod on Saturday afternoon. It is believed that the two were in a relationship.

The 18-year-old boy Aman Sansi and 17-year-old girl Sonia Mahavar were found dead on the railway tracks near Jekot on the up line. Officials of the Government Railway Police (GRP) rushed to the spot on being informed about the bodies.

Parents of the deceased duo were informed about the incident.

It is believed that the boy and the girl were in love and took the extreme step due to opposition to the relationship.

GRP personnel handed over the bodies to the Dahod taluka police that sent them for an autopsy. Investigations were started by taluka police after registering the incident as an unnatural death.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Doctors posted in tribal areas to get allowance up to Rs 75,000/month
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: Good news for doctors posted in tribal areas of Madhya Pradesh as they would now be getting extra allowance than their urban counterpart. State government has launched CM Susheshan Medical Officers appreciation scheme to pay incentive allowances along with salary to medical officers to ensure their presence at health institutions in tribal areas. An order in this regard was sent to CMHOs of 20 districts with tribal population to implement it.

The government under the scheme decided to pay allowance ranging from Rs40,000 to Rs 75,000 to permanent and contractual medical officers and specialist working in primary health centres and community health centres in identified areas along with existing salaries. The allowances will be paid to all contractual and permanent doctors posted in those health facilities in identified 89 backward blocks in 20 districts including Chindwara, Betul, Dindori, Dhar, Khanwa, Alirajpur, Khargone, Barwani, Siwni, Shahdol, Umaria, Annuppur and Ratlam.

There are 338 primary health centres and 96 community health centres in these identified areas. Among these 89 backward blocks, 21 are identified as more backward blocks

The government decided to pay Rs40,000, Rs50,000 and Rs, 75,000 as incentive allowance to medical officers, specialist(diploma) and specialist(degree) respectively to permanent and contractual doctors.

Welcoming the decision, state medical officers association general secretary Dr Madhav Hasani said, “This is the first time, when the government has thought about permanent medical officers already working in backward district.”

“We can hope that this step of government will attract more doctors to state for working in rural areas,” said Hasani.

According to a reply of ministry of health and family welfare in Rajya Sabha during monsoon session last year, there are 3858 doctors serving at government facilities in the state against sanctioned posts of 6,002 as of March, 2018. There are 248 specialists working at around 300 CHCs in state against 1236 sanctioned posts. Also, there are 1112 allopathic doctors serving against 1771 sanctioned posts at PHCs in state.

Title: Darul Uloom VC ‘asks women to call off anti-CAA stir’, faces protest from students
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

VC Nomani urged women protesting in Deoband to end the protest in the wake of Union home ministry's clarificat... Read More

MEERUT: Hundreds of students at renowned Islamic seminary Darul Uloom, Deoband held a protest and demanded resignation of their vice chancellor Abul Qasim Nomani over his alleged appeal to Muslim women to call off the anti-CAA protest. The students’ protest was held at the seminary campus on late Friday evening, prompting the VC to issue a clarification and disassociate himself from the remark.

VC Nomani said, “I reached out to the agitating students and cleared the confusion over my remark. The issue was immediately resolved.”

It all started when a video of VC Nomani, speaking at local peace committee meeting, went viral on Friday. In the video clip, Nomani could be heard purportedly urging women protesting at Eidgah ground in Deoband to end the protest in the wake of Union home ministry’s clarification on NRC.

It triggered widespread criticism with many on social media taking potshots at the VC Nomani’s statement.

The protests prompted the VC to issue a press release.

“The video is in fact a clip of meeting held by district administration regarding peace in Deoband. I was also part of this. But, I never issued such a statement. My opinion is being wrongly twisted. Darul Uloom, Deoband has not issued any appeal to end the country-wide protests,” he said in the release.

The late night protest by students sent the local administration into a tizzy. Police was also on alert though senior officials refrained to comment on it claiming it to be the “internal matter” of the institution.

Title: Polls in 55 cantonments, including Deolali, deferred
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nashik: The Ministry of Defence (MoD) has deferred elections in 55 cantonment boards across the country.

Officials said the ministry will now release a fresh date for the elections.

Of these 55 cantonment boards, seven are in Maharashtra — Deolali (Nashik), Aurangabad, Ahmednagar, Pune, Khadki, Dehu Road and Kamptee (Nagpur).

Deputy director of MoD Rajesh Kumar Shah, in a written communiqué on February 5, informed the General Officer Commanding-in-Chief (GOC-in-C) about the ministry’s decision. The letter cited “administrative” reasons.

“The term of office of all elected members of these cantonment boards has been extended for six months, or till the date of the constitution of the Board, whichever is earlier,” read the MoD communiqué.

Elections in these 55 cantonment boards, which last took place in 2014, were slated for this month. In fact, Cantonment Board, Deolali (CBD) had already started preparations for elections in the eight seats. It had recently conducted a lottery to reserve three seats for women candidates as per instructions from the MoD in November.

Ajay Kumar, the CEO of CBD, told TOI that the board has decided not to proceed with the poll preparations given the latest instruction from the MoD.

“We will restart the poll preparation work after we receive the green signal to do so from the ministry,” Kumar said.

Elected members of the CBD said they are happy that the MoD had extended their tenure. CBD vice-president Bhagwan Katariya said the feedback he has received suggested six other cantonment boards are due for elections in June this year.

“It is possible that the MoD is planning to organise simultaneous polls in 61 cantonment boards simultaneously in June. That is perhaps why elections in 55 boards were deferred,” Kataria said.

Prabhavati Dhiware, another elected member of the CBD, said an extension to her tenure meant she will now get some more time to finish pending projects.

“We have been waiting for funds to build a community hall in Ward No. 1. We also need a dialysis machine at the cantonment hospital. We will try to ensure that funds for the projects reach us before the election,” Dhiware said.

Another elected member of CBD, Baburao Mojad said even new projects can be planned by existing members due to extensions of their tenures.

Title: Akash bats for people affected in demolition drive on MGM campus
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Indore: The stage was set for another ‘ballebazi’ by MLA Akash Vijayvargiya on Saturday on MGM Medical College campus during an ongoing encroachment removal drive meant to pave way for proposed development work. But the ‘batsman’ even after ‘padding up’ for another show of strength showed restraint this time and ‘went back to the pavilion’ after finding out that all eligible people among the affected would be provided alternate arrangements.

Vijayvargiya was approached by affected people, who raised objections over the encroachment removal drive and demanded time of a few days to vacate staff quarters. After reaching the spot, the MLA contacted district collector Lokesh Kumar Jatav over the phone and also had discussion with tehsildar Brahmaswaroop Shrivastava and Rajesh Soni to press for the demand of affected people.

The BJP leader however returned after administrative officials on the spot informed him about making alternative arrangements for eligible people. “The drive was execution of legally passed order,” the collector told TOI.

According to college dean Dr Jyoti Bindal, the management has been waiting from around a year for removal of staff quarters, most of which are illegal acquired, to follow due course of law and after getting clearance from all authorities concerned, they urged district administration and Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) to remove structures posing as hurdles in proposed works of development.

“We have identified three groups of people, who have acquired staff quarters on college campus. There are around 28 people in the first group, who were never allotted staff quarters but have illegal possession while in second group, there are around 41 employees, to whom quarters were allotted but they are residing somewhere else and have not given up possession,” Dr Bindal told TOI.

She added that in the third group, there are around 54 employees, who have been allotted quarters and they are working in college but structures have been declared ‘unfit for human use’ by district administration.

“Before starting a drive to remove 16 structures of the first group, occupants were issued notices thrice and given adequate time to vacate the staff quarters,” dean said. She added that to provide alternate arrangements to people of third group, the college administration has approached IDA to provide them flats in its scheme.

“We will become guarantor in the affected people of third group to avail flats and will pay installment as per their rent allowance. In this way, they will become owner of the property,” the dean said. She added that after removing hurdles, a 300-seat lecture hall, installation of transformers, parking lot and different services of Super Specialty Hospital will be developed.

Title: Panels to check illegal abortions will be set up in all dists: Silawat
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Indore: State health minister Tulsiram Silawat on Saturday said that local committees under pre conception and pre natal diagnostic techniques (prohibition of sex selection) act ( PCPNDT ) would be set up in all districts where they don’t exist at present to check illegal abortions and help increase sex ratio.

“We will soon set up PCPNDT cells in all districts of state. The meetings of these cells will be held quarterly while meeting of PCPNDT state-level supervisory board will be held every four months,” Silawat said.

The minister was presiding over supervisory board meeting, which was held after a gap of over three years.

During the meeting, MLA Kalawati Bhuria alleged that sex determination tests were still being carried out in hospitals in Dahod near Jhabua and proper monitoring was needed to stop them.

Another MLA Jhuma Solanki said that while action was being taken against those carrying out sex determination tests, the ones seeking such tests should also be made accused. “Doctors should not be blamed for everything as they are already scared of various clauses in PCPNDT Act. Relaxation should be given on technical issues,” she said .

Senior radiologist, Dr Alok Lahoti, alleged that in-vitro fertilization (IVF) centres were deciding sex of a baby even before a mother conceived them. “This should be addressed and all IVF centres should be registered under PCPNDT Act. MGM Medical College dean Dr Jyoti Bindal raised questions over sale of pregnancy termination medicines over the counter.

The health minister said that steps taken in Indore for improving sex ratio would be followed across the state.

Later, replying to a question over 5000 untraced pregnant women, whose state of delivery was not known, Silawat said, “The matter has come to my knowledge. I will talk to the minister concerned and senior officials of woman and child development department (responsible for physical verification of such women).”

The women had undergone sonography tests in last calendar year but local PCPNDT cell had no record of whether they had delivered or terminated their pregnancies. The district administration has asked WCD officials to carry out a physical verification of these women but the department is yet to furnish the report.

Title: Archbishop condemns MTP Act amendment
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The Archbishop of Latin Archdiocese M Soosa Pakiam has slammed the Union government over the amendment in Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, extending the period of abortion till six months of pregnancy. Terming the government move unfortunate, Pakiam has also demanded the government to withdraw the amendment.

In a statement issued here, Soosa Pakiam said that the new amendment in MTP Act will only contribute to more abortions in the country. The amended law will only help cultivate a culture in which people will not regret to terminate an unborn child “for their selfish needs”.

“The government should be duty bound to develop a society that has equal space for all categories of people, including unborn children. The government must aim to encourage life and survival against all odds rather than allowing to terminate precious lives,” Pakiam said in his statement.

The Archbishop exhorted the people to align with Kerala Catholic Bishops’ Council Pro-Life Samithy to fight against the amendment. Awareness campaigns will be carried out to sensitise students and youths in this regard. He also urged the support and participation of people in various events, including a seminar and a rally, being organized in the capital city by KCBC Pro Life Samithy on March 25, which is observed as the International Day of Unborn Child. tnn

Title: Leopard found dead in Bijnor, 7th death this yr in west UP
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Bijnor: A leopardess was found dead at Bijnor’s Baharia village on Friday. The carcass seemed to be three or four days old. Going by the condition of the carcass, forest department officials suspect that the big cat succumbed to some disease. However, they will wait for its autopsy report before drawing any conclusions.

This is the seventh case of leopard death in west UP this year. Three of them were killed by villagers in Bijnor, Moradabad and Badaun, respectively. While the fourth died of age–related issues in Bulandshahr’s Bawanpur village. Two were killed in road and rail accidents, respectively. All the deaths took place last month,

According to sources, the carcass of a leopardess, around three years old, was found in a sugarcane field at Baharia village in Bijnor district. A team led by sub divisional forest officer Imtiyaz Siddiqui rushed to the spot on being informed and sent the carcass to the Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI) in Bareilly.

Later, talking with TOI, Siddiqui said, “There were no injury marks on the carcass of the leopard. Prima facie it seems that it died of some disease. Autopsy was carried out on Saturday at IVRI in Bareilly. Viscera of the big cat has been preserved for chemical examination. The real cause of the death is yet to be ascertained.”

The discovery of the leopard carcass comes days after a five-year-old spotted cat was hit by a running train in Haldaur in Bijnor district on January 30. A day earlier on January 29, a leopard was run over by a vehicle on Najibabd-Haridwar road along East Ganga canal.

On January 22, a leopard has been found dead in Bulandshahr’s Bawanpur village. Foresters suspect that it died of old age.

On January 12, a leopard was beaten to death Budaun district. An FIR was registered against eight named and 30-35 unidentified villagers in the case. An SIT was also constituted to probe the brutal killing.

On January 8, forest department filed an FIR against unknown persons after a leopard carcass was found in Kanth area of Moradabad. Postmortem report said a head injury was the cause of death, which could be the result of being “run over by vehicle or hit in the head by someone”.

On January 6, villagers in Bijnor had gunned down a leopard after a child was allegedly mauled to death by the big cat. In all, 80 villagers were booked. After the incident, a special team led by principal wildlife conservator of UP Sunil Pandey visited Mohandiya village in Bijnor tehsil, 30 km from Bhogpur village in Najibabad tehsil, where the leopard was killed. He issued orders to capture a leopardess suspected to have killed at least three of the six people mauled to death by big cats in the district since November 27.

Since November 27, six people have been mauled to death by big cats in west UP and three of the victims hailed from Bijnor district

Experts fear that the increase in man-animal conflict will serve as a boon for hunting tribes and poachers. The wild animals whether alive or dead will end up in wildlife trade as official agencies have not been able to mitigate the growing crisis, they added.

“There is a growing disenchantment among villagers whose role is critical to conservation of wildlife. The fact that forest department is ill-equipped to reduce man-animal conflict will give poachers and hunting tribes like Kanjars and Badhiya a chance join hands with frightened villagers and convince them that they will ‘solve their problems’ and this will obviously expose leopards and other animals in the region to grave risk,” warned Abrar Ahmed, illegal wildlife trade investigator and former programme officer at Trade Records Analysis of Flora and Fauna in Commerce (TRAFFIC-India).

(With inputs from Sandeep Rai from Meerut)

.

Title: Rajasthan: Roadways to get prototype of electric bus by March-end
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Luxury Volvo buses, which are plying between Jaipur and Delhi, running into heavy losses

JAIPUR: The Rajasthan State Roadways Transport Corporation (RSRTC) is going to procure 48 electric buses and is expecting to get the prototype of the bus by the end of March. After suggesting modifications and requirements, the final fleet of buses is expected by July 2020.

Out of the 48 buses to be bought by the corporation, 22 would ply on the Jaipur-Delhi route so that these buses will operate between Sindhi Camp (Jaipur) to Bikaner House (New Delhi). According to the sources from the RSRTC, the ongoing route of the super luxury buses run on diesel is becoming lesser popular as passengers between Jaipur to Delhi don’t want Kashmiri gate to be their halt in Delhi.

“We are likely to get the prototype of the buses by March. After completing the tender process a letter of intent has also been given to the company which had fulfilled the requirement of the tenders. We will further suggest modifications and requirement after seeing the sample. Thereafter, we will get 48 buses out of which 22 of these buses would be operated on the Jaipur-Delhi route. This will enable us to operate between Jaipur(Sindhi Camp) to New Delhi(Bikaner House) after getting the required permissions,” said UD Khan, managing director, RSRTC told TOI on Saturday.

Khan added that these buses would be environment friendly and passengers would be having a comfortable journey while travelling in these buses. “We are also planning to have CCTV camera in these buses and would be connected to the main server at the Sindhi camp bus stand for the safety and security of the passengers,” Khan added.

According to the officials the electric bus will be equipped with two batteries. Each fully-charged battery will be enough to run the buses for 200 km. On the routes, battery charging facilities would be available in the depots so that during halt time these batteries are fully charged.

Electric buses are currently plying in Delhi, UP and Himachal Pradesh. Rajasthan will be the fourth state to use electric buses for public transport.

Title: Loudspeakers at mosques, temples to promote UP govt scheme
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

MEERUT: Apart from religious chants, loudspeakers at mosques and temples in western Uttar Pradesh will now make announcements to popularise state government’s latest scheme — UP Kisan Asan Kisht Yojana, according to Pashchimanchal Vidyut Vitaran Nigam Limited (PVVNL) officials.

Notably, loudspeakers have always been a bone of contention in Uttar Pradesh, even resulting in communal clashes in the past.

PVVNL managing director Arvind Mallapa Bangari said that the move is aimed at facilitating maximum registrations for the state government’s UP Kisan Asan Kisht Yojana in all 14 districts under its jurisdiction. The scheme helps tube well owners to pay their bills in easy instalments without interest. He added that similar initiatives are in place across the state.

A senior power corporation official said, “It’s good that loudspeakers that have caused undue tensions in the past will be put to some good use now.”

The PVVNL MD said, “During my visit to a camp for promotion of the scheme in a Meerut village, I found that the advertisement of the scheme was not too penetrative to ensure maximum registration. Hence, I have directed the officials concerned to utilize each and every possible means to maximize the reach of the scheme, be it beating of drums, pasting posters or even making announcements on loudspeakers at religious places like mosques and temples. The message should reach even the last person.”

The 14 districts of west UP that fall under PVVNL jurisdiction are Meerut, Baghpat, Ghaziabad, Bulandshahr, Hapur, Gautam Buddh Nagar, Saharanpur , Muzaffarnagar, Shamli, Moradabad, Sambhal, Amroha, Rampur and Bijnor.

Title: Protests helping Muslim women assert their voice in Jaipur
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

File pic of the three sisters at an anti-CAA protest in city

JAIPUR: Twenty one-year-old Saba Naaz, a hijab-clad medical student at a private university, doubles up as an anchor-cum-coordinator at the ongoing protest at Albert Hall in Jaipur.

She is the eldest among the three sisters who come from the orthodox Ahmed family. Saba’s two schoolgoing sisters — Hiba, 17, and Huda, 16, along with their parents Tariq Ahmed and mother Gulshan Tariq have been attending the protest at the hall since January 2 (Day 1). Facing objections from the family and friends for taking girls at the protest site has not deterred Tariq, who believes that his daughters are fighting for a cause.

The family has changed its routine just to adjust to the protest timings. Soon after the trio comes from their institutes and Tariq, a stamp vendor at the local court, they head for the protest site. Initially, the family was among the several protesters, but soon the trio became noticeable faces. Tariq’s eldest child is a son who works to support his family.

“My father has invested everything including his savings on our education. I am proud to have born in a family which has gone all out for our studies. We are the only sisters in our extended family who got the privilege to study in an English medium school,” Saba said. Her two sisters Huda and Hiba are class 11 and 12 students, respectively.

Hiba and Huda hold the banner from the opposite ends and make sure the protest ended on time, while Saba delivers a speech every day which includes updates from the country. “Time management is important as elders have asked us to finish at 7pm every day. We also ensure that speakers don’t use unparliamentary language and keep the speeches restricted to the subject,” Hiba said.

Explaining the reason behind attending the protest, Tariq said, “Education for girls has been a taboo in our society. I wanted to show that girls are no lesser than boys. I have been facing objection from family and friends for taking my girls to the protest site, but I told them that they will not only make me proud, but they will lead by an example.”

Title: Intrepid ambulance driver saves cardiac patient’s life
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Brave effort: Ambulance driver Hameed after being felicitated

MANGALURU: An ambulance driver successfully brought a 40-year-old patient , who suffered a massive heart attack , from Ujire in Belthangady taluk to Kasturba Medical College (KMC), Mangaluru, in 40 minutes.

The patient from Chikkaballapura, who was on his way to Dharmasthala, fell ill when his vehicle reached Sakleshpur on Saturday. The doctor of a private hospital in Ujire near Dharmasthala suggested that the patient’s relatives shift him to KMC Hospital in Mangaluru immediately. Ambulance driver Hameed took just 40 minutes to cover nearly 65km, thereby saving the patient’s life.

Interventional cardiologist Dr Padmanabha Kamath, HoD, cardiology department, KMC, treated the patient and managed to open the artery and restore flow.

Dr Kamath told TOI, “When a 40-year-old tourist from Chikballapur suffered a massive heart attack somewhere near Sakleshpur, little did he know that life will take a different turn. When he reached Dharmasthala, his destination, the chest pain had peaked, and he visited the nearest hospital for treatment. He was having a massive heart attack, and he was advised to go to Mangaluru for further treatment.”

The patient had very low BP and his condition was extremely grave, he said. “After some medication was administered, the patient was taken in the ambulance, fully knowing that the odds are against him. The roads were dug up, and there was a double lane project under way. Hameed drove at a rapid pace under very treacherous conditions to reach Mangaluru within 40 minutes. The real drama unfolded then. When the patient was being shifted to the emergency ward, his heart stopped due to a fatal condition. Since the patient was within the emergency room, shock treatment was administered, which restored his heart beat. Later on, we intervened and managed to open the artery and restore flow,” he added.

Dr Kamath and relatives of the patient felicitated driver Hameed after the surgery.

Title: Police trying to cover up murder, will stage protest: Farmer’s kin
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Meerut: Family members of the sugarcane farmer who was murdered allegedly by bouncers at Daurala toll plaza on Tuesday have now threatened to launch a protest claiming that the local police are hand in glove with the accused.

The victim Sohanveer Chauhan’s brother Ravindra Chauhan said, “We don't want any compensation. All we want is justice. We will stage a protest at the commissioner’s office on Monday and if our grievances are not heard, we will begin an indefinite protest.”

Narrating the sequence of events, he said, “We were returning from the field with cane produce when the incident happened. There was a long queue in the cash lane and we decided to take the FASTag lane. This did not go down well with the plaza employees who initially confronted us. The argument soon turned into a brawl and bouncers at the toll plaza began thrashing my brother with rods, lathis and other weapons.”

The postmortem report of the victim has also corroborated claims of torture before death. According to the report, the victim sustained 10 injuries on his body with fractures and ruptures in the internal organs at five places. It read, “The cause of death is shock and haemorrhage as a result of ante-mortem injuries following blunt force trauma.”

The victim’s family members claimed that the toll plaza staff tried to portray the incident as an accident and not murder. Chauhan said, “The toll plaza staff have been giving different statements every time and are trying to destroy evidence. When I returned to the spot, I saw the tractor abandoned near a 11KV power line. The staff told police that my brother was electrocuted. Later, they claimed that my brother lost control of the tractor due to which it turned turtle resulting in his death. They have been making this up despite the fact that I was present at the spot with my brother.”

Meerut SP (city) Akhilesh Narayan Singh said that a 6-minute footage in the CCTV DVR has been erased which is most likely to be an attempt to cover up tracks. “An FIR has been registered and two contractual employees arrested. Based on the findings of the postmortem report, evidence and statement of witnesses, we are carrying out further investigation,” he added.

Title: Over 500 people attend Times group’s Heritage Walk
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nashik: Over 500 people from Nashik took part in the heritage walk at Nandur Madhmeshwar bird sanctuary on Saturday which was jointly organised by the Times group and the forest department.

The local forest officials informed the people about the various aspects of the sanctuary as forest officer Ashok Kale explained to them about how the birds migrate in different seasons.

“It is really beautiful here round the year. There are 265 species of birds at the sanctuary and 148 species that keep migrating to the sanctuary in various seasons from all over the world,” said Kale.

The visitors had gathered at a fixed spot near the sanctuary at 8.30 am. The forest department had provided eight guides to take the group to eight towers made at the sanctuary.

“All of us were divided into eight small groups and each group had a designated guide. We went to all the towers to watch the different types of birds with the help of binoculars provided to us by the forest department. The most unique bird was the spoon bird as its beak is spoon shaped,” said the organisers.

The group was able to see over 40 birds between 9am to 12 noon as the birds have their timings to come out of their nests. “We were strictly told not to wear dark and printed clothes during the visit as it keeps the birds away,” the organisers said.

The sanctuary also has over 30 species of fishes. The visitors could also see snakes, wild cat and deer.The visitors age ranged from 3 years old to 85 years old.

Deepak Chougule, one of the visitors, said, “It was a wonderful morning spent with nature. I would love to go for such excursions.”

The sanctuary is the first Ramsar site (a wetland site designated to be of international importance under Ramsar Convention) in Maharashtra.

Title: Reports of all suspected patients are negative
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Indore: Much awaited reports of three suspected coronavirus patients including a two-year-old came negative on Saturday.

MY Hospital superintendent PS Thakur said, “We have received reports of three suspects including a two-year-old. The reports of all of them are negative. These people don’t have infection of coronavirus,”

The two suspects including the child were admitted to isolation ward in MY Hospital on February 5 and samples were sent to NIV lab. Earlier, reports of two other patients including one girl were found to be negative.

A 19-year-old student and a two-year-old child, who had returned from China on February 1 and 2, had common cold symptoms. But suspecting that they might have contracted coronavirus, they were admitted to MY in isolation ward. The teenager was studying in Zhangzhou city while the child returned with his parents from Shanghai. The third suspect was found on February 1 and was put under home isolation as precautionary measure. The girl didn’t have any symptoms and her report was also found negative. The reports of first two patients found on January 31 in district including one girl were also found to be negative.

Title: Prithvi Raj Nagar residents may get Bisalpur dam water after 2 years
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Rs 563 crore has been sanctioned for the drinking water project

JAIPUR: Even after regularisation, the residents of Prithvi Raj Nagar (PRN) scheme will have to wait for at least two years to get drinking water supply from Bisalpur dam . The public health engineering department (PHED) has prepared a plan and completed paperwork to supply 90 million litre per day (MLD) under the scheme. According to sources, the project will take 30 months for completion. A senior official said, “The work order will be released to firm next month. The department will lay pipelines in 30 km which will cater to the needs of nearly 5 lakh residents,” he said. As per the proposal, Rs 563 crore has been sanctioned for the drinking water project. The department has issued tenders for Rs 378 crore work. Sources said, “The PHED has already given Rs 60 crore of its share, while it’s waiting for Rs 118 crore from the JDA,” he added. The project might face problem if the JDA takes more time to transfer its share of funds. After series of meetings, there was an agreement that the JDA would pay the amount. But funds have not been released till date. Earlier, the JDA had provided Rs 60 crore to develop the infrastructure. However, the amount is not sufficient. The official said, “During a meeting at finance department, the JDA was directed to pay Rs 118 crore. We have written to the JDA to release the balance amount,” he added. As per the proposal, the PHED will lay 1,150 km distribution line to supply water in 30 square kilometre area. In June, chief minister Ashok Gehlot had approved the proposal of finance department for this scheme, under which an amount of Rs 445.25 crore will be payable by the state government. According to proposal, the scheme will be completed in two phases up to 2022-23. “The estimated cost of its first phase is Rs 854.22 crore. According to Part-A of the first phase, infrastructure development in 175 square kilometre of Prithvi Raj Nagar and water distribution network in 30 square km will be done. Its estimated expenditure is Rs 563.93 crore,” said the official.

Title: Polls in 55 cantonments, including Deolali, deferred
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nashik: The Ministry of Defence (MoD) has deferred elections in 55 cantonment boards across the country.

Officials said the ministry will now release a fresh date for the elections.

Of these 55 cantonment boards, seven are in Maharashtra — Deolali (Nashik), Aurangabad, Ahmednagar, Pune, Khadki, Dehu Road and Kamptee (Nagpur).

Deputy director of MoD Rajesh Kumar Shah, in a written communiqué on February 5, informed the General Officer Commanding-in-Chief (GOC-in-C) about the ministry’s decision. The letter cited “administrative” reasons.

“The term of office of all elected members of these cantonment boards has been extended for six months, or till the date of the constitution of the Board, whichever is earlier,” read the MoD communiqué.

Elections in these 55 cantonment boards, which last took place in 2014, were slated for this month. In fact, Cantonment Board, Deolali (CBD) had already started preparations for elections in the eight seats. It had recently conducted a lottery to reserve three seats for women candidates as per instructions from the MoD in November.

Ajay Kumar, the CEO of CBD, told TOI that the board has decided not to proceed with the poll preparations given the latest instruction from the MoD.

“We will restart the poll preparation work after we receive the green signal to do so from the ministry,” Kumar said.

Elected members of the CBD said they are happy that the MoD had extended their tenure. CBD vice-president Bhagwan Katariya said the feedback he has received suggested six other cantonment boards are due for elections in June this year.

“It is possible that the MoD is planning to organise simultaneous polls in 61 cantonment boards simultaneously in June. That is perhaps why elections in 55 boards were deferred,” Kataria said.

Prabhavati Dhiware, another elected member of the CBD, said an extension to her tenure meant she will now get some more time to finish pending projects.

“We have been waiting for funds to build a community hall in Ward No. 1. We also need a dialysis machine at the cantonment hospital. We will try to ensure that funds for the projects reach us before the election,” Dhiware said.

Another elected member of CBD, Baburao Mojad said even new projects can be planned by existing members due to extensions of their tenures.

Title: Reduce climate change, Sahgal implores
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Vadodara: ‘There is a need to reduce climate change and conserve biodiversity’, noted environmentalist Bitto Sahgal, while speaking at a seminar organised by city-based Society for Clean Environment (SOCLEEN). Sahgal rued that change in environment has led to not only crop loss, but loss of human lives too with 40 farmers committing suicide in Maharashtra.

He said there are more than 300 small and big dams that have changed the balance of the ecosystem.

Fish, frogs and crocodiles are water quality engineers.

“We are interfering with the management of nature,” Sahgal stressed, while imploring the government to help change the scenario of water availability in the country.

Title: 18 Disha police stations set up in Andhra Pradesh
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy inaugurates Disha Police station in Rajahmundry on Saturday.

VIJAYAWADA/RAJAHMUNDRY: AP government on Saturday launched 18 special Disha police stations across the state for speedy investigation and trial of cases related to sexual offences against women. The state government recently amended rules to ensure that trial in rape cases are completed within 21 days and these police stations will help in fast completion of investigation.

The government also launched the Disha mobile application on Saturday. Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy inaugurated the first Disha police station at Rajahmundry and launched the mobile app. Later, Disha police stations were opened at other towns in the state.

One Disha police station has been set up at every police district headquarters in the state. The police stations will be headed by a deputy superintendent of police (DSP) rank officer with two circle inspectors and three sub-inspector rank officers to handle investigation. There will be between 36 and 47 support staff to assist the investigators.

“Setting up of Disha police stations is a historic decision and first of its kind in the country. Incidents like Nirbhaya and Disha have moved the collective conscience of society. However, little was done to prevent such incidents in the first place. Disha Act and creation of infrastructure for its implementation will ensure not only justice to the victims but will also save women from ending up as victims,” Jagan said in Rajahmundry.

The CM added that Disha Act is in the concurrent list. “The state government has sent it for central government’s assent. The Act is being vetted by the Union ministry and will be notified in the state gazette soon. Once notified, the new legislation will come into force,” he said. Without waiting for the Act to come into force, the state government has sanctioned Rs 100 crore to create an ecosystem to implement the Act, he said.

Jagan added that apart from establishing special police stations, special courts will also be set up once the high court gives the green light. “These special courts will deal with cases booked under Disha Act exclusively and deliver justice in two weeks,” he said.

The chief minister, after launching the Disha app, tested it by pressing the SOS button. The process of initiating the call from the mobile device to receiving it at the Disha control room and deploying the teams to the location were demonstrated live. The Disha enforcement team reached the spot by tracing the coordinates of the call origin and reported to the chief minister. The CM appreciated the officers involved in designing of Disha app.

While city police commissioner Ch Dwaraka Tirumala Rao inaugurated the Disha police station in Vijayawada, Krishna district SP Ravindranath Babu launched the station at Machilipatnam. All district SPs and commissioners of police participated in the video conference held by the chief minister.

Title: Barber’s body found in farm field
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Rudrapur: A 32-year-old man’s body was found in a farm field on Saturday at Kashipur in Udham Singh Nagar district. The deceased’s neck was reportedly slit with a sharp-edged weapon and body dumped in the field.

Police officials said that they are yet to ascertain the reason behind the man’s death. According to police, he owned a shop at Thana Sabik Road. The barber ’s kin told the police that Salmani had left his house on a bike on Friday evening and did not return at night.

Title: 70% staff opt to work in Jaipur Greater
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Jaipur Municipal Corporation office

JAIPUR: The local self-government has initiated the process of appointing employees following the division of Jaipur Municipal Corporation into parts, Jaipur Heritage and Jaipur Greater .

It seems the employees have developed an affinity towards Jaipur Greater. Around 70% employees have opted to work in Jaipur Greater. Most of the employees are showing interest in working within the existing corporate headquarters.

The reasons appear to be the fact that most of the areas in the Jaipur Heritage office are of boundary wall and slum area which is disputed. Apart from this, problems like dirt, sewer and traffic congestion are constant issues in the said area. Compared to this, in Jaipur Greater, there is neither such disputed area nor there are more complaints related to cleanliness.

According to sources, the municipal commissioner has sent the format to all the section and zonal offices of the corporation. In this, employees and officers have been asked their choices regarding they municipal office they want to work in. The office of Jaipur Heritage is being built in the old PHQ office in the boundary wall, while the office of Jaipur Greater will remain in the existing corporation headquarters on Tonk Road.

There will be a total of four zone offices in the Jaipur Heritage area including Hawa Mahal , Civil Lines, Kishanpole and Adarsh Nagar Zone. The number of wards in this will be 100. At the same time, there will be seven zones like Vidyadhar Nagar, Murlipura, Jhotwara, Sanganer, Mansarovar, Malviya Nagar and Bagru offices in the Jaipur Greater. It will have 150 wards.

Title: Vadodara: BJP councillor’s SUV stolen from outside his house
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Alpesh Limbachiya at Makarpura police station

VADODARA: Continuing the recent spate of break-ins in and around the city, thieves this time struck rich from the houses of BJP councillor of Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) as well as that of a joint charity commissioner of Surat.

Thieves stole BJP councillor from ward 17, Alpesh Limbachiya’s SUV from outside his house in Motinagar in Tarsali early on Saturday morning. According to Limbachiya, two persons came in a car near his house at around 4.15 am.

After parking their car at a distance, the duo broke open the SUV door’s lock and opened the car’s bonnet. Within a couple of minutes, they started the car and quickly escaped with Limbachiya’s car along with the hatchback they had come in.

Limbachiya realized about the theft of his SUV only at around 8.30 am when he came out of the house to leave for work.

He searched for the car in the neighbourhood but not being able to locate it anywhere, he checked the footage of CCTV camera installed outside his house. The footage revealed the theft of the SUV.

The councillor, who is also the ruling party’s chief whip in the civic body, said that Rs 80,000 which he had kept in the car’s glove box was also stolen. The cash, he said was to be paid to industrial labourers.

In the incident, Burglars entered joint charity commissioner Rajendra Vyas’s house at Officers’ Colony in Alkapuri in the wee hours of Friday. Vyas and his wife Ketaki were in Surat when the burglars broke into their house. The burglary was detected only when the errands man came to their house in the morning. After reaching the city, the duo found that thieves had stolen gold jewellery worth Rs 51,000 along with Rs 23,500 worth of silver jewellery.

Title: Private players can aid health sector: Vishwajit Rane
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

PANAJI: To improve healthcare and ensure quality health services, even in rural areas, the private sector has to be roped in, said health minister Vishwajit Rane on Saturday.

Rane said that while the government could take care of the primary and secondary tier of healthcare, the private sector could be tasked with providing tertiary healthcare.

The minister was speaking at a conference on financing India’s healthcare needs organised by the Goa Institute of Management . “I believe that public-private partnership is very important. Primary and secondary health care can be taken care of by the government and the tertiary care, here is where the private sector can come in,” Rane said. He said finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman’s Budget proposal to set up medical colleges in existing district hospitals under the public private partnership (PPP) mode would be a game-changer.

“In Goa, if you give us the money or if we put in 40%, and the colleges the rest…We have been asked if we were interested in such a project. Having one more government college in Goa may not be viable but taking the private sector onboard can work,” he said.

Title: Doon station resumes operation after three months
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Dehradun: The Dehradun railway station, which was closed for three months due to renovation work, reopened on Saturday. However, some construction work was still ongoing in the station as a result of which all seven trains that entered the station on Saturday were delayed. Platform 5 had construction materials scattered all over at the start of the day, but railway officials cleared them eventually. Doon station director Ganesh Chand Thakur told TOI, “Train movement started at the station after a long time today. Therefore, there was some inconvenience. A little bit of construction work is still left and going on in the station premises, but will be completed very soon.”

Meanwhile, in the renovated station, lengths of all five platforms have been increased by 630 metres in order to accommodate trains with 18 to 20 coaches. All old tracks have also been replaced. A third platform (platform number three) has been built. However, the new platform has only one staircase and no lift or escalator, which passengers said on Saturday, was creating major inconvenience especially for the elderly.

Most passengers though were relieved that the station has opened. Jugal Desai, a resident of Mumbai who works in Haldwani, said that the three months that the station was closed were difficult for him. He boarded the Doon-Naini Jan Shatabdi to reach Doon station on Saturday. “I used to travel by bus from Doon to Haldwani during the three months that the station was closed. It was very difficult,” Desai said.

Mukesh Kumar Yadav, a porter at the station said, “It was a tough time for us when the station was closed. We went to Uttar Pradesh for alternate sources of income. Around 45 porters work at Doon station, all of whom were affected.”

Anil Jain, the owner of a book kiosk at the station, too, expressed similar sentiments. “There was nothing to do for the last three months. It was difficult to run my household. Railway authorities should have thought of vendors like us before they decided to close the station for such a long time.”

The trains that reached Doon station on Saturday were Doon-Naini Janshatabdi, Doon-Delhi Shatabdi, Doon-Amritshar Lahori Express, Doon-Howrah Express, Mussoorie Express, Gorakhpur Express and Nandadevi Express. However, no 18-coach train entered the station on Saturday.

Title: 333 Gunner recruits take part in passing out parade
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nashik: A total of 333 Gunner recruits were part of a glittering passing out and attestation parade at the Artillery Centre in the city on Saturday.

The chief instructor and faculty of the Gunnery at the School of Artillery, Major General P Ramesh, was the chief guest at the event, which was also attended by the parents of young recruits.

Major Ramesh, in his address, lauded the high standards exhibited by the recruits. He called on them to uphold the rich tradition of the Indian Army. He also presented trophies to recruits who excelled during training.

Gunner (Lt) Pratheek K S was adjudged the overall best recruit.

Army authorities also presented the parents of recruits with the ‘Gaurav Padak’ — a gesture of appreciation for committing their wards to the service of the country.

The Artillery Centre is the Indian Army’s biggest recruit training centre in the country. An average of 5,000-6,000 recruits join the Gunners after undergoing a rigorous 42-week training at the facility.

Candidates who join are given a basic military training for 19 weeks, which includes fitness improvements and weapons instructions. Later, they move on to more specialised training in which they are taught the nuances of military operations.

Title: Rs 1cr project to build check dams, sow plants to curb pollution in Chhoiya
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Bijnor: To prevent further pollution of river Chhoiya and clean it up, the forest department here has proposed a Rs 1 crore project to construct check dams on the river and sow plants along its banks that absorb pollutants like heavy metals. A seasonal river, Chhoiya is a tributary of the Ganga. Over the years it has been heavily polluted as industries along its banks discharge effluents into it. It is feared that the polluted water will also harm the Ganga and wildlife at Hastinapur Wildlife Sanctuary, through which the river flows.

The Chhoiya is so polluted that the groundwater in the area is also contaminated and unfit for drinking.

The river flows past some 50 villages, including Sundarpur, Ravanpur, Navada, Gadana, Hadarpur, Sihora, Salmabad, Bhairera, Agri, Jalalpur, Sikandari and Shahpur Lal, Residents said they have repeatedly complained against the polluting industries. Earlier, Pollution Control Board had cracked the whip on the industries over this issue. Now, forest officials claimed that the condition had worsened.

According to a survey carried out by Jal Nigam authorities in 2018, water samples collected from 17 villages, some 20-25 km away from the Chhoiya, were found to have 0.05 mg/l arsenic against 0.01 mg/l permissible level.

Forest department officials said the polluted water not only affects human beings but also wildlife. It poses a threat to Hastinapur sanctuary, a hub of black buck, swamp deer, otters and several domestic and migratory birds. The Chhoiya passes through both Bijnor and Chandpur ranges, which are a part of Hastinapur sanctuary, before merging with the Ganga.

Now forest department has come up with a plan to make this tributary free of pollution. Giving details about the plan, Bijnor divisional forest officer M Semmaran said, “We have chalked out a project with the help of a private engineer. Our team conducted a survey of the Chhoiya. The project is part of the Namami Gange campaign. Around seven check dams estimated to cost Rs 1 crore will be constructed across the river and banana and other plants that absorb heavy metals will be sown along it. In these check dams, water will be stored so that the heavy metal and effluents settle at the bottom. Certain types of bacteria will be introduced in the polluted water for absorbing the effluents. The filtered water will then be released through pipes into the Ganga. This project was earlier implemented in Agra as well.”

According to villagers of Navada village, said, “Some industries are releasing untreated water into the Chhoiya and this seeps into the ground, polluting the groundwater. The river stinks so much that its foul smell pervades even at a distance of 4km from it. Water drawn from pumps is murky with chemical pollutants. Earlier, several villagers who consumed this water developed stomach and skin ailments and some succumbed to cancer. The situation is so bad that many villagers have shifted away from the polluted Chhoiya.”

Title: 1 dead, 3 hurt as triple-storey building collapses in Mohali
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

The triple-storey building with a basement collapsed at Sante Majra village on Kharar-Landran road in Mohali o... Read More

MOHALI: A triple-storey building with a basement collapsed in Mohali on Saturday, leaving one person dead and three others injured.

Around 12.30 pm, a JCB machine was digging the basement adjoining the building owned by Parveen Kumar Ambika of Ambika Constructions for a hotel/restaurant.

According to eyewitnesses, when the machine had dug up around 10-feet of earth, the building suddenly came crashing down, burying four people. While two people were rescued within minutes, one of them was pulled out of the debris after eight hours. Passers-by rushed to the rescue of the people trapped and managed to pull out two, identified as Harjeet Singh, and Prem Bahadur, who is under treatment at civil hospital, Kharar. The victim was identified as Harvinder Singh, alias Babbu, a JCB driver.

Deputy commissioner Girish Dayalan said, “We got information around 12.35 pm about the building collapse. The district administration led by sub-divisional magistrate and additional deputy commissioner reached the site. Emergency services, including fire tenders and medical teams, were pressed into action. A team of NDRF with specialised equipment was contacted and called from Panchkula. A team of 25 people started the rescue operation. A back-up team from Ludhiana was also called.” The DC said that the Western Command of the Army was also contacted for help.

He said machines for clearing the debris required by the NDRF were locally arranged. A total of seven to eight JCB machines and four to five cranes were pressed into rescue operation.

Title: Separate wards set up for coronavirus in Meerut city
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Meerut: Days after three samples of suspected cases of novel coronavirus – which were sent to Lucknow for testing – tested negative, special wards have been set up in the district hospital and Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial (LLRM) Medical College.

So far, 56 people who returned from China last month have been identified in Meerut and are being closely monitored for any symptoms.

“In the backdrop of the instructions that we’ve got from the state authorities, a 10-bed ward dedicated to the suspected case of Coronavirus has been set up. We have also maintained personal kits for each patient—if required in any case,” said Dr PK Bansal, superintendent in chief, PL Sharma district hospital.

An equal number of beds have also been set up in the LLRM Medical College as well. “We have set up a 10-bed ward at Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial Medical College to isolate suspected cases of Coronavirus,” said Dr RC Gupta, principal LLRM Medical College.

Requesting people to calm down, Bansal said, “One should not panic in the backdrop of Corona virus. Rather, one should focus on keeping clean surroundings and washing their hands from time to time to prevent any infection. While there is no cure of coronavirus till now, but isolating the patient and putting them on antibiotics to prevent secondary infections is a way that will be dealt with currently.”

Notably, death toll in China has sharply risen to 722, while the total number of confirmed cases has jumped to 34,546.

Title: Navi Mumbai: Jawaharlal Nehru Port Trust starts screening foreign crew for coronavirus
Content:
A thermal scanner is used in screening

NAVI MUMBAI/MUMBAI: Since the outbreak of the Novel Coronavirus (nCoV), the port health officer of the government of India had begun screening crew members of cargo ships from foreign countries at JNPT. The JNPT administration has provided a thermal scanner to the officer and the screening reports are sent to the Union government daily.The Central government has directed all states to follow a set protocol for scanning of the crew of cargo ships that dock at major and minor ports. The Centre has asked major ports such as JNPT to be in a quarantine mode. For quarantine, these ports must immediately set up an isolation ward in each of their in-house hospitals. Throat swabs will be collected by the district authority.Captain Amit Kapoor, deputy conservator at JNPT, said, “As per the directions of the Union shipping ministry, crew members onboard cargo ships entering JNPT are being screened. The screening for nCoV-infected persons is the mandate of the port health officer (PHO) from the government of India. The JNPT administration has provided the thermal scanner machine, which JNPT had procured during the outbreak of SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) Coronavirus (SARS CoV) in 2003 and had then provided it to the PHO for screening process. Since then, the PHO uses it whenever there is an outbreak of any deadly virus.”Kapoor further said, “We have already stopped entry for cargo ships and vessels from China. Though no Chinese national or Chinese crew come directly to JNPT, they may come via Malaysia, Singapore and Colombo. Hence, as a precautionary measure, the crew of all cargo ships and those onboard container vessels are being screened at the JNPT port.”Meanwhile, a cargo ship has been docked one hour away from the Redi port in Sindhurdurg following a scare that the crew members were Chinese. District authorities said the vessel had sought medical clearance for all its crew members when it left Mumbai port two days ago. The 22 shipmen were tested by state health as well as port officials and showed no symptoms of any infection. “They had left China over three months back, and they were not going to enter Redi village,” said state health director Dr Archana Patil.

Title: Rs 1,204 crore spent, but 153 projects still remain incomplete: CAG report
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: Pointing out that at least 153 infrastructure projects remain incomplete despite Rs 1,204 crore being spent on them, the Comptroller and Auditor General on India (CAG) said that delay in completion of projects can lead to losses to the state exchequer.

In its report for 2017-18, the CAG report said that as on March 31, 2018, there were 111 roads, bridges and buildings across the state that remain incomplete. The remaining incomplete projects are in the irrigation and water supply category.

“As the delay in completion of projects entails the risk of cost escalation and denial of intended benefits to beneficiaries, the state government may re-evaluate the cost of all incomplete projects and evolve a mechanism for timely completion of projects,” said the CAG report.

The report has taken into account only those projects valued at more than Rs 1 crore.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant , in his budget for 2020-21, has taken it upon himself to complete 50 ongoing projects in the coming financial year.

The CAG report found significant time and cost escalation in the Tillari irrigation project, which is a joint venture between the Goa and Maharashtra governments. Officials said that the project remains incomplete due to a delay in land acquisition. The directorate of accounts did not provide the CAG with any estimate of the cost escalation.

A bridge linking Benaulim to Sinquetim has been left incomplete since 2010, with the Keri-Tiracol bridge suffering a similar fate. The JICA water pipelines and sewerage network remain incomplete in Goa despite being launched several years ago, and with the National Games scheduled to be held this year, the Chicalim squash complex and tennis court at Fatorda are also nowhere close to completion.

The report also said that the financial results of the undertaken irrigation works have not been worked out by the state government. The Goa government incurred an expenditure of Rs 79.6 crore on maintenance of irrigation projects in the state during 2017-18, which was Rs 12.6 crore more than the maintenance expenditure incurred by it in 2016-17. In 2016-17, the expenditure on maintenance of irrigation works stood at Rs 66.9 crore.

Title: Mohali building collapse: Punjab CM orders probe, seeks report in week
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

The NDRF team and local residents carry out rescue operation on a war footing on the Kharar-Landran Road on Sa... Read More

MOHALI: Taking serious note of Saturday’s building collapse in Mohali , Punjab chief minister Captain Amarinder Singh has asked the additional district magistrate (ADM), Mohali, to conduct a thorough probe into the incident and submit a report within a week.

The chief minister also directed the district administration to take all possible steps to rescue those who might be still trapped in the debris, according to an official spokesperson.

According to information received from the deputy commissioner, Mohali, Girish Dayalan, two or three persons were believed to be still under the debris and rescue operations were going on a war footing.

The entire cost of the treatment of those injured in this incident would be borne by the state government as per the chief minister’s orders, said a spokesperson, adding that so far two persons had been rescued and were under treatment.

According to the deputy commissioner, preliminary information suggests that a JCB was at work on the construction site adjacent the building when the structure collapsed. Probe would also ascertain if the construction was illegal or not, said the spokesperson.

Deputy commissioner Girish Dayalan said, “A magisterial enquiry have been marked to SDM Kharar supported by three other officers. He will ascertain causes of building collapse and will mark responsibility after which we will go in for registration of FIR. It will be seen if any of this was illegal or necessary permissions obtained. If found not in order, the guilty will be brought to book.”

He said the report would be initiated once the rescue operations were over ensuring that no one was trapped and no fatalities.

Title: Rajasthan gets three more Shaheen Baghs
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

A large crowd outside a women-only sit-in protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and National Registe... Read More

JAIPUR: Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh protest continues to inspire round-the-clock anti-CAA protest in Rajasthan . In the last one week alone, Chittorgarh, Sawai Madhopur and Bundi have started living the Shaheen Bagh moment by taking the tally of 24/7 protests to six in the state. The other three districts are Sikar, Kota and Jaipur.

Inspired by the longest non-stop sit-in by women, retired police officer Faizullah Sheikh spread a banner featuring symbols of all major religions and a picture of BR Ambedkar at Quilla Road to start an indefinite sit-in against CAA from Friday. “The round-the-clock protest in Chittorgarh is to raise our voice against the injustice, to establish social leadership and to establish communal harmony. Here we have decided to reach out to non-Muslim brothers and tell them our concerns with the CAA aiming to seek their support like the way women in Delhi are doing,” Sheikh said. They have decided that women will join the protest during the day, while men will be stationed at the site at night. The historic Mirzaji Ka Bagh in Sawai Madhopur city has become an epicentre for round-the-clock dharna. From the past four days, the dharna has continued. Unlike Shaheen Bagh in Delhi, here women control the movement during the day, while men hold the charge in the night.

Nisar Ullah, chief quazi of Sawai Madhopur says the protest will continue till Shaheen Bagh protest is on. “This is in solidarity with the brave women of Delhi who have shown us the way to raise our voice. We had two choices either to join the protest at Shaheen Bagh or create our own Shaheen bagh and we chose the latter. I am happy the way we have been receiving support from the people of all faiths and communities,” said the quazi over phone. Barely 40 metres away from Lok Sabha speaker Om Birla’s residence in Kota, a group of women are holding round-the-clock sit-in. A graduate in human rights, Shifa Khalid, who started the sit-in with five other women for a couple of hours in the afternoon of January 14 outside Eidgah, had no idea of receiving immediate support and that it will turn into a non-stop protest. The protest site and Birla’s residence are divided by a road and a lane.

Birla has given them a written assurance of raising their demand with PM Narendra Modi. Most of these women come from low income areas like Kishorpura, Rampura, Makbara, Shreepura and Waqf Board.

Khalid, a mother of three sons, credits her husband for being able to lead the non-stop protest. “My husband is my biggest support who picks and drops me to the protest site and takes care of our children in my absence,” Khalid said. The core group which is managing the protest includes 10-15 women, mostly students. They have been receiving support from non-Muslim women, but they are either activists or academicians. So far, no commoner has extended support to them. They have kept the protest non-religious and don’t raise slogans which are religious in nature.

The round the clock sit-in requires logistics support like bedding, water, food, urinals which is being supplied by community members at these places. At none of the protesting sites, the protesters have complained of police using any coercive measures to disperse them.

Title: MahaRERA directs developers to file source complaints if unable to register project
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

PUNE: The Maharashtra Real Estate Regulatory Authority (MahaRERA) has directed developers with occupancy certificate to file a source complaint on denial of project registration with sub-registrar offices for want of Rera enrollment.

“Once a developer files a source complaint, the authority will look into it at the earliest. If the authority decides that the project doesn’t require MahaRERA registration, the developer can approach the sub-registrar office and get the project registered,” a MahaRERA officials said.

The move brings relief to developers in the state as they were not able to register their projects with the sub-registrar office for want of RERA registration, though they had occupancy certificate ready.

As per the rules, projects with occupancy certificates are not required to register with MahaRERA. However, a revenue department circular issued in September last year insisted on registration of all projects with RERA before registering them with sub-registrar offices in the state.

Members of the Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association of India (Credai) too had raised the issue, saying that the RERA rules specifically mention that projects with completion/occupation certificate before the registration of sale deed were exempted from RERA registration.

Revenue minister Balasaheb Thorat had told TOI last week that he had directed all the departments concerned to issue clarity on the subject.

MahaRERA hearings to commence in Nagpur

The MahaRERA, which presently conducts hearing in Mumbai and Pune, will extend the hearings to Nagpur too, MahaRERA officials said on Saturday. The move aimed at addressing the pending cases, they added.

Title: MahaRERA directs developers to file source complaints if unable to register project
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

PUNE: The Maharashtra Real Estate Regulatory Authority (MahaRERA) has directed developers with occupancy certificate to file a source complaint on denial of project registration with sub-registrar offices for want of Rera enrollment.

“Once a developer files a source complaint, the authority will look into it at the earliest. If the authority decides that the project doesn’t require MahaRERA registration, the developer can approach the sub-registrar office and get the project registered,” a MahaRERA officials said.

The move brings relief to developers in the state as they were not able to register their projects with the sub-registrar office for want of RERA registration, though they had occupancy certificate ready.

As per the rules, projects with occupancy certificates are not required to register with MahaRERA. However, a revenue department circular issued in September last year insisted on registration of all projects with RERA before registering them with sub-registrar offices in the state.

Members of the Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association of India (Credai) too had raised the issue, saying that the RERA rules specifically mention that projects with completion/occupation certificate before the registration of sale deed were exempted from RERA registration.

Revenue minister Balasaheb Thorat had told TOI last week that he had directed all the departments concerned to issue clarity on the subject.

MahaRERA hearings to commence in Nagpur

The MahaRERA, which presently conducts hearing in Mumbai and Pune, will extend the hearings to Nagpur too, MahaRERA officials said on Saturday. The move aimed at addressing the pending cases, they added.

Title: Navi Mumbai: Jawaharlal Nehru Port Trust starts screening foreign crew for coronavirus
Content:
A thermal scanner is used in screening

NAVI MUMBAI/MUMBAI: Since the outbreak of the Novel Coronavirus (nCoV), the port health officer of the government of India had begun screening crew members of cargo ships from foreign countries at JNPT. The JNPT administration has provided a thermal scanner to the officer and the screening reports are sent to the Union government daily.The Central government has directed all states to follow a set protocol for scanning of the crew of cargo ships that dock at major and minor ports. The Centre has asked major ports such as JNPT to be in a quarantine mode. For quarantine, these ports must immediately set up an isolation ward in each of their in-house hospitals. Throat swabs will be collected by the district authority.Captain Amit Kapoor, deputy conservator at JNPT, said, “As per the directions of the Union shipping ministry, crew members onboard cargo ships entering JNPT are being screened. The screening for nCoV-infected persons is the mandate of the port health officer (PHO) from the government of India. The JNPT administration has provided the thermal scanner machine, which JNPT had procured during the outbreak of SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) Coronavirus (SARS CoV) in 2003 and had then provided it to the PHO for screening process. Since then, the PHO uses it whenever there is an outbreak of any deadly virus.”Kapoor further said, “We have already stopped entry for cargo ships and vessels from China. Though no Chinese national or Chinese crew come directly to JNPT, they may come via Malaysia, Singapore and Colombo. Hence, as a precautionary measure, the crew of all cargo ships and those onboard container vessels are being screened at the JNPT port.”Meanwhile, a cargo ship has been docked one hour away from the Redi port in Sindhurdurg following a scare that the crew members were Chinese. District authorities said the vessel had sought medical clearance for all its crew members when it left Mumbai port two days ago. The 22 shipmen were tested by state health as well as port officials and showed no symptoms of any infection. “They had left China over three months back, and they were not going to enter Redi village,” said state health director Dr Archana Patil.

Title: Rajasthan: NEET board, medical education department spar over counselling
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: NEET UG medical and dental admission/counselling board chairman has informed the medical education department that it would not conduct counselling over allegations levelled against it of gross irregularities in 2019 admissions. The board is headed by principal and controller of Sawai Man Singh Medical college.

“Rajasthan is the only state in the country where the counselling for NEET is done by medical colleges. In other states, it is done by directorate of medical education (DME). We are disciplined professionals (health) and we are not legal experts.
