We do not want to conduct the counselling anymore as our clinical and teaching work hampers as a large number of doctors have to get involve in counselling. So it is better that DME should conduct the counselling now,” Dr Sudhir Bhandari, principal and controller, SMS medical college told TOI on Saturday, who wrote to the government for quitting the post of chairperson of NEET counselling board.

The board has 38 members who are representatives of 38 medical colleges of the state. Besides, the board has representatives from the government. The government nominates two legal advisors.

The head of the board, which has been conducting it for years, has written to the medical education department that it does not want to conduct it anymore.

There were alleged irregularities in NEET PG counselling last year and the matter landed up in Rajasthan High Court. Following the high court directions, counselling was held again. Therefore, the SMS Medical College is reluctant to conduct counselling this year, while the medical education department is insisting that the college should do it.

The board has also expressed its resentment for being blamed for gross irregularities in 2019 in NEET counselling. “We are not legal experts. The government had appointed two legal experts in the NEET counselling board. Despite of that, we are blamed for gross irregularities in NEET counselling. There were legal issues for which we were made responsible. We cannot handle legal issues, if anything goes wrong. For the purpose, the government nominated two legal advisors. The board did as per legal advisors,” said Dr Bhandari.

However, the board has also alleged that there are differences in opinions between the board and the DME in NEET counselling. The board alleged that the DME always turned down board’s suggestion and blamed the board for gross irregularities.

Despite repeated attempts, medical education principal secretary Vaibhav Galriya did not respond the calls. However, the medical education department is insisting the board to continue conducting NEET counselling in a letter written to the medical education department.

Title: MahaRERA directs developers to file source complaints if unable to register project
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

PUNE: The Maharashtra Real Estate Regulatory Authority (MahaRERA) has directed developers with occupancy certificate to file a source complaint on denial of project registration with sub-registrar offices for want of Rera enrollment.

“Once a developer files a source complaint, the authority will look into it at the earliest. If the authority decides that the project doesn’t require MahaRERA registration, the developer can approach the sub-registrar office and get the project registered,” a MahaRERA officials said.

The move brings relief to developers in the state as they were not able to register their projects with the sub-registrar office for want of RERA registration, though they had occupancy certificate ready.

As per the rules, projects with occupancy certificates are not required to register with MahaRERA. However, a revenue department circular issued in September last year insisted on registration of all projects with RERA before registering them with sub-registrar offices in the state.

Members of the Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association of India (Credai) too had raised the issue, saying that the RERA rules specifically mention that projects with completion/occupation certificate before the registration of sale deed were exempted from RERA registration.

Revenue minister Balasaheb Thorat had told TOI last week that he had directed all the departments concerned to issue clarity on the subject.

MahaRERA hearings to commence in Nagpur

The MahaRERA, which presently conducts hearing in Mumbai and Pune, will extend the hearings to Nagpur too, MahaRERA officials said on Saturday. The move aimed at addressing the pending cases, they added.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: 17-year-old girl found killed, cops, mother suspect brother
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: A 17-year-old girl was found murdered under suspicious circumstances at Lingamguntla village under Narasaraopet mandal in Guntur district on Saturday. Lakkana Tanusha was a student of intermediate second year. Initial police probe suggest death by strangulation. The mother of the two teenagers suspects the girl’s brother, Kumara Swamy, as he is known for violent behaviour.

Swamy, 19, was the only person home apart from the victim on the intervening night of Friday and Saturday when the incident took place. He told police three unidentified miscreants barged into their house between 11 pm and midnight and attacked him and his sister. He survived the attack but his sister died, he said in his statement to police.

But answers given by Swamy and circumstantial evidence point towards him. Narasaraopet rural inspector Y Achaiah said there was no scope for outsiders to enter the house as Swamy and his sister bolted doors from inside. Though Swamy claimed the miscreants entered from the back door by pushing it hard there was no evidence to suggest breaking of the latch.

Achaiah added they did not find any visible injuries on Swamy contrary to his claim miscreants attacked him and his sister. “Even on the victim’s body except for a small scar on the forehead and strangulation marks around the neck there are no visible injuries” he said.

Swamy’s and Tanusha’s parents separated about two years ago. The kids stayed with the father who runs a small printing press. Swamy, a school dropout, works with his father at the press.

All family went to Tiruvuru in Krishna district on Friday to attend their grandfather’s death ceremony. The father told police he sent the kids back to Narasaraopet as Tanusha had examinations on Saturday and Sunday. Interestingly, no exams were scheduled on Saturday and Sunday at her college.

Swamy and Tanusha reached home around 9 pm on Friday. He phoned his father at around 1 am to say Tanusha died in an attack by unknown miscreants. The father informed police after coming to Lingamguntla at around 5 am on Saturday.

Achaiah said all angles to identify killer/s and motive are being probed. The mother too suspects Swamy. “Swamy’s answers do not match circumstantial evidence. He is a suspect. We will come to a conclusion after completing our probe,” the police inspector said.

Title: Thieves giving hard time to patients’ attendants at SMS
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Jaipur: Thieves on Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital premises have become a major problem for the patients’ attendants, who have to sleep outside the main hospital building braving the bone-chilling cold.

They also target the vehicles parked at parking lot of the hospital for stealing belongings of patients’ attendants such as helmets. A speaker installed at the parking lot keeps alerting the vehicle owners about the safety of their belongings.

Inside the hospital, the guards are deployed and it is equipped with CCTV cameras. But, outside the hospital, attendants of the patients have to remain vigilant all night while sleeping on the floor. “We regularly get complaints of petty theft, such as thieves took away someone’s bags and other belongings. We have deployed guards but since a lot of patients and attendants come to hospital every day, it is difficult to get security for all of them. The attendants have to remain careful to avoid such theft,” said Dr DS Meena, medical superintendent, SMS Hospital. Apart from the ‘drug’ mafia and those involved in selling and purchasing blood, the petty thieves have become a menace in the hospital. Recently, the hospital administration called the cops, when it found two persons allegedly sold blood to patients.

However, police are yet to take it seriously. “We are aware about it and have deployed policemen in civil dress,” said SHO, Moti Doongri.

Title: No postive case of coronavirus, Panchkula administration prepared: Deputy commissioner
Content:
Representative image

PANCHKULA: In view of the coronavirus , deputy commissioner M K Ahuja held a meeting with the officers of the Civil Hospital, Sector 6, Command Hospital, district development and panchayat officer (DDPO), Aasha workers and NGOs working in the district.DC Ahuja said the district administration was all set to tackle coronavirus and there was nothing to worry about.A total of 11 persons came to Panchkula from China till now and checkup of all the persons have been conducted at the Civil Hospital, Sector 6, Panchkula. All the persons tested negative of coronavirus.While providing information, the DC said till now no positive case of coronavirus had been reported in the district and the administration and the health department was on high alert.The administration, while taking precautionary measure, has asked all the suspects to remain at home in isolation for 14 days.Necessary medical checkup of 11 persons will be done by the administration from time to time and their family members have been informed to take care of diet and other precautionary measures to be taken.CMO Jasjeet Kaur said, “The administration is prepared to check people coming from China at the airport. The hospital is also prepared and has made necessary arrangements and setup an isolation ward at the hospital.”The administration is also seeking help of residents living in Panchkula to inform them about any person coming from China to their area so that a complete checkup of the person can be done.The CMO also stated that the virus has spread over 27 countries at present and the department has setup special helpline numbers 91-11-23978046, 9779494643, 8054007102 and 01722573907. A rapid action team has also been setup in this regard.

Title: CII, industries department to give impetus to entrepreneurs
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

PANAJI: The department of industries and the Confederation of Indian Industry ( CII ) have decided to partner and form a consultative committee to assess and provide policy inputs which can drive entrepreneurship and innovation in the state. As part of the partnership, the industries department will provide support to entrepreneurs who come up with business ideas that address Goa’s challenges, officials said.

The consultative committee will study existing legislations, identify gaps and subsequently suggest changes which can help entrepreneurs get access to mentors, investors and infrastructure. This, said CII, will help in the development of an entrepreneurial ecosystem that is conducive to the specific needs of entrepreneurs in Goa.

“Industries department exchanged a memorandum of understanding with regional director of CII, Jane Karkada, to generate an entrepreneurial policy for the growth of an investment-friendly ecosystem in the state by guiding and mentoring budding entrepreneurs and start-ups,” said industries minister Vishwajit Rane .

As per the agreement, CII will identify problems that entrepreneurs face, while the industries department will rectify or resolve the challenges. The industries department will facilitate the formation of the committee and coordinate between relevant government departments while also providing administrative support, the MoU said.

Industry stakeholders who can assess and provide inputs on existing policies will be identified by CII so that they can be included in the consultative process, said CII officials.

CII has also signed an MoU with the department of skill development and entrepreneurship with an objective to promote and enhance skills development initiatives and enhance employment opportunities in the state.

Title: Poll code, series of transfers ground campaign to make roads safer in Pune
Content:
TimesView Some ground rules are necessary to ensure that elections and transfers do not stall projects and initiatives on important issues like road safety. The city needs some action on the ground to bring order and discipline in traffic. We are fortunate to have several individuals and organisations willing to spare time and help achieve some method. The least the officials can do is to ensure that matters move forward, irrespective of who is in the office, once an action plan is worked out. Only then can we make some impact and address problems before they become chronic.

PUNE: Two elections and transfers of the municipal commissioner, the head of the Pune traffic police and the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) have affected the Pune Road Safety Campaign launched by former mayor Mukta Tilak last February.“The progress of the campaign has been slow. Two elections and the model code of conduct were in place for several months in 2019. There has been a change in leadership and transfers of government officers. The mayor changed, the deputy commissioner of police for traffic was transferred, followed by transfers of the PMPML chairperson and managing director, the municipal commissioner and head of PMC ’s road department,” Harshad Abhyankar, director of Save Pune Traffic Movement , said.A review meeting was chaired by Tilak last May.“She proposed that the next meeting be held after the road safety committee was formed. We picked up a few initiatives and started work. One was establishing mid-block crossing prototype at one road in association with Parisar, an NGO. The next was training for PMPML drivers to ensure that they halt at the stop lines at traffic signals. They needed material, including a laptop, which was approved by former PMPML CMD Nayana Gunde, but the actual purchase is yet to be made,” he said.Abhyankar said they are working on pedestrian signals and have discussed the needful with the PMC electrical department.“However, no funds have been allocated in the draft budget. We have met the head of the department and he keen on getting it done. The enforcement of a helmet is a priority. We have met the police commissioner about a month and a half ago,” he added.Mayor Murlidhar Mohol said he has already been apprised of the campaign and will initiate the work soon. “I have got all the information about the Pune Road Safety Campaign. We will meet the municipal commissioner, officials and NGOs soon,” he added.According to Parisar’s programme director Ranjit Gadgil, the campaign has failed to pick up pace.“We are working on mid-block crossings and the tender has been allotted. We will be working with the contractor on developing the crossing on one road, first. We will also evaluate whether it has helped make crossing the road safer. However, the head of the road department has changed and we will have to apprise the new person of what needs to be done. The campaign must pick up pace,” he said.Samaiirah from Safe Road Foundation added that the committee must be formed.“We are going to propose shortlisting an area where road safety measures will be implemented. A similar plan can then be replicated in other areas of the city. We will meet the authorities next week,” she added.

Title: Docs save girl by removing Rs 1 coin lodged in windpipe
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nashik: A tribal girl from Surgana got a new lease of life on Saturday after doctors at the Nashik civil hospital performed an emergency surgery to remove a Re 1 coin she had swallowed by accident.

Her parents thanked the doctors profusely as it emerged that they were twice refused immediate care — A rural hospital in their taluka said it didn’t have expert doctors and another doctor at a private hospital, near their village, gave up.

Payal Ashok Varade, a nine-year-old resident of Avalpada in the Surgana taluka, was playing at her home on Friday when she accidentally swallowed the coin at around 5.30 pm.

The girl soon started to experience breathing difficulties. Senior doctors at the Nashik civil hospital said her parents first took her to the Surgana rural hospital. But there, the parents were asked to take the girl to a private hospital because the rural facility did not have an ear, nose and throat (ENT) specialist.

The parents then moved her to a private hospital at the taluka headquarters. But the private doctor there was unable to provide help.

Sanjay Gangurde, the ENT surgeon at the Nashik civil hospital said the girl’s parents were finally able to reach Nashik at around 12.30 am. Gangurde, who was on duty at the time, immediately ordered an X-ray, which found the coin lodged in Payal’s windpipe. Anaesthetists were then told to prepare her for surgery.

“The coin was stuck in the cricopharynx level. This is dangerous and people have lost their lives for such obstructions. But my team and I were able to remove the coin using laryngoscopy. The operation lasted 45 minutes,” Gangurde said.

Laryngoscopy is a medical procedure that gives doctors a close-up view of the larynx and throat. By Saturday morning, Payal, declared out of danger, was up and speaking to her parents.

Civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale, additional civil surgeon Nikhil Saindane and other senior doctors praised Gangurde and his team for their timely action.

Title: Primed for success: Badminton stars Satwiksairaj Rankireddy, Sikki Reddy & Lakshya Sen
Content: Face shields for an added protection when you step out of your home

Title: Mohali building collapse: We thought it was an earthquake, says residents
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Many residents panicked and rushed out of their houses and shops to save their lives thinking it to be an eart... Read More

MOHALI: The people residing in the nearby flats and colonies opposite the building which collapsed thought that there was an earthquake as the tremors were felt after the huge structure collapsed with a thud.

Many residents panicked and rushed out of their houses and shops to save their lives thinking it to be an earthquake. They said after they came out, they discovered that it was not an earthquake, but the vibrations were caused due to a triple storey building collapsing across the road.

When the massive structure collapsed to hit the ground, it produced shock waves which replicated as earthquake tremors sending shivers down the nerves of the residents.

Ranjit Singh, Kuldeep Singh, Birjesh Kumar, Meena, Saroj Gupta, Varinder Pal, Surinder Kumar said, “We thought that it is an earthquake. When we rushed out of our house, we learnt that a building opposite our housing society has collapsed.”

Meena, a housewife, said, “I was working in the kitchen when I felt tremors and thinking that it to be a massive earthquake, I rushed out of my house. Then I saw huge smoke of dust just across the road and learnt that the triple storey building collapsed and it was not an earthquake.”

Residents said on learning this they all rushed to the spot to find that the entire structure came crashing down and many people were trapped under the debris.

Ranjit Singh, Kuldeep Singh, Birjesh Kumar, Varinder Pal, Surinder Kumar said they immediately started the rescue operation as they could listen the cries of the people trapped under the debris. They rescued two injured and rushed them to a hospital. One of them suffered fractured legs whereas the other one was discharged after treatment at the Civil Hospital, Kharar.

Title: Carnival 2020: CCP plans to make parade plastic-free
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative Image

PANAJI: The Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP) has discouraged the use of single-use plastics at this year’s carnival float parade, instead recommending that eco-friendly, recyclable and sustainable materials be used in an effort to reduce waste.

“We will aim for the floats to be plastic-free. The use of single-use plastic will be curtailed in a serious way,” said CCP commissioner Sanjit Rodrigues .

To ensure that tourists and locals visiting the parade do not litter the place with plastic bottles, CCP plans to install water stations, wherein water will be served to attendees in disposable cups.

This year, the flagship Panaji event has shifted back from the more-recent Miramar to Dona Paula route to the traditional Patto to Adil Shah palace to Kala Academy route. Goa celebrates carnival from February 22 to 25 this year.

“The police will draw up arrangements, with traffic diversion plans. We have asked for permission from the North Goa collectorate. We have also asked for volunteers to manage the crowd,” Rodrigues said. Efforts are also being made to ensure that the festival floats feature qualitative tableaus ,this year, he said. Entry forms will cost Rs 1,000, while spot-entries will be levied a fee of Rs 5,000. Moreover, consolation prizes have been cancelled for categories which evoke poor response each year.

Apart from the float parade, CCP will also organise their popular music and food fest, ‘Samba Square’, at the Jardim Garcia de Orta. This year, CCP will host activities for children as well as senior citizens, besides the usual entertainment .

The commissioner also said that local artistes will be given exposure in the entertainment section, wherein musicians and local performers will get a platform to showcase their talent. As a safety precaution, emergency and fire services personnel will be posted at the venue.

Title: IRSDC to now execute installation of CCTVs at Chandigarh railway station
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

At present, the railway station has 35 CCTVs which have poor quality recording

CHANDIGARH: The decade-old project on installation of CCTV cameras will be executed by the Indian Railway Stations Development Corporation Limited ( IRSDC ) at Chandigarh railway station .

S K Lohia, managing director and chief executive officer of the IRSDC said that during the world class project, the IRSDC would install hi-tech CCTVs as per the requirement of the station.

He said CCTVs, bag scanner and metal detector would be installed by the IRSDC as per the railway norms. The RPF and GRP would continue their services for security arrangements at the station.

The proposal for installing new CCTVs at 25 spots, including entry and exit points, end of the platforms, circulating area and near booking counter, has been chalked out by the GRP which was submitted to the Ambala division for implementation. But after the station was handed over to the IRSDC, confusion prevailed that which agency would execute the project.

At present, the station has 35 CCTVs which have poor quality recording.

On the recommendation of the station improvement group (SIG), the security department has drafted the proposal for new CCTVs and baggage scanner. The proposal also includes metal detectors on the entry and exit points on both Chandigarh and Panchkula side of the station.

Another proposal which will be executed by the IRSDC will be face lifting of the railway protection force (RPF) office at the railway station. A plan has been mooted out by the department to the Indian Railway Stations Development Corporation Limited (IRSDC) about the requirement in the new building constructed under the world class station project at Chandigarh.

Sources said the RPF, Chandigarh, had been asked by the headquarters to prepare a detail plan about the infrastructure required by them at the Chandigarh station.

In a plan which was chalked out by the RPF, a demand was raised for a room for RPF in-charge, hall for staff of the RPF, separate lock up for male and female, investigation room, record room, weapon strong room and a store.

Title: After gloom, Gujarat is milking its cows again
Content:
Liquid milk still brings in nearly 92% of the revenue

Plan Of New Dairies

Worst fears gone

TRQ abolished, BCD now at 40%

For two consecutive years, the dairy co-operatives of Gujarat had witnessed an unprecedented glut of milk. It was for the first time in the history of Gujarat, the cradle of India’s White Revolution, that procurement price paid to farmers had plummeted by 10-15% in 2017-18 and 2018-19. This was happening in a state which prides itself for paying the highest procurement price to dairy farmers.But improvement in domestic skimmed milk powder (SMP) prices coupled with increase in demand for dairy products has once again put the dairy co-operatives on a growth trajectory."The final price which farmers in Gujarat got for milk fat last year was Rs 690 per kg. This year, this price is likely to be 10 to 15 % more," said a top official of the Gujarat Co-operative Milk Marketing Federation (GCMMF) – the apex body of all the milk co-operatives of Gujarat that markets dairy products under the brand Amul.The SMP price in India had crashed to Rs 150-160 per kg in 2018-19 which has currently recovered to Rs 325 per kg.This financial year, GCMMF, which has now turned into an 18-member milk co-operatives body, is expecting to touch the Rs 40,000 crore mark, a 20% growth compared to Rs 33,000 crore annual turnover mark, which it had clocked in the last financial year.‘Taste of India’ had got a billion-dollar tag in 2007 when the home-grown dairy giant had become the country’s largest food business by clocking Rs 4,300 crore turnover.GCMMF’s managing director R S Sodhi is predicting that within the next five years (by 2025), Amul will be a Rs 1 lakh crore enterprise."For this, we (GCMMF) and our member unions will be adding capacity to process 120 lakh litres per day (LLPD) of milk taking up our total milk processing capacity to 500 LLPD with nearly Rs 5,000 crore fresh investment," Sodhi told TOI.Last year, Prime Minister Narendra Modi had urged the home-grown dairy giant to emerge as one of the world’s top three milk processors by 2022.Milk cooperatives of Gujarat have already left footprints across the country – be it Manesar in Haryana or Kolkata in West Bengal. GCMMF and its member milk cooperatives currently run 84 dairy processing plants inside and outside Gujarat. And all of them are currently on expansion mode."Projects are being planned for setting up dairies at Pune, Kolkata, Punjab, eastern and western Uttar Pradesh, Ujjain, Madhya Pradesh by our member unions in addition to expansion projects for milk and milk products at the dairy plants within Gujarat," a top official of GCMMF said.Liquid milk still brings in nearly 92% of the revenue. "But growth is also coming from newer segments. We believe that the segments which are witnessing 2% growth will see 10% growth in the next five years," said Sodhi.In October last year, millions of farmers in Gujarat, had faced their worst fears. As government was in final stages of the proposed Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), women milk producers from Gujarat had sent 15 lakh postcards urging Prime Minister (PM) Narendra Modi’s intervention. RCEP, proposed free-trade agreement (FTA) between ten member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and its six FTA partners – China, India, Japan, South Korea, Australia and New Zealand, would have meant dumping of foreign surplus milk in India impacting domestic milk prices. Itwould have proven suicidal for India’s dairy sector, both Amul and the National Dairy Development Board (NDDB) – had said. In November, much to the relief of farmers, the PM announced India is pulling out from RCEP.A big relief for dairy cooperatives in Gujarat has come in the form of the Centre’s Budget announcement to abolish tariff rate quota (TRQ) and restoring basic customs duty (BCD) on imported dairy products from 30% to 40%. "Developed countries will no longer be able to dump their surplus milke and dairy products at cheap rates in India," said a field expert.

Title: RTI activists condemn ‘blackmailer & extortionist’ tag
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

PUNE: Right to Information ( RTI ) activists have condemned government officials for calling them “blackmailers and extortionists”, while saying the tag only meant to dissuade them from seeking information under the act.

The activists have also urged the new government in the state to review the act, which came into force 14 years ago.

Former chief information commissioner Shailesh Gandhi has written a letter to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray , urging him to upload RTI queries and their responses online to leave no scope for any allegation. “This demand has been long pending and was put forth before the previous government as well,’’ he told TOI.

In the letter, Gandhi has also sought appointment of six information commissioners to overcome RTI case pendency. “The Rajasthan government has been doing it, then why can’t Maharashtra follow suit,’’ he asked.

In a recent RTI-related case filed by Anjali Bhardwaj, the Chief Justice of India (CJI) is reported to have said on December 16 that they were are not against the right to information but there was a need for guidelines and it cannot be “an unbridled right”. It has also been stated that there should be locus for seeking information, and that the administration is almost coming to a standstill because nobody was willing to take decisions.

The activists, however, said there was almost no known instance of government getting paralysed in legitimate work due to RTI. “RTI is a fundamental right of citizens under Article 19 (1)(a) and it stands to reason that the restrictions or curbs on the right to free speech, publishing and information must be uniform, and any curbs on one will apply to the others. The law also requires that most decisions should be taken in three levels and should be done within 45 days and if it is violated, it mandates disciplinary action against public servants,” an activist said.

Another activist Vijay Kumbhar said if the government was uploading all the information online, citizens would not have to procure information under the RTI Act. “Besides, the discretion of giving out information lies with the officials as under Section 8 they can choose to give or deny information considering the repercussions. So, RTI can never be used to blackmail,’’ he said, adding that in a democratic set-up, what was the need to hide information.

Title: PCMC to construct parallel Pimpri-Pimple Saudagar bridge
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The civic body has finalized the design of a parallel bridge between Pimprigaon-Pimple Saudagar and is expected to commence construction by March 31, joint city engineer Shrikant Savane said.

Civic officials said the cost of the project was Rs12.56 crore.

The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) had constructed a two-lane bridge to link Pimprigaon with Pimple Saudagar around 30 years ago. Residents of Pimpri use this bridge to go to Rahatani, Pimple Gurav and Pimple Nilakh. The existing two-lane bridge has proved to be inadequate to handle the increasing vehicular traffic, resulting in snarls almost every day.

Pimpri resident Ramesh Shinde said, “The existing bridge needs to be repaired as it has developed potholes, causing hardship to commuters. PCMC must start construction of a parallel bridge at the earliest to ensure smooth flow of traffic.”

Pimple Saudagar resident Rakesh Kale said, “The new bridge should be constructed at the earliest for the convenience of commuters using the existing bridge to reach Pimpri Camp or Pimpri railway station and PCMC main building.”

When contacted, National Congress Party (NCP) corporator Vithal, alias Nana Kate , and NCP corporator Sheetal Kate from Pimple Saudagar said they had been pursuing the demand for a parallel bridge with PCMC for the past 10-15 years. “The existing bridge has only two lanes while approach roads on both the sides have four lanes. It leads to congestion and chaos at the merging point,” Kate said.

BJP corporator Sandeep Waghire from Pimpri said, “Once completed, the parallel bridge would become the first in the city to have a spectator’s gallery. Members of the Sindhi community, devotees of Sant Jhulelal, feed the fish in the river while standing on the bridge. They face hardships due to constant traffic on the bridge. A 6x14 metre gallery will be constructed on the bridge for the Sindhi community.”

A civic official said the civic body has finalized the construction of the bridge on the downstream side of the river. The height of the new bridge will be the same as that of the existing bridge.

Title: Power department project sees ray of hope, 4 firms come forward
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The UT electricity department ’s ambitious project under the Smart City Mission of conversion of existing overhead lines to the underground system and replacement of infrastructure in Sector 8, finally see ray of hope as four companies have come forward.

The UT in the past had floated tender on three occasions, but there were no bidders. But this time, four companies have participated in the tender and soon the administration will open financial bid of these companies, and accordingly will allot the work to successful bidder.

Already three years have passed, but the project failed to start in Chandigarh. The planning work on this project was started in January 2017 and the UT planned to carry out project after Chandigarh was selected as one of the fast-track cities under the Smart City Mission of the ministry of urban development, Government of India.

The UT administration had finalised project of conversion of existing overhead lines to the underground system and replacement of infrastructure in Sector 8. The Joint Electricity Regularity Commission (JERC) has already accorded approval for capital expenditure of Rs 17.89 crore for the project on pilot basis.

The department had picked Sector 8 as the existing infrastructure is about five decades old and frequently breaks down, especially during the peak summer season.

The project was a part of the UT electricity department’s 20-year roadmap for improving power infrastructure in the city.

As per the official record, there are five 33 KV sub-stations and thirteen 66 KV sub-stations located in different parts of the city. As per the laid down norms, a sub-station has a life span of 25 years. Around six 66 KV sub-stations have crossed their life span and the number of such sub-stations will continue to grow.

To address the problem, the department has prepared a detailed project report (DPR) for upgrading infrastructure which the department plans to execute in a phased manner in the next 20 years at a cost of Rs 2,773 crore.

As per the plan, a total of 12 new 66KV grid sub-stations will be established while all the existing 66KV sub-stations will be upgraded in the next 10 years. There is overhead transmission line of 2,037 km in the city, which will be converted into underground line.

The department has set a deadline of 10 years for completion of the work. There is also a plan to install new 1,825 distribution transformers.

Title: Veteran composer rues lack of good lyrics
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Usha Khanna.

PUNE: Usha Khanna was one of the few female music directors in the Hindi film industry for 30 years beginning in the late 1950s, composing for nearly 250 films across languages, and as per her account, she ‘wasted’ years convincing people she was indeed a composer.

“No one would believe that I had composed music for films. People I met thought that someone else had done the work. I wasted four years of my life over this,” she said, during an interaction with the press in the city.

Khanna is in the city to attend a live show in her honour on Sunday. She was scheduled to be in Pune last month to receive the SD Burman Award from the Pune International Film Festival (PIFF), but could not make it at the last minute. Among other recent honours, the state government accorded her the Lata Mangeshkar Award last year, recognizing her pioneering work as a female music director, who produced dozens of hit songs in an industry dominated by men.

Khanna has not composed music for films for quite a few years now. While she admires a few music directors these days, she is not quite a fan of contemporary film music.

“See, there is no change possible in the sargam. That will remain a constant. But I have never worked in this style of music. If there are no shayaris, or nice lyrics, there is not much fun in composing. Everything is in one style. There is no melody, and you can’t really figure out what a song is trying to convey, whether it’s comedy or romance or sadness. There are no good lyrics these days,” she rued.

The first Hindi feature film that music composer worked on was Dil Deke Dekho (1959). She went on to receive a Filmfare Award for composing the songs for Souten (1983).

Changes have been rife in the music industry since she stopped actively composing for films, such as the end of live orchestras and the move towards tracks and mixing. Also present is the mushrooming of talent shows to find new singers for the film industry. In that context, she says that young singers must be kept motivated for them to remain in music.

“At these talent shows, kids achieve name and fame in a short time. They don’t get time for riyaaz (practice) as kids, and they won’t have that time either when they grow up, as they will be expected to earn. The money that they get through these talent shows makes a big difference to their careers. I think that kids should be given such motivation that they should work in music for the rest of their lives,” Khanna signed off.

Title: 2 northeast Delhi seats way ahead of rest of city
Content:
Voters stand in queues to cast their votes at a polling booth at Seelampur constituency in Delhi on Saturday.

NEW DELHI: Seelampur in northeast Delhi witnessed the highest voter turnout with 71.4% eligible voters turning up. According to Delhi election officials, Mustafabad came a close second with 70.55%.The two Muslim-dominated assembly constituencies in northeast Delhi were among the five that had witnessed high turnouts in the 2015 assembly election as well. While 71.8% voters had cast their votes in Seelampur in 2015, Mustafabad had witnessed a 70.9% voter turnout with Gokalpuri recording the highest voter turnout of 74.2% followed by Seemapuri with 73.3%.Interestingly both in 2015 and 2020 assembly segments, the top two constituencies that witnessed the highest voter turnouts were from northeast Delhi.The lowest turnout this time was witnessed in Delhi Cantonment assembly segment with 45.28% per cent voters exercising their franchise, followed by 46.51% in Chhatarpur. In 2015 too, Delhi Cantt had witnessed the lowest voter turnout at 58.6% followed by the reserved constituency of Bawana with 61.8%Interestingly, not only did the overall voter turnout drop in Delhi, all the constituencies in the national capital registered a fall in the number of voters.While in most cases, the dip registered in voter turnout in comparison to 2015 was between 4-10%, Shakur Basti, represented by Delhi health minister Satyendar Jain, registered the sharpest fall of 22.7%. Jain is pitted against two-term MLA SC Vats of BJP. In 2015, Shakur Basti witnessed a voter turnout of 71.9% but it fell to 59.2% this year.The second highest fall was registered in the reserved constituency of Trilokpuri, where a 55.8% voter turnout was reported in comparison to 71.7% in 2015, a dip of 15.8%. Here, AAP had changed its sitting MLA, Raju Dhingan, this year and given the ticket to a first-timer, Rohit Kumar Mehraulia. BJP, however, repeated Kiran Vaidya, who had contested the 2015 election as well.While Delhi was off to a sluggish start on Saturday with just 4.33% voters exercising their franchise in the first hour of voting, which began at 8am, the turnout spiked after 1pm with over 35% of total voters coming out to vote in the last five hours of the day. According to election commission officials, 26.4% voters had cast their votes till 1pm.The lowest fall of 0.3% has been witnessed in Badli assembly segment where 63.8% voters had cast their votes in 2015 in comparison to 63.5% this time. Mustafabad, which has witnessed the second highest voter turnout this year, has registered a dip of 0.4% votes with 70.55% voters coming out to exercise their franchise this year in comparison to 70.9 % in 2015. Mustafabad, a Muslim-dominated constituency, was among the three seats won by BJP in 2015. The saffron party has repeated Jagdish Pradhan as its candidate from the constituency.To ensure that people come out and vote in good numbers, the election office had launched a massive campaign across the city but it seems to have failed to encourage voters to come out in large numbers. “Several voter awareness campaigns through street plays, magic shows and cultural programmes were organised by district electoral offices across the city. Similarly, outdoor media campaigns in metro trains, railways stations and bus queue shelters were held,” an election official said.The election office also made regular appeals through newspapers, SMSs and WhatsApp messages and radio jingles, apart from running messages on electricity and water and phone bills, which encouraged voters to come out and cast their votes,” the official said.The election office also carried out awareness programmes in every polling station to educate voters how the EVM-VVPAT machines work. About five lakh voters saw the demonstration and nearly four lakh used the opportunity to cast mock votes.

Title: UT has violated wetland rules for Sukhna: Kansal residents
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

The residents, who have also submitted their objections to the UT’s draft notification, have also written to t... Read More

CHANDIGARH: Terming the UT’s draft notification for declaring Sukhna Lake as wetland as a violation of the Wetland (Conservation and Management) Rule, 2017, residents of Kansal have now approached the Union minister of environment Prakash Javadekar.

The residents, who have also submitted their objections to the UT’s draft notification, also wrote a letter to the Union minister stating that the draft notification by the UT administration was contrary to the Wetland (Conservation and Management) Rule, 2017, and devoid of scientific inputs.

The letter reads, “The MoEF guidelines clearly states the case of Trans boundaries, it shall be endeavour of all the state/UT along with stakeholders to have mutual consultation to decide upon the subject. In both (Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary and Sukhna Wetland) cases there appears no consultation or coordination committee.”

The residents alleged that on account of lack of consultation and agreement between the UT, Punjab and Haryana, there were different views.

They also submitted that the scientific study of the area had been comprehensively completed by a world-class institute (National Institute of Hydrology, Roorkee) based on technical inputs by ISRO. Unfortunately, the UT administration ignored this study.

Recently, the UT administration had written to the Survey of India for latest map of Sukhna Lake and its catchment area that would be used in the final notification declaring Sukhna as a wetland.

In the draft notification, the Chandigarh administration had used Survey of India’s 2004 map, according to which, the area was surveyed and assessed in 1996-97. But one of the objections the UT received was the use of old map. Thereafter, the administration had written to the Survey of India to provide latest map with a scale 1:5,000.

However, sources have revealed that the Survey of India, in its response to the administration, has stated that such a map does not exist with them.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: 5-year-old girl tries to save drowning brother, both die
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: A five-year-old girl died in a desperate attempt to save her little brother from drowning in a canal in Shivpuri district , around 700km north of Bhopal , on Saturday. The boy died too. An entire village is now in mourning.

A family member told mediapersons that Anicha and her four-year-old brother Surendra of Navli village had gone out to relieve themselves on Saturday morning when the boy slipped into a canal. Anicha jumped in to save him, but they both drowned.

The canal is barely 100 metres from their house, said Ashok Lodhi, a relative. “Neighbours saw the girl jump into the canal, screaming for help to save her brother. Villagers raised the alarm, called the children’s father Shivkumar Lodhi and ran towards the canal, but it was too late. The children were swept away and drowned,” he added.

The bodies were sent for post-mortem and a case has been registered by Khod police station.

Title: After rain, state braces for another round of cold wave
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Bhubaneswar: If you were planning to pack up the woollens and get ready for the hot summer months, don’t do it yet. For the cold wave is set to return soon after the rain and cloud disappear.

The Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) has predicted that chilly weather conditions will continue till February 10 and there will be a further drop in temperature after the cloud cover clears.

“The rain and return of cold is due to a western disturbance. Besides, a low level easterly wind is instrumental in bringing back the chill. The situation became worse due to a cyclonic circulation in West Bengal and a trough line over Tamil Nadu and Chhattisgarh. These systems are causing extortions of moisture from the Bay of Bengal,” said H R Biswas, director of IMD’s Bhubaneswar centre.

On Saturday, thick fog engulfed several parts of the state which witnessed rain accompanied by cold winds. The fog affected road, rail and flight movement. A flight from Jharsuguda airport was cancelled due to bad weather while several trains got delayed due to early morning fog.

The met office has issued yellow warning for rain, thunderstorm with lightening and gusty surface wind in 13 coastal and interior districts in the next three days. “Besides, there will be dense fog in the districts of Sundagarh, Keonjhar, Jharsuguda, Bargarh, Kalahandi, Sonepur and Balangir,” the IMD bulletin said.

“After the cloud cover clears, cold wave conditions may return to some districts. Temperature may fall significantly in Angul and Sonepur districts,” said Biswas.

He further stated, “February is considered as the last month of winter and conditions like this is not very unusual. By the end of the month night temperature starts increasing while day temperature starts increasing much before that. But this winter has seen intermittent fall in temperature for short periods,” he pointed out.

Minimum temperature saw appreciable fall in the districts of coastal Odisha and was below normal. The highest maximum temperature of 32 degree Celsius was recorded at Malkangiri and the lowest minimum temperature of 11 degree Celsius was recorded at Sundergarh in the plains of Odisha. Keonjhar recorded highest rainfall of 22 mm between 8.30 am and 5.30 pm on Saturday.

The day temperature in Bhubaneswar plunged to 20.6 degree Celsius while minimum temperature fell down to 16.6 degree on Saturday. Due to bad weather, many people preferred to remain indoors while roads and markets wore a deserted look.

“It was a very unusual weather in Bhubaneswar, one very similar to North India. Cold winds are blowing throughout the day. The nights are quite cold. I had stored my woollens but have brought them out again with the chill’s return,” said Swastika Mishra, a private firm employee.

Title: City’s history on offer at restored lighthouse
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Four years after the old lighthouse in Visakhapatnam was restored and thrown open to the public, the project has become a big hit, attracting a large number of tourists every year.

The Andhra Pradesh Tourism Development Corporation (APTDC) conducts a daily city tour, and the old lighthouse is the final destination on its itinerary. Apart from this, several private operators also conduct package tours to the lighthouse everyday.

“In the past four years, it has been observed that during peak season—November to March—APTDC receives 90 to 120 tourists every day. There are also private operators. The project is a big hit,” the spokesperson of the Visakha Container Terminal (VCT) said. The Visakhapatnam Port Trust, the custodian of the lighthouse, had roped in VCT for the restoration.

A sum of Rs 25 lakhs was spent to restore the lighthouse. VCT had appointed Vikash V Dilwari, a Mumbai-based conservationist, for consultation works on the project. The restored lighthouse was thrown open to the public in June 2015.

“The idea was quite clear. We wanted to restore the building in a fashion that replicated its original shape, size, design and colour. During the restoration, we ended up constructing a washroom within the compound for tourists which also replicates the original lighthouse design,” the VCT spokesperson added.

The 59-feet-tall lighthouse has an illustrious history. The British constructed the structure in 1903 on present-day Beach Road , facing the harbour. For the next 59 years, till 1962, it served as a lighthouse and guided ships to the harbour.

The lighthouse had a gas-fired white dioptre light of the second order. It flashed every 20 seconds and was visible up to a distance of 12 miles from the shore in clear weather. The dome and lantern of the lighthouse were visible from the lighthouse at Chantilly or Chintappal, 18 km from Bheemunipatnam.

During World War II, two anti-aircraft guns were set up next to the lighthouse. These guns were excavated when the tower was being restored. One of the guns is on display right next to lighthouse. The gas-fired light in the lighthouse could not be restored.

“All these buildings are living pages of the city’s history. Many port cities abroad have restored their old lighthouses and are showcasing them for tourists. I am happy Visakhapatnam has also done this and happier that I was part of the project,” said conservationist Dilwari.

Title: Arvind Kejriwal: BJP stalks Arvind Kejriwal, AAP through the day
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: As Delhiites started queuing up in the morning, another battle was beginning to simmer in the virtual world with senior BJP functionaries taking turns to target chief minister Arvind Kejriwal and his Aam Aadmi Party .

Union minister Smriti Irani was quick to latch on to a tweet by the CM to label him “anti-women”. The trigger was an appeal by Kejriwal to women to come out in large numbers to exercise their franchise. “Special appeal to all women — just as you bear the responsibility at home, similarly the responsibility of Delhi and the country is on your shoulders. All you women must go vote and also take the men of your house. Make sure to discuss with the men who the right candidate will be to vote for (sic).”

Irani asked if Kejriwal considered women incapable of taking their own decisions. “Do you not consider women competent enough to independently decide who to vote for,” she tweeted. It drew an immediate response from Kejriwal, who said the women had already decided where their votes were going. “Smiriti ji, the women of Delhi have decided who they will vote for. They have made the decision for their entire family this time. Ultimately, it’s the women who have to run the household,” Kejriwal said.

A little later, Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari retweeted a video of the CM taking off his shoes and garlanding an Hanuman idol “without washing his hands” and called him a “Chunaavi Hanuman Bhakt”. BJP MP Parvesh Sahib Singh Verma kept up the ante, claiming that the residents of Shaheen Bagh were voting for AAP and urged people to turn out in large numbers and vote for the “deshbhakt party”.

AAP leader Sanjay Singh slammed Tiwari for his remarks, dubbing it “politics of hate”. He said: “It has deeply hurt me...Tiwari is saying that by offering prayers, Kejriwal has turned Hanuman ji impure. They consider Kejriwal untouchable and look down upon him.”

BJP’s Verma claimed that AAP was arranging biryani for the Shaheen Bagh protesters and, as a result, they were voting for it. “People of Delhi, what I was saying for a long time... the media is also saying that today. People from a particular community from Shaheen Bagh, Jamia Millia and Seelampur are standing in long queues and proclaiming their support to AAP. Why would they not? AAP has been feeding them biryani for more than a month (sic),” Verma stated in a video message that he shared on Twitter.

He called it a mode of “repayment of loan” given by AAP and urged the people of Delhi to turn up in large numbers, vote for the “nationalist party” and shout “Jai Shri Ram”.

Title: Rishikesh’s yoga instructor who was in China’s Wuhan kept under observation
Content: Authorities at AIIMS-Rishikesh have sent blood samples of a 36-year-old yoga instructor for novel coronavirus test on Saturday, and he has been kept under observation.The patient is a resident of Rishikesh who was working as a yoga instructor in China for the past five years, officials said, adding that he had been living in Wuhan city for past one year.Notably, the yoga instructor went for a routine health check-up after referral from Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme team. His vitals were found to be stable and he is kept in home isolation, officials said. “He returned to India on January 23, although did not report any kind of discomfort. He informed us that he didn’t visit any market or over-crowded place in Wuhan city. After arriving in India, he stayed at home with rest of his family members who at present have not developed any kind of symptoms,” an official told TOI.
