Title: BJP targets govt for razing guest house at heart of PEO death row
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The demolition of an illegally constructed two-storied guest house in Charabatia village, under Haridaspur gram panchayat of Jajpur district , has triggered a row with the BJP slamming the state government for it. The guest house is where Smitarani Biswal, the panchayat executive officer (PEO) of Haridaspur, was found hanging in October last year. The guest house belonged to Rupesh Bhadra, husband of Haridaspur sarpanch Madhusmita Bhadra. Rupesh was arrested for abetting Smitarani’s suicide.

On Friday, the guest house was torn down, which BJP alleged was done by the state government to destroy evidence in connection with the PEO’s death.

Blaming the state government, senior BJP leader Lekhashree Samantsinghar said, “From circumstantial evidence, it seemed Smitarani was murdered. But the Jajpur SP did not deal with the case in an impartial manner. Now, the guest house has been demolished in a bid to destroy evidence. It is clear that the state government doesn’t want the truth behind the incident to come out in the open.”

Senior BJD leader Subash Singh said the BJP is trying to politicise the issue. “The guest house was demolished because it was an unauthorized construction. The investigation is going in the right direction and as per law,” he said.

Earlier, the BJP had demanded action against the Jajpur SP as he had gone on record to claim the deceased had illicit relationship with Rupesh. “The police are mandated to ascertain the cause of death and not cast aspersion on the deceased at the beginning of the investigation,” BJP had then said.

The husband of the deceased had also pointed fingers at Rupesh and had denied the suicide angle. Smitarani’s father Sadananda Biswal had also lodged a complaint with Dharmasala police alleging that his daughter was murdered.

Title: AIBEA meets in Pune to launch national campaign against 'bank blunders'
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

PUNE: The All India Bank Employees Association (AIBEA) met in Pune on Saturday as part of a national campaign to create awareness about the “series of wrong steps that the government is taking in respect to public sector banks”.

Blighted by the government's move to merge public sector banks, AIBEA general secretary, C.H. Venkatachalam said, "such mergers do not benefit the public." He said that even the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) has become a back door channel to give clean chit to promoters.

“IBC is a sham. Earlier at least the wilful defaulters were charged to the extent that they were not give other loans…Now, under the resolution process only the company is declared insolvent and sold at a discount (haricut) and the promoter goes scot free,” he said.

Citing six resolutions under the code, he said, that the bank’s have taken haircut of as much as 95% -- generally favouring big corporate groups. The average haircut that banks took in six cases was 46%, AIBEA said.

“All this money foregone is recovered from common people by the way of service charges, minimum balance charges, lower interest on deposits and higher interest on loans, among others,” the general secretary said.

The officials of the association said that customers do not benefit from bank mergers and instead there is a cut in the number of branches, at a time when more people are enrolled into banking.

“We have rallied against mergers since 2004 and so, it has taken a long time. Otherwise these mergers would have happened long back…similarly the government had to withdraw the Financial Resolution and Deposit Insurance (FRDI) Bill after the unions opposed,” Venkatachalam said, when asked about the effectiveness of one or two-day bank strikes in the time of alternate banking.

AIBEA also criticised the economic survey’s reference of public sector bank’s as “inefficient”.

“Yes, there is room for improvement in PSBs, but nowhere else are so many non-bank related services pushed through the banks,” said Devidas Tuljapurkar, joint secretary of the All India Bank Employees Association (AIBEA).

'Wage settlement close to fruition'

AIBEA general secretary, C.H.Venkatachalam, said that the delayed wage settlement is close to fruition.

“Last time, we settled the 2012 settlement in May 2015. This time, we still have 2-3 months for the 2017 wage settlement,” he said, adding, “it is close to completion”.

About 7-8 lakh employees of the public sector banks have been waiting for enhanced salaries since November 2017 and the delay has become a pattern.

“My priority is to sign the agreement. No one is really bothered about the wages of employees. So along with national issues, this is one of the issues we will finish first,” he said.

Title: 17 benches dispose of over 3,600 cases at Lok Adalat
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Over 3,600 civil and criminal cases were disposed off on Saturday at the national Lok Adalat held on the premises of the district court . A total of 17 benches were constituted for the purpose.

Speaking on the occasion, chairperson and principal district judge B S Bhanumati said the Lok Adalat is the most effective means to resolve differences in an amicable manner.

Secretary of district legal services authority S Damodar Rao said each bench consisted of judicial officers, an advocate and a social worker. Additional DCP V Suresh Babu and additional SP B Atchut Rao also participated in the Adalat.

Title: Revoke CAA immediately, NRC and NPR will lead to victimisation: Goa church to Centre
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Filipe Neri Ferrao

PANAJI: Archbishop of Goa Filipe Neri Ferrao , on behalf of the Catholic community in the state, released a strongly-worded statement on Saturday appealing to the Centre to “immediately and unconditionally revoke the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and desist from implementing the National Register of Citizens (NRC) and the National Population Register”.

“The very fact that the CAA uses religion goes against the secular fabric of the country,” he said.

Urging the government to “listen to the voice of millions in India”, Ferrao said the recently enacted CAA and the proposed NRC and the intended NPR is causing “great concern and anguish” to millions of Indians spread throughout the world.

He said the CAA, the NRC and the NPR “are divisive and discriminatory” and would certainly have a “negative and damaging effect on a multi-cultural democracy like ours”.

Ferrao said the NRC and the NPR exercises would result in “a direct victimisation” of the underprivileged classes, “particularly the dalits, adivasis, migrant labourers, nomadic communities and the countless undocumented people who, after having been recognised as worthy citizens and voters for more than 70 years in this great nation, will suddenly run the risk of becoming stateless and candidates for detention camps in their teeming millions”.

He said Christians in India have always been a peace-loving community and deeply committed to the ideals of justice, liberty, equality and fraternity, enshrined in the Constitution of India.

“It is observed, sadly, that these initiatives issuing forth from the government are forecasting a systematic erosion of the values, principles and rights which have been guaranteed to all citizens under our Constitution, and which citizens are called to protect and promote,” he said.

The archbishop said he would pray for the country and “that good sense, justice and peace prevail in the hearts and minds of all”.

Title: Delhi: Police nip trouble in the bud as tempers flare up
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

In all, 42,000 personnel from Delhi Police, 190 companies of CAPF and 19,000 from Home Guard were deployed

NEW DELHI: Petty fights and verbal duels between members of political parties and jostling by voters were reported from various places during the assembly polls on Saturday. However, none of the incidents were termed serious by police. Most tiffs were resolved by the cops on the spot.

Tempers rose at a polling booth in Neb Sarai in Sangam Vihar assembly constituency where some voters complained about the narrow entrance to a school and tried to force their way in. Policemen had to push some of them out and open the school gate for the crowd to enter.

A senior police officer said there was a sudden rush of voters after 4pm at the government school, which had led to the ruckus. However, it was controlled within a short period. The police control room received 223 election-related calls till 6pm. The calls ranged from “putting more tables” to “seeking help for transportation”, “canvassing inside restricted area”, “quarrel among party workers” and “not being permitted to cast vote”.

Heated arguments took place between voters and poll officials at Inderpuri over delay in voting. People also got into an altercation with policemen posted there over the same issue.

In total, 42,000 personnel from Delhi Police , 190 companies of CAPF and 19,000 Home Guard were deployed for the elections. Senior officers personally supervised the arrangements on directions of the Election Commission. Special emphasis was given to area dominance, critical polling stations and booths and borders were strengthened to ensure security.

Title: Another seer announces hunger strike for the Ganga
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Haridwar: A week after Matri Sadan seer Padmavati, who had been on an indefinite fast for the cause of ‘Clean Ganga’, was lifted by the police and admitted to Doon Hospital, another seer, Gopal Das on Saturday, announced to sit on a hunger strike to push for the same demands.

Das had been on a similar indefinite hunger strike in October, 2018 as well. In the same year, he had also written to Prime Minister Narendra Modi in blood to protect the river. However, after nearly 165 days of fasting, he was lifted by police and taken to PGI Chandigarh and later to AIIMS Delhi. Subsequently, he went missing and was thereafter found in South India.

Gopal Das told TOI that “under my Deal-to-Death revolution, I will sit outside the CM’s house and stage a protest very soon.” “I have fasted for 165 days and even after the death of professor GD Agrawal, I continued fasting. I will not allow his sacrifice to go in vain. Both the central and state governments are playing games with the holy Ganga in the name of Namami Gange.” He added that his protest will continue till the government brings a Ganga Act.

However, Matri Sadan ashram functionaries said that they are not associated with Gopal Das. “He has never been a part of Matri Sadan ashram. In 2018, we allowed him to use our premises for meditation (tapasya) after his request. The permission was given in good faith as he had been fasting for Ganga and his aim coincided with late professor GD Agrawal’s demands,” said Matri Sadan seer Dayanand. He added that Matri Sadan has no information regarding the hunger strike announcement made by Das.

Title: Won’t allow anti-CAA floats at carnival: CCP
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

PANAJI: The Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP) announced on Saturday that protest floats, particularly those depicting CAA or NRC, will not be permitted to participate at this year’s edition of the Goa carnival float parade.

“Festivals like carnival are not a place to protest,” said CCP commissioner Sanjit Rodrigues . “People who wish to protest in favour of or against CAA/NRC can do so at Azad Maidan in Panaji; we will grant them permission.”

The CCP, as per its rules and regulations, usually discourages the depiction of religious and political themes, figures or personalities.

The annually-held Goa carnival float parade sees an array of tableau showcasing Goa’s art, culture and rural life. In recent years, the event has also opened its platform for commercial floats, wherein brands can showcase themselves.

This year, however, CCP has cracked a whip on such tableau too.

Rules state that the products of a sponsoring company should not form the main part of the float, and that the tableau must have a cultural theme.

Brands will therefore not be allowed to liberally promote their products at this year’s float parade in Panaji.

“Branding can be done, but direct cutouts of products should not be projected in front of, back of, or on top of the float. This is not a product display festival,” Rodrigues said. “Brands can only feature their logo or banner on the sides of the floats.”

All floats desirous of participating this year will therefore have to be pre-approved by the CCP. Goa celebrates carnival from February 22 to 25.

Title: In Bhadrawati Ordnance Factory, it is tigers and leopards which are on a safari
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Chandrapur: A healthy prey base in the forest swath on the premises of Ordnance Factory in Bhadrawati has turned it into an ideal habitat for wild predators. Tigers, leopards and bears are being frequently sighted in the civilian area under factory.

There is a thick forest on either side of the road in the factory. A majestic tiger talking a royal walk or sudden flash of leopard across the road has become quite common.

According to sources, the OF area is spread over 7,500 acres. Apart from the walled manufacturing unit and magazine (store house), there is residential colony for officers and staffers. The remaining area is a dense forest with rich sources of water and prey base. “While cycling, I saw a tiger sitting on the road a few hundred yards ahead just 15 days back. Bears, leopards, Indian gaurs, spotted deer and wild rabbits are frequently sighted in the area,” said businessman Shekhar Singh.

Singh said that other than killing of a small girl named Ankita on the road a few years back and charging at bikes, no untoward incident has taken place so far. “Over half a dozen leopards who had intruded in the area have been captured in the last few years,” he claimed but also feared there could a wild animal attack due to presence of large predators in the area.

“Though locals have become used to the sightings, they have also grown cautious of close presence of predators around their residences,” said Dr Pravin Keshwani, who works in the hospital in OF. He claimed that people have stopped going out for morning and evening walks and take all precautions while stepping out in the night. In fact, a leopard had intruded in the OF hospital building a few years back.

The recent poaching of leopards and bears in the factory area also points towards flaring up of man-animal conflict. CCF, Chandrapur, SV Ramarao who recently had a meeting with general manger of OF, Chanda, said that the situation is even more volatile than Chandrapur Super Thermal Power Station (CSTPS), where tigers have been sighted since couple of years, as there is no exact estimation of predators in the area.

“The forest under OF area is quite large and in continuation with buffer forest. Also, a porous boundary allows uninterrupted entry and exit of wild animals. The forest is under OF management jurisdiction. We have suggested mitigation measures to the OF management and assured our full support,” he said.

Wildlife NGOs have alleged lapses in security after poaching of leopards and bears. OF officials claimed that protecting people from wild animals is responsibility of forest department.

As per regulations, Defence Security Corp (DSC) is responsible for protection of walled area of ammunition manufacture and its storage and transport. Keeping wild animals in check, nabbing poachers and keeping thieves away from civilian area are jobs related to forest and police departments.

The production unit and magazine are secured location guarded by army men and there are no security lapses, officials claimed and added that DSC is cooperating with forest and police officials in curbing the menace of poachers. They, however, said it’s far-fetched to expect DSC men to walk around the forested areas to catch poachers.

Title: Hyderabad cops to RBI: Make bank verification stricter
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: After the cybercrime case in which six fraudsters were nabbed for availing instant loans and credit cards in the name of four IT professionals who died in accidents last year, the Cyberabad police plan to write to Reserve Bank of India ( RBI ) and banks and ask them to make the verification process stricter.

“If a person can hack into your net banking account, they can easily apply for an instant pre-approved loan and credit card with a pre-approved limit. All they have to provide is the correct phone number and e-mail address. The bank will check the CIBIL score and accordingly transfer money within minutes or maximum, hours,” said ACP cybercrime, Cyberabad, Y Srinivas Kumar.

The accused persons used the same trick to cheat over Rs 53 lakh by impersonating the deceased IT professionals, who had decent CIBIL scores. “Now applying for loans and the credit cards has become easy, as everything can be applied for online and no physical verification is required. The offenders are taking advantage of it,” said the officer.

The case came to light when a victim’s wife discovered that her dead husband’s phone number was blocked. The victim, Raghuram worked at Infosys, and had died in September last year.

“When she approached the service provider, she discovered that the same number was active on another SIM card. She grew suspicious and was approached by bank officials to clear credit card dues,” said the ACP.

According to cops, the banks need to carry out physical verification for approving loans and credit cards, and the verification procedure has to be more complex. “The banks are choosing speed over safety. They need to have stricter procedures,” said the officials.

Title: Four suspected coronavirus patients sent to Delhi hospital for check-ups
Content: Pithoragarh: Four suspected novel coronavirus patients, including two Chinese nationals, were admitted to district hospital in Pithoragarh for tests on Saturday. After preliminary examination, they were sent to Ram Manohar Lohia Hospital, Delhi, for further check-ups.The two Chinese nationals work at a company as consultants. The firm is involved in the construction of a power station at Bagarihat in Didihat tehsil.They are in their 30s, and had recently gone home to China and returned to Uttarakhand a few days ago. When they complained of fever-like symptoms, they were taken to district hospital. Two of their Indian colleagues who complained of similar symptoms have also been admitted in hospital.Chief medical superintendent of Pithoragarh HS Kharayat said that all the four patients had cold and cough, and were kept in an isolated ward and the required tests were being conducted.Both the Chinese nationals reside around 500 km away from the virus-hit city of Wuhan and had come to India only a month ago. There were no advisory issued by the Government of India at that time, so no medical checkups were conducted at the airport, he added.Two other patients also worked in the same company and stayed with them, said Kharayat.“The hospital is now sending blood samples to virology laboratory and advised the four persons to be kept in an isolated ward but they insisted on going to Delhi for further check-ups,” Kharayat said.“Officials of their company first discussed the matter with district administration. They then requested for permission to be allowed to go to a higher medical facility for further check-ups. After district administration’s nod, they were sent to Ram Manohar Lohia Hospital in Delhi,” said Vijay Kumar Jogdende, DM Pithoragarh.

Title: At Mapusa rehab, off-season is peak time
Content:
Representative Image

PANAJI : Of the 63 opioids users undergoing treatment at the North Goa district hospital in Mapusa , seven have relapsed since the season started while one has died of an overdose. Doctors at the hospital’s drug treatment centre (DTC) point to a relation between the tourist season and relapses.Monsoon is the tourist off season in the state and during this period narcotics become difficult to source, and to tide the period drug users turn to the centre’s Methadone Maintenance Treatment (MMT), medical officer and psychiatrist at DTC Dr Ravindra Patil said.“They go back to doing drugs when the season starts. That’s how, we see more patients during the monsoon months than at any other time of the year, and see more relapse patients during the tourist season,” Patil said.Since November 2019, the start of tourist season in the state, the DTC has seen several relapse cases besides two drug overdose cases and one death.Patil said the patient who died used to attend the clinic on and off. “He had been arrested for peddling drugs and died of an overdose the day he was released on bail. We suspect he might have used hard drugs, which he was not able to use while in prison,” he said.“Many drug users work in the tourism industry. It is but natural they will do drugs when they see their friends who are also users,” said Rihan, 23, who has been on MMT for about a year-and-a-half.Most patients relapse and some more than once. The rate of relapse is higher than success in terms of patients not touching drugs for a year or more. Patil said their task is a difficult one, and that they try to help their patients stay away from drugs as much as possible. “We aim at harm reduction rather than de-addiction,” he said.Over 90% of the patients who relapse offer a common reason. “They blame it either on a break-up or betrayal in love,” Patil said.One drug user, who recently overdosed but was saved, pleaded with the doctors at the centre to speak to his girlfriend and help him reconcile with her. “The users don’t require a reason to use drug. They will find something or someone to blame when asked to explain,” Patil said.When asked Rihan said he went back to drugs after a break-up. “My girlfriend at that time had left me and two days later I was at a party. So I told myself I’ll use drugs only once. But believe me, it never stops at that one shot,” he said.At the clinic is a young couple, Ravi and Neena, who are parents to a two-year-old girl. Neena said she picked the drug habit from her husband as she could not cope with her mother-in-law. Their inter-religious marriage is a bone of contention in Ravi’s family.“I sought relief in drugs as I could not handle his mum,” Neena said. While she is doing well, Ravi relapsed after a fight at home.“Both complain against each other. I keep telling them to at least look at their daughter,” said Patil, who also counsels patients and helps them sort their domestic issues.Drug uses will also go to any length to support their addiction.A twenty-something Nikhil Marathe said he was advised by his drug using friends to forge a doctor’s prescription to secure morphine if he was in difficult. “I once pinched a prescription from a doctor’s clinic. Scribbled the name of the drug I wanted and signed it. I got the drug without raising any suspicion,” he said.But whether a regular or occasional user, all face the risk of overdose with chances being the highest for those using multiple drugs.“Those using multiple substances such as cocaine, heroin, weed and alcohol face higher risk of overdose. They start with alcohol and smoking cannabis. Next, they chase or sniff cocaine and later will go for a fix of the hard drug heroin. If by mistake more heroin is injected than what the body can handle the user can die of an overdose unless timely medical help is administered,” Patil said.An overdose can also happen if the substance consumed is spurious, he said.

Title: Turning small potatoes into big biz
Content: Neel Kotak, managing director, Iscon Balaji FoodsFarmers in Banaskantha and Sabarkantha districts of Gujarat, who grew potatoes for companies making chips and wafer were plagued by the problem of undersized potatoes, which not just caused wastage but loss of revenue to farmers. Exploring this untapped potential, Ahmedabad-based entrepreneur, Neel Kotak, founded Iscon Balaji Foods, roped in farmers to manufacture potato flakes, using undersized potatoes. A huge chunk of unutilized potatoes was brought to use, thus boosting farmer’s income.Past JourneyA BTech in chemical engineering from IIT Bombay, Neel Kotak, managing director, Iscon Balaji Foods, started the company in 2012, primarily to address farmer’s concerns. “The income of farmers grew by 20% when the potato flakes were supplied to companies that manufactured namkeen. Keeping the aim of boosting farmer’s income, we further diversified our business into manufacturing frozen french fries in 2016. We encouraged farmers to farm for the processing variety of potato, which yielded them better income,” he said.As on date, IBF owns nearly 35% market share in the Hotel, Restaurant and Catering segment of India for supplying french fries. “We’re getting more and more farmers on our platform through contract farming agreements. We supply them seeds, and our team helps and monitors the health of the crop and we buy back the crop at a pre-approved price; which helps farmers secure their income from market disturbances,” he added.The french fries, manufactured at the company’s plant are not just supplied to the Indian market but also exported to middle east and south east Asian countries. As on date, the company works with some 5,000 potato farmers in Gujarat and Punjab and clocks revenue of Rs 230 crore.Next StepsBeing an exporter of frozen potato-based products to more than 14 countries, the company’s next challenge is to increase productivity and expand to other markets. “We plan to begin exporting to more countries and focus on the European and US markets in the next phase,” said Kotak.ChallengesImproving productivity of farmers from time to time is a challenge, according to Kotak. “A lot needs to be done at the ground-level to improve productivity and yield of farmers and ensuring that their income grows,” he said.Secret to SuccessPrioritizing long-term relationship with farmers and stakeholders at all levels over short-term gains is something that has clicked right since the company’s inception believes Kotak. “Helping all stakeholders grow is the only way our company will grow and that is what has worked for us over the years,” said Kotak.

Title: Boys of ballet
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Chennai: Chandrashekar K A was just beginning his PhD in computational biology, when he decided to enroll for ballet classes in 2015. For the senior research fellow, it was a spontaneous leap into something "starkly different, and challenging".

But from then to now, the dance form has turned out to be a lot more for this 29-year-old who has been training under Ann Toner of The School of Ballet and Contemporary Dance in Chennai. "Ballet is so unique and regimental — it naturally cultivated the ability in me to strive for excellence in anything I did," he says. "And that is my high."

The reasons are many and varied, but young men like Chandrashekar are at the forefront of turning the tide for ballet — once considered the domain of the feminine — as they realise its paybacks are more far-reaching than just physical agility and fitness, which are just the tip of the iceberg.

Twenty-four year-old Milton Obadhia for instance, joined dancer-choreographers Gowtham Sundararajan and Kokila Hariram’s Academy of Modern Danse in Chennai, to learn hip-hop (the popular culture style that has caught the fancy of most young men in dance according to the couple). But six years into learning ballet — that Gowtham and Kokila offer as a mandatory foundational course — Milton still wants to pursue and teach hip-hop and contemporary dance, but cannot imagine doing that without the strong spine of ballet backing him. "Its tough, structured techniques make it easier to learn any other dance form," he says. "Elements like pirouettes — the act of spinning on one foot, and the jumps — help tremendously while learning styles like jazz."

Kokila says while most of their boys shrug off ballet when they’re young, they invariably come back to learning again when they’re older and want to find a career in dance. "Because there’s nothing that strengthens your core and technique the way this does. A grade four in jazz could is equal to a grade one in ballet, for instance," she says.

Another student of theirs, Chiraag R, is a classic example. The 22-year-old joined them with his heart set on jazz, and later moved to Salsa, which he now wishes to pursue seriously. But if there has been a constant, it has been ballet. "I see it as a pivotal element in all forms of dance," he says. "It opens up your body and makes you stronger, so you look stronger too, especially when you are holding your partner in Salsa. You are also so much more confident and presentable," he says.

Because what’s really happening when you practice on the barre is that you get an excellent understanding of your body and your central gravity," says Gowtham. "Your joints open up and your mobility increases. Many times, we have skaters and gymnasts training in ballet from us for these reasons."

Teachers in the city say that while more young male dancers training professionally are taking to ballet, popular perception still needs to change, particularly among parents of young boys. "Although both men and women play prominent roles in classical ballet, many parents want their sons to learn an on-field sport or something ‘more masculine’ in the long run," says Ann. "But I explain to them that a ballet dancer isn’t just equipped with the technique and skill of a sportsperson but refines it into something beautiful, smooth and fluid to watch. The man has to be extremely strong as the athleticism here is harnessed and refined. If you’re doing a leap in a track event, you can fall, kick and shout, but when you leap in ballet, you have to be graceful, as if emulating the movement of a bird soaring freely through the air."

It was this innate grace and skill that caught the eye of Israeli-American classical ballet master Yehuda Maor in two Mumbai boys, Amiruddin Shah and Manish Chauhan, and inspired him to mentor them. Amiruddin, son of a welder, and Manish, a former stuntman, also demonstrated what passion and flair in the dance form could do when they bagged scholarships to the Oregon Ballet Theatre School in the US and went on to perform at some of the finest ballet theatres there.

"In Asia, there is great demand for men in ballet, because they are so few," says Kokila. "Many hesitate to take it up professionally because it’s tedious and intensive. But, if you set your mind to it, you can travel and perform extensively, or be picked up by prestigious dance companies in the UK, the US and Singapore. The road ahead is versatile and rewarding,"

Title: Female leopard suffering from pneumonia dies
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Almora: A female leopard rescued from Chaubatia-Nagpani area of Ranikhet has died on Saturday. Forest officials said the leopard was suffering from pneumonia-like conditions and had high fever.

“From the time when this female leopard was trapped by the forest department team, it was suffering from very high fever and was in a weak state. Treatment by veterinarians was ongoing but it died around 11:30 am on Saturday morning,” said Umesh Pandey, range officer at Ranikhet forest range.

The official said that due to snowfall and cold in the past days, this leopard may have been vulnerable to pneumonia. The leopard’s body has been destroyed after the postmortem.

Title: IAS officers take over probe of Kasnasur-Boriya encounters
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nagpur: The magisterial inquiries of the country’s biggest encounters of Maoists at Kasnasur where 34 of their cadres were killed on April 22, 2018, followed by another at Nainer the next day, where six were gunned down by Gadchiroli police, are now being conducted afresh by IAS officers to expedite the investigations. The inquiries, which are already delayed by almost two years, were left midway by the sub-divisional magistrates (SDMs) who moved out to join in their posting keeping the inquiries incomplete.

There are around 10 magisterial inquiries, instituted under the provisions of 176 Criminal procedure code (CrPC) by the Gadchiroli collector following police encounters in which alleged Maoists were gunned down, that have been pending in the district for a period of around two years including the crucial ones of Kasnasur at Etapalli and another at Nainer in Aheri talukas. Out of the 10, half of the inquiries entrusted with the Aheri SDM have been pending.

The vacancies in the official posts and the two elections, general and state in 2019, were cited as the most cogent reasons for the delay in the inquiries which were to be completed by SDMs in a “time-bound” manner.

Incumbent collector Deepak Singla, who has ordered to expedite the inquiries, have said there would be free and fair probes conducted into the encounters without any influence or bias. “Two inquiries of Aheri would be wrapped up soon while one at Kurkheda is on the verge of completion with only the statement of the doctor is awaited,” he said.

Singla also admitted about the complexities in the Kasnasur and Boriya encounters which were fraught with allegations despite the national limelight it had brought for the Gadchiroli’s elite commando force of C-60. The encounters had catapulted the C-60 commando unit to the top slot in the country overshadowing the earlier best of the Telangana’s Greyhounds.

“The encounters of Kasnasur and Boriya have been started afresh by two IAS officers who are in their first posting. Given the gravity and complexities of the encounters, their inquiries would take time and expected to be over in the next two-three months. Since the inquiries are to be conducted in the public domain, there would be complete fair practices followed. I have instructed the IAS officers to conduct the inquiries in a transparent manner as their findings may be sought through the RTI Act,” he said.

After the last encounter in Gadchiroli on November 30, 2019, near Modmetta close to Maharashtra-Chhattisgarh border in Bhamragarh tehsil, where two alleged Maoists were killed, Gadchiroli polices’ C-60 commandos had come under heavy criticism for having bumped off villagers on the pretext of taking action against the Reds. Apart from magisterial inquiries, police also had to institute a separate inquiry under Addl SP, Aheri, Manish Kalbaniya, an IPS officer.

Title: Delhi elections: Volunteers save day for differently-abled
Content:
Young volunteers rose to the occasion to make polling a reasonably comfortable experience for the wheelchair-b... Read More

NEW DELHI: Young volunteers rose to the occasion to make polling a reasonably comfortable experience for the wheelchair-bound and ageing voters . The capital has taken the lead in making elections accessible, but a visit to some polling stations revealed the distance yet to be travelled to make elections disabled- and age-friendly.It is no surprise that the polling centre at the Leprosy Complex in northeast Delhi’s Tahirpur area would have a high number of voters who suffer from leprosy and are wheelchair-bound. Volunteers didn’t have a moment to breathe as they wheeled-in one voter after another, hampered by insufficient numbers of wheelchairs and one even non-functional.Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections“Given the centre’s location, there should have been large numbers of wheelchairs and volunteers. We feel bad since there are only so many voters we can help at a time,” said a volunteer who didn’t wish to be identified. “One wheelchair is damaged, making our jobs tougher,” he said.“I don’t have a leg and I have been in queue for over an hour. There should be some special facilities for us so that we don’t have to stand for so long in queues,” said Rehman (40), a resident of the complex. Phool Chand (35), who has lost his fingers and legs to leprosy, sat on the floor helpless, waiting for the crowd to thin so he could crawl his way into the booth. “Volunteers are all busy, there is no one to help me and I don’t know how long I will have to wait,”he said, watching the few volunteers running around.In RK Puram, too it was left to the volunteers who had to compensate for the lack of a ramp at a booth. Disabled voters had to be aided to climb a few stairs before they could be ferried on wheelchairs.A 65-year-old man with a fractured leg spoke highly of the volunteers in his Laxmi Nagar booth. “I was undecided about going to vote, but my family helped me go. And volunteers immediately helped once I reached, taking me in a wheelchair to the booth.”Across the city in Madangir, Poonam Devi, partially paralysed for five years, was helped by her husband Laxmi Narayan to reach her poll station. Her speech impaired, she was helped as she walked to the booth and cast her vote. The election commission had earlier announced a pick-and-drop facility for ageing voters who had no one to bring them to polling booths.

Title: Enraged, Alka Lamba tries to slap AAP member
Content:
Screen grab of the video

NEW DELHI: In a mobile video that went viral on social media, a man reportedly belonging to AAP was heard shouting at Alka Lamba , the Congress candidate from Chandni Chowk assembly constituency, on Saturday morning during polling.A visibly angry Lamba tried to slap the man in a fit of rage. When the AAP worker allegedly passed some comments that offended her, she lunged at him. However, the man moved back before Lamba could hit him.A fuming Lamba was stopped by police at Majnu ka Tila polling booth. The man was then escorted away. However, angry Congress supporters surrounded the policemen to catch hold of the man. “As soon as I came out of the polling booth , I saw the AAP candidate’s son arguing with police over entering the booth. At that moment, an AAP worker, Harmesh, verbally abused me. I thank police for arresting him immediately,” Lamba told a news agency.Lamba, a former AAP MLA from Chandni Chowk, had left the party last year and gone back to Congress.In Video: Delhi polls: Alka Lamba drags BJP into ‘slapping’ incident

Content:
Screen grab of the video

Title: Ponzi scheme busted in Panaji, 4 held for duping 400
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative Image

PANAJI: Goa police on Saturday busted a ponzi scheme in which over 400 people across seven states were duped of over Rs 1 crore in just a month. The police also arrested four people, including the scheme’s masterminds from Telangana and Tamil Nadu. The four cheated customers by promising returns of 3% per day, while also wooing them with luxury sedans to get new customers.

SP Shobhit Saksena of the Goa police’s economic offences cell told TOI that the four cheated people in Goa, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh and Telangana.

The four accused were earlier real estate agents, and then became ‘agents’ in other ponzi schemes in Andhra Pradesh and Maharahstra. “This time they decided to start their own scheme,” Saksena said.

Saksena said that the incident came to light when they received a complaint from one Ismail Munshi, who invested Rs 10,000 in a scheme run by a company called Dreams2Reality . It accepted deposits from persons ranging from Rs 10,000 to Rs 5,00,000, and promised daily returns up to 3% along with air tickets to Goa, free entry into casinos, and hotel stays.

It also offered investors additional benefits like iPhones, scooters, motorcycles and German luxury cars. The complainant further told police that the ‘company’ didn’t get provide receipts for investments, and their entire functioning was online, on a website that functioned like a casino.

Saksena said that the accused persons promised investors that they would invest the money through casino operators and daily customers, and delivered daily interest between Rs 100 and Rs 200.

The EOC then found that Dreams2Reality ran its office at Patto, Panaji , in the guise of a travel agency.

“It had no permission from RBI, SEBI or any other regulating agency for accepting deposits or investment,” said Saksena. “Nor was any investment being made when their suspected bank accounts were analysed and the money circulating between various accounts of the fraudsters was being paid back to investors to build confidence in the scheme and draw more investors.”

The Goa police then filed an FIR under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code and other laws. After that, the EOC raided all the fraudsters’ known premises — their rented place of residence at Kadamba plateau, and their office at Patto. Four persons — Dasarath Boora, the mastermind, Adi Ganesh, the head of the company, Fakruddin, their Goa agent, and Sandeep, their IT expert — were arrested.

“One Goan woman called Shweta was also involved in their marketing operations in Goa, and her involvement is also being verified,” Saksena said.

Saksena also said that all known bank accounts of the fraudsters have been frozen. “Since the scheme was less than a month old, a major loss of hard-earned money was prevented by the swift action of Goa police’s EOC,” he said.

Upon interrogation of the accused persons, it was established that although they had fashioned their scheme as a scheme for investment in casino games, it was actually a money circulating, multi-level marketing and ponzi scheme where they just transferred parts of funds received as investments from new customers to old ones.

“They stated that they started the scheme in Goa after they came to the state in September 2019,” Saksena said. “They hatched a plan to exploit the unique and attractive casino tourism of Goa by offering people outside Goa to be able to play and invest in these casinos.”

As per the plan, they were going to accept investments for up to three months, and when they estimated they would have made around Rs 5 crore, they would simply have shut shop and absconded with people’s hard-earned money. “They promises investors that they would double the amount invested,” Saksena said.

Title: Shepherd hid AK-47 for 3 yrs
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Hyderabad: A shepherd, who created a flutter by opening fire at his neighbour with an AK-47 over a petty fight, had hid the assault rifle in an empty drum in his Akkannapet village home for the last three years, police learnt during investigation.

The AK-47 was the same weapon which had gone missing from Husnabad police station. The accused, Sadanandam, who was picked up on Friday, was formally arrested on Saturday and sent to judicial remand. Police, however, are still not sure as to how the AK-47 ended up in his hands.

“There are inconsistencies in Sadanandam’s statement during our investigation on how he got the AK-47. We are yet to come to any conclusion. He will be taken into custody with court permission to probe the matter further,’’ a senior police official told STOI.

After nabbing the accused, cops recovered the AK-47, a magazine containing 25 live rounds, one 9 mm carbine gun and a sword from his residence. Police, however, are unwilling to confirm whether any photographs of Sadanandam with policemen were seized.

Title: City devpt body readies 16-point infra upgrade list
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Visakhapatnam Development Council ( VDC ) has prepared a 16-point suggestion list for the state government and Greater Visakhapatnam Municipality Corporation ( GVMC ) on the infrstructure upgrade needed in Visakhapatnam before it becomes one of the capital cities.

“The city needs to be upgraded as per requisite of a state capital,” Uday Kiran Patta, youth president of VDC told TOI.

The suggestions include drinking water, need for footbridges at important junctions, upgradation of government health and education facilities, development of industries, introduction of metro rail and electric-run environment friendly public transport system, direct air connectivity between Visakhapatnam and five major capitals in the world and a proper nightlife.

Title: Delhi elections: Volunteers save day for differently-abled
Content:
Young volunteers rose to the occasion to make polling a reasonably comfortable experience for the wheelchair-b... Read More

NEW DELHI: Young volunteers rose to the occasion to make polling a reasonably comfortable experience for the wheelchair-bound and ageing voters . The capital has taken the lead in making elections accessible, but a visit to some polling stations revealed the distance yet to be travelled to make elections disabled- and age-friendly.It is no surprise that the polling centre at the Leprosy Complex in northeast Delhi’s Tahirpur area would have a high number of voters who suffer from leprosy and are wheelchair-bound. Volunteers didn’t have a moment to breathe as they wheeled-in one voter after another, hampered by insufficient numbers of wheelchairs and one even non-functional.“Given the centre’s location, there should have been large numbers of wheelchairs and volunteers. We feel bad since there are only so many voters we can help at a time,” said a volunteer who didn’t wish to be identified. “One wheelchair is damaged, making our jobs tougher,” he said.“I don’t have a leg and I have been in queue for over an hour. There should be some special facilities for us so that we don’t have to stand for so long in queues,” said Rehman (40), a resident of the complex. Phool Chand (35), who has lost his fingers and legs to leprosy, sat on the floor helpless, waiting for the crowd to thin so he could crawl his way into the booth. “Volunteers are all busy, there is no one to help me and I don’t know how long I will have to wait,”he said, watching the few volunteers running around.In RK Puram, too it was left to the volunteers who had to compensate for the lack of a ramp at a booth. Disabled voters had to be aided to climb a few stairs before they could be ferried on wheelchairs.A 65-year-old man with a fractured leg spoke highly of the volunteers in his Laxmi Nagar booth. “I was undecided about going to vote, but my family helped me go. And volunteers immediately helped once I reached, taking me in a wheelchair to the booth.”Across the city in Madangir, Poonam Devi, partially paralysed for five years, was helped by her husband Laxmi Narayan to reach her poll station. Her speech impaired, she was helped as she walked to the booth and cast her vote. The election commission had earlier announced a pick-and-drop facility for ageing voters who had no one to bring them to polling booths.

Title: Don’t question our nationalism, Aasu hits back at PM over CAA
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

GUWAHATI: A day after Prime Minister Narendra Modi said in Kokrajhar that there have been attempts to mislead the people of Assam and the northeast over the CAA, All Assam Students’ Union ( Aasu ) chief adviser Samujjal Bhattacharyya hit back at the PM on Saturday by saying that people opposing CAA are more patriotic than those supporting the Act.

Addressing an anti-CAA rally at Pathsala in lower Assam’s Barpeta district, Bhattacharyya said people voicing concern over CAA love their state and their nationalism and affection for the nation cannot be questioned.

He added that the Centre cannot “bargain with anti-CAA agitators” by granting constitutional safeguards to the indigenous communities of Assam by implementing Clause 6 of the Assam Accord.

On Saturday, Aasu and 30 other allied organisations took out torch rallies against CAA across district headquarters of the state. Significantly, AGP MLA and party vice-president Pabindra Kumar Deka also joined the protest rally.

Title: Delhi elections: How these booths made women voters feel special
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

At a station in Uttam Nagar, voters were given tokens and instead of standing in a queue, they were asked to s... Read More

NEW DELHI: From providing tokens and seats to voters to all-women and all-disabled teams managing polling stations—there were several special and model polling stations set up by the Election Commission this assembly polls. While there were a total of 70 ‘pink’ stations with waiting areas, creches and first-aid rooms, the west Delhi constituency had some ‘special’ stations.

In Uttam Nagar constituency, Nigam Pratibha Vidyalaya stood out from a distance. Covered in pink balloons and red carpets, the booth resembled a wedding venue. Those entering were being provided ‘tokens’ and instead of standing in a queue, voters were asked to take a seat. They were allowed to go inside and vote based on their token numbers that were getting displayed on large screens. The exercise was aimed at reducing the waiting time, said an official.

Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections

Ravinder Kumar, a resident of Bindapur, said that the idea was novel and should have been replicated across more polling stations.

Voters could also get ‘mehendi’ applied on their hands here. In another corner, schoolchildren were busy exhibiting their projects.

The government senior secondary co-ed school in Dwarka’s Sector-22 had only women inside, while the polling team at Oxford Public School in Vikaspuri only included disabled staff.

At the Kirara polling booth, an inflatable outdoor bouncing carnival ride kept the kids busy as the parents went inside to cast their votes. Selfie stations were a huge hit and the women voters even got a tiny teddy memento as a return gift. “Never expected anything like that,” said 41-year-old Deepa Gupta.

Title: Coronavirus scare: 50 Goan seafarers could be on board quarantined ship
Content:
Representative Image

MARGAO: Anxiety gripped the families of several Goan seafarers on Saturday following reports that among the 300 persons onboard the cruise ship Diamond Princess, quarantined off the coast of Japan , several are Goans. By some estimates, up to 50 Goans are onboard.Japanese authorities, it is learnt, have quarantined a large number of people onboard the ship as a preventive measure against coronavirus as the vessel is reported to have travelled to Japan from China.Commissioner of NRI affairs Narendra Sawaikar said that while details are awaited, the Union government was keeping a close watch on the emerging situation.Union minister for external affairs S Jaishankar said that as per information from the Indian embassy, no Indian has tested positive.“Many Indian crew & some Indian passengers are onboard the cruise ship #DiamondPrincess quarantined off Japan due to #coronavirus. None have tested positive, as per the latest information provided by our Embassy @IndianEmbTokyo. We are closely following the developments,” minister for external affairs S Jaishankar posted on his Twitter account.Sawaikar responded to Jaishankar’s tweet stating that of the 300 Indians onboard the ship, 50 were Goans.Dixon Vaz of the Goan Seafarers Association of India said that while information pertaining to the number of Goans aboard the shop was yet not known, he urged all seafarers joining the ships to carry with them sufficient face masks and protective gear.Meanwhile, in a video that has been widely circulated, a person identifying himself as a crew member aboard Diamond Princess is seen urging PM Narendra Modi to intervene and save their lives.

Title: SDRF rescues nine stranded people in Uttarkashi
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

UTTARKASHI: The State Disaster Response Force (SDRF) rescued nine members of a cultural group from Radi-Kafnol region in Uttarkashi district on Friday night after the vehicle they were travelling in got stranded due to a thick blanket of snow and frost on the road. All the nine locals were escorted to their homes on Saturday morning after being administered primary treatment at Barkot health centre.

According to sources, the cultural group was returning to Chinyalisaur from Kafnol village on Friday night after giving a cultural performance at an event organised under Centre’s Indra Dhanush scheme.

Howver, they got stranded in the snow and after some attempts, managed to reach out to SDRF personnel who went to the spot and rescued them.

All the nine persons, who were in bad shape due to hunger, thirst, and severe cold were later sent to Barkot health centre for primary treatment.

Sub inspector (SI) Manmohan Singh, leader of the SDRF's rescue team, told TOI, “All of the local residents are safe and doctors have sent them back to their homes after primary treatment.

At a station in Uttam Nagar, voters were given tokens and instead of standing in a queue, they were asked to s... Read More

Title: Sunshine in my drink
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Chennai: Some time ago, the West discovered turmeric latte, the ‘haldi doodh’ grandmothers believed was the panacea for all ailments on account of its anti-inflammatory properties. And now, Indian mixologists are using the golden powder to create drinks of a different kind — turmeric cocktails, which are now the buzz in bars across the country and abroad.

When Kiron Kumar, director, food and beverage, The Park Chennai, wanted to do something different for Pongal, he came up with the idea of creating ‘ayurvedic cocktails’. The ‘spiritual high’ menu features ‘underground magic’ – a drink made of turmeric-infused handmade gluten-free vodka, carrot juice, honey, fresh lime, and angostura bitters.

"We used ingredients commonly used in Ayurveda, such as sandalwood, nannari, and turmeric to create cocktails," says Kumar, adding that though each ingredient has medicinal qualities, it changes once alcohol is added.

"We use the root to give the cocktail an earthy flavour, and fresh aroma," says Kumar, adding that it works well with neutral spirits, such as vodka. "They don’t have a specific flavour profile, so they pick up any flavour added to it."

‘Golden rain’ is the signature cocktail at Mumbai-based Talli Turmeric, said to be the country’s first turmeric-centric restaurant. "It’s a mix of vodka, turmeric syrup (equal parts of turmeric powder and water), all-spice syrup (cardamom, star anise and cloves), lime juice and a dash of Angostura bitters," says Mansij Vaidya, co-founder, Innovative Culinary Concept He says the place uses 100% organic turmeric powder.

"We believe in championing the golden spice, so we wanted to let it shine not only in our food but also in our cocktails. Turmeric adds a distinctive edge to the taste of the cocktail and lends the drink it’s signature yellow shade," he says, adding that turmeric as an ingredient is so versatile, it has the potential of working well with all kinds of cocktails.

Chipstead at Taj Coromandel also offers ‘Curcumin indianna’ on request. Pomegranate juice is mixed with the turmeric paste (collected from the root) and cooked along with jaggery to convert it into a thick syrup used as the sweetener. "This cocktail was basically made to make Campari a favourite drink among the masses. The addition of Indian ingredients like jaggery and turmeric were used to bring more traditional flavours and aromas to the cocktail," says Arun Kumar D, bar supervisor.

City-based beverage consultant Harinath Shankar has worked with the golden ingredient while crafting the drinks menu at Barracuda Brew, which opened in Nungambakkam a month ago. The concept of the bar is to go back to the roots of Madras and see how culture evolved around food and drinks. "We found that seven spices — pepper, chillies, cardamom, cloves, nutmeg, mace, and turmeric — were exported from Madras to the rest of the world, so we took the spices as heroes and made drinks around them," he says.

Title: Chennai: Olive Ridley season begins on bright note, 6 juveniles spotted
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

An injured turtle being treated at a hatchery in Chennai.

CHENNAI: Sea turtle conservationists are a happy lot this season. The sighting of half-a-dozen juvenile Olive Ridleys along the city’s coast in just over a fortnight has given rise to hope that there are more to come.

Shravan Krishnan, a member of the Students Sea Turtle Conservation Netrwork (SSTCN), said it was injured adult turtles with three flippers that normally wash ashore before being treated and released back into the sea. This year, in a reversal of trends, more juvenile turtles with injuries have been coming to the shore and this is a good sign, Shravan said.

The number of dead Olive Ridleys getting washed ashore is also relatively less compared to last year. The situation in 2018 was worse when the season began with a high number of dead turtles washing along the coast in the city, plunging conservationists into gloom.

Principal chief conservator of forests and head of the forest department P Durairasu said that from the 72 nests identified along the Marina and Elliot’s beaches the department had collected 8,141 eggs and placed them in the department’s hatchery in Besant Nagar. Besides, the 24 nests in Pulicat on the Tamil Nadu-Andhra Pradesh border had disgorged 2,738 eggs. Pulicat is one of the hotspots where turtles have been able to lay eggs without human disturbance, he said.

Forest officials and volunteers will soon get busy as the number of nesting turtles coming to shore slowly increases. The turtles will lay eggs that will take between 45 days and 60 days to hatch and the hatchlings will be released into the sea, Durairasu said. Anti-poaching watchers of the department and SSTCN volunteers have divided the walking time among themselves, ensuring that the entire coastline of the city is covered, Durairasu said. While the SSTCN volunteers walk between 11pm and 2am, the anti-poaching watchers walk between 3am and 6am, he said.

However, the authorities concerned have a big role to play in implementing the rules, say conservationists, adding that trawlers, whose nets pose the biggest threat to Olive Ridleys, should not be allowed to fish within five nautical miles of the shoreline. The fisheries department needs to be vigilant and should penalise anyone found violating this rule, they added.

“If this is strictly monitored the turtles can safely come and lay the eggs in the shore,” said one activist.

The turtles mate in November while females begin coming to the shore to lay eggs in January, heralding the start of the nesting season.

Title: Rivals exchange blows over CAA at Kolkata book fair
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

KOLKATA: A scuffle broke out between anti-citizenship law protesters and BJP supporters at the Kolkata book fair on Saturday after a senior functionary from the saffron party visited a stall there.

The two sides exchanged blows after West Bengal BJP member Rahul Sinha entered the stall early in the evening. A group of Left-backed students surrounded Sinha when he visited the counter, and raised slogans against the CAA and NRC. Police confirmed the incident and said a number of protesters were detained. BJP supporters claimed one of them suffered injuries in the tussle.

The clashes apart, the CAA-NRC episode has had a positive effect as well, with books themed on the topic selling like hot cakes at the fair and in stores. Niche publications that print books on current affairs and little magazines that usually struggle to survive are making the most of the spike in interest about the CAA, NRC and NPR , fuelled by the ongoing nationwide protests.

Nearly all the publications have come out with is sues focusing on these topics in December and January and these are flying off the shelves at the fair and at stores across Bengal’s capital.

Almost all these books are paperbacks and priced between Rs 15 and Rs 50. An obvious example is ‘The Saga of Assam ’s National Register of Citizens (NRC)’, a book that had been gathering dust on a shelf at Parchment Books in Kalighat for months, but saw all its five copies getting sold within 48 hours of the passage of CAA.

The seller called the publisher to order more, only to learn that no more copies were available. The scenes are similar at various other book stores across the city.

Bookstore owners said that besides their regular customers, mostly students and researchers are buying these books.

With inputs from PTI

Title: HC calls for poromboke land survey, encroachment details
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Chennai: Madras high court has called for details of poromboke lands available district-wise, and directed officials to furnish the extent of encroachments and explain action taken against government law officers and other officials who fail to properly defend and protect public properties. They shall also explain the proceedings pending before various courts to retrieve the public lands.

A direction to this effect was issued by a division bench of Justice N Kirubakaran and Justice Pongiappan, while hearing a writ petition filed by S V Subbiah.

“This court is of the view that this case is only the tip of the iceberg. There are many government properties and poromboke lands being knocked away by private parties and land grabbers by using political influence, money power, muscle power and in collusion with government officials. The value of the lands has now gone up and therefore, the lands have to be preserved for public purposes. Otherwise, the land grabbers will swallow the properties and unjustly enrich themselves.”

Petitioner Subbiah sought a direction to the Bar Council of Tamil Nadu and Puducherry to expeditiously complete inquiry against K Damodaran. The government advocate failed to file the written submissions despite several adjournments in a case where one TP Ramaraj tried to put up a construction in the natham land at Marchanayakkanpalayam village near Anaimalai in Pollachi taluk.

After Ramaraj’s construction on the natham land was prohibited by the sub-collector in January 2018, he filed a suit before the district court, making only government officials as defendants in the suit and seeking a decree declaring that he is the absolute owner of the suit property.

The bench pointed out that inspite of many opportunities given to the official respondents from March 14, 2018 to September 24, 2019, no written statement was filed and therefore, the official respondents were set ex-parte in the suit. After several adjournments, trial court posted the case for judgment on February 10.

The bench said it would not go into the title of the property, but observed that the government pleader's conduct in the case was suspicious. “It seems that he colluded with the plaintiff as a result of which written statement has not been filed,” it said.

Title: BJP moves Telangana high court over K Keshava Rao’s vote in Tukkuguda
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: BJP councillors from Tukkuguda municipality on Saturday approached the Telangana high court and have urged it to declare as invalid, the vote filed by TRS Rajya Sabha member K Keshava Rao in his capacity as ex-officio member in the election conducted to the posts of chairman and vice chairman of the municipality.

“Keshava Rao was elected as a Rajya Sabha member in 2014 prior to the formation of Telangana and authorities had declared that he was elected under AP quota,” the BJP councillors said.

The BJP workers contended that TRS had used his vote during the Tukkuguda municipal chairman election in an unlawful manner only to ensure the victory of its candidates and had, in the process, thwarted chances of candidates from the saffron party which had won more seats in the municipality.

“Our appeals and representations to election officials have fallen on deaf ears. Even the distrcit collector did not intervene,” said M Raju, one of the petitioners said adding: “The officials are working under pressure from TRS regime. Our representation to the state municipal administration secretary too did not yield any result.”

The petitioners said that the saffron party had complained to governor Tamilisai Soundararajan and the central authorities about the alleged unilateral attitude of the election authorities and sought action against them.

Title: Centre is in denial mode about the state of economy: P Chidambaram
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Former Union finance minister P Chidambaram

HYDERABAD: Coming down heavily on the Narendra Modi-led government in the Centre, former Union finance minister P Chidambaram on Saturday said that it is living in a state of denial about the economy , which is like a patient that needs to be admitted into the ICU but is languishing because the doctors are refusing to diagnose the condition.

Delivering a talk on the Union Budget 2020-21 at the Muffakham Jah College of Engineering and Technology here, he said the government would do well to seek advice from former PM Manmohan Singh on getting the economy back on the rails.

“When Manmohan Singh took over as FM, he plainly admitted to the Parliament that the economy was not doing well. He was brave to admit the fact despite him having practically no support in the Cabinet,” Chidambaram said, adding that growth rates have been falling for six successive quarters now and may decline further or remain flat in the next quarter as well.

Chidambaram said the economy is facing two problems. Firstly, people are not spending either because they have no money or are unwilling to loosen their purse strings. Secondly, corporates have hit the pause button on investments despite being cash surplus due to lack of demand, resulting in existing capacities lying idle.

“Manufacturing sector is operating at 70% of capacity and even power units are operating at 55% plant load factor, which means 45% of power plant capacities are lying idle,” he added.

The former minister also accused the Centre of indulging in ‘ tax terrorism’ which led to a successful entrepreneur like Café Coffee Day founder V G Siddhartha committing suicide. “Even the lowest rung officer in the IT department can summon anyone,” he said.

According to Chidambaram, the new I-T rules have complicated the tax structure and do not incentivise savings, which can impact household savings. He also said he was “deeply suspicious” about the government’s motives on LIC as there was no clarity on whether it wanted to list it or divest stake. He added the Budget was not only anti-poor and anti-farmer, it had not provided a roadmap for revival of MSMEs, that have been reeling under the impacts of demonetisation and GST.

Title: Watchman held for murder
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Hyderabad: One person was arrested by Chikadpally police on Saturday for the murder of a security guard. The guard had been stabbed near RTC X-roads on Friday.

The arrested was identified as Praveen Kumar who had allegedly stabbed brother-in-law, G Sagar. Both worked as watchmen at a public sector bank. According to police, Sagar would visit Praveen’s house in his absence due to which the latter started suspecting that Sagar was having an illicit relationship with his wife.

To confirm this, Praveen kept a phone with recording on before leaving his house. Upon return, he found that the phone had recorded Sagar’s voice. Praveen confronted his wife and on Friday night picked up an argument with Sagar and reportedly stabbed him repeatedly. Police have recovered the knife from him. TNN

Title: Woman kills self over alleged harassment
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Hyderabad: A housewife committed suicide due in SR Nagar on Friday night due to alleged harassment by her husband. According to police, there had been a dispute between the woman and her husband over her paying Rs 2 lakh to unknown persons in Chatrinaka.

It was learned that, a few moths back, the unknown accused started blackmailing her and demanding money through social media. Without the knowledge of her husband, she had paid the money. Upon knowing, the husband had filed a case but over the last few days, had been allegedly harassing his wife and demanding the money back. Cops were yet to nab the accused. TNN

Title: Hyderabad: 20-year-old tries to kill self near police station
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 20-year-old attempted to commit suicide by slitting her throat near Jubilee Hills police station on Saturday night after allegedly being rejected by a man, whom she came to know through a social network platform.

The woman had come to the Jubilee Hills police station to file a complaint against the man for cheating but seeing the police was taking time, she went on to take the extreme step. Before that, she had even left a video on her phone.

The woman was admitted to a hospital where her condition is now said to be stable.

Title: Centre denying Telangana of tax share: P Chidambaram
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Former Union finance minister P Chidambaram

Former Union finance minister P Chidambaram said Telangana chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao should realise the duplicity of the BJP-led government at the Centre and claimed that it was depriving Telangana and other states of their legitimate tax devolution. “For the chief minister, Narendra Modi is sometimes a friend and sometimes a foe,” Chidambaram said. The ex-minister also found fault with the Centre for keeping three former chief ministers of Jammu and Kashmir under house arrest. “This is an abomination and an assault on liberty of individuals,” he said.

During the question-answer session, a chartered accountant pointed out to Chidambaram that the figures given out in the budget speech did not match with the PDF document in some cases. “This is a grave lapse. There should be no place for errors. I will raise it in Parliament on Monday,” Chidamabaram said.“The mixing of the halwa probably was not done well,” he said, commenting about the customary halwa ceremony that takes place before the printing of budget documents.

Title: Sudhir Reddy named Musi Corporation chief
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

HYDERABAD: LB Nagar MLA D Sudhir Reddy will be the new chairman of Musi Riverfront Development Corporation . Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao signed the file pertaining to Sudhir Reddy’s appointment on Saturday.

Sudhir Reddy would enjoy cabinet rank and would be in the post for three years. Earlier, chairman Premsingh Rathod had resigned during the assembly elections and the post was lying vacant since then.

Title: Hyderabad: Blaze guts car service centre, Rs 1 crore worth property damaged
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

It took an hour for four fire tenders and 25 firefighters to douse the flames.

HYDERABAD: A short circuit triggered a fire at a car service centre in Musheerabad , damaging three cars partially in the early hours of Saturday. Fire department personnel estimate property worth nearly Rs 1 crore may have been damaged in the blaze.

“We received an alert around 12.15am that a fire broke out at The Mitra Motors, which sells and services Maruti cars, in a G+1 building,” district fire officer Srinivas Reddy said.

According to the official, the fire started on the first floor and spread to the ground, where cars were kept for servicing and repair. “The first floor is for administration work. Furniture and computers were completely gutted after a short circuit triggered the fire. The fire then spread to the ground floor,” the officer added.

Before the fire could spread further, the firefighters controlled the flames due to which only three cars were partially gutted. Four fire tenders and 25 firefighters were rushed to the place and it took them over an hour to completely douse the flames.

Title: Tamil Nadu: 14 new centres in districts under Mahila Shakti scheme
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Tamil Nadu will soon have centres for women under the Mahila Shakti Kendra scheme in 14 more districts . These centres will serve as one-stop support points aimed at empowering rural women with opportunities for skill development, employment, digital literacy, health, and nutrition.

Now, there are centres in Salem, Chennai, Cuddalore, Virudhunagar, Perambalur, Villupuram, Namakkal, Tiruvannamalai, Trichy , Thiruvallur, Ariyalur, Thanjavur, Theni and Vellore. Officials from the department of social welfare said the new centers will help provide better linkages and implementation of women-centric schemes.

They will also give a foothold for the ‘Beti Bachao Beti Padhao’ scheme, aimed at providing education and welfare services to girls in every district. They will provideinformation about women-related schemes to all citizens, though women will be given priority. Each centre will liaise among the local administration, state government and the Union ministry of women and child development for implementing women-centric programmes.

Each centre will have three members who will work with the local bodies and panchayats. Their activities will be supervised by the collector. The funding will be shared by the Centre and state in the ratio of 60:40.

Senior officials from the department said they are awaiting fund sanctions from the government, following which the centers will be established in the next six months. “There are several women who still don’t know their rights or are not aware of the welfare scheme available to them, these centres will benefit all these women. After the 14 are set up we will have set up centres in the remaining districts by next year,” the official said.
