Title: Burn survivor’s health worsens, put on ventilator
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nagpur: 24-year-old Ankita Pisudde , who was set on fire by a stalker on February 3, is on ventilator since Friday evening as her health took a turn for the worse. The accused, Vikesh Nagrale, is now in magisterial custody.

The Orange City Hospital and Research Institute (OCHRI) in city where the lecturer is undergoing treatment for 40% burn injuries declared Ankita’s health status as ‘critical’. A medical bulletin released by the hospital stated that she had respiratory distress and fluctuations in blood pressure.

“She had to be put on ventilator support as her oxygen levels in the blood significantly reduced in view of inhalation injury in lungs. Ankita has been ventilated with 80% oxygen whereas normally 21% is required. She is also on high antibiotics,” the hospital said.

Pisudde, who was working as a contributory lecturer in Hinganghat (Wardha district), was targeted by Nagrale after she complained to her father about the harassment three months ago.

Nagrale, a married man with a child, was nabbed by MIDC Bori police of Nagpur Rural and handed over to their Hinganghat counterparts on the day of the assault. The Hinganghat JMFC court on Saturday sent Nagrale to magisterial custody till February 20.

The accused was in police custody till Saturday. Police have informed the court that they will utilize the remaining nine days of custody at a later date. Nagrale was sent to Wardha jail under tight security from Hinganghat court.

After producing him on February 4, the police interrogated Nagrale till Saturday. He has been slapped with charges for attempt to murder under section 307 of Indian penal code (IPC) and also for setting Ankita on fire under 326A IPC.

Even as prayers are being offered in Ankita’s village Daroda, three men tonsured their heads in Hinganghat for her recovery.

Home minister Anil Deshmukh and city police chief BK Upadhyay visited the private hospital for the second time on Friday to inquire about Ankita’s health. They also looked into the support being provided to her family members.

Along with the family, an officer of the Hinganghat police station and a revenue official have been stationed in the city for any emergency.

It’s learnt that an officer of sub-divisional police officer (SDPO) rank convened a meeting of the villagers at Daroda which is around 12km from Hinganghat. He appealed for peace and harmony among the villagers.

Nagrale’s family too is under police protection.

Title: Revoke CAA unconditionally, stop NRC, NPR: Goa archbishop
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

PANAJI: Archbishop of Goa Filipe Neri Ferrao, on behalf of the Catholic community in Goa, released a strongly-worded statement on Saturday appealing to the Centre to “immediately and unconditionally revoke the Citizenship Amendment Act and desist from implementing the National Register of Citizens and the National Population Register”.

“The very fact that the CAA uses religion goes against the secular fabric of the country,” he said, adding that CAA, NRC and NPR are causing “great concern and anguish” to millions of Indians spread throughout the world.

The archbishop further added that the NRC and the NPR exercises would result in “a direct victimisation” of the underprivileged classes, “particularly the Dalits, adivasis, migrant labourers, nomadic communities and the countless undocumented people who, after having been recognised as worthy citizens and voters for more than 70 years in this great nation, will suddenly run the risk of becoming stateless and candidates for detention camps in their teeming millions”.

Title: Woman gets into scuffle at Tirumala temple, attacks guard
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Tirupati: A 60-year-old woman got into a scuffle with vigilance and security guards of Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams at Lord Venkateswara temple at Tirumala in the early hours on Saturday.

According to TTD sources, the woman entered the temple via the Sarvadarshan queue early in the morning. After she entered the sanctum sanctorum, she began hurling abuse at the Srivari sevaks and other devotees.

Realising that the woman might have a mental disability, pilgrim volunteers escorted her outside. After the Srivari sevaks took the woman outside the ‘Vendi Vakili’ — silver gated entrance — a female security guard then tried to escort the woman outside the Tirumala temple but the 60-year-old woman physically attacked the guard. The female security guard retaliated and allegedly slapped the 60-year-old woman.

A group of vigilance and security guards along with other TTD staff came to the rescue and overpowered the woman and took her outside the temple premises.

It was learnt that senior TTD officials have ordered an internal inquiry into the incident and CCTV footage were checked to verify the sequence of events.

TTD sources said the identity of the woman could not be established as she entered the temple through the Sarvadarshan queue.

Title: Boycott census if it’s not done on caste basis: Patole
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

At a public function, Nana Patole said as the assembly speaker he is in the role of a court judge and advises ... Read More

Yavatmal: Maharashtra assembly speaker Nana Patole on Friday gave a call to boycott the national census to be launched in 2021 if it is not done on the basis of castes. In January, Patole had moved a suo motu resolution in the assembly asking the Centre to include Other Backward Classes (OBC) column in the census. The resolution was passed unanimously.

The caste numbers were last collected under the British in 1931. At the special session of the assembly in January, Patole had said that including the column would help in finding the correct population of the OBCs in the state.

Addressing a public felicitation organized in Yavatmal on Friday, Patole stated that as the assembly speaker he is in the role of a court judge and advises the government on ensuring justice to all sections of society.

Urging people to fight against injustice, the Congress MLA from Sakoli said that though the Constitution has guaranteed equality to all citizens, it hasn’t been achieved so far.

Patole, who had resigned as BJP MP over issues of farmers before joining the Congress, said that his resolve is to fight for genuine cause of farmers. “In 2018, a debt-ridden farmer from Titvi village in Ghatanji tehsil had committed suicide after writing the name of Prime Minister Narendra Modi on a leaf. I visited the bereaved family to console them.

“For me, the chair is not for meeting personal goals but for ensuring justice for the oppressed and needy,” Patole said adding that he has written to the PM in this regard and if needed he would meet him in this regard.

Organizer of the felicitation function Devanand Pawar highlighted contributions of Patole and expressed concern over the irrigation backlog of the region. “Not even 25% of the targeted water is being supplied to farmers from Tapi and Godavari irrigation projects,” he said.

Well-known scholar AH Salunke lauded Patole’s move to resign from BJP over problems of common man.

Later, Patole also chaired a review meeting where he instructed the district administration to mobilize men and machinery to take government’s schemes to the people to solve their problems.

Prominent among those who attended the felicitation function included ex MLAs Vijaya Dhote and Waman Kassawar, Javed Ansari, Vasant Guikhedkar, Dr Dilip Mahale, Nana Gadbaile, Milind Dhurve Chandu Chaudhari and others.

Title: ‘Puducherry makes a good start for heritage tag certification’
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

PUDUCHERRY: Unesco director (New Delhi) Eric Falt said any government ambitious of getting ' heritage city' certification from the international organization must bring together the civil society and private agencies and work in tandem to achieve the goal.

He was here on Saturday to participate in a one-day conference on 'Road to Unesco nomination' organized by the Puducherry town and country planning department and Puducherry planning authority in association with the Indian national trust for art and cultural heritage (Intach), Puducherry chapter.

"It is important to bring together civil society. The government, of course, must lead. The civil society must be fully supported. It is also important to involve the private sector. It will take some time. We made all aware of the challenges ahead," Falt told reporters after the conference.

"I am here to give a few suggestions as we do in other parts of the country for anybody who is interested in the nomination process. We wish you well. You are to a good start, but it will take time," he said.

Chief secretary Ashwani Kumar said the government will commence the process of creating an inventory that will be projected for the 'heritage site' certifications from the international agency.

"It is a technical work. It must be researched and fine-tuned. There are a lot of challenges within the country. We must borrow ideas from the already successful heritage sites like Ahmedabad and Jaipur. The template is available, and we have to modify it based on our unique selling points and create our own template," Kumar said.

He said the town and country planning department will prepare a dossier, take all stakeholders on board, hold discussions at various levels and fine-tune the proposal before presenting it to the government.

Secretary (town and country planning) K Mahesh also underscored the importance of the involvement of the local community in achieving the goal.

"The involvement of the local community is the key to the success of the project. It started in Ahmedabad in 1998. Another important issue is we may be certified as the world heritage site but to sustain and maintain the certification will certainly be a very big challenge without the community’s support. The purpose of this conference is to involve all the stakeholders and experts in achieving our goal,” Mahesh said.

Earlier addressing the conference Falt outlined the guidelines for nomination under the world heritage city. FRAS architect Rabindra Vasavada enlightened the audience on how Ahmedabad was nominated as the first Unesco world heritage city in India.

CEPT University professor (planning) Saswat Bandyopadhyay gave an insight on the heritage-based city development programme in India while Intach co-convenor Ashok Panda and architect A Arul listed out the trust's efforts towards heritage preservation in Puducherry and IIT Madras associate professor (civil) Arun Menon spoke on 'retrofitting' of heritage buildings.

Title: Discontinuing white ration cards poor decision: Yanamala
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Vijayawada: Senior TDP leader and former finance minister Yanamala Ramakrishnudu on Saturday said the state government’s decision to discontinue white ration cards and pensions would affect eligible beneficiaries.

In a statement, the former minister said the government is neglecting the welfare of the people, particularly the poor. In the eight months since coming to power, the government had avoided the payment of Rs 20,872 crore to the people, he said.

He alleged that the government discontinued 19 lakh white ration cards and seven lakh pensions for 26 lakh eligible beneficiaries.

The former minister found fault with the government for closing Anna canteens and distributing benefits to people for festivals and said the government was diverting SC, ST sub-plan for various welfare schemes instead.

Ramakrishnudu said the spirit of development and self-sustainability that marked the state after bifurcation in 2014 had been undone due to the reverse policies of the government.

The former minister said the government was borrowing to fulfil its electoral promises and had borrowed over Rs 40,000 crore in the last eight months and is set to borrow another Rs 20,000 crore.

Title: Kolkata: Doctors webcast coronavirus awareness tips
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: The novel coronavirus (nCoV) outbreak has prompted a group of healthcare professionals start webcasting to create awareness about the virus. Though the virus so far has restricted its reach only to Kerala with three positive cases in India, the doctors who have taken to webcasting said the recent outbreak has the potential to be an international health emergency with widespread morbidity and mortality.“We wanted to reach out to the maximum number of people, disseminating the right kind of information. There are lots of doubt among people, including those in the medical fraternity. Our aim is to educate people without creating panic,” said critical care specialist Arindam Kar of CMRI Kolkata. Kar, who moderated the session along with two other doctors from Kolkata, are among the 11 medics across the country who initiated the campaign on web in association with a pharma major.In Bengal, the health department has so far got 11 swab samples screened. While the result of one sample is still awaited, 10 have tested negative. Despite no positive case in the state till date, the rising death toll in China has triggered panic in Kolkata.The doctors who took part in the webcast are from different specialities — critical care, pulmonology, infectious diseases and clinical microbiology.“Considering the high infectivity of this new strain, not only the suspects but healthcare professionals dealing with such cases need to adhere to safety protocols for themselves,” said patient safety specialist Subhrajyoti Bhowmick of Peerless Hospital. Bhowmick, who recently had a stint with WHO on patient safety, was also part of the webcast, along with clinical microbiologist Debkishor Gupta from Kolkata.The pharma company that initiated the webcast is working on compliance approval so that the video can be uploaded on social networking sites.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Tankers continue to dump sewage into Cooum river
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Sewage dumped on the banks of the river Cooum in Maduravoyal.

CHENNAI: Sewage collected from Ambattur, Vanagaram and Adayalampattu areas in trucks and discharged into Cooum river through stormwater drains is a common sight near Maduravoyal flyover. Such a violation is draining efforts of river restoration work by the government.

An official from Chennai River Restoration Trust (CRRT) said they regularly receive complaints from residents who send photographs of trucks dumping untreated sewage into the stormwater drain network and causeways. The CRRT had identified causeways, Tiruverkadu, Adayalampattu and Maduravoyal where sewage was being let out. Metrowater had planned a mini treatment plant on the banks of the Cooum near Maduravoyal flyover. However, this idea was changed and now the location of the treatment plant has been shifted elsewhere, said the official.

A Metrowater official said to check release of sewage by trucks, closed circuit television cameras (CCTV) were fixed at strategic locations. Monitoring of the CCTV camera footage was entrusted to local civic authorities. Soon after the cameras were installed the monitoring was done properly, but slowly it stopped. Now, there is no one to stop or check these violations, the official said.

Another official said Metrowater is yet to start work on Illam Thorum Inaippu, the scheme that will provide sewage connections to households in extended areas . Once this work is completed the sewage from these areas will be collected and sent to the nearby treatment plant. “At present residents in these areas are dependent on the tankers to collect sewage from the chambers built in the houses. If the tankers are not there then it will become a major issue,” the official said.

A Metrowater official said the sewage tankers are operated by political party cadres. Once the underground sewage system is launched in these areas, then automatically the tanker lorry operations will be stopped. “Till then the local body authorities and police have to keep a vigil on the movement of these tankers. They have to seize vehicles that are found to release untreated sewage into the storm water drains or causeways. Only active monitoring by these two agencies will help in reducing this menace,” he said.

Title: Man booked for Rs50L land fraud, yet to be arrested
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nagpur: A case of cheating and criminal breach of trust was registered by Beltarodi police station after a builder, his partner and another person were allegedly duped to the tune of around Rs50 lakh in a land deal. The case is being probed by the Economic Offences Wing (EOW) of the crime branch.

The case was registered on February 6 but the accused, identified as Shibhu John Mathew, is yet to be arrested.

Mathew, instead of transferring the land, allegedly transferred the ownership to his wife and gave the rest of land to his two sons through gift deeds. It’s learnt Mathew’s wife runs an English coaching class at Hindustan Colony.

It’s learnt that builder Prashant Jhulkantiwar and his partner Dilip Hirani had entered into an agreement to sale with Mathew for a 10,000 sq feet plot at Shankarpur on Beltarodi road in 2006. The duo had paid Rs16 lakh to Mathew as an advance.

The district administration allotted the non-agricultural status to the land in 2007 and also sanctioned a layout there. Later, Jhulkantiwar and Hirani took possession of some plots from Mathew.

The deal was cancelled after the administration reversed its earlier decision. In the meantime, Mathew entered into a similar deal with one Girish Gundawar. Mathew was supposed to sale 30,000 sq feet land to Gundawar for Rs87 lakh. Gundawar had paid Rs34 lakh. After the administration decision, Gundawar too started demanding refund.

Their dispute was earlier was referred to Beltarodi police station when Mathew had lodged a complaint against Jhulkantiwar and Hirani.

An officer of the EOW said that evidence is being collected against the accused and they are also trying to ascertain whether others are involved too.

Title: Gautam Adani meets Naveen Patnaik, talks about Dhamra Port expansion
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Naveen Patnaik

BHUBANESWAR: The Adani Group on Friday assured a huge investment to expand the capacity of its Dhamra Port Company Ltd (DPCL) to 300 million tonne per annum and for other industrial projects. The Adani Group chairman also discussed its investment plans in Odisha in logistics, industrial park, information technology and metal industries.

The issue was discussed when Adani Group chairman Gautam Adani and his son and CEO of Adani Ports and SEZ Limited Karan Adani met chief minister Naveen Patnaik at Naveen Niwas here on Saturday. There was no discussion on the volume of investment. The company is likely to reveal its detailed investment plan during the third edition of Make in Odisha conclave that will be held this year, official sources said.

The chief minister assured all support to the Adani Group in its future projects. He also invited the Adani Group for the conclave, said an official source. The DPCL currently runs two berths to handle dry cargo like iron ore, coal and limestone with a capacity of 25 million tonne per annum (MTPA).

It has already received clearances to expand its capacity to 100 mtpa. According to media reports, the Adani Group plans for a Mundra-like expansion plan at Dhamra. The government has approved a proposal to acquire 274.41 acres of land in the first phase for construction of a commercial airstrip by DPCL in Bhadrak district .

Title: A walk down cradles of West Bengal Renaissance
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Participants at the houses of Iswar Chandra Vidyasagar

KOLKATA: On an overcast Saturday morning, a motley group walked down a 3km stretch to retrace a movement two-and-a-half centuries ago that had reshaped the fate of women, not just in Kolkata or Bengal, but the whole of India.

The Twins Tour (named after twins Arijit and Surajit Dutta), organised in collaboration with Incredible India and ICCR, delved into Bengal Renaissance — a social, cultural, intellectual and artistic movement from the 19th century to the early 20th century that had questioned existing orthodoxies, particularly with respect to women, marriage, the dowry system, the caste system and religion.

The tour began from Amherst Street at the house of Raja Rammohan Roy , considered the father of modern Indian renaissance.

“The property was bought by Roy from Frenchman Francis Mendes for Rs 13,000 around 1815. Its called the Simla House as the neighbourhood is known as Simla. He was the ‘morning star’ of Indian renaissance,” pointed out walk curator Indradeep Narayan Banerjee.

The next stop was around 100 metres down the road at the residence of Iswar Chandra Vidyasagar. After Roy had stopped Sati, Vidyasagar took the next crucial step by promoting widow remarriage. In fact, he was instrumental in arranging the first widow remarriage. Vidyasagar, who was then in Sanskrit College, convinced his friend Ramdhan Takabagish to allow his son Srischandra Vidyaratna Bhattacharya, who was assistant secretary of Sanskrit College at the time, to marry 10-year-old Kalimati, daughter of Brahmanda Mukherjee and Lachmani Devi. This wedding took place on Sunday, December 7, 1856, at 12 Sukeas Street, now 48 Kailash Bose Street, again a short walk from Vidyasagar’s residence. This was the third stop of the tour, the house that once belonged Rajkrishna Banerjee .

Next, the group went to Naba Bidhan, the Brahmo Sabha temple that Keshub Chandra Sen had set up after breaking away from the Brahmo Samaj. Sen was instrumental in setting up Albert College, where the College Street Coffee House is now located. He also started the Victoria School for women that was subsequently relocated to his residence on AJC Bose Road and is now known as Victoria Institution.

“Time permitting, I would have liked to take the group to Bethune School and Balika Brahmo Girls School that had promoted girls’ education. Though Hindu College and Sanskrit College were also a product of Bengal renaissance, they initially welcomed only male students,” Banerjee said.

Title: Darul VC ‘asks’ women to end stir, sparks row
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

MEERUT: Hundreds of students at Islamic seminary Darul Uloom, Deoband held a protest and demanded resignation of vice-chancellor Abul Qasim Nomani over his alleged appeal to Muslim women to call off the anti-CAA protest.

The protest was held at the seminary campus on Friday, prompting Nomani to issue a clarification and disassociate himself from the remark. “I reached out to the agitating students and cleared the confusion over my remark. The issue was resolved,” he said.

It all started when a video of the VC speaking at local peace committee meeting went viral on Friday. In the video clip, he could be heard purportedly urging the women protesting at Eidgah ground to end the protest in wake of the Centre’s clarification on NRC . “I never issued such a statement. Darul Uloom, Deoband has not issued any appeal to end the protests,” Nomani said.

Title: Dwindling catch spurs westward migration of north AP fishermen
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Srikakulam: To reach the shores of the Bay of Bengal, B Laxman must walk only half-a-kilometre from his single-storey house in D Matchylesam village in Srikakulam district. Yet the sea has little to offer the fisherman who migrates with his neighbours to Gujarat every year and spends eight months in a mechanised boat on the Arabian Sea. Migration is mandatory if he is to earn a livelihood.

In 1993, when NT Rama Rao was chief minister of undivided Andhra Pradesh, the government had announced the construction of jetties along the 197-km-long coastline in Srikakulam district. Time passed, the government changed and the state was bifurcated, but the jetties remained only on paper.

For the 35,000-odd fishermen in the region, venturing out to sea on a mechanised boat from the shore along their village remained a dream. Over the years, Laxman and other fishermen learnt how to manouevre mechanised boats and migrated to Gujarat, where their skills were in demand.

“Owing to a lack of jetties here, we can venture out only on small boats and these small boats cannot be beyond a distance of five km from the coast. Fish population within a five km stretch is low due to overfishing and waste from factories. We are left with no other option but to migrate to states such as Gujarat, and even Kerala, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu to earn our livelihood,” Laxman said.

The 18401/18402 Puri-Okha Express reaches Srikakulam Road Station every Sunday at 2.40 pm and departs at 2.42 pm. Every September, Laxman and fishermen from the 104 coastal villages in the district board the train to reach Rajkot. From there, another train takes them to Porbandar, the nearest railway station to the port town of Veraval in western Gujarat.

“We have our dedicated ‘sethji’ (employers who own mechanised boats) who appoint us on a monthly basis. The salary is lucrative. If the catch is good and the ‘sethji’ is impressed, we get tips in the form of cash, cellphones and jewellery,” said C Appa Rao, another fisherman.

A new migrant from the region is first appointed as a cook for seven to eight fishermen, before progressing to the status of ‘khalasi’, sorting and segregating the catch of the day. Within a few years, he learns how to steer the boat and is appointed as an assistant helmsman, and finally a full-time helmsman.

While a cook and a ‘khalasi’ earn between Rs 10,000 to Rs 12,000 a month, an assistant helmsman earns Rs 14,000 to Rs 15,000. The ‘tandal’ or primary helmsman earns between Rs 22,000 to Rs 25,000.

“Although a monthly salary is fixed for us we accept the full payment only after eight months. In between, if ‘sethji’ is happy with the catch he offers us tips. Often he directly sends the tips to my family during Sankranti. Gujarat, especially Veraval port, is a golden duck for us,” said G Rama Rao, another fisherman.

The history of fishermen’s migration from Srikakulam district goes back to 1982, when G Suryanaranaya, a fisherman from Garamandal Mogdalparu village, went to Gujarat for the first time.

Chintapalli Suryanarayana, an advocate and fisheries activist, recollects how his relative from the same village and employed with the Railways was in Gujarat at the time. He informed Suryanarayana about the prospect of fishing in Gujarat and introduced him to a boat owner at Veraval port.

“He was employed and returned with a handsome salary after a few months. The next year, he took along some other fishermen to Gujarat with him. Over the years it became a trend,” added Chintapalli, who also belongs to a fisherman family.

Migration, however, has brought with it its own set of problems. The hunt for a good catch often takes fishermen as far south as the coast of Karnataka and Kerala. Venturing into the sea adjacent to these states requires care, as “the local fishermen don’t allow us to dock our boats on show, and if they do, they take away our catch. We are in trouble if we run out of fuel or develop a technical snag,” said K Raju.

But it is the area north-west of Okha, known as Pak Jalasandhi among local fishermen, that is especially problematic. The territory of Pakistan begins barely 450 km north-west of Okha and “at night when we anchor our boats, we have to be very careful. The boat may drift to Pakistani territory in case of inclement weather. We need to calculate where we drop anchor. Normally, I don’t venture north of Dwaraka after sunset,” said Laxman, who has been helmsman for over 15 years.

Closer home, activists said constructing jetties is not enough, but fishermen need mechanised boats and the money to purchase them.

“The only solution to this is to implement the deep sea fishing policy in Andhra Pradesh. Under this scheme, fishermen would get 50 per cent subsidy to buy mechanised boats,” said Arjilli Dasu, executive director of Fisherfolk Foundation, a community-based organisation for fishermen in Andhra Pradesh.

While the foundation stone for a jetty was recently laid in Srikakulam district, the chief minister has promised to construct more jetties. A draft deep sea fishing policy is ready and needs approval before coming into effect. “It might take some more months or years now,” added Dasu.

Till that time, Laxman and other fishermen from north Andhra have only one road — the Puri-Okha Express from Srikakulam Road Station to Rajkot, and then onwards to Veraval.

Title: Young Delhi shows clarity, conviction at first attempt
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

Title: Kolkata cops to induct dog breed that tracked Osama bin Laden
Content:
Belgian Malinois

KOLKATA: Belgian Malinois , the breed that had helped the US Seal team track Osama bin Laden, will now become the ‘attack’ dogs for Kolkata Police combat force and are likely to be introduced in the new kennel being set up near Nabanna. According to sources, a maximum of 12 such dogs will be acquired for now, taking the total number to 60. One of the dogs, trained outside the state, has already been “inducted for a short time”.“The plan has been on for a long time, but it is finally taking shape. They will be trained by experts outside the state and will take a year before being inducted. The trainers here too need to get acquainted with them,” said an IPS officer.The main reason, claimed sources, to introduce this breed is that they can withstand harsh weather conditions. “Just like our previous decision to start a swimming pool for dogs, this induction too has to do a lot about dogs getting tired too soon. The Malinois is a very sturdy dog and do not get tired too easily. They can travel long distances under challenging conditions. They are rugged and an intelligent breed of dog. They can be used in Indian conditions whereas labradors and German shepherds get exhausted within minutes,” said the officer.CRPF has already inducted Belgian Malinois dogs. The Maharashtra police have also written to the home department and the DGP to procure Belgian Malinois for Naxal-hit areas and for Force One, their elite team that deals with terror activities.The city police dog squad, which is attached to the detective department, comprises 35 dogs of different breeds — labrador, doberman, German shepherd, golden retriever, rottweiler and a beagle. Each dog specialises in one of the five policing categories: narcotics tracking, explosives tracking, crime tracking, search and rescue and guard and assault.

Title: Midday meals vendor was already under radar for poor quality
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nagpur: The food vendor, a local self help group (SHG), which had prepared the midday meals at a Hudkeshwar school where over 30 kids suffered food poisoning, was already under the radar of authorities regarding quality of food.

Shagun Women’s SHG had apparently been chided by the zilla parishad’s education department after its flying squad last month noted that it’s kitchen facility and quality of food were not up to the mark.

Chintaman Vanjari, district’s education officer (primary) said, “A small team had conducted a surprise check on their facilities and the report was not satisfactory.”

He had promised to provide specific details about it to TOI later, as the information was not readily available. Multiple calls to Vanjari later in the evening went unanswered.

Another officer in zilla parishad, under whom the midday meals section too comes, confirmed to TOI that an adverse report about the SHG had been sent and a show-cause notice issued. The ZP team then informed the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) as they were the nodal agency for tender contract.

NMC’s education officer Priti Mishrikotkar admitted that the state’s education department had submitted adverse report against two SHG over quality of mid-day meal served by them. “The education department has served show-cause notice a couple of days ago. I am unable to provide further information as no one will be in office due to it being a Saturday,” said Mishrikotkar.

Additional municipal commissioner Ram Joshi said the NMC has sought report of khichdi from Food and Drugs Administration (FDA). “If the report comes adverse, we will definitely cancel the tender of the particular SHG,” he said.

To a query, Joshi said that last month the NMC had scrapped tenders of two SHGs supplying mid-day meal following adverse reports against them. “Later, they challenged the NMC’s decision in the high court and brought stay,” he said.

Education activist Shahid Sharif said a police complaint has been filed against SHG Shagun for ‘negligence’. “It is a matter of serious concern that a SHG which is already under the scanner for poor quality of food, is allowed to operate freely,” said Sharif.

Title: Delhi polls: In unauthorised colonies, no clear effect of ‘legal tag’
Content:
Voters stand in a queue to cast their votes at a polling booth in Burari constituency of Delhi on Saturday.

NEW DELHI: In January this year, 20 residents of two unauthorised colonies received conveyance deeds under Pradhan Mantri Unauthorised Colonies in Delhi Awas Adhikar Yojana (PM-UDAY) and property registration papers . Some more residents have received conveyance deeds since then and over two lakh residents have registered themselves on the Delhi Development Authority’s web portal While most people living in these colonies said that PM-UDAY is likely to benefit them, they added that it didn’t influence their voting choices.Bakul Chaudhary (32), a resident of Vashisht Enclave, an unauthorised colony in Burari assembly constituency, said that many people would now be willing to buy property in the area. “Voting for this assembly election, however, will be on other issues. Water and power are fine, but for me people blocking roads for months is an issue,” he added.Mithilesh Thakur (33), a resident of Sangam Vihar, said that he wants the law and order situation to improve. “I have not received any benefits of the subsidy on electricity bills as I am a tenant. The next government should also take care of tenants,” he added.Surabhi Devi, a resident of Govindpuri, who was waiting to cast her vote at a school in CR Park, wanted the government to improve the condition of roads in illegal colonies. “Even though the lanes have been paved with concrete, the problem of drainage remains. My vote will go to the party that will make such colonies liveable,” she said.“I will vote for the party that has worked hard in the past few years. From water to electricity, and from good schools to CCTVs, it gave us all basic amenities,” said Anil Jaiswal, a resident of H-Block in Ambedkar Nagar.Mangal, a resident of Uttam Nagar, said: “I will support a party that may help us have a better standard of living. We are thinking of the city first.”

Title: Kolkata: Civic body takes tax arrears burden off new flat buyers
Content:
The new rule will ensure promoters complete a project with all amenities before handing it over to buyers.

TimesView This move will give some relief to property buyers. The KMC should ensure there is no loophole that unscrupulous sellers can use to their advantage.

KOLKATA: Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) will adopt a two-pronged strategy to deal with a section of real estate developers who flout civic rules that ultimately land flat-owners in trouble. First, all tax arrears have to be paid by the builder and not the buyer and second, a buyer cannot be handed possession until the KMC issues a clearance certificate (CC) to the developer.Mayor Firhad Hakim on Saturday asked senior officials in the KMC assessment department to ensure that under no circumstances should an apartment owner be forced to pay property tax that has not been paid prior to registration of the flat. Instead, the land owner or project developer will be held responsible for the outstanding property tax.Hakim was visibly agitated when a senior citizen residing in Behala called him on Saturday and complained of high-handedness by a section of assessment department officials who demanded property tax shown as pending since 2017 while he had received possession of the flat in 2019. Addressing a senior KMC assessment official present in the meeting, Hakim asked why the department had not checked the demand notice carefully before dispatching it to the flat-owner, who did not own the flat then, and hence, could have been a defaulter. Hakim also asked the caller to send an application to his office seeking a remedy.Later, Hakim said officials of the assessment department would be intimated that at the time of issuing outstanding tax notices, they would assess the liabilities of flat-owners vis a vis the land owners or real estate promoters. Hakim also reminded the KMC buildings department officials to ensure that no occupancy certificate was issued from the civic body’s end till a promoter was given a CC by the buildings department.“A section of promoters seek occupancy certificates for selling flats without completing the project. In such cases, the flat buyers, once given possession of flats, find that essential services like water supply or drainage connections are pending. This is gross violation of KMC building rules and under no circumstances we would allow this,” Hakim said.A KMC buildings department official conceded that from now, the civic body would first compel a promoter to apply for a CC and after proper inspection of the site, a proper occupancy certificate would be issued. “If we are satisfied that that the building has been fully complete with all sorts of essential services in place and there is no violation of building rules, we will issue CC to a promoter, following which he can apply for occupancy certificate,” a senior official in the KMC buildings department said.

Title: Delhi elections: BJP will win 48 seats, says Manoj Tiwari; AAP stays guarded
Content:
Manoj Tiwari shows his finger marked with indelible ink after casting vote in New Delhi on Saturday. (Photo: PTI)

NEW DELHI: Senior Bharatiya Janata Party functionaries, including Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari , on Saturday claimed that the exit polls, which predicted a clean sweep for the Aam Aadmi Party, would fail when the votes were counted on February 11.An average of the exit polls predicted that the broom (AAP’s symbol) would sweep Delhi on February 11. Some of the exit polls even predicted that AAP would repeat its 2015 landslide victory when it bagged 67 out of 70 seats.Putting up a brace face, Tiwari claimed that BJP would win 48 seats and form the government in the capital. “All of these exit polls will fail. Save my tweet carefully. BJP will win 48 seats and form the government in Delhi... Please do not search for excuses to blame EVMs,” he tweeted.Delhi BJP MP Parvesh Sahib Singh Verma claimed that BJP would win 50 seats, while 16 seats would go to AAP and four to Congress.Union home minister Amit Shah held a review meeting with Delhi MPs and other party functionaries at the end of polling to analyse the performance of the party at the booth level and get a feedback. The meeting was also attended by party national president Jagat Prakash Nadda. In the extensive election campaign, both Shah and Nadda had claimed that BJP would win more than 45 seats in Delhi.The exit polls boosted AAP’s confidence, which was already hoping to form the next government. “People voted on the basis of work done by AAP even as BJP kept calling chief minister Arvind Kejriwal names and tried to communalise the election. BJP functionaries didn’t discuss the vision of the party and focused on communal politics. I feel that the people of Delhi have given their verdict. It will be out on February 11. I am confident that the results will be better than 2015,” AAP Rajya Sabha MP Sanjay Singh said.AAP functionaries, however, are not letting their guards down about electronic voting machines. Kejriwal called a meeting to review AAP’s performance in the election and directed party functionaries to keep a vigil outside the strong rooms where the EVMs have been stored. AAP workers were also following the movement of EVMs from the polling booths to the strong rooms.Tweeting a video of a DTC bus carrying EVMs standing in the middle of the road, Sanjay Singh urged the Election Commission to take cognisance. The location of the bus was, however, not clear.Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra also rejected the exit polls and said they would turn out to be wrong. “Congress will surprise everyone with its performance,” he said.In Video: AAP set to retain Delhi, third term for Kejriwal, predict exit polls unanimously

Title: Bhopal: Just one in five non-faculty posts at AIIMS is filled up
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Eight years after All India institute of medical sciences (AIIMS) Bhopal was inaugurated, 94.4% of all non-fac... Read More

BHOPAL: Eight years after All India institute of medical sciences (AIIMS) Bhopal was inaugurated, 94.4% of all non-faculty positions are yet to be filled by permanent employees.

RTI activist, Chandra Shekhar Gaur said only 20% of 3,066 permanent posts for non-faculty at the premier institute are filled. This was revealed in reply to an RTI query by Gaur.

“People of Madhya Pradesh and nearby regions will vastly benefit by a fully-functional AIIMS Bhopal ,” said Gaur.

Only 12 of 214 sanctioned posts for senior non-faculty staff is manned by person with permanent post. Important posts like deputy director (administration) and financial advisor were vacant in all important project cell of AIIMS Bhopal, as of December 31, 2019, according to the reply to RTI query. Only 28% of 1,836 group B nursing posts have been filled through permanent appointments.

101 of 398 other group B posts are filled by permanent employees, it includes posts like library and information officer, chief pharmacist, assistant engineer (civil), assistant engineer for vigilance cell (civil), assistant stores officer, CSSD supervisor, assistant administrative officer, medical record officer, among others.

The premier hospital and medical college is functioning with about 6% of its senior administrative posts, about 25% group B posts (assistant in various roles, staff nurses) and only 0.48% of group C posts filled in permanent capacity. Outsourcing and contractual recruitments are the backbone of the institution that was established in 2012, on the lines of AIIMS New Delhi .

Order to start recruitment for non-faculty posts was issued on May 7, 2017.

The delay in appointments are due litigations challenging appointments for various posts in the recent past. When contacted, AIIMS Bhopal and PMSSY officials did not respond.

AIIMS Bhopal hospital is yet to reach is full capacity of 950-bed. Glitches in trauma and emergency care were also highlighted by AIIMS Bhopal president, Dr YK Gupta in a recent visit to the hospital.

Only recently, AIIMS Bhopal governing body approved standing selection committee recommendation to select 48 posts of top faculty positions. The institute has taken services of nine retired consultants.

Recruitment of employees working in contractual and outsourced positions into permanent posts has been a long-standing demand. According to the RTI, one employee in group B posting quit the institute in December 2019, while 8 new posts were filled.

Title: Rs 1,800cr to spice up NRG’s pizza, e-vehicle run in India
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nandish Patel

Ahmedabad: Few years ago, a large Indian corporate was looking to forge a joint venture with US-based Little Caesars for setting up pizza outlets across the country.

When the deal did not materialize, the pizza chain, which has for long been looking for an India foray after rivals like Pizza Hut and Domino’s Pizza captured a major chunk of the business here, turned to US-based entrepreneur Nandish Patel.

For Patel, 35, who holds franchise of Little Caesars in the US, it was an opportunity he had been long waiting for – to take his business to India by selling his favourite pizzas.

“It’s like homecoming for me. Back in the US, the idea of running Little Caesars outlets came to me when my father, who is very conservative in his food habits, kept asking for more after he tasted these pizzas,” said Patel, who hails from Dhandhuka and did his schooling from Ahmedabad.

Last month, the Pennsylvania-headquartered Phoenix Nexus, where Patel is the founder CEO, launched Little Caesars in India with the first outlet opening in Ahmedabad.

“We are not in the business of selling pizzas. We are into the business of ‘feeding families’. The Indian food market is huge, and we want to sell best quality pizzas at a very affordable price,” says Patel.

Phoenix Nexus, which bagged the India franchisee for Gujarat and Maharashtra, plans to roll out about 250 outlets within the next five years by employing 5,000 people in these two states before expanding pan-India.

He joined his family business of road construction before moving to the US in 2012.

“I moved to USA for personal reasons. I was harnessing a dream to do something big and did not want to restrict my capabilities as an individual to attempt and achieve, no matter the challenges. I acquired multiple convenience stores, liquor stores in and around Langhorne during the mid-2010s. It was my chance to learn about the market, the consumers and the new territory,” Nandish Patel says.

The annual turnover of the US business, which includes construction and real estate, is soon going to touch USD 100 million (approx. Rs 700 crore), he adds. Phoenix Nexus presently employs over 1,000 people in India and the US.

Patel’s plans for India are not limited to Little Caesars pizza outlets. He is hungry for more!

BIG PLANS

The company is in the process of lining up capital of about Rs 1,800 crore for expansion in the Indian market over the next decade.

“I want to create more than 30,000 direct and indirect jobs in India over the next decade by investing in different business verticals,” he says. Phoenix Nexus is planning business acquisitions both in India and the US.

He foresees potential in businesses of e-mobility, biodegradable corrosion solutions and corporate gifting, among others.

“I am keen to learn and evolve with changing economic landscape. Humans live to eat and eat to live. I will focus on businesses that will make everyone's lives better,” he says.

Title: Delhi polls: Divided down the middle over local issues, nationalism
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

NEW DELHI: Middle-class voters have always been a key target area for the political parties during any election. This time, too, it wasn’t much different. But all of them weren’t guided by the same issues. While hyper-local issues like better roads and parking dominated some areas, national issues and the country’s safety were more important in a few others.

Many of the voters also admitted that they had switched sides since the last year’s Lok Sabha elections. “My family has long been a BJP supporter but I had voted for AAP last year. This time, all of us are voting for AAP for Delhi’s development,” said Yogesh Kapoor, a resident of Varinder Nagar in west Delhi.

Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections

At Rohini , considered to be a BJP stronghold, there’s a clear divide between AAP’s development and BJP’s patriotic planks. “You can’t ignore that Delhi government has shown that a lot can be achieved with a bit of innovation and positive intent,” said Ramesh Kumar , a Sector 15 resident. His neighbour, Sunil, however, felt sitting BJP MLA Vijender Gupta would increase the margin due to the Modi factor. “We need a fearless leader and not a person who promises freebies.”

Shashank Sharma, a resident of Greater Kailash-I, was also caught between two narratives, but finally decided to go with BJP. “The incidents of violence in December mirrored the lack of security in the capital. Development always comes after national security,” Sharma said. But Amit Malhotra of Defence Colony voted for the candidate who “can bring more development”.

S M Duggal, a senior citizen, said people were clearly divided between the state and the nation. “For the past few years, Delhi has mostly been about freebies and nothing more,” said Duggal, who voted with his wife and son at a government school in Vasant Kunj .

But Navneet Singh of Janakpuri’s C Block was sure that welfare schemes at the state level would be the deciding factor. “A friend had a major accident a month ago and got free treatment at a private hospital. It saved him. There are several other schemes that have been introduced by AAP for the benefit of everyone,” he said.

Title: Delhi assembly polls: Muslims vote against ‘divisive’ politics
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

NEW DELHI: Safety, peace and development were the three main factors that were considered by Delhi’s Muslims when they came out to vote on Saturday. Several members of the community admitted that they would vote “strategically” to defeat divisive politics, while affirming that Aam Aadmi Party had gained their confidence over the past five years.

In most Muslim-dominated belts in Chandni Chowk , northeast and east Delhi, AAP emerged the clear choice, especially among women who lauded the party for providing electricity, water and healthcare at subsidised rates.

“Over the last five years, there have been noticeable changes in the basic infrastructure in the health and education sector in our area. Our country can be strong only when we have an educated government, whose priorities reflect the aspirations of the common people,” said Farheen, who cast her vote in northeast Delhi’s Seelampur where Chowdhary Mateen Ahmed of Congress is fighting a new AAP candidate, Abdul Rehman . The BJP candidate is Kaushal Mishra.

Some people, however, hinted that Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the communally charged election campaign became reasons for a slight shift towards Congress, which was the only party to take a strong position against the “discriminatory” law.

“We need a strong leader right now, who would not be afraid of becoming our voice. Addressing basic necessities is important, but the fight is for survival right now. We need someone who is not scared of lathis,” said 41-year-old Mohammad Yasin Khan. A divide was visible within the men as well, with those younger than 30 supporting “politics of change”.

At Seemapuri, 24-year-old Faizan, who is preparing for civil services, said his vote “had nothing to do with national issues.” “We may support a prominent national party in Lok Sabha, but in these elections only local issues matter. And only one party has spoken about their plan for Delhi,” he added.

The highly polarised environment was not lost on the candidates either. In Chandni Chowk, AAP’s Parlad Singh Sawhney was contesting against Congress’s Alka Lamba , who had supported the anti-CAA protests at Jama Masjid when she arrived to lend support to Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad late in December. And some voters said they still remember that image.

At Ballimaran, former environment minister Imran Hussain was against Congress veteran Haroon Yusuf . Despite getting nearly 60% of the votes in 2015, Hussain hoped to race ahead as many in Old Delhi were supportive of Kejriwal.

All five polling stations at Shaheen Bagh , which has been a hub of anti-CAA protests, were declared “critical” by Delhi’s Chief Electoral Officer. As voters lined up for long hours to exercise their franchise, they made their discontent with CAA apparent and said they voted for “development”.

Nida Shaheen, a first-time voter, said, “AAP is doing a lot for improving the quality of education in government schools and healthcare facilities through mohalla clinics. No state government in Delhi ever thought about these issues before.”

At Jamia Nagar, Zubeda Sheikh reiterated Shaheen’s words. She pointed out the poor sanitation condition in the area due to negligence of the municipality, which is governed by BJP. “Our councillor is putting his best efforts, but unless the municipal staff works efficiently one can’t expect the situation to improve,” she added.

Abeeda and her daughter had reached a polling booth in south Delhi’s Malviya Nagar to vote for “peace”. “This was the first time that I was not dictated by my husband or family to cast my vote. I feel strongly for a cause and dragged my daughter along with me. I am against polarisation of votes. I want peace to prevail,” she added.

Title: Delhi: 5-year-old kidnapped from home found dead near dump
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The body of a five-year-old girl , who had been kidnapped from her residence in outer Delhi , was found near a garbage dump in Nihal Vihar. Police said the accused, a juvenile , had been apprehended.

Officers said the juvenile “seemed to be an immature boy who killed the girl in a fit of rage”. Police have not ruled out the possibility of a sexual assault. Postmortem report of the girl is awaited.

At 9.30pm on Friday, police received an information about a girl gone missing from her house. The girl was last seen playing outside her residence. A case of kidnapping was registered. A team of officers searched for the girl through the night but could not find her. On Saturday morning they were informed that the body of the girl had been found at a vacant plot, which was being used as a garbage dump by the local residents.

The girl had been hit by bricks multiple times. Some blood-stained bricks were found by cops. The accused was apprehended on Saturday evening. He told officers that he killed the girl as she would not let him “play games”. “It was a frivolous fight and the minor boy killed her. He said he had slapped her during their earlier fights as well,” an officer involved in the investigation said.

The girl’s father works as a driver and her mother had died a year ago. “I was out at work when I got a call from home asking if I knew where my daughter was or if she was with me. I informed my family that I was at work alone. It was then that we realised that she had gone missing,” the girl’s father said.

“There were brick-hitting marks on the face and skull of the girl,” said A Koan, DCP, Outer.

Title: Kerala govt’s portal leads among states in e-service delivery
Content:
Representative image

KOCHI: Kerala has topped the first-ever national e-service delivery assessment ( NeSDA ) by the department of administrative reforms and public grievances with an overall score of 0.83. Goa with 0.74 and Haryana with 0.68 points have been adjudged second and third while Tamil Nadu with 0.13 stood last in the list of 17 states grouped together.Nine northeast and hill states and six Union Territories were considered separately to ensure fairness.The government portals were assessed based on factors like accessibility, content availability, ease of use, information security, privacy and end-service delivery, service delivery, integrated service delivery and status & request tracking.The initial framework of NeSDA based on Online Service Index (OSI) of UNDESA eGovernment Survey was customized to suit the country’s federal structure.The framework covered sectors like finance, education, labour and social welfare (including health and agriculture). Among the central ministries, the portal for health and family welfare topped with overall score of 0.68. Northeast and hill states were topped by Himachal Pradesh while UTs were led by Andaman & Nicobar Islands.“Kerala government’s portal is designed with the citizen in mind and has single sign-in for both the portal and the ancilliary M-Keralam mobile app. Users can avail services, make utility payments and generate transaction certificates without multiple clicks,” said Sabareesh K, head, e-governance. Another interesting feature is tracebilty, which helps citizens track the file movement and integration with e-office. Kerala.gov.in, with content in both Malayalam and English, emerged as the leading state in content availability. But it lost leadership in two key parameters — information security and end service delivery — to Goa and Telengana .“We could not document everything in time. The process of evaluation was itself around four stages with 700 fields in single questionnaire. Out of the 46 mandatory services, we could provide data only for 36,” said Sabareesh. The portal provides more than 60 services spanning nine departments. It is disabled-friendly and has been integrated with services of e-districts. It would be able to provide more than 400 services once government departments begin providing timely APIs that support real time system interaction and data access, officials said.

Title: NPR tweet by Karnataka BJP sparks a row
Content:
"Kaagaz Nahi Dikayenge Hum" ! ! ! Keep the documents safe, you will need to show them again during #NPR exercise.… https://t.co/nJZ6G0PjAm — BJP Karnataka (@BJP4Karnataka) 1581146141000

NEW DELHI: The Karnataka unit of BJP stirred a controversy on Twitter after it warned women voters to keep their papers ready for the National Population Register ( NPR ) exercise.The official verified handle of Karnataka BJP posted a video, which showed women in hijab in a queue, holding up their voter ID cards as they wait in a queue, seemingly outside a polling station. The video was accompanied by a caption that read, “Kaagaz Nahi Dikayenge Hum!!! Keep the documents safe, you will need to show them again during #NPR exercise. #DelhiPolls2020”.The tweet had a a reference to a popular poem by writer Varun Grover , which has become a catchphrase of the movement against CAA , NRC and NPR.Political commentator Meghnad, from his verified Twitter handle @Memeghnad wrote, “Either these guys are misleading the public. Or the government is misleading the parliament. Which one is it?”Another user, @CrazyViku, wrote, “To those saying CAA, NPR, NRC has nothing to do with Indian muslims, can they explain why BJP Karnataka’s handle shares video of Muslim women?”

Title: Gujarat: FDI seeks taste of frozen potato items
Content:
Gujarat is the largest producer and exporter of frozen potato-based products in India, particularly french fri... Read More

With the potential growing for manufacture of frozen potato-based products, Gujarat is poised for an inflow of foreign investments. Several European and American companies are looking to invest in manufacturing facilities for frozen potato-based products or in the food processing equipment sector."Foreign players are looking to invest in Gujarat because of the availability of process-variety potatoes. Investment from several European companies alone in the equipment, manufacturing and allied sectors is pegged at 200 million euros (More than Rs 1,500 crore) in Gujarat in the next two years," said Paul Oosterlaken, director, Kiremko, a Dutch food processing equipment manufacturing company.Gujarat is already the largest producer and exporter of frozen potato-based products in India, particularly french fries . With easy availability of processing variety of potato in the state, several domestic companies are growing and expanding, say industry stakeholders."In the food processing equipment sector, we are looking to invest roughly 35 million euros in the coming year and a half. Foreign companies are looking to invest in Gujarat, because it may be easily used as a production hub and supplier for processed potato products," Oosterlaken further said."Kiremko is also working to install flake manufacturing equipment in units at Mehsana, Vadnagar and Visnagar," said a senior company executive.Industry sources revealed that other firms are also eyeing investments in the state. "McCain is already an established player in the state. That apart, an American company is also eyeing investments in the state, whose representatives recently visited the state," said a well-placed source."Gujarat is an ideal location for cultivation of processing potatoes, it is likely to attract more investments in the sector. There is a rising demand for frozen potato-based products globally. Against the global market size of 15 million metric tonne for frozen potato-based products, Indian exports are barely scratching the surface," said Haresh Karamchandani, CEO, HyFun Foods, which manufactures frozen potato food products at Mehsana.

Title: BU prof looking for coronavirus vaccine hospitalized in Kolkata
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Bhopal: A professor of Bhopal’s Barkatullah University, who was heading an investigative project on a potential coronavirus vaccine, has fallen sick during a tour to Kolkata and is said to be in a critical condition.

Ashok Munjal, senior professor heading BU’s department of biochemistry and genetics, and his three-member team were working on the pattern of spread and possible source of infection of the novel coronavirus (nCoV) outbreak in China. “We found that though the bat is a major host for the virus, the role of other wild animals — like Sika deer, green peacock (an indigenous Chinese peacock), and masked palm civet — in spreading the infection can’t be ruled out. We are also investigating how a potential vaccine may be prepared as soon as possible,” said assistant professor Dr Rekha Khandia, who works with Prof Munjal.

“He was already working on the genomics and immunoinformatics part with bat viruses, including Nipah. As soon as it started in Wuhan city, it caught our attention. Zoonotic viruses are our field of work,” she said, calling Munjal an “extremely good HOD, colleague and person”.

Unlike its cousin SARS, nCoV spreads much faster. Prof Munjal’s team studied 45 animals that are reported to be sold in Wuhan’s wet market.

Investigations have shown a possible link between masked palm civet, which was reported to be the host of SARS virus, and the nCoV epidemic. Sika deer, green peafowl and duck-billed platypus were also found to be potential hosts harbouring nCoV, Munjal’s research says.

The virus may have been transmitted from infected animals to humans through aerosols created during slaughter of the animals as well from their nasal and fecal secretions, the study says. “In Wuhan’s wet market, animal are kept in crowded cages and share space with animals of other species as well. Body discharges, like nasal secretions and urine of diseased animals, act as the source for infection to spread to other stressed animals,” says research, pointing out that animals are often slaughtered in front of consumers, opening another channel of infection.

Title: Co-op society installs an RO plant for 19 villages
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Madurai: People of Paganeri and other surrounding villages in Sivaganga are a lucky few who have had access to potable drinking water for more than two years now, thanks to a reverse osmosis plant installed in the village by the Paganeri Primary Co-operative Credit Society, which went out of the way to help the villagers.

L Devadoss, who is the chairman of the credit society for a second term, said that though credit societies usually deal with agricultural loans, he had been disturbed by the man hours being lost by a villager to bring water from far off places. During drought, many of them were not been able to pay for packaged drinking water, which was sold for more than Rs 20 a pot.

He had approached the then member of parliament Senthil Nathan of the AIADMK for installing an RO plant in the village. With an allocation of Rs7.80 lakh from the MP’s fund, the plant was installed in Paganeri in 2017. While many panchayats and local bodies did the same and then closed their plant due to lack of maintenance, this plant is going to complete three years of service in March.

“For a five rupee coin we get 10 liters of water, which is the cheapest by all means, and this plant is a big boon,” said Marieswari of Paganeri, adding that she spent more than three hours a day for collecting water before the plant was installed.

The coin operated plant has two sections; school children can take two liters of water for just one rupee. In the last financial year, the plant collected a total of Rs 90,000 by dispensing water, and most of the money was used for the maintenance of the plant. “This year we received about Rs 25,000 as collection. Good rain in the last season has resulted in borewells in our area getting recharged,” said Devadoss.

During summer last year and the previous year, they had been drawing about 5,000 liters of water a day. But since January, the consumption is about 700 to 800 liters per day. The demand is expected to go up as the summer advances. People from 19 villages, which come under this credit society, take water from the plant.

“Our society is 65 years old, and this plant is the reason behind me becoming the chairman of the credit society for the second consecutive time,” said Devadoss, adding that it was the only credit society, which had looked beyond the agricultural needs of people and come forward to help them.

Title: Bengaluru: No cash to pay for littering? Swipe your card
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

BBMP has appointed 228 marshals — while 15 each are deployed at Bellandur and Varthur lakes, the remaining hav... Read More

BENGALURU: Caught throwing garbage or urinating by the roadside? You can now pay the penalty through your debit or credit card.

With most offenders trying to get away by stating they’re not carrying cash to pay spot fine, Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike ( BBMP ) has decided to allow card payments. On Saturday, it distributed point of sale (POS) machines to all marshals appointed by the agency to crack down on those defacing the city.

BBMP has appointed 228 marshals — while 15 each are deployed at Bellandur and Varthur lakes, the remaining have been tasked with keeping an eye on black spots in their respective areas. Currently, the marshals have been collecting money from those violating solid waste management rules by issuing them physical challans. They collect around Rs 10-15 lakh per month as penalty. In several areas, there have been verbal clashes between violators and marshals as the latter could not establish their credentials when questioned.

“But this will change now as the marshals will not only wear uniforms (green) but also issue challans from the hand-held machines,” BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar told STOI. While the penalty for dumping garbage on road is Rs 500, for urinating in public, one has to pay Rs 200.

BBMP on Saturday launched the Sahaaya 2.0 mobile application through which citizens can lodge complaints. The first Sahaaya app was launched in 2016 and received more than 1,000 complaints within one month of its launch. However, later it was dogged by technical glitches. A BBMP official said: The upgraded version of the app is better as a citizen can also register complaints with regard to Bescom, BWSSB, BMRCL, KSPCB and other agencies. “If a complaint is not resolved in a stipulated time, it will be escalated to higher authorities, who will check the complaint based on proof and video. “There is a special feature of geo-tagging. People can track their complaints online from their mobile app,” said Basavaraju S, special commissioner IT and revenue.

Title: Three women from Haryana killed in road accident
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Three women tourists from Haryana were killed when a speeding private bus hit the van in which they were travelling near Thirumangalam in Madurai district on Saturday morning.

The victims have been identified as N Thayar, 62, H Mohali, 70, and S Rathini Devli, 70. Some of the seriously injured were shifted to the Government Rajaji Hospital.

According to police, around 40 tourists from Haryana had come to Madurai to visit southern Tamil Nadu and took a couple of vans to visit Kanyakumari first.

When the vans crossed Thirumangalam at 4am, the driver of one of the vans stopped the vehicle on the roadside at Nesaneri Junction on the Madurai-Tirunelveli four-way road to attend nature’s call. A private bus from Coimbatore proceeding towards Kalakkad, hit the van from behind at around 4.10am. In the impact, the tourist van toppled, injuring at least 15 passengers in the van. The private bus veered and ran over the centre median before coming to a halt on the opposite road.

On being alerted, a police team from the Thirumangalam Taluk station came to the spot and helped shift the injured to the hospital.

Higher police officials too visited the spot later and conducted an inquiry to improve safety measures at the spot.

The Thirumangalam police have registered a case against the bus driver identified as E Premsingh from Kalakkad in Tirunelveli district and an inquiry was conducted.

Title: Coronavirus in Chennai: Chinese tourist tests nCoV negative, opts to return home
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Health officials and a police team escort Chengzu to the Madurai airport.

MADURAI: A 30-year-old tourist from China opted to return to his country after health officials in Ramanathapuram asked him to either remain under isolation for monitoring for two weeks or leave India due to the corona outbreak in China.

His visit created a flutter when he arrived in Rameswaram on Saturday morning. In the evening, he was escorted by health officials to the Madurai international airport, from where he flew to Chennai and is expected to fly to China at the earliest. The tourist was identified as Chengzu, 30, of Anhui, 480km from Wuhan, the epicentre of the outbreak.

“He flew to Kolkata on a tourist visa on January 28. After visiting a few places there he came to Rameswaram on Saturday morning,” Ramanathapuram collector K Veera Raghava Rao told TOI.

He checked in at MCM Towers in Rameswaram. On finding that he had come from China, the staff alerted police. “Public health and revenue officials and police immediately went to the hotel. A team of doctors confirmed that he did not have symptoms of nCoV,” the collector said.

Chengzu was annoyed by the inquiries made by government officials and police.

Meanwhile, the health officials pacified the hotel staff, other tourists and local people, saying there is no need to panic as he is not infected.

Health officials faced difficulty in communicating with him as he was not fluent in English. The officials then used an online translator application.

Since he has already been in India for two weeks, the officials gave him an option to be under quarantine for two more weeks or return home. Though he was upset that he could not visit a few more places in Tamil Nadu, he said he preferred to return to China.

He was escorted by a team of health department personnel and a policeman in a separate vehicle from Rameswaram to the Madurai airport at 2 pm, where he was screened before he was flown to Chennai at 6pm.

Title: Blood donation camp today
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Aurangabad: A blood donation camp is organised from 9 am to 2.30 pm on February 9 at Kali Mata Mandir premises near Kargil Ground.

The camp has been organised by Bengali Association, Aurangabad, in association with Dattaji Bhale Blood Bank. Aurangabad East MLA Atul Save and Anant Pandhare, medical director at Hedgewar Hospital will attend the inauguration ceremony of the camp.

The office-bearers of Bengali Association and Dattaji Bhale Blood Bank have appealed to people to participate in the camp.

AMC staffers fined for spitting in office premises

The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has now taken an austere stand against those found spitting in its premises.

Following the instructions of municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey, head of solid waste management cell Nankishore Bhombe slapped fine of Rs 100 on 19 people, including staffers of the civic body, for spitting in the office premises on Friday.

CMIA invites business ideas

The ministry of micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) has invited applications from startups, technocrats, students, and MSMEs from all over India under the scheme of the office of development commissioner – MSME for ‘support for entrepreneurial and managerial development of MSMEs through incubators’.

The ideas are being invited from innovators, and the incubators or host institutions (HI) approved for the scheme.

Title: Why was TVM neglected, irate residents ask FM
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Soon after finance minister TM Thomas Isaac completed his budget speech on Friday, people protested on roads and social media , claiming that he had neglected the capital while allocating funds. A petition was launched by Sabari Somasekharan Nair to finance minister, chief minister and two local MLAs at change.org that earned over 250 signatures within eight hours.

The petition, which begins with words ‘We didn’t get anything’, questions the allocation for development of Trivandrum Airport (Rs 1 lakh) and the plan to develop Thiruvananthapuram as a metro. “Initially, we thought no major project received funding because of the financial crisis. But another city (Kochi) received Rs 6,000 crore. We had a lot of expectations from budget as it was announced before elections. We didn’t get anything,” states the petition.

Friends of Trivandrum, a collective of city residents, staged dharna in front of Secretariat holding begging bowls, seeking aid for city projects.

Trivandrum Indian, a social media page, in a post shared on Saturday said, “In addition to basic facilities, a city requires development projects which can create job opportunities. If the people representatives are not able to seek funds for developments project, why should be they elected for the post.” Another social media page, Trivandrum Rises, stated that the city was neglected in the budget just like Centre neglected Kerala in its budget.

MLA VS Sivakumar said the MLAs from Thiruvananthapuram will take up the matter with Isaac. “While FM declared several packages for other districts, nothing was proposed for the development of capital. Projects proposed in previous budgets are incomplete. We demand projects for Thiruvananthapuram,” he said.

MLA KS Sabarinadhan said there was nothing wrong in giving Rs 6000 crores to Kochi, but budget completely neglected Thiruvananthapuram. Vizhinjam project, declared during UDF regime, is lagging; Light metro has not seen the light of the day, he wrote on Facebook.

BJP too organized a protest march to Secretariat on Saturday and burned chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan, finance minister Thomas Isaac and tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran in effigies.

BJP district president VV Rajesh said the city was left out by FM’s budget. Many of the ongoing and proposed projects such as Karamana-Kaliyikkavila road development, airport development, coastal area package, Attukal township plan, renovation of city road and Attakulangara overbridge and Light metro either received negligible allocation or were forgotten in the budget.

Representatives of Trivandrum Chamber of Commerce and Industries said that Thiruvananthapuram should get its due as the capital. “I raised this issue with FM. The response that projects will be funded through KIIFB is impractical. Thiruvananthapuram is the capital city and should be given its due. People assess a state by development projects in the capital,” said TCCI president S N Raghuchandran Nair.

Title: For first time in country, Aadhaar details of deceased to be gathered in Virudhunagar
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Virudhunagar: For the first time in the country, work on identifying Aadhaar numbers of deceased people will commence soon as a pilot project in Virudhunagar district, assistant director of the Unique Identification Authority of India (UIADI), Bengaluru, Santhana Gopalan said here on Friday.

Speaking after a meeting on the UIDAI programme, which was presided over by Virudhunagar collector R Kannan, where the functioning of Aadhaar centres in schools were reviewed, he said that Aadhaar cards had become mandatory for all purposes. In the past decade, 128 crore people across India had were distributed the Aadhaar cards. However, till now no steps were taken to gather information on cards belonging to the deceased people. Now, the process of gathering information of such people who had died in the last eight years will be initiated in Virudhunagar district.

Gopalan also said that in Tamil Nadu, children did not have Aadhaar cards as they are linked to the child development scheme and school education department. When the card is obtained for a child below five years biometrics are not recorded. It is mandatory that children who obtain their Aadhaar cards renew them at age five and then again at 15 years, as biometric details including fingerprints are taken then. They would be given a grace period of two years to renew their cards.

In Virudhunagar district, special Aadhaar centres had been established in schools to enable students to get them. Such centres are functioning in 770 schools in the state and in 55 schools in Virudhunagar district. About 75,000 children in Virudhunagar are yet to obtain Aadhaar cards. He also said that about 99.5% of the elders in Tamil Nadu had obtained Aadhaar cards, and there was a need to cover about 28 lakh more.

Gopalan said that a person who needs to change his address can submit any of the 25 documents specified in the UIDAI website. These cards should be obtained only through authorised centres and people should not share copies of their Aadhaar cards with others, he said.

Title: National award winning director says his movie is bringing a change in the society
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

AURANGABAD: Hellaro , a Gujarati movie that was declared as the best feature film at the 66th National Film Awards , is being screened at the Aurangabad International Film Festival (AIFF) among 39 other national and international movies.

Hellaro director Abhishek Shah said that though the movie is set in 1975, it is very much relevant today and is bringing a change in the society gradually.

During his visit to the festival, Shah spoke to TOI about the conception of the film. “In 2016, I came across an old (woman) friend who is working as a manager in a corporate firm. She had not uploaded even a single picture on her social media account. When I asked her about it, she told me that she was not allowed to post her pictures online. This triggered me to make a movie on the issue,” Shah said.

He said that the sense of proprietorship for another human being cannot be accepted and that is what the film is all about. Set in a rural backdrop, Hellaro portrays a group of women who go against the diktat that restricts them from dancing. “The other reason that led me to make this film was that what is destined will happen... may what come. Just like the movie’s title, Hellaro, which means wave that changes everything, the women end up liberating themselves from the diktat imposed on them,” the 37-year-old said.

The movie released in October 2019 continues to be screened in various theatres in Gujarat. Shah said that he received several texts and calls from many women telling him that Hellaro is based on their story. “Men too feel a connection with the film.
