After a screening, a 55-year-old man stood up and said that after watching Hellaro, his conduct towards women in his family has changed,” the director said.

The five-day AIFF will see its finale on Sunday. A panel of movie experts have selected a collection of regional, national and international films for the film fest. Film and art students, movie lovers and enthusiasts have planned to watch various movies and attend classes by film makers.

Title: Lakhs turn up to watch Palani car festival on Thaipoosam
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Madurai: Lakhs of devotees thronged the Palani Dandhayudhapani temple for the car festival, a culminating event of the Thaipoosam festival.

This year the festival began with the flag hoisting at the Periyar Nayagi temple in Palani on February 2 and the deity Sri Muthukumarasamy and his consorts Valli and Devasena were taken around the temple roads in procession in the morning and evening. The celestial wedding was performed on Friday night.

At around 4.30 pm on Saturday the car was taken around the temple roads, and people followed chanting the name of the deity. Devotees were seen carrying different kavadis including ‘paravai kavadi’ where they are suspended with iron hooks pierced into their skin from a pole in cranes or other vehicles. Women were seen carrying milk pots on their heads in a grand procession behind the moving car.

Over 3,000 police personnel were deployed on duty for the festival. Close circuit television cameras were also installed in vantage points and the crowds were monitored. Tonsuring of hair were also performed in many places.

The district administration had made all arrangements in coordination with the temple administration to provide basic amenities to the people. Chief executive officer of the temple Jaya Chandra Banu Reddy, assistant commissioner of the temple Senthilkumar among others monitored the festival.

Title: Grandeur marks float fest in Madurai
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Madurai: Thousands of devotees gathered around the Mariamman Teppakulam on Saturday, when the float of the Sri Meenakshi Sundareswarar Temple was pulled around the brimming tank. The tank was filled with clean water which was brought through its traditional channels from river Vaigai, after nearly 40 years.

The float festival began on January 28 with the flag hoisting and the deities were taken out in a procession on the streets of city, since then. On Saturday, goddess Meenakshi and her consort Lord Sundareswarar were taken out of the temple and around the temple streets at 5.30am.

They were then brought to the grandly decorated float, placed on the pedestal, and taken around the tank twice in the morning.

As per tradition, members of the Devendra Kula Vellalar from Anupanadi village were given the first rights to touch the ropes and initiate the pulling of the float. This tradition has been in vogue for more than 300 years. The ropes were decorated with colourful flowers and people vied with each other to touch them and pull the float around the tank. A large number of foreigners too witnessed the festival.

The central mandapam of the tank was also decorated with colourful lights and it was illuminated in the night when the float was again pulled around the tank.

Two boats under the supervision of the district fire officer, S Kalyan Kumar were also stationed in the tank as a precautionary measure. A large posse of police were deployed on duty.

Joint commissioner of the temple N Natarajan and members of the board of trustees were also present.

Title: Norms for ward reservation violated: Corporators
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Aurangabad: Some corporators and aspirant candidates have alleged that the civic body has violated several norms laid down by the state election commission (EC) while defining the ward boundaries for the upcoming elections

Until Friday, 97 objections were filed for the ward reservations and ward boundaries.

In a letter to to the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation’s election department, the EC had notified the guidelines and criteria to fix ward boundaries. However, some alleged that the municipal wards have been designed to benefit selected individuals.

According to the details from the draft ward formation report in 2005 civic body election, there were 17 wards reserved for scheduled caste (SC), which was based on the 2001 Census. The draw to pick SC wards was initiated from Ambedkar Nagar ward which had a population of 9,124 with 8,197 SC population comprising 89.7% of the total ward population. The SC ward reservation that started from Ambedkar Nagar ward was ended at Kotwalpura ward which had a population of 8,749 which included 2,028 SC population i.e. 23.20%.

From 2010 onwards, wards were reserved according to the descending order of reservation rotation which means it should have been fixed in the descending order of SC population.

In 2010, Wankhede Nagar was reserved as SC ward with a population of 8,057 which included 2,075 SC population comprising 27% of the total population. In 2010, the SC ward reservation ended at Nyay Nagar ward which had 17.41% SC population.

In 2015, the 2011 Cencus was considered forward formation. Therefore, the SC wards increased from 17 to 22. The SC ward reservation started from Cidco N-1-MIDC Chikalthana, with 43.47% SC population. The SC ward reservation ended at Padegaon ward which had 14.34% SC population.

For 2020, the AMC election ward reservation, based on the descending order of reservation rotation the wards with less than 14.34% SC population should have been reserved for SC first and then based on descending order the other SC wards should have been fixed. However, the AMC election department has again reserved Cidco N-1-MIDC Chikalthana ward as an SC ward which now has an SC population of 21.11%. Surewadi and Indiranagar-Baijipura West wards are also reserved for SC category even though they had a relatively lower SC population than other non-SC wards.

The reservation of Surananagar ward is also under suspicion. In 2005, the ward was reserved for OBC, but was left open for all in 2010 and again was reserved for women (general) in 2015. Now, the ward has again been left open. The ward has not received SC reservation for the 4th successive term. The rule to not cross DP road and state highway has also been violated while defining boundaries of Surananagar ward.

AMC election department head Kamlakar Phad said that the EC will take a decision on the objections filed.

Title: ICG seizes 700kg tobacco leaves floating near IMBL
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Madurai: The Indian Coast Guard (ICG) in Ramanathapuram seized 700kg of tobacco leaves that was abandoned by smugglers near Katchatheevu at the International Maritime Boundary Line (IMBL) on Saturday. Preliminary inquiry revealed that the tobacco leaves were smuggled from Ramanathapuram district to Sri Lanka in fishing boats.

On Saturday morning, fishermen from Rameswaram area who were fishing near the IMBL noticed suspicious parcels and informed the ICG camp at Mandapam and police sources. ICG alerted their ship Rani Avantibai that was patrolling near the IMBL. The ship headed to the spot where the bundles were found floating. The bundles were retrieved and handed over to a smaller ICG boat.

The bundles were brought to ICG Mandapam and opened. The personnel said the bundles contained 700kg of tobacco and handed over to the customs department for further inquirys. ICGS patrol ships and boats and fishermen also searched near the IMBL and in the seas near Dhanushkodi, Olaikuda and Vadakadu to check if more bundles were abandoned by the smugglers.

Title: Illegal diamond mines raided in Panna reserve
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Screenshot

Bhopal: After reports of illegal diamond mining in protected forest area near Panna National Park, forest department conducted raids to curb the shallow –mining of precious stones very close to the buffer zone of the park on Friday.

Equipment used for digging were confiscated while the people involved in mining escaped.

A senior forest official said that after years of shallow mining of diamonds in Panna, the precious stones are hard to find in the mines situated outside the jungle. Most such shallow mines are now located on the private lands and farm fields. “Villagers have now started carrying the mining operations right inside the forest. And this, is not possible without connivance of our staff,” he said.

A large number of diamond mines are operated inside the protected area of the forest in Pahadikheda region where Baghin river flows. There are more illegal diamond shallow mines than the number of legal mines leased out by the administration, forest department sources claimed.

Friday-raids were conducted in the Vishramganj forest circle of North forest division of Panna, said Ajay Bajpayee, the sub-divisional officer (Vishramganj range). He said that diesel pump sets, large number of shovels and spade were confiscated. After a tip-off, a team was constituted which conducted the raids, he said.

Almost on regular basis, villagers mine diamonds from the shallow mines in Panna. Their price varies from few lakh rupees to over a crore rupee. The diamonds are auctioned by the administration every three months and the proceeds are handed over to the miner after deducting the royalty.

Title: Relieving back pain, butt numbness for bikers
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

The floating pad with air bubbles adapts to the shape of the rider’s buttocks and evenly distributes air for b... Read More

It was the typical engineers’ journey for the three graduates of National Institute of Technology (NIT) at Surat — Viswanadh Malladi, Santosh Samala and K Madhav Reddy – when they passed out in 2011 and 2012. They opted for corporate jobs and tried to settle in. But it was not their destiny.

"I used to commute about 30km daily to and fro in Hyderabad. On a regular bike – which forms about 70% of the private vehicle owners in India – a long ride is often uncomfortable," recounts Reddy. "For starters, one has to shift positions often on the seat as butt numbness is quite common. Another idea we thought had some potential was of reducing pollution inhalation for the commuters."

Reddy, along with his two seniors sat down literally to find that ‘Eureka!’ moment when they decided to address the uncomfortable ride with technology. The team members cited air suspension technology of advanced buses as an example. "If we reduce the passing of innumerable jerks caused by bad road conditions from vehicle to the rider, it would be possible. Thus, we looked at the options and finally selected the air float tech as a feasible idea," said Samala, adding that it was the birth of Feel Good (Fego) Innovations.

The idea was simple to start with – but the execution was not that easy. They used inflatable material where the user can blow air and can strap the inflated pad to the seat. The floating pad with air bubbles adapts to the shape of the rider’s buttocks and evenly distributes air for better suspension.

The team members said that they received Rs 10 lakh each from government of Gujarat and National Institute of Design (NID) as part of initial funding as a design project.

Reddy said NID sanctioned them Rs 25 lakh, but they had already raised Rs 1 crore from other investors in 2017. "Ours was one of the biggest crowdfunded projects when it was launched. People were hooked to the idea," he added.

The brand ‘Fego,’ based in Hyderabad, currently offers two variants of the air float seats for bikes, and air cushion for cars. "In 2019, we sold about 20,000 units. The number is very encouraging," said Reddy.

Malladi said they are working on a product for commuters that can revolutionize long-distance travel. "Positive feedback by the users on social media sites is the testimony we believe in and that keeps us going," he said.

Title: WhatsApp complaints on food, edible items on the rise
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The Madurai district food safety department has received 209 complaints over WhatsApp related to bad food and sub-standard edible items in 2019, which is one of highest number registered in the state.

Officials said that of the 32 districts, only four districts, including Madurai, had received WhatsApp complaints crossing the 200 mark. They said that it was result of the kind of awareness measures carried out and publicity taken up by pasting stickers at eateries and hotels. In fact, Chennai had received more than 500 complaints, while Kancheepuram received more than 300 complaints. Sources said that of the 209 complaints received, action was taken against the concerned eateries with 24 hours, while action against 29 eateries was taken between 24 and 48 hours. However, all the complaints have been addressed subsequently. WhatsApp method, which was popularized a couple of years ago by the food safety department, is the most preferred means for raising complaints.

Designated officer for food safety, Madurai district, Dr M Somasundaram said that most complaints were related to food served at hotels and eateries. There were fewer complaints in connection with adulteration or substandard food materials. All the complaints were taken seriously and checked at the earliest by pressing the food safety officer for the area concerned, he said.

Officials lifted 88 samples in 2019 from food business operators dealing with various food products of which 77 were sent to laboratories for testing. Of the 77 samples, 36 were found unsafe and 52 did not confirm to the standards set by the Food Safety and Standards Authorities of India. As on December, 2019, 21 civil cases filed by the food safety department were pending before the RDO court. As many as 62 criminal cases were filed from Madurai district, sources said.

Title: Punargeham housing project to take off soon in Kozhikode
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Kozhikode: ‘ Punargeham’ , the housing project of the fisheries department to relocate fishermen families living in the close vicinity of the sea will take off soon in the district. The plan is to construct houses for 210 families in the first phase.

The implementation of the project has been lagging owing to the reluctance of the fishermen families to relocate from their existing homes. However, after much awareness, 210 families have submitted their consent to relocate from the risk prone zones.

The department has received an allocation of Rs 21 crore for the first phase implementation of the project, said an official with the office of the fisheries deputy director. The decision is to spend Rs 10 lakh each for every applicant, said the official.

While the government has decided to allot Rs 6 lakh for purchase of land, the remaining Rs 4 lakh will be used for the construction of house. If it is possible to get land for a lesser price then the excess amount will also be invested for the construction of house.

The fisheries department is introducing the scheme aiming to relocate fishermen and non-fishermen families living in the proximity of the sea to a safer distance in the backdrop of frequent incidents of sea erosion. The unavailability of suitable land for the construction of houses is a major hurdle.

The department is also planning to construct flats on the availability of suitable land. A survey conducted earlier by the fisheries department had identified over 2,609 families living 50m away from the sea.

The plan is to shift the families at least 200m away from the sea as they don’t have to run to safety during every rainy season. The survey was conducted along the 71km stretch of Kozhikode coast from Beypore to Azhiyur aiming to relocate all susceptible families to a safer distance.

According to the survey, over 954 families are living within 10m limit from the sea and are living in high risk areas. “The proximity of houses to the sea increases the worries during cyclones and sea erosion,” said the official with fisheries department.

The fund for the project is allocated from the chief ministers’ Disaster Relief Fund. The officials are expecting positive response from more fishermen families after the completion of the first phase project.

Of the total number of families, only 210 families have expressed their willingness to relocate, said the official adding that the reluctance of the beneficiaries was a major concern.

Title: Civic polls: Parties start search for woman candidates
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Aurangabad: With 58 of the 115 wards in the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) having been reserved for women, political parties have now launched a hunt for woman candidates.

Based on the quota fixed by the Maharashtra government for local bodies, the state election commission reserved 50% of the seats in the civic body for women. In a 115-seat AMC, 58 seats, therefore, are earmarked for women.

However, despite the reservation, local body politics continues to be dominated by men. As soon as the ward reservation declaration was made on Monday, men aspiring to contest from particular wards started planning to field female members from within their families.

While different parties have different criteria for selection, functionaries said the job of a corporator is not an easy one. This is because a corporator must be ready to face irate residents on a daily basis.

Madhuri Adwant-Deshmukh, the BJP corporator from Cidco N-3, N-4 ward and former women and child welfare committee chairperson, said her party selects the candidates through an interview process and based on the elective merit. “Everyone aspiring to contest on a party ticket gets a chance to appear for the interview with the senior party functionaries. The workers of the BJP Mahila Morcha, who have been working for the past several years, are given preference,” Adwant-Deshmukh said.

When asked if the women corporators have the freedom to work, she said that she herself has been working independently without any interference from any family member. “If the party has placed trust on the women, the family members should give them a free hand too,” she said.

Foreseeing a large number of its seats going to the women’s quota, the MIM had launched its state women’s wing just a week before the ward reservation draws were held. Many of the wards, including the ones of the former leader of opposition Zameer Quadri, former group leader Naser Siddiqui and current group leader Gangadhar Dhage have now been reserved for women. Saira Ajmal Khan, the MIM corporator from Chelipura, said the party is not limited to the Muslim community. “The party is looking for experienced, sincere and able women from all communities to represent the wards. The newly formed women’s wing, under the state president, will be making candidate selections,” Khan said.

Shiv Sena office-bearers, including mayor Nandkumar Ghodele, House leader Vikas Jain and former standing committee chairperson Raju Vaidya have had their wards reserved for women for the April AMC elections . Jain, whose ward is now reserved for women in the open category, expects the party to allow his wife to contest from the ward. “This is my fifth term from the Vedantnagar ward. Based on the party decision, my wife or some other candidate will be contesting from the ward for the Shiv Sena,” Jain said.

Title: GHMC first civic body to pass anti-CAA resolution
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC), on Saturday, passed a resolution against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), making it the first civic body in the country to take a stand against CAA . The decision was taken at GHMC ’s council meeting held to approve its budget. The move was supported by corporators from AIMIM and TRS.

Speaking about it, Hyderabad mayor, Bonthu Rammohan said: “Chief minister, K Chandrasekhar Rao has opposed the CAA and we want to stand in solidarity with him. That is why we have passed this resolution.” Asked about implementation of the National Population Register (NPR) exercise he added: “After the resolution is passed in assembly, the procedure (for NPR) will be followed as per the mandate.”

Lauding the move, Hyderabad MP, Asaduddin Owaisi later tweeted: “The resolution was adopted after former mayor & @aimim_national corporator Majid Hussein proposed it & it was accepted by @bonthurammohan...I thank all @aimim_national corporators & must also thank @TelanganaCMO for his support.”

Earlier, the meeting took an ugly turn when AIMIM and BJP corporators clashed with each other over CAA. AIMIM corporators said they would not allow officials to enter their wards if they asked for details pertaining to CAA, NPR or NRC. Their comments did not go down well with their BJP counterparts who accused AIMIM of playing politics over CAA and wasting time during the budget session. “This is a budget session, why is CAA being discussed,” asked BJP’s G Shanker Yadav, corporator from Begum Bazar.

TRS too joined the melee with members demanding a resolution against CAA. “It should be rolled back,” said TRS MLC, M S Prabhakar Rao who was backed by GHMC deputy mayor, Baba Fasiuddin. He called CAA unconstitutional.

Title: Essaying a character role remains her dream
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Sreelatha Namboothiri

Thiruvananthapuram: Veteran actor Sreelatha Namboothiri , who moved with her husband to the city 15 years ago after he took up a new job, said that the warmth and love of residents has won her heart and now the Alappuzha native takes pride in being a resident of the capital.

Sreelatha, who turns 70 on Monday, will celebrate her birthday with the inmates of Gandhi Bhavan at Pathanapuram. “I am happy that God has given me a happy and healthy life and I will celebrate my birthday with 1,000 residents of Gandhi Bhavan,” said Sreelatha who will also receive NL Balakrishnan memorial award , instituted by Gandhi Bhavan, on Monday.

Loved by Keralites for her comedy and mother roles, Sreelatha is still busy with classical music concerts, films , serials and even mimicry. From Padicha kallan to the recent film Ambili, she has done roles big and small and it was music that made her a part of the showbiz.

She remembered how KPAC asked her to sing a song in the late 60s. “I was in Class X when I joined it as a singer. The only eligibility I had was that I had won prizes in music at school festivals. Later playwright Thoppil Bhasi made me act in a drama, Koottukudumbam. This paved the way for my acting career,” she said.

Sreelatha became known for her comedy in films. “I was featured with Adoor Bhasi in 90% of my films. One would be surprised to know that I rejected acting with him when I was approached for Viruthan Shankhu. It was the rejection of a teenager who wished to be the heroine of Prem Nazir and Satyan (laughs...). Finally, I found my place in comedy genre with Bhasi chettan as my pair,” she said.

Sreelatha reminisced that there were no young women back then to do comedy films. “Back then, along with the film plot, there will be a separate comedy track mostly written by Sashikumar or Bhasi chettan. After 10-12 film pairings, Bhasi chettan knew that I had rejected a film with him. He told me that comedy is a permanent space for an actor rather than the heroine and comedians can always win the audience with humorous counters,” she said.

Adoor Bhasi was a mentor who inspired her to love and respect oneself. “He was an example of dedication. Even when he was down with high fever or other ailments on film sets, he would play his role with perfection. For him, Nazir the perfect human being. When gossips were published in newspapers about me and him, I was depressed. He said that gossips reflected my popularity and I should be happy that people are noticing me,” she said.

Sreelatha has an unfulfilled dream, “I always wanted to perform some character roles, but I failed to get them,” she said.

Title: Centre’s health outlay woefully off course for 2.5% of GDP target
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

India will be nowhere near spending the promised 2.5% of GDP on health at the current rate at which budget allocation for health is increasing. The allocation is short by over Rs 55,000 crore going by government’s own projection of what should have been allocated in 2020.

A National Health Mission presentation from 2018, provided a road map for reaching the targeted 2.5% by 2024-25. It calculated that the combined allocation of the centre and states should reach 1.58% of GDP by 2020-21 and 35% of this would have to come from the centre.

By that calculation, the central outlay for 2020-21 ought to have been Rs 1.24 lakh crore. Instead, it is only Rs 69,234 crore or about 56% of what was needed to stay on course.

The health outlay increased by a measly 4.2%, when it needed to go up by 80% to reach the government’s target of Rs 1.24 lakh crore. Similarly, in 2019-20, the calculations show that central allocation for health should have been over Rs 1 lakh crore and that of states Rs 1.86 lakh crore for total public health expenditure to touch 1.4% of GDP.

However, the central allocation of about Rs 66,500 crore fell short by almost Rs 34,000 crore, while the states allocated well over their target (see graphic). Thus, central allocation increased by just 18% in the 2019-20 budget when it had to go up by about 78% to reach the target.

According to RBI ’s study of state budgets, in 2019-20, all states put together allocated Rs 1.97 lakh crore for health, accounting for 75% of the total public expenditure on health. By the government’s projections in the roadmap, states needed to allocate only Rs 1.86 lakh crore.

The pattern was the same in 2018-19 too. States allocated well above their target and accounted for 76% of public health expenditure, while the centre fell short of target and accounted for barely 24% instead of the expected 35%. The roadmap calculated future allocations based on an estimated GDP growth of 7.5% and inflation rate of 4%.

Based on these estimates, the allocation would have to be over Rs 1.5 lakh crore in 2021 22 (next budget) to touch 1.76% of GDP, a more than 100% increase from the current allocation of Rs 69,000 crore, which seems unlikely. Thus the steady increase over the next three years from 1.76% to 1.98% and then 2.22% before reaching 2.5% of GDP by 2024-2025 seems to be averitable pipe dream.

With economic slowdown, there are apprehensions that allocations for sectors like health could fall even further short in the coming years as the government struggles to meet expenditures it cannot cut back on like salaries and pensions. In such a scenario, even maintaining the current level of health spending as a percentage of GDP could prove to be a challenge.

The Comptroller and Auditor General’s report tabled in Parliament last year had also noted that the allocation in 2019-20 was way short of the target of Rs 1 lakh crore allocation for health sector by 2019-20.

Title: Local poll winners vow to better basic amenities
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Trichy: It was a rare occasion of experience-sharing as candidates of the recently-held local body polls met at an interactive workshop organised by ‘Thannatchi’ (self-governance), a registered society, in Trichy on Saturday.

While the successful candidates elected as panchayat presidents and ward members assured to strive for improving the basic amenities in their villages, the unsuccessful ones were encouraged to support and guide the endeavours of their respective elected representatives.

Around 30 candidates from 10 districts, who contested for the posts of panchayat president and ward members, attended the meeting. Former panchayat presidents who have made their villages a model in self-governance spoke.

The new panchayat presidents were encouraged to study and understand the requirements of the respective villages to chalk out area-specific solutions. The unsuccessful candidates were told to continue their social work by serving as a bridge between people and authorities. “Do not worry about the defeat, continue to understand the requirements of your villages. Visit panchayats in other districts and states to emulate the best practices pursued there for sustainable living,” said, R Elango, ex-panchayat president of Kuthambakkam, a model village in Tiruvallur district.

Dream projects of the elected representatives, the demands from the unsuccessful candidates and support system needed to make villages self-sufficient were discussed. K Saravanan, organiser of the event told TOI that the purpose of the interaction is to promote the importance of rural local bodies in villages to address the needs and make a replicable success panchayat model.

“Resolving the existing woes in basic amenities available in my village will be the top priority. Since our villages are rain-fed area, rainwater harvesting will be promoted to address the water needs,” S Jothilakshmi, panchayat president, Theeyathur, Pudukottai district told TOI.

Women representatives were urged to stay independent in executing their duties by ignoring the domination of their spouses. “Motorable roads are the need for our panchayat. Will make efforts to address it,” K Sathyakala, president of Thirukalapatti panchayat, Sivaganga said.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: Nine new corona suspects in Hyderabad hospital, 141 in quarantine
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: As many as nine new suspected cases of the novel coronavirus (nCoV) were reported in the city on Saturday and affected persons were put in isolation facility at Gandhi hospital.“Five others who were tested yesterday were found to be negative. So far samples have been taken from 70 suspected cases of which 62 tested negative, while results are awaited for 8 others,” said Vijay Kumar, state nodal officer for corona.The health department has issued a memo to district collectors to prepare for contact tracing of all people who have come in touch with the people listed by IDSP (integrated disease surveillance programme) for nCoV. So far, 67 people are on the list and contact tracing will be initiated soon, said insiders. The total number of suspected cases in Telangana including the ones who are in home isolation is now at 141. Among them are 8 patients traced by IDSP teams on Saturday.Until now, only people who have travelled to Republic of China or to other affected countries, and those who have come in contact with persons who tested positive were to be monitored. With the new memo everyone who has come in contact with suspected cases with symptoms will be traced and tested. At the state level, the list is received daily from RGIA and central government.“The list of persons will be communicated to the districts from the state IDSP team and district teams are required to ensure that every person in the line list maintains home isolation for 14 days. Based on the directions of state IDSP team, list of persons who came in contact with line listed persons are to be traced and surveillance is to be maintained. It is reiterated that as and when a request is made by the State IDSP team on the above lines, immediate action should be taken,” read the memo. The line list is the list of persons to be monitored, maintained by IDSP team.The memo further explained critical and non-clinical aspects to control and prevent spread of nCoV being followed. The latest memo is in line with instructions issued by the Centre to ensure district level readiness to prevent and control spread of the virus..

Title: School director held for abusing 10-year-old
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The director of an educational institution was arrested for allegedly sexually assaulting a 10-year-old girl. M R Yesodharan , director of Chempazhanthy Sree Narayana International Study Centre, was arrested on charges of abusing the student of a private school in Valiyamala. The school was founded by Yesodharan.

Yesodharan was charged under Sections 7 & 8 (sexual assault) and 9(f) (aggravated sexual assault by someone in the management of an educational institution) of the Pocso Act.

Police said as per the girl’s complaint, Yesodharan abused her at the school during lunch break on Thursday. The child told about the incident to her parents, who filed a complaint before the police on Friday.

“Women officers were sent to record the child’s statement. Two hours later, we subjected the girl for a medical examination and registered a case,” said Valiyamala police station house officer inspector J R Renjith.

The police also produced the girl before the local magistrate, who recorded her sworn statement. The accused was taken into custody from his residence the same night following which his arrest was recorded. On Saturday, the police produced him before the court and remanded in judicial custody. Sources said Yesodharan was involved in a similar case in 2008. A nine-year-old girl had raised abuse allegations against him but the court exonerated him following a trial.

Following Yesodharan’s arrest, cultural affairs minister A K Balan issued a statement on Saturday stating that he has been removed from the post of director of the study centre with immediate effect. tnn

Title: Suspended Chhatarpur SDM in police remand
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Bhopal: The sub-divisional magistrate (SDM), Chhatarpur, Anil Sapkale, who was suspended on Friday, allegedly for hatching a conspiracy to stage an attack on his own office in connivance with the chairman of a private university, was remanded to police custody till February 11.

Amidst heavy police presence, Sapkale was produced in a court of Chhatarpur. Additional SP Jairaj Kuber told TOI that before Sapkale was produced in court, his voice samples were taken. These samples will be sent for forensic tests to confirm the whether the audio clips found in different mobile phones were the same.

Attack on the office of Sapkale by masked men- who have already been arrested- and firing in the air by them, created a sensation. Investigations revealed that Sapkale had connived with chairman of a private university to settle score with the owner of another varsity.

Sapkale was arrested on Friday along with Pushpendra Singh Goutam, chairman of Krishna University in Chattarpur, Javed Akhtar, a state-level office-bearer of BJP’s minority cell, Rajendra Bundela, an associate of Pushpendra, and alleged accomplices Arjun Shriwas and Amit Parmar. He was suspended after his arrest. tnn

Title: In Auli, a three-day skiing extravaganza starts
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Dehradun: The three-day National Skiing and Snowboarding Championship started at Auli in Chamoli district of Garhwal on Saturday. The championship, which is taking place after a gap of three years, will see nearly 300 participants from across the country. It was inaugurated by CM Trivendra Rawat who was accompanied by tourism minister Satpal Maharaj.

The championship has three categories — senior, junior and sub- junior. Participants from 12 states are competing in various events, including Slalom and Giant Slalom (Men/Women/Junior U-21, Junior-18), Giant Slalom (U-16, U-14), Snowboard – Slalom and Giant Slalom (Men/Women), Snowboard – Giant Slalom (Junior U-21, U-18) and Cross Country (Men/Women).

While inaugurating the championship, CM Rawat also announced a separate adventure sports department. “To mark the completion of three years (of BJP government) in the state, we are going to host an adventure sports summit in March. It will be aimed at promoting adventure sports in our state,” said the CM.

Tourism minister Satpal Maharaj said that a masterplan is being prepared for Auli to host winter sport activities. “Presently, teams from Delhi, Bihar, Himachal Pradesh, Karnataka and other states are participating in this event. In the future, our plan is to conduct international events as well, where foreign players in large numbers will come to Auli,” he said. The minister added that possibilities to promote adventure and winter sports at other locations of the state were also being explored.

Title: Meat stalls remain open on Vallalar day
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Trichy: Defying the ban imposed on the sale of meat on Vallalar day on Saturday, meat stalls at Ponmalaipatti falling under the Ponmalai zone of Trichy City Corporation continued their business as usual.

Trichy City Corporation in a circular dated February 5 has ordered all the meat, chicken and seafood stalls in the city to down shutters on the account of Vallalar day on February 8. As per the GO 45 dated January 23, 1980 of the rural development and local administration department, the state government has ordered closure of meat stalls and slaughterhouses on three days annually -- Thiruvalluvar day, Vallalar day and Mahavir Jayanti. The civic body had also warned that legal actions will be taken against the meat stalls that function on the Vallalar day. TNN

Title: ‘Classical music is like Sun, no artificial light can beat its warmth’
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Hariprasad Chaurasia

BHOPAL: One of the best known exponents of flute, Padma Vibhushan Pandit Hariprasad Chaurasia , who was in Bhopal for a performance at MANIT on Saturday, said he is happy to see the youngsters today taking more interest in classical music than the previous generations and performing on stage more confidently.

"It's nice to see the youth take deep interest in classical music. Future of classical music is bright as so many youngsters are learning classical music and performing on stage. They discuss ragas, artistes and have a lot of knowledge about music and its nuances. They are far more confident than we were at their age,” he said.

Enthralling the audience with classical ragas, the maestro added, "Though Western countries are more interested in Indian classical music, the trend is also on the rise in our own country. "Many youngsters are learning classical music through Internet, due to lack of availability of good teachers. Most of the artistes who teach are busy travelling across the US and Europe for concerts, which deprives new learners of proper guidance. For this, I wish the government comes up with a solution and helps budding classical musicians who want to learn from a good teacher."

Commenting on artistes who begin with classical music and then switch over to other genres or opt for television shows to get fame, he said, "That was happening a few years ago, but now students of classical music prefer to make a career in classical music only.

Besides, ups and downs happen everywhere; they are a part of life. Eventually, we all realise that classical music is like Sun. No matter how many artificial lights are invented, nothing can beat the warmth of sunlight. Classical music will never die, no matter how many other kinds of music get popular." The legendary musician concluded his performance with the bhajan 'Vaishnav Jan'.

Title: Probe ordered after convict’s death
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Kannur: DGP (prisons and correctional services) Rishi Raj Singh ordered a probe after Mattannur native NPK Harris was found hanging in the TV room inside the central prison compound on Friday evening. He was serving a life term for the sexual abuse of a minor girl in his family and his involvement in a sex racket. He was awarded life term in July 2008. “DIG (north zone) will conduct an enquiry and submit the report within three days and follow-up measures will be taken accordingly,” said Singh.

Though there were complaints about security measures, including defunct surveillance cameras , prison officials said that the issues were addressed recently. Cameras are in place now. But these are mainly used for inside surveillance and places like TV room are not covered, they added.

In the backdrop of Friday’s suspected suicide, prison officials, including DIG, conducted an internal enquiry and recorded the grievances of some prisoners, especially those in prison in sex abuse cases (including pocso), as there were complaints that such prisoners were often targeted by other prisoners for torture. After studying all complaints, a report would be submitted to the DGP, they said. Incidentally, Singh had visited the prison on the day Harris committed suicide.

Harris’s duty in prison was welfare activities for prisoners. This duty is assigned to inmates who are not troublemakers and hence they are not under much surveillance. This was the reason why nobody may have noticed him and the incident came to light as he failed to turn up in his cell in the evening. Though there is lack of permanent staffers in prison, temporary staff is appointed for work, said officials.

In August 2018, V Soumya, a resident of Pinarayi accused of poisoning her parents and daughter, committed suicide inside the compound of the women’s prison, located next to the central jail. Two officials were suspended in that case. There is complaint that manpower crunch and security deficiencies were not addressed in prisons.

Title: JD(U) MLC for new leadership in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

JD(U) MLC from Bihar, Javed Iqbal Ansari, at Rims in Ranchi on Saturday.

PATNA: As Delhi went to vote in the assembly election on Saturday, focus will now shift to Bihar where former minister and ruling JD(U) MLC Javed Iqbal Ansari caused ripples in the state’s political circles after he called on incarcerated RJD chief Lalu Prasad at Ranchi-based hospital and talked in favour of supporting a “new leadership” in the state. Ansari’s term as MLC is to end on May 23 this year.

Ansari also hinted to quit the JD(U) and support the RJD in future. “Nitish Kumar was a good leader. You all better know what he is today. Bihar needs a new leadership,” he said after meeting Lalu on Saturday.

Sources said Ansari, who was a cabinet minister in a previous government led by Nitish Kumar, met Lalu for around half an hour at Rajendra Institute of Medical Science (Rims). “I was born in politics by Lalu Ji. Both Lalu and former CM Rabri Devi always showered their blessings on me. Currently I am a JD(U) MLC. Even while in JD(U), I used to get blessings of Lalu Ji,” Ansari told media.

To a query, Ansari said, “Bihar requires a ‘yuva netritva’ (young leadership).” It is widely beings considered that he was referring to Lalu’s son Tejashwi Prasad Yadav , who is the RJD chief ministerial candidate in the next election.

Ansari was earlier in the RJD. He had won from Banka assembly seat in 1995, February 2005 and 2010 on the RJD ticket. But he rebelled against the RJD leadership in April-May 2015 along with 12 other MLAs to extend support to then CM Nitish Kumar.

Ansari and two other RJD MLAs -- Samrat Choudhary and Ram Lakhan Ram Raman -- officially quit the RJD and assembly membership on May 18, 2014. A few days later, Ansari and Raman were nominated as MLC from the governor’s quota.

Ansari and Raman were prominent among the 13 RJD MLAs who had earlier proposed to the Speaker to recognize them as a separate group in the assembly. But, later, nine out of the 13 MLAs returned to the RJD. The resignation of the three MLAs had then reduced the RJD’s strength in the 243-member Bihar assembly to 21.

Title: Swine flu makes a comeback in Telangana
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: At a time when a large part of the state’s healthcare machinery is being pressed into action to monitor and quarantine suspected cases of coronavirus Swine flu virus activity has seen a rise in the city. In the last couple of days, 12 cases have been reported at the Gandhi Hospital. Of the 12, five are currently undergoing treatment at the hospital. One patient was admitted on Saturday to the hospital with symptoms of severe respiratory distress.As per latest records available, till January 20, 30 cases of swine flu were reported in the state. Only one death was reported during the period. The solation facility at Fever Hospital has been earmarked for suspected novel cronavirus cases and swine flu cases are being redirected to the Gandhi Hospital. “ There is lot of pressure on the staff. In addition to testing for coronavirus, tests for swine flu are also pouring in” said an insider.

Title: Schools, vehicle operatorstold to ensure student safety
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Aurangabad: Police have asked school managements and bus operators to follow the safety norms while transporting students and also exhorted rickshaw operators to desist from cramming in too many schoolchildren in their vehicles.

“The call went out during a meeting headed by police commissioner Chiranjeev Prasad on the commissionerate premises on Friday evening,” said assistant commissioner of police (crime)Nagnath Kode.

The meeting was attended by the representatives of various schools, principals, bus, van and rickshaw operators and vehicle owners engaged in the transportation of students to school and back home.

Kode said the meeting was held in view of recent cases involving a school bus driver molesting a minor and an incident on the school premises in Cidco area.

Police officers told the participants about the precautions that have to be taken. The school managements were told to ensure that vehicle drivers have the licence, PUC (pollution under control) for the vehicle. They were also told to do a background check of the drivers.

The managements were also told not to allow students more than the capacity of the vehicle and that every bus should have a male and a female attendant. These vehicles should be equipped with CCTV cameras and GPS.

The managements were asked to update the Vishakha Samitis in their respective institutions and place complaint boxes on the premises.

Those who attended the meeting included deputy commissioner of police (home) Meena Makwana and officials of the regional transport office, Kode added.

Title: Muslim women take out rally against CAA
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Trichy: Women’s India Movement (WIM) the women’s wing of Social Democratic Party of India (SDPI) and National Women’s Front (NWF) on Saturday took out a rally and organised a public meeting to vehemently oppose the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR).

As many as 2,000 Muslim women took out the procession from Thennur to the Uzhavarsandhai grounds where a public meeting was held. A nine-point resolution was passed in the meeting and an oath was taken by the participants to ignore CAA, NRC and NPR which ‘were against the Constitution’.

One of their resolutions termed CAA an amendment biased towards the Muslims and Sri Lankan Tamil refugees. The women’s forums accused the government of attempting to roll out NPR with a hidden agenda. They also disapproved of NRC and NPR stating that they were impossible in the country.

They also condemned the AIADMK and the state government for ‘being anti-people’ and demanded that it should not implement CAA and NPR.

One of the resolutions also condemned the BJP for ‘suppressing the Muslims’.

CPM leader K Balabharathi, leaders of WIM M Najima Begum, M Mehraj Banu, NWF leader M Fathima, SDPI state president Nellai Mubarak and others spoke against the BJP government at the Centre and the AIADMK government in the state over their stand on CAA, NRC and NPR.

Title: EB fixes meters with motor pumps, farmers confused on free power supply
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Trichy: Even as authorities from the electricity board have started the process of fixing digital meters to the motor pumpsets used for irrigation purpose, delta farmers suspect that the state government may levy charges on the pumpsets received under the tatkal scheme.

The state government had introduced tatkal scheme in 2018, under which free power connections was provided to farmers for cultivation. They had to pay Rs 2.5 lakh for a 5 HP (horsepower) motor, Rs 2.75 lakh for 7.5 HP motor and Rs 3 lakh for 10 HP motor. Ever since the government made the announcement, small and marginal farmers had been opposing it stating that they cannot afford it. Despite the opposition, the scheme was implemented.

Though the power supply is free of cost, Tangedco has begun fixing digital meters with the existing electric motor pumpsets installed in fields across the delta districts. This has created panic among the farmers whether the government would levy any charge for power consumption in the future, state spokesperson of Bharatiya Kisan Sangam, N Veerasekaran said.

“I have been using a pumpset with 7.5 HP motor that I got under the tatkal scheme for the last two years. Without any prior intimation or any circular from the government, technical staff from EB office came here and fixed a meter. When I asked the reason, they said that it was for a monitoring purpose. I paid Rs 3 lakh to get power, why should I be monitored?” asked L K Arumugam, a farmer from Manakal village in Lalgudi in Trichy.

When contacted, a senior official from Tangedco, Thennur Trichy told TOI that this was in practice a few years ago for ordinary agriculture power connections too. As per the government’s notification, this initiative is being implemented, he said.

“This is only for study purpose, to ascertain the average consumption and total consumption per month of a particular connection. As per norms of the scheme, fixation of a meter is being done,” he added.

Meanwhile, secretary of Thanjavur district Cauvery farmers’ protection association Swamimalai S Vimalnathan alleged that it was a clear indication that charges would be levied for the power supply.

“If they want to study anything, they can do it from the transformer itself. They need not spend money on procuring meter and fixing it with motor pumps,” he added.

Title: Hyderabad: Activists cry foul after residents trap & choke cats, complaint filed
Content:
Screengrab of the video of abuse

HYDERABAD: A case of animal cruelty was brought to the notice of Director General of Police, Hyderabad against members of a gated community in Tolichowki . The issue came to light after an animal welfare organization received images and videos of cats being chased and tortured.It is alleged that before killing the cats, the animals were choked using steel ropes and placed in plastic sacks.According to Humane Society International/India (HSI/India), the animal welfare organisation that wrote to the Director General of Police, the Secretary of the Resident Welfare Association of the gated community issued a letter stating that a ‘team’ was hired to catch stray cats and residents must cooperate.HSI/India’s managing director Alokparna Sengupta who had forwarded the complaint to the DGP said, “There has been a rise in cruelty against street animals in affluent gated communities. The reason given for removal of cats was defecation by cats in the gardens. The community could have easily contacted an animal protection organization to seek help in a humane manner.”When TOI spoke to one of the complainants who brought the issue to the fore, it was informed on condition of anonimity that the decision to trap the cats came after a few residents complained to the secretary on the WhatsApp group about cat menace in the community.“These cats are very friendly and were fed by few residents of the gated community. The decision to trap them came after someone complained to the secretary of the community following which a few people trapped these cats.”“The people who were hired were promised Rs 500 for each cat they trapped. They chased about four cats and used steel ropes to catch them by their necks. The pressure of ropes was such that cats fell unconscious before they had put them in plastic sacks,” the complainant said under condition of anonymity.The inspector of Golconda Police Station K Chandra Shekar Reddy said, “We have not received any complaint about this case yet. If a complaint has been sent to DGP, action will be taken.” The Resident Welfare Association of the gated community could not be reached for a comment.In Video: Hyderabad: Activists enraged over videos of cats being trapped and choked

Title: Footpaths to be free of encroachments
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Over 300 encroachments covering footpaths and blocking the walkway of pedestrians have been identified in three zones as part of an audit conducted by the town-planning wing.

Shops jutting on to walkways and unauthorized street vendors are also included in the list compiled by three zones: Central zone, Fort zone and Kazhakootam.

The town-planning committee, which received the list of encroachments from central zone and Kazhakootam zone last week, received the list from Fort zone on Friday. Town-planning committee will present the list before mayor K Sreekumar in a meeting to be held on Tuesday. The final action on removing the encroachments and freeing the footpaths for pedestrians will be initiated after the meeting.

Multiple teams, led by respective assistant executive engineers, will be deployed in what is going to be a simultaneous eviction drive in all the zones. Two new vending zones are also likely to be announced this month; one at Museum and another at Poojappura.

The corporation has so far conducted two surveys of street vendors. As per the first survey, 1,884 vendors have been identified of which, 509 have been issued ID cards.

Licences have not been distributed to any of the vendors so far. Around 1,500 vendors were identified in the second survey.

The town-planning committee has also taken a list of encroachers identified by health wing earlier. Licenced vendors are being filtered out from the list and they will be allotted designated vending zones.

Meanwhile, a seven-member team, led by executive engineer and assistant revenue officer, has begun processing the files received from various commercial establishments in response to the notice served on them regarding parking violations.

Details of each building from tax assessment register have been collected from the revenue wing and handed over to the team. The team is expected to finalise the report on file processing by next week. Palayam Rajan, chairman, town planning committee said removal of encroachments from footpaths and parking violations in the city are being handled with utmost priority by the town planning standing committee.

“During the audit, we have come across unauthorised street vendors occupying lion share of footpaths depriving pedestrians of the space. Some of the shops have also been found extended unlawfully on to the footpath,” said Rajan.

Title: 2-BHK fraud: 6 culprits arrested in Telangana
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Six persons were nabbed for allegedly cheating 170 people by providing fake double bedroom allotment letters, a government housing scheme for eligible BPL families, and collected Rs 2.25 crore from the victims.

Cyberabad police arrested Velisetty Venkata Sathya Krishna Vara Prasad, Aduri Murali Krishna Murthy, Palakollu Srinivas Rao, Aela Laxmi, and Nagalla Krishna Rao, all from Suraram colony, Quthbullapur and K.Srinivas, from Bachupally .

Laxmi, who runs a tiffin centre, showed a fake double bedroom allotment letter to her customers and collected Rs 1.5 lakh from customers as allotment. Keeping her cut, she used to give the remaining amount to tge others Similarly, the other accused too used to collect Rs 1.5 lakh from people and give the money to Prasad after deducting commission.

The fraud came to light after one of the victims approached Dundigal police, claiming that the fraudsters cheated her by providing fake allotment papers for Rs 1.6 lakh.

Investigation revealed that Prasad hatched the plan after he overheard two people at a wine shop discussing fake allotment letters.

Police recovered Rs 1.11 crore cash, six mobile phones, a HP laptop, printer, gold ornaments (115.16 grams), a gold necklace, a Maruti 800 car, a Honda City car and fake 2-BHK allotment letters, all worth Rs 2.25 crore from their possession.

Title: Shops looted, cash, laptop taken away
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Trichy: Police investigation was launched after an unidentified gang stole cash and laptops from two shops and attempted to a few more and ATM kiosk here early on Saturday.

Police said the miscreants looted cash of Rs 16,000, laptop and stationery goods by breaking open a medical insurance office located in the first floor of a shopping complex, near Malaikoil, in Thiruverumbur.

They also stole Rs 18,000 and laptops from a construction office owned by one Pradeep. Following this, they made an unsuccesful try to break open a tailor shop and solar plant office in the complex. Police said they attempted to loot a saw mill too.

Moments later, they tried to open an ATM kiosk of Punjab National Bank. The incidents came to light when the owners of all these shops went to open their shop. Police have begun investigation to nab the culprots .

Title: Trichy: Cops tighten grip on child sexual abusers
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Taking a serious view of sexual offences against children and women, Trichy range police tightened its grip over the offenders by creating history sheets against them.

V Balakrishnan, deputy inspector general of police (DIG), Trichy range, said that the police department prepared a list of 222 convicts found guilty of crime against women and children in Trichy range since the protection of children from sexual offences (Pocso) Act came into effect in 2012.

Trichy range police consists of Trichy, Karur, Ariyalur , Perambalur and Pudukkottai districts. “We have listed out the convicts in the Pocso cases and opened history sheets in all women police stations (AWPS) on selected persons based on the precedence of their criminal activities. They will be under surveillance,” DIG Balakrishnan told the reporters, adding that the measure of keeping the offenders under the check is a measure to prevent the crime against women and children.

He was speaking in a seminar organised for the police and media personnel to elaborate on the law that restrict the revelation of the identity of the victims of rape and child sexual abuses as mentioned in the IPC, Pocso and Juvenile Justice (JJ) Act. “This seminar is aimed at ensuring that their identities are not revealed by anyone and we should not cause mental stress to the victims,” he said.

On the prevention measure against the child sexual abuse, DIG said that five schools each in five districts in the range have been equipped with the police club to sensitize the students on child sexual abuses, child marriage and other crimes against children and to teach them self-defense arts.

He said that the superintendents of police (SPs) of the each district have been asked to visit the villages on every Saturday to meet the people as a part of participative decision making program to get their views on protection of women and children in their areas.

Title: Drug peddler gives info on peddlers across MP
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Bhopal: A day after crime branch arrested a Mumbai-based woman with party drug MDMA (ecstasy), police on Saturday claimed that during interrogation she has revealed information about her drug peddling network across cities of Madhya Pradesh including Bhopal, Indore and Jabalpur.

Police said that the woman, Rehana Khan, 45, revealed the names of many Bhopal-based students, who were either her clients or worked as peddlers for her. Many high-profile contacts of the woman in the city have also been revealed during interrogation, police said.

ASP (crime branch) Nishchal Jharia said that during interrogation, Rehana revealed the names of drug peddlers associated with her across MP. The names have not been made accused in the case but, police claim that information on them could help them get a clearer picture of drug peddlers in the state.

ASP Jharia said that police have now started keeping a close eye on the movement of suspects revealed by Rehana.

Title: Mutharasan slams I-T raid against Vijay
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

CPI state secretary R Mutharasan

Actor Vijay would not have faced any action from the income tax department, if he too had backed the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), CPI state secretary R Mutharasan said in Trichy on Saturday.

Actor Rajinikanth has expressed his support to the CAA, only to safeguard himself from any legal action from the Centre in connection with income tax issues, he told reporters while commenting on the actor’s recent statement.

Rajinikanth’s recent comment on CAA drew sharp criticism from the opposition parties in the state. He had stated that the new Act poses no threat to Muslims. If they face trouble he would be the first person to raise the voice for them, he had stated. Backing the National Population Register exercise, Rajinikanth stated that the drive was essential.

To a query on the Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission (TNPSC) scam, he said that people had 100% trust in the TNPSC and its recruitments.

Title: ‘Celebrate Shiv Jayanti as per English Calendar’
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Aurangabad: Aurangabad Mahasangh, an apex body of different social groups and mandals that celebrates Shiv Jayanti every year, has demanded that the birth anniversary of Chhatrapati Shivaji must be celebrated as per the English calendar across the state on February 19.

In a memorandum submitted to the state government, Mahasangh founder president Prithviraj Pawar has sought an official end to the row over separate celebrations taking place on Shiv Jayanti as per Hindu calendar.

“The date February 19 has been officially decided as the birth date of Chhatrapati Shivaji by an expert committee set up by the state government almost two decades ago. Despite this, the row over different celebrations continues in Maharashtra. To bring an end to the issue, we demand that Shiv Jayanti must be celebrated as per the English calendar year across Maharashtra on February 19,” he said.

While Shiv Jayanti as per English calendar is round the corner, it falls on March 12 this year as per Hindu calendar.

Stating that Chhatrapati Shivaji is an inspiration for every generation, Pawar said that it is inappropriate to celebrate the birth anniversary of such a towering personality on two different occasions.

Incidentally, the appeal made by Aurangabad Mahasangh is likely to put local unit of Shiv Sena in tight spot as the saffron party celebrates Shiv Jayanti as per Hindu calendar every year. Earlier, NCP leader Amol Mitkari had appealed to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray to celebrate Shiv Jayanti on February 19.

BJP MLA and son of ex-CM Narayan Rane has already appealed to the government to end the ‘row’ over Shiv Jayanti. “The NCP is in power at present and, therefore, only one Shiv Jayanti celebration must take place. Let’s bring an end to the row over two celebrations,” he tweeted.

Title: Forest officials raid Nalgonda market, seize protected species
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

HYDERABAD: Following concerns of illegal trade of birds in Nalgonda ’s Ramgiri market, forest department officials conducted raids in the market and seized munias, a species of birds listed under schedule IV of Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972. Several of the birds were found to be dead.

On Monday, TOI had published a report on protected species of birds such as white-breasted waterhen , grey francolins, partridges, quails, and heirs being openly sold at the market.

Officials who reviewed the matter after the report was published, designated a team to conduct raids.

“Our teams who patrolled the entire market caught one person with munias. Upon questioning, the man said that he was unaware of the law and did not know that capturing and selling these birds was illegal. We will penalize him as per the law and continue these raids to see if there are more people involved in such illegal activities,” said Shantha Rao, divisional forest officer of Nalgonda district. Rao also said that they have planned awareness programs in surrounding areas and villages to educate people about illegal wildlife trade and its impact.

Title: Over 2k to take part in run for merit
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Aurangabad: Over 2,000 citizens are expected to participate in the mini-marathon ‘ run for merit ’ organized by the advocacy group ‘ Save Merit Save Nation ’ on Sunday morning.

The run will begin from the divisional sports complex and is scheduled to cover several areas, including Jawahar Nagar, Garkheda and Seven Hill, before returning to the start point.

“We have received good response to the registration drive. We also welcome spot registration. In all, minimum 2,000 citizens are expected to take part in the run on Sunday,” organisers said.

As announced earlier, the event will be held in two categories — 3km and 5km. “We will be carrying badges and posters to spread awareness during the marathon. We hope that the event will further spread our anti-excess reservation movement to the masses and create the desired public pressure,” organisers said.

Besides Aurangabad , ‘Save Merit Save Nation’ has also organized a similar mini-marathon in cities such as Latur, Mumbai and Solapur, among others, on February 9.

Title: Four cops suspended in Kattakkada murder case
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: In a major development in the Kattakkada Sangeeth Balan murder case, four policemen attached to Kattakkada police station were placed under suspension pending inquiry for the alleged laxity they displayed in reaching the crime scene on time, allowing ample time for the assailants to escape.

Additional sub-inspector Anilkumar and civil police officers Harikumar , Baiju and Sukesh are the officers who were placed under suspension. They were all on night duty at Kattakkada police station on the intervening night of January 23 and 24 when the murder took place. The suspension order was issued by deputy inspector general ( Thiruvananthapuram ) Kori Sanjaykumar Gurudin based on an preliminary inquiry report submitted by Nedumangad DSP Stuart Keeler.

The DSP had concluded his report stating that there was a delay of more than an hour for the cops to reach the crime scene at Kattakkada which was only 7km away from the Kattakkada police station. At night, when the vehicular traffic along the roads are very less, the cops could have reached the spot in a few minutes.

Speaking to TOI, superintendent of police (Rural District) B Ashok said that a formal inquiry has been launched into the alleged dereliction of duty of the four cops. An officer of the rank of deputy superintendent will be assigned to conduct the inquiry. The inquiry officer is yet to be decided, the Rural SP said.

Sangeeth Balan, 37, was allegedly murdered during the wee hours of January 24 by a gang of real estate mafia, who were trying to dig soil illegally from his plot. The gang turned up at his property with an excavator and a tipper lorry. When Sangeeth tried to prevent them from digging the earth, they attacked him. The gang hit him using the bucket of the excavator, inflicting serious injuries that eventually caused his death.

Title: Bamu to form supervisory body for its centres
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Aurangabad: Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University ( Bamu ) will form a special supervisory body to oversee the functioning of different study centres run under its aegis.

Bamu vice chancellor Pramod Yeole said all the study centres would be clubbed under the new body.

“A special complex will be also raised under which different existing study centres will be brought together. We have decided to appoint a special director-level officer to manage the functioning of the new supervisory body for the existing study centres,” he said.

Yeole, while speaking at the inauguration of study centre named after the 12th-century poet from Marathwada, Mukundraj, on Friday, also appealed to the authorities to broaden the horizon of the existing study centres.

“These centres must undertake activities and projects in keeping with the social relevance and emerging challenges,” he said.

Bamu, which is considered as one of the oldest universities in the country, has around 14 study centres named after different individuals. These include centres in the memory of Shivaji Maharaj, Rajashtri Shahu Maharaj, Bhagat Sing, Annabhau Sathe, Wamandada Kardak, Vasantrao Naik, Gautam Budhha, Mahatma Gandhi, Maulana Azad, C V Raman Tarabai Shinde and others.

Student activist Tukaram Saraf said, “The study centres at Bamu are by and large under-utilised so far. These are key bodies which can be used for social research among other works. The university administration must maintain these centres in order to achieve a larger goal,” he said.

BAMU was criticised by the National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC) over the alleged expansion of study centres under the university.

The peer team of NAAC, in its official report submitted on March 29 after carrying out an assessment of the university, had observed that Bamu “spreading its resources thin by creating too many chairs and centres.” The NAAC authorities had listed such decisions under the ‘weakness’ category of the university in its official report.

Title: Telangana education dept asks for undertaking to improve results, teachers miffed
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The education department’s recent decision to ask teachers to give an undertaking taking the responsibility of under-performing students has not gone down well with teachers.

The teachers said that asking them submit such an undertaking was a move to turn them into scapegoats.

“We are doing our best to ensure that all students clear SSC examination by strictly adhering to the board’s timetable and making students take practice tests. However, even after giving our best, there is a chance that a student may fail. Asking us to give undertaking is not fair,” said M Ravinder, president, Telangana Progressive Teachers Federation .

“You are hereby informed to give a certificate of undertaking about students identified by you with lower performance in your subject in special practice test held in August 2019,” read the proforma of the undertaking being circulated in the schools. “I do hereby declare that I will take responsibility of improving the academic standards of the above students and put my best efforts to ensure their improvement in my school,” states the acknowledgement.

Teachers said that they are not ready to submit any such undertaking and added that they have even raised this issue with the officials.

While the DEO, Hyderabad refused to comment on the issue, officials in the department said the undertaking would ensure that teachers put in their best.

“If they are doing their best in preparing students, what’s stopping them from giving the same in written?” questioned an official.

Title: Trichy: Locals lock horns with PWD over sand quarry operations in Cauvery
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

TRICHY: A group of residents of Gunaseelam village engaged in an altercation with the officials of the public works department (PWD) at Manjakorai in Trichy on Saturday over the commencement of quarry operations along the Cauvery.

Citing the stay vacated by the Madras high court, the PWD started operating the newly-opened quarry in full swing at Manjakorai on Friday.

Quarrying near the village triggered unrest among a section of people prompting them to oppose the operations on Saturday morning. The agitated villagers tried to block the Trichy-Namakkal Road near Gunaseelam on Saturday. But, PWD officials and Trichy district police reacted quickly and prevented them from blocking the road and held talks with them. According to the villagers, drinking water level will be hit if quarrying was carried out in the area. They also recalled a previous case filed by the villagers against the proposal to quarry in the area several years ago. PWD officials attempted to assuage the villagers stating that the quarry operation was carried out with proper environmental clearance in August 2018 and a Madras high court order in November 2019.

The officials said that a resident of the village moved the high court seeking stay on the environment clearance citing drinking water depletion. The court appointed a committee to verify the facts. The committee also visited the spot and submitted a report following which the court gave nod for the quarry operation. Following this, the PWD officials started preliminary work to carry out quarry operation on 24 hectares along the river as per the guidelines of the court. Sand can be mined for one metre depth as per the order. Mined sand will be transported to the government sand depot at Konalai where the online registered trucks can load minimum two units and maximum three units of sand with a price of Rs 1,330 per unit.

The officials tried to convince the agitating people saying that 1.78 lakh units can be mined from the area without causing any harm to the environment. The villagers still argued.

Title: Hyderabad doctors give 70-year-old Somalian farmer new lease of life
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 70-year-old farmer from Somalia got his life back to normalcy after a team of doctors from the city reconstructed his urethra which was completely cut-off due to bullet injury.

The patient, Dahir afrah Mohamed , was hit by a bullet near his pubic bone seven months ago when he was caught in a firing between rival groups near his farm in Somalia. The bullet passed through his urethra below the prostate and exited through his buttock. He was taken to local hospital where he underwent a surgery and a tube was pushed directly into his bladder. While he was lucky to have survived as the bullet missed his major blood vessels. But even after the surgery, he faced issues in passing urine.

The patient then came to Hyderabad for further treatment and tests revealed that his urethra had completely cut-off. “As his urethra was completely cut off, we had to devise a plan for this surgery to be successful. To get the two ends together, we cut-off the pubic bone and mobilized both ends and sutured them in a marathon five hour surgery,” said Dr AV Ravi Kumar, consultant urologist , MediCover Hospitals.

This was a very rare case due to its severity and such a complex disconnected ends of urethra. “Patient’s tubes were removed after four weeks and he is passing urine freely now,” added Kumar.

Title: 1,451 licensed recruiting agents
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Hyderabad: As per eMigrate portal of the government, there are 1,451 licensed recruiting agents as on February 4. The number includes 70 in Telangana and 13 in AP. Police in some of the districts in Telangana have been booking cases against illegal agents but the numbers are only a few. Karimnagar police alerted people not to fall prey to illegal agents who promise to get their passports done and also recruit them for Gulf jobs . In 2015, three illegal agents were arrested in Metpally and 266 passports were seized from them. There are stray cases like this and cheating cases are booked against them.

“Most important thing is people should be educated about operations of illegal agents so they don’t fall prey to them,” said Patkuri Basanth Reddy, president, Gulf Telangana Welfare and Cultural Association. He launched a campaign against fake agents. TNN

Title: Hindu outfit chief’s killer held after encounter
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

LUCKNOW: Less than a week after Ranjeet Bachchan, who founded an outfit called Vishwa Hindu Mahasabha, was shot dead,the alleged shooter was arrested after a brief encounter, a little after midnight on Friday.

Police said, Jitendra, the shooter, had come to collect cash from a relative’s house before fleeing to Nepal . A .32 bore pistol was seized from his possession, which was also the murder weapon, police claimed. On Friday, Jitendra came to meet a relative in Charbagh and police teams were pressed into action.

Police said they laid a trap on Lucknow-Kanpur Road. Around 12.30am, they stopped his bike near a checkpoint and asked him show the bike’s registration papers, at which he opened fire and sped.

Another police team intercepted him but he again opened fire. A cop shot him in the leg and Jitendra fell off the bike.

Title: Excise sleuths seize truckload of foreign liquor at Vadakara
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Kozhikode: The excise team from Vadakara , on Saturday made a major seizure of smuggled Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL). The team seized a truckload full of liquor during a search operation carried out based on a tip off received by the excise team.

The team seized 475 bottles of IMFL from the vehicle. It also recorded the arrest a worker of the truck.

The excise team carried out the search operation by blocking the vehicle by stopping the department vehicle across the road. The excise officials identified the accused as K P Rashid (19). As per the statement of Rashid, the vehicle was driven by Haneefa from Mukkali, when the police stopped the vehicle. According to officials, they had to chase the vehicle for some distance as the driver did not stop the vehicle when the excise team directed him to stop the vehicle. The seizure was made around 8am.

The liquor was being smuggled by packing the bottles in small containers. There were 42 cardboard containers in the truck. To evade inspection, the husk of tender coconut was used, the liquor boxes were covered with coconut husk. According to the officials, the plan was to smuggle the liquor from Mahe towards Malappuram.

The search was carried out by a team led by excise inspector K K Shijil Kumar, preventive officers Pramod Pullikool and K K Jayan.

Title: English speaking workshop
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Aurangabad: The Department of Lifelong Learning and Extension at the Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University ( Bamu ) has organised a special workshop for students to help improve their English speaking and communication skills.

The month-long initiative will have training sessions between 4 pm and 6 pm every day from Monday, an official release said.

“The special workshop aims at improving communication skills of students in English language. It has been observed that the students from Marathwada possess immense talent, but a considerable number of them struggle in different screening tests for jobs due to inadequate English speaking skills. The month-long workshop to sharpen the necessary skills of students,” Bamu authorities said.

Title: Secunderabad follows Delhi’s lead in drain revamp
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

SECUNDERABAD: To prevent road damage from rainwater stagnation, Telangana deputy speaker T Padma Rao has told civic authorities to construct permanent structures to drain out the water, on the lines of a similar system in New Delhi.
