He told GHMC ’s engineering wing officials that Rs 5 crore was sanctioned for road repair and construction of culverts at various places in Secunderabad .

“This money was for infrastructure development, such as laying new roads, culverts and improving the drainage system. However, the roads are damaged every time a portion is dug up to lay water or sewer lines, thereby wasting the money that was utilised to repair it,” said Padma Rao, adding, “A system that is being followed in Delhi to drain rainwater must be implemented in the city also. For this, civic officials need to go to Delhi to study the system.”

Ravi Kumar, deputy commissioner, GHMC (north zone), said, “We will chalk out a schedule to visit Delhi and study the system.”

S Hema, GHMC Sitaphalmandi corporator , said that civic body has sanctioned Rs 1 crore for road revamp in Sitaphalmandi.

Title: SCB: Special teams to tackle duplicate votes
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Secunderabad: The Secunderabad Cantonment Board has deployed special teams to weed put duplicate voters’ name from electoral rolls.

Cantonment officials who received a representation on list of duplicate voters, conducted a detailed probe. According to the representation, 600 voters names were duplicated, a large share of which was observed in Ward 4 of SCB .

In some instances, members of the same family and same address were given entries in multiple wards.

“Special teams will visit the premises personally and verify the names, based on the faults mentioned in the representation,” sources in SCB election wing told TOI. The drive comes after the SCB polls were deferred for another six months.

Officials said it would take at least a month to identify duplicate voters, after which the list of duplicate voters with addresses will be sent to SCB chief executive officer.TNN

Title: Khap slaps Rs 5 lakh fine on inter-faith couple in Jhansi, asks woman to undergo 'purification'
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

JHANSI: A khap panchayat has issued a diktat against an inter-faith couple, allegedly ostracized by the community since 2015, asking the woman to undergo 'purification' by consuming 'gobar' (cow dung) and 'gaumutra' (cow urine). The couple were also asked to pay Rs 5 lakh as fine if they wanted the community to accept them. One person has been arrested.

According to police , property dealer Bhupesh Yadav had married Aastha,from the Jain community, in 2015. Though Bhupesh's family had no objection to the marriage, community members snapped all ties with them . On Friday, the couple lodged a complaint with the district magistrate.

A case was also lodged against a community member, Jhallu Mate, and his associates on Saturday under sections of the IPC . Mate was later arrested. Arindam Ghosh

Title: Secunderabad junctions get strip lights to curb jumps at signals, improve traffic flow
Content:
New strip lights at work at Sangeet junction.

SECUNDERABAD: In a bid to improve adherence to traffic rules, Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation ( GHMC ) has installed special lights known as strip lighting at Sangeet junction. The lights that synchronise with traffic lights to change colours will also come up in other parts of Secunderabad .“The aim is to reduce the number of signal jump cases. The strip lighting,which will provide commuters with better visibility is part of pilot project,” said Srinivas Reddy, GHMC zonal commissioner, Secunderabad.Other areas that have been earmarked for similar lighting includes Paradise Junction, Patny Junction, Rasoolpura junction and Neredmet cross road.The civic body also recently took to refurbishing open fuse boxes in Secunderabad. Many citizens had complained that open fuse boxes and dangling wires were threats to motorists and pedestrians.“Unlike previous iron boxes, the newly installed boxes are made of shock proof fibre and can cap all cable wires inside the box. Municipal Administration and Urban Development minister KT Rama Rao has appreciated the initiative and instructed GHMC officials to refurbish fuse boxes in other zones too,” said Reddy.The boxes, which are being installed in a phase wise manner, has been set up on all major flyovers in the city. “Due to budget constrains, we have placed only 800 boxes as of now,” said a GHMC official. Officials have also planned to improve green cover at junctions where these lights have been installed.

Title: CAT questions AP on delay in IRS officer’s repatriation
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Hyderabad: The Central Administrative Tribunal (CAT), Hyderabad, on Friday reserved its orders in a plea filed by suspended IRS officer J Krishna Kishore who challenged the punitive action taken by the Andhra Pradesh government against him.

A bench comprising tribunal chairman Justice L Narasimha Reddy and member (administration) BV Sudhakar earlier stayed the suspension and sought the version of the state government as to why it was proceeding against the officer. The IRS officer was an income-tax commissioner and, on a request from Andhra Pradesh under TDP regime, came to AP Economic Development Board (APEDB) as its CEO in 2015 on deputation.

However, in July 2019, the current YSRCP regime shifted him to the general administration department. In December, it suspended him and ordered ACB and CID probes against him on the grounds that he had committed certain irregularities during his stint with APEDB.

Senior counsel Neeraj Malhotra argued the case of Kishore and said the government had crossed its brief and was acting with a sense of vengeance against him. The IRS officer was part of the income tax probe against Jagathi Publications, a firm owned by AP chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy, and the findings of this probe team were not liked by Jagathi management.

“They had, in fact, challenged the findings of the probe team before higher judicial forums,” he said.

Neeraj expressed apprehensions whether this background is working against Kishore now. “Since the income-tax department is also asking the government to repatriate him, let there be a direction from this court ordering immediate repatriation of the officer. He was promoted as a principal commissioner of income tax and all his batchmates have joined in the new posts. Any delay here will make him a junior officer there,” he added.

Appearing for the AP government, senior counsel D Prakash Reddy argued that government has jurisdiction to act against the central employees if they are working with it on deputation and its interests were adversely affected by the actions of such employees. He refuted the allegation that the state was acting against the officer with malice.

“It was Kishore who sought repatriation to the Centre immediately after YSRCP came to power in AP,” he said. The bench, however, has made it clear that it will not go into the personal allegations that each party is making. The bench sought to know from the government whether it is ready to send the officer back to the Centre.

“If you (government) want to conduct a probe into the alleged irregularities committed by him, you are free to do so. You have already moved him out of APEDB. Why this suspension which looks like a double punishment? Where is the need to retain him here?” the bench asked.

Prakash said if the officer is sent back to Delhi, then the probe in AP would suffer. The bench reserved its judgement.

Title: Anti CAA Protest in Hyderabad: Pass anti-CAA resolution in T assembly; Advocates JAC
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Lawyers at CAA protest in Indira Park in Hyderabad on Saturday.

By: Omer bin Taher

HYDERABAD: Advocates from the Telangana advocates JAC gathered at the Dharna Chowk near Indira Park to register their protest against Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ).

The advocates said that CAA violates articles 14 and 21 of the constitution.

The lawyers stressed upon chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to pass a resolution in the state assembly with a strong recommendation to the central government by noting that the Citizenship Amendment Act , amended passport rules, foreign order amendments are “class legislations harping, interalia, on the religious identity of an individual.”

“We appreciate and welcome the stand of the TRS government as it has registered a protest against CAA and NRC. But it can be understood in a practical manner when the government passes a resolution in the state assembly and follow it up by filing a case under Article 131 of Indian Constitution,” said Muzzar Ullah Khan, an advocate.

The advocates JAC also requested the state government to allow citizens to organise protests against the Act and grant police permission. It further said that JAC had committed to extend all possible legal aids to those who stand against CAA,and NRC.

Meanwhile, Congress leader P. Chidambaram and TPCC president Uttam Kumar Reddy met protesting advocates and read the preamble of the Constitution and sung the national anthem with the advocates.

Title: PM insulted 3.5 crore T people: Gutha
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Hyderabad: Taking a strong objection to Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s comments on the passage of a bill in the Lok Sabha in 2014 to create a separate Telangana state, legislative council chairman Gutha Sukhender Reddy said Modi has insulted 3.5 crore population of Telangana with his remarks.

Addressing a press conference in Miryalaguda on Friday, Sukhender said that separate Telangana was achieved after thousands of people sacrificed their lives. “PM should remember that BJP had supported the Telangana bill in both the Houses. Modi’s remarks are not only an insult to Telangana people, but also to Sushma Swaraj, then BJP leader in the Lok Sabha,” he said. TNN

Title: Jagan will face public wrath: Kanna
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Hyderabad: AP BJP president Kanna Lakshminarayana on Friday said Jagan will face unprecedented public wrath for his decision on shifting capital to Visakhapatnam. He said the wrath would be more than what TDP chief Chandrababu Naidu faced from people when was the CM.

He said Jagan shifted AP capital from Amaravati with ulterior motives. “If Naidu had tried to loot Amaravati, Jagan is trying to do the same in Visakhapatnam, Amaravati was decided as the state capital in a consensus. If a government changes every time, a capital cannot change. Investments will stop flowing into AP,” he said. TNN

Title: Trademark row: 2 get jail for not removing gym title
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Ahmedabad: In a first, two persons have been sentenced imprisonment for one month in a case related to intellectual property right. A local court has ordered to send them to civil imprisonment for disobeying court order and thereby committing contempt of the court.

Two owners of a fitness centre in Makarba, Alamkhan Pathan and Muhibullah Saiyed, have been ordered one-month imprisonment for not changing the name ‘I Gymholic’ of their fitness centre. Their former partner, Ishan Qureshi, had been claiming exclusive trademark right over the branch and had sued them for usurping his trademark.

In 2018, Qureshi sued Pathan and Saiyed in Ahmedabad district court for trademark infringement claiming that he had started the gym in Makarba in partnership. It was named as ‘I Gymholic’, in which I stands for Ishran. Later, there was a dispute between partners, and Qureshi started a separate fitness centre in Bopal. His partners, however, continued to use the same brand, to which he registered his protest.

In September 2019, the court restrained Pathan and Saiyed from using the brand and ordered them to remove the name ‘I Gymholic’ within three days from receipt of its order.

According to Qureshi’s advocate Rushvi Shah, Pathan and Saiyed did not remove the name and continued to run their fitness centre under the same title. The court was informed about the development and action was demanded against the duo for contempt of court for not following court’s order. “The court has awarded one-month jail to both the defendants for not following the court order,” she said.

The lawyer also said, “The court has ordered plaintiff (Qureshi) to pay for the subsistence allowance for both the persons during their custody which will be of civil nature.” After awarding one-month civil imprisonment, the court directed its Nazir (court staff) “to accept Rs 10,000 against the subsistence allowance for keeping the defendants in civil imprisonment for one month… An endorsement to be also made by the Nazir disclosing the total subsistence allowance required in this case for keeping two defendants in civil imprisonment for one month.”

The court, however, has granted time to Pathan and Saiyed to appeal against the order of civil imprisonment.

Title: Standing committee increases budget size by Rs126.85 crore
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Surat: Standing committee of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) has increased the size of budget for 2020-21 by Rs126.85 crore on Friday. The Rs6130.76 crore budget, which has been ratified by 12-member standing committee, will now be taken up for discussion by the general board of the BJP-ruled corporation this month-end.

Standing committee chairman Anil Goplani said, “We have made allocations for tourism, heritage and many other sectors. Though we have not hiked taxes, but decided to provide free medicines to patients from health centres. Our focus is on health and fire safety.”

The standing committee through amendments to the draft proposals submitted by municipal commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani has provided additional money for purchase of a firefighting robot and modern fire equipment worth Rs2 crore. There are plans to add another 29 health centres to the existing 52, a food laboratory in Vesu, a mobile dispensary for every zone, a model school in each zone and a souvenir shop in Surat castle. Provision of Rs50 crore has been made for new areas being brought under the city limits. There are plans too to make special vegetable markets for women sellers and buyers, special app for Surat heritage and development of tourism etc.

Title: L K Advani ends tie with Gujarat as a voter after three decades
Content:
LK Advani and his daughter Pratibha Advani show their ink marked finger after casting vote in Delhi Legislativ... Read More

GANDHINAGAR: Former deputy Prime Minister and BJP patriarch L K Advani , 92, ended his three-decade-old relationship as a voter from Gandhinagar Lok Sabha constituency and Ahmedabad’s Jamalpur-Khadia constituency. On Saturday, Advani voted in the Delhi assembly elections from his “permanent” address. It was after the 1991 Lok Sabha polls when Advani had contested from New Delhi and Gandhinagar, that the BJP veteran had won from Gandhinagar with a handsome margin, and moved from New Delhi to Gujarat, his ‘karmabhoomi’ as an MP.In Ahmedabad, Advani was a registered voter from Jamalpur-Khadia assembly constituency. The BJP’s old office at Pandit Dayal Bhavan, JP Chowk, Khanpur, in Ahmedabad was listed as his address.On Saturday, Advani voted at Atal Adarsh Vidyalaya, on Aurangzeb Road in New Delhi assembly constituency in the Delhi state assembly elections. Advani last voted in Lok Sabha election in May 2019 in Ahmedabad.Chief electoral officer and ex-officio secretary to state general administration department (Election) S Murali Krishna said: “L K Advani’s name has been shown in the deleted voters list in our records. So he must have applied in Ahmedabad RO office. If he has got his name deleted from Ahmedabad electoral rolls and registered in New Delhi he can vote there now but not here any more.'”Surprisingly, Advani's name appeared as a voter in Gujarat chief electoral officer (CEO) website in Delhi and in Gujarat when TOI checked on Saturday. TOI has screenshots of both websites as they do not seem to be updated.In 1991, BJP leader Advani had fought for the first time from Lok Sabha on two seats, New Delhi and Gandhinagar, as he was being projected as BJP’s prime ministerial candidate that year. In New Delhi, he faced a stiff competition from Congress candidate and Bollywood superstar Rajesh Khanna and barely managed a win by a thin margin of 1,589 votes. In Gandhinagar, Advani won by a mammoth margin of 1.25 lakh.Advani resigned from the New Delhi constituency and then Khanna won in the New Delhi byelection. The superstar came back to haunt Advani in the 1996 byelection of Gandhinagar Lok Sabha after A B Vajpayee who was then BJP’s prime ministerial candidate won but resigned from Gandhinagar and kept the Lucknow seat. That year, Advani refrained from contesting elections in the wake of the Jain hawala diary case. Advani chose not to contest the 1996 Lok Sabha election till his name was cleared. But in 1998, Advani won from Gandhinagar and since then represented the constituency till 2019 when BJP national party president Amit Shah was fielded from Gandhinagar and won.

Title: Hubei students in home quarantine
Content:
Representative image

KOCHI: The 15 students who returned from Hubei province in China have been home quarantined.Immediately after the 12 girls and three boys landed at Cochin International Airport from Bangkok on Friday at 11pm, they were taken to Kalamassery Medical College in sterilized ambulances, where they were examined. “As they had no symptoms, swab samples were collected and they were advised home quarantine,” said a health official.The students had travelled from Kunming Airport in China to Bangkok and boarded an AirAsia flight for Kochi.Meanwhile, the tourism department has asked hotels and homestays in the state to provide a list of tourists from novel coronavirus-affected countries who checked into their properties between January 30 and February 4.Accordingly, the department has received a list of 80 to 90 nationals from five countries – China, Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia and the Philippines.Most of these tourists are from China and Hong Kong. “The tourists checked out in the first week of February itself. But the staff of hotels and homestays do not have details of their later movements. Most of the tourists stayed at homestays and hotels in the Fort Kochi area,” said a tourism official in Ernakulam.The details have been shared with health officials. “We are in touch with hotels and homestays in Kochi and have asked them to adhere to the revised guidelines regarding coronavirus infection. As of now, no tourist in Kochi is under quarantine,” said an official.Speaking in Thiruvananthapuram, state health minister K K Shailaja said 3,144 people in the state are still under observation. However, no new positive case has been reported and only 45 people have been isolated in various hospitals.The remaining people are under home quarantine. Even though the 'state-specific disaster' tag has been withdrawn, the minister said surveillance and monitoring of people is continuing. Of the 330 samples sent for testing at the National Institute of Virology in Pune, 288 have tested negative. The remaining results are expected in a day or two. Of the 72 people who travelled from Wuhan two are from Tamil Nadu. All the three positive patients are stable, she said.Fears recede in ThrissurThe fears of an outbreak are receding in Thrissur, where the first positive case in the country was reported.Only seven people are under hospital-based surveillance now, after the discharge of another two persons on Saturday, according to an official release. In all, 253 people continue to be under home quarantine in the district.Results of 70 out of the 80 samples sent for tests from the district have been received and no fresh cases have been reported.The condition of the student who was infected is improving. Another sample of the student has tested negative.However, district collector S Shanawaz said it is not clear whether the result was of the latest sample. “We had sent a couple of samples for testing, and only by Sunday will we be able to ascertain whether it is the latest sample. One of the earlier samples from the student had also tested negative. Also, we can say she is cured only if two consecutive samples test negative,” the collector said.Two more persons have been arrested in the district for spreading false information on the virus outbreak.1 admitted in Kozhikode District collector Sambasiva Rao chaired a meeting on Saturday to assess preventive measures in the district. The collector also assessed the functioning of the helpline for people who arrived from nCoV-hit countries who are under home quarantine.The collector also had a phone conversation with Dr Jamaluddin, in-charge of screening of passengers arriving on international flights at Karipur airport.One person was admitted to the Beach Government General Hospital isolation ward with mild fever. Till Saturday, 378 persons have arrived in the district from nCoV-hit countries, of which 377 have been kept under home quarantine by the health department.

Title: ‘Not importer, India will be major defence producer’
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Rajnath Singh

Title: Edu dept tells schools to hold parents’ worship on Feb 14
Content: Surat: In a bid to scuttle students’ attempts to celebrate Valentine's Day, the district education officer (DEO) in Surat has issued a circular to all schools in the city and district to organise ‘Matru Pitru Poojan Divas’ - Mother Father Worship Day by students on February 14.In the covering letter of the circular the education department has stated: “In current times the youth is blindly following those practices which are against the glorious tradition of our country. To nurture best values from childhood and to protect our culture, Mother-Father Worship Day message should be given.”Apart from instructions to organise the ‘worship day’, the schools have also been asked to send photos of the event in reply to the DEO.The letter also instructs schools on how to celebrate the day.The schools will have to call five to 10 parents belonging to different religions and castes. They will also have to invite members of Nagar Prathmik Shikshan Samiti’s members, Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) members, municipal councillors, educationalist or social worker to witness the event.“In the event, the children should worship their parents in accordance to Indian tradition with tilak, garland, vandan – with folded hands, circumambulating in pradakshina and offering them sweets. A speech should also be delivered about importance of parents in life,” it read.DEO H H Rajyaguru defended the circular. “The circular only asks schools to follow our tradition. There is no other issue in it,” he said, refusing to elaborate on why the worship is to be specifically organized on V-Day.Director of Centre for Social Studies, Kiran Desai told TOI that it is not the role of the education department to get involved in such non-academic activities. “Valentine’s Day has nothing to do with our culture. But when we have accepted many western things without objections, we should not try to impose religious rituals on students and bring parents in,” he said.

Title: Despite ban, air passengers continue to carry e-cigarettes
Content:
Representative image

KOCHI: Even though central government recently banned the consumption, production, sale and transportation of e-cigarette, lack of awareness about the ban amongst air passengers from foreign countries is turning out to be a headache for CISF staff at the Cochin International Airport Ltd (Cial). Arguments over possession of banned e-cigarattes have become quite frequent at the security counter at the airport.Around six cases were reported over the past one month. Security officials said passengers cite lack of proper warning by airlines as the main reason for carrying e-cigarette. According to airport sources, many passengers are coming with e-cigarettes in their baggage, which are being seized during security checks, mostly during the departure times.CISF officials said that e-cigarettes are brought by the passengers for personal consumption as its use is legal in other countries. “Though they are not supposed to bring in e-cigarettes, during immigration these e-cigarettes go unnoticed as the customs officials haven’t yet started seizing them. But when these passengers return they will have to go through thorough checking and frisking. Though we try to inform them about the ban, they argue that no intimations were given about the ban during the visa application time or by the airlines during ticket booking,” said an official.E-cigarettes are the most common form of electronic nicotine delivery systems (Ends). These are basically devices that do not burn or use tobacco leaves. Instead, they vaporize a solution using a battery. This vapour is then inhaled by the user.E-cigarettes were promoted as a way to get people out of their smoking habits but reports have shown that many people are not using it as a weaning mechanism but are rather addicted to it. The finance ministry in September announced a ban on e-cigarettes saying they pose health risks to the youth as their addiction is increasing.Officials said that there is a need to highlight e-cigarettes as a banned product and give awareness to air passengers not to carry it. “Unless proper awareness is given, there is no use in banning it. The price of these items range from Rs 450 to Rs 30,000 and custom-made e-cigarettes are even costlier. Passengers argue with us more when the seized product is pricey,” said an official.Customs officials also said that though the item is banned, there are no directions to the officials regarding checking and seizures of e-cigarettes. “During immigration we mostly check for those items prohibited under the Section 11 of Customs Act. As of now there are no directions to seize e-cigarettes from passengers. Moreover, it is impractical to check each passenger for e-cigarette unless it is brought in bulk quantities. So the problem comes during departure as CISF will be screening each of the passengers,” said a senior customs official.

Title: Patriotism peaks as showstopper DefExpo sends Lucknow into a frenzy
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

At Gomti Riverfront, people tore banners for a glimpse of action while Vrindavan Yojana saw a 3km queue

LUCKNOW: The denizens of the city wore their patriotism high on their sleeves and marched to the Defence Expo venues in swarms from all corners, stood in lines for hours without any signs of fatigue and cheered each other by intermittently shouting ‘How’s the josh?’ and a loud ‘High Sir!’ reverberating in response.

“Nawabon ka shehar, sena ke shaurya ka shehar, Bharat ke vir jawanon ki jai,” were some slogans that echoed at Vrindavan Yojana, the Defence Expo venue open to public for free on Saturday for the first time.

People started trooping at 5am, stood in serpentine queues extending up to 3km and later even climbed nearby trees, buildings to get a glimpse of the live demonstrations of the Indian Army and Air Force personnel in action.

“I came at 6am but got to witness the live show in the afternoon due to massive crowd, but I’m not upset as I came for our soldiers who stake their lives to save our borders,” said advocate Amit Srivastava.

People waited in queues moving at a caterpillar’s speed with excitement for their turns to pose with battle tanks, aircraft and missiles on display.

“I gasped after climbing up a tank to take a selfie, salute to our Army which operates it in extreme temperatures,” said Anurag Kashyap, a student.

The spirit of young and old remained high as they saluted the aircraft zipping in the sky above and shouting “Bharat Mata ki jai”.

“I feel privileged that I could see the aerobatics of the Surya Kiran team . Defence Expo made this possible for us,” said Arundhati Verma, a homemaker.

The crowd tried every way out, displaying ingenuity by bringing down the posters blocking the sight for a peep of the naval commandos performing acrobatics and enacting anti-terrorist operations at Gomti Riverfront.

Title: Canada woos Raj MSMEs, seeks tie-ups
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Jaipur: From 34,000 students about six years ago to over two lakh, Canada is becoming a preferred destination for Indian youths, replacing China and the US. Building on the new relation, the country is looking to expand its engagement with India on fresh frontiers.

In a first, Canada is reaching out to the business communities of 10 tier-II cities in India, including Rajasthan , seeking collaboration and investment. Recently, a delegation led by Canadian commercial minister Andrew Smith and CEO of Indo-Canadian Business Chamber (ICBC) Nadira Hamid, expressed Canada’s eagerness to partner with the small and medium industries of the Pink City.

Smith said, “Our traditional industries are in commodities and agriculture. But we want to broaden to new areas. Canadian companies are not very large. That’s why I wanted to explore whether Indian SMEs in tier-II cities might be a better match for the Canadian SMEs.”

He said India produces 8.5 lakh computer engineers and scientists every year and there are large numbers of startups in India. “They provide us the best opportunities to work on new technologies like Internet of Things, block chain, cyber security, agri-tech, clean tech, and connected vehicles. We want to find synergy in these new areas where the SMEs of both the countries can work together and develop the future trade relationships,” Smith added.

Currently, the bilateral trade between India and Canada stands at around $6.7 billion and Canada expects the volumes to increase to $25 billion in the next five years.

Hamid said after the roadshows in 10 tier-II cities, they will analyse potential areas where alliances can be forged. “Interactions with the SMEs in the roadshow will give us understanding on how we can build new partnerships. In the next level, we will try to engage in a more specific way with the companies.”

Arun Agarwal, executive president of Federation of Rajasthan Trade and Industry, who attended the roadshow, said there is potential for investing in Canada and also developing alliances in multiple areas

Title: Gujarat ranks 8th in India in justice delivery, says study
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A study has placed Gujarat at the 8th rank among major Indian states in its capacity to deliver justice to citizens.

The study titled ‘India Justice Report’ was undertaken by Tata Trusts in collaboration with the Centre for Social Justice (CSJ) and various other organizations. The report was launched at the Gujarat National Law University on Saturday. The survey conducted, and the study of data received from the governments revealed that Maharashtra tops the list of 18 major and mid-size states in justice delivery .

The states’ performances have been evaluated on basis of police department’s performance, prison conditions and their staff, functioning of judiciary and the legal aid services prevalent in the states in last few years.

According the report, Gujarat has fared reasonably well on the front of judiciary and legal aid securing 7th and 6th ranks respectively. But, the condition of police department and prisons pulls it back to overall 8th rank because the functioning of police was ranked 12th and prison conditions at 9th.

The study has also ranked the states in respect of their intentions to improve as seen in last five years by analysing recent trends. In this, Gujarat ranks third with West Bengal and Maharastra ahead of it.

Though Gujarat fares poorly on police functioning, it has been praised for improving gender ratio after 2015-16 when the Anandiben Patel-government introduced 33% reservation for women in recruitment.

Gujarat still suffers from 31.5% vacancy at constabulary level with nearly one out of three positions remaining unfilled. The national average vacancy is of 21.2%. Over a period of five years, vacancies showed a declining trend.

In Gujarat prisons, 32% posts are vacant. The national average is 33%. Women representation among jail officials is the lowest at 5.5% as against the national average of 10%.

In Gujarat’s judiciary, the report highlighted that only one out of 10 judges in the Gujarat high court is a woman.

Title: Rajasthan: Now, you can buy booze from RTDC hotel counters
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Rajasthan Tourism Development Corporation (RTDC) hotels and compounds can now sell Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL), beer, heritage liquor and foreign booze from their counters, says the new excise and temperance policy released by the state government on Saturday.Liquor sale at RTDC bars and counters was stopped in 2004.“But after the government received complaints about shops selling liquor at inflated rates, the government decided to reopen the counters at the hotels,” an official said.The policy also mandates that country liquor shops should sell 30% ENA (extra neutral alcohol)-based Rajasthan Made Liquor (RML) and introduce MRP on it.The policy also focuses on providing good quality liquor to consumers and put a check on alcohol consumption.“The state government will issue notification for conducting lotteries soon. The applicants can start applying from February 11-12. The first lottery will be conducted in the first the week of March. There is a provision that this new policy is likely to continue in 2021-22. The heritage liquor, which is manufactured at the Rajasthan State Ganganagar Sugar Mill, will be given major focus and will be promoted at the national and international levels,” it added.The government has also decided to take a tough stand on illicit liquor. “On the lines of Uttar Pradesh, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu, the government shall replace 30% of the volume of country liquor by ENA-based RML in a phased manner. To check sale of illicit liquor, 3 per cent of RML will be sold in tetra packs,” the official added.RML is available in form whiskey, rum, gin and vodka. “Liquor will be prepared using ENA, which is a better quality spirit. It will be sold at affordable rates,” the document states.To ensure transparency and abolition of inspector raj, the state plans to set up Points of Sale (PoS) and issue sale receipts to customers, an official said.The policy document also talks about strengthening the excise department by e-auctioning vehicles used in illegal transportation of liquor seized by it and police in 2020-21. The move is estimated to fetch Rs 25 crore of which 50 per cent will be given to the department for purchasing logistics. It also proposes setting up excise laboratories in Bharatpur and Bahrod.“According to the policy, the state government will focus on three things — temperance, responsible drinking and social responsibility. Revenue generation is one of the objectives of the government, but not primary. Temperance and running a campaign to discourage people from consuming liquor will be the primary objective so far as implementation of this policy is concerned. De-addiction centres will be set up on similar lines of Kerala,” said an official.The number of IMFL (1,000) and country liquor shops (6,665) has not been increased and the timing for the sale of liquor remains the same from 10am to 8pm, the policy says.“We have also started the concept of geo-tagging and the location of the shops has to be approved online by the district excise officer (DEO). In addition, it has been proposed that liquor shops should not be located within 200 metres of anganwadis, along with schools and religious places (which was introduced earlier),” the official said.

Title: Coronavirus: 2 Wuhan students put in isolation 2 wks after return
Content:
Representataive image.

MUMBAI: Two medical students from Wuhan who landed in Mumbai on January 25 were placed in isolation at BMC’s Kasturba Hospital on Friday, February 7, and tested for the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (nCoV).It is not clear how these 24-year-old medical students, who hail from Kerala, reached Andheri despite the central health ministry’s guideline to test every traveller from Wuhan—the epicentre of the 2019-nCoV outbreak— for the virus even if they are asymptomatic.“We got a call from Kasaragod (Kerala) health officials stating that these two medical students are in Mumbai and should be picked up for testing,” said Maharashtra Disease Surveillance Officer Dr Pradeep Awate on Saturday. The state health officials then called the students who willingly came to Kasturba, near Saat Raasta.“Both these medical students left Wuhan on January 22 and are without symptoms so far,” said BMC’s additional municipal commissioner S Kakani. Their swab samples are being tested at Kasturba, but have also been sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune. The tests results are awaited.“As our testing facility is new, we have to send 13 samples to NIV which will check them for corroboration,’’ said Kakani. Incidentally, only swab tests are available for the 2019-nCoV, but the state is also collecting blood samples from suspects for future tests that can be developed.While 35 travellers are in isolation, 30 have tested negative and results of five more, including the two students from Wuhan, are awaited.Meanwhile, the Chinese traveller at Pune’s Naidu Hospital isolated after vomiting on a flight tested negative.Between January 18 and February 8, 18,084 travellers were screened at Mumbai airport. “Field surveillance is also actively on for people coming from nCov-affected areas,” said Dr Awate, adding the state has got 140 travellers so far, 57 of whom completed their followup of 14 days.

Title: KSFE upbeat despite Rs 110cr drop in profit
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: A steep fall in profit is not necessarilyan indicator of debilitating financial health. It is so at least in the case of Kerala State Financial Enterprises (KSFE), which, as per a review report by state bureau of public enterprises, has posted a significant slump of around Rs 110 crore in its profit for the 2018-19 fiscal.

The report tabled in the assembly, along with other budget documents, sheds light on a seemingly disturbing fact about the financial health of KSFE. In the summary of performance, the report said the public enterprise’s profit plummeted by 57.39%. According to the report, KSFE’s profit dropped despite a much impressive annual growth of 14.38% in its gross income. The gross income of KSFE jumped by Rs 301 crore to Rs 2,473.61 crore in 2018-19 from Rs 2,161.68 crore during the previous fiscal.

But in the balance sheet, the profit of the public enterprise tumbled to Rs 81.36 crore from Rs 190.93 crore in the previous financial year. “It is reported that it is mainly due to an increased expenses of employee benefits and other expenses incurred by the company during the year under review,” concluded the public enterprises review report, leaving room for speculation about KSFE’s financial health.

But the state economic review report tells a different story. It shows that thePSE achieved a strong financial strength despite incurring a significant reduction in profit. According to the report, the company has jacked up its reserve and surplus by Rs 315 crore in the 2018-19 financial year, taking its cash reserve to a whopping Rs 854 crore as against Rs 620 crore as on March 2017.

People in the know say it was a well-thought-out move anticipating possible action by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) aimed at non-banking finance companies like KSFE, especially since financial experts have started blaming the liquidity crisis faced by NBFCs, including IL&FS and DHFL, for the current financial stress in the market. Words of KSFE chairman Peelipose Thomas give credence to such arguments.

“The profit slump doesn’t set the alarm bells ringing in the case of KSFE. It’s not accidental, but the result of a deliberate and cautious decision we have taken in consultation with competent authorities in the government. KSFE, no doubt, is in the pink of health. Anybody who goes through our gross income figures can find it so. We simply don’t want to fall into a crisis if at all the RBI, sometime in the future, asks us to keep reserve and surplus on par with what it stipulates for banking institutions,” Thomas said.

The decision to set apart a large chunk of gross income to reserve and surplus would help KSFE to achieve a more formidable financial position that could help the institution address possible changes in the RBI rules. “KSFE would continue to build up its reserve and surplus more in the coming years, even if it means that its profit doesn’t look that flashy,” he said.

Title: Ahmedabad: Intimations of higher love
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nooran Sisters will perform on February 14 at 8.30pm

AHMEDABAD: The stillness of the riverfront props up one side of Mallika Sarabhai ’s Darpana Academy of Performing Arts . A torrent of traffic holds up the other end.

In the academy’s red-brick calmness — lying between blue-green water and blurred colours of flowing traffic — Sarabhai conducts inquiries into truth and beauty, which Keats argued become one.

That oneness will be the theme of the Nooran Sisters ’ performance at Natarani, on Darpana’s campus, on February 14. The sisters are hailed as the ‘Queens of Sufi music’. “We are delighted that we are bringing the sisters for the first time to Ahmedabad,” Sarabhai told TOI. “Sufi music is powered by the yearning for the beloved: that beloved could be divinity.” It is fitting that the sisters will sing of love on Valentine ’s Day.

The quest for wholeness, completed with the union with God, is a motif that has produced the brightest moments of plaintiveness in music. In the Carnatic tradition, for instance, Saint Thyagaraja’s kriti “Nanu palimpa nadaci vaccitivo” imagines that God has disregarded the minor logistic inconvenience of travelling from heaven to earth. God makes that trip because the call of love cannot be ignored. The Telugu line, roughly translated, means: “Have you walked all the way to save me?”

The Nooran Sisters — Jyoti and Sultana — come from Jalandhar and are in their twenties. But their voices carry the ageless echoes of spiritual longing.

From their padmasana pose on the stage, they erupt with the lava of rockstar energy.

Their molten notes have made audiences jump off the seats in India, the US, Canada, and Bangladesh. Their hits include “Patakha Guddi”, “Allah hu”, and “Jugni”.

Sarabhai told TOI that Darpana does not eschew everyday concerns in its meditations on art.

Arthur Miller believed that a good newspaper is a nation talking to itself.

Art, then, could be beauty asking life to tell the truth. After the sisters perform, Amdavadis will perhaps suspend their worries about commuting to office the next morning and think about the destination where art answers honest questions.

Title: Performance-based fin aid for 21 blocks in Rajasthan
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Rajasthan’s 21 blocks in 17 districts will be rewarded with financial assistance by the jal shakti ministry under the Atal Jal Yojana, provided they show improvement in groundwater table, socio-economic condition and better implementation of social welfare schemes.Introduced by the Centre on December 25, 2019, the scheme has formally been started by the regional office of jal shakti in Jaipur. All these blocks are in rural areas. The baseline survey of villages falling under the scheme has started and will form the basis for evaluation for financial rewards.S K Jain, regional director, Central Ground Water Board, jal shakti told TOI that financial benefits will be based on the overall performance of the block. “Implementation of schemes like Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Siddhi (PMKSS), MGNREGA, Swachh Bharat Mission, Pradhan Mantri Awas Yogna to name a few will be evaluated along with its impact on the irrigated areas, crop productivity, crop diversification, social parameters of residents’ like health, education and community development,” said Jain.In Jaipur, two chosen blocks under the scheme are – Govindgarh and Amber. Other than implementation of schemes, evaluation will be made also on how effectively farmers under the block will be utilizing limited water resources for better crop productivity.He said budget allocated for scheme for five years is Rs 6,000 crore for the chosen blocks across the country. “The office feels that all chosen blocks to claim 100% reward which will be utilised for extension of the government scheme benefiting the residents quality of life,” said Jain.The ministry is developing a reward model or guidelines based on performance. The Centre will work in tandem with water resource, agriculture, panchayati raj and PHED departments. Other than monitoring, these departments will encourage the residents to save water, sustainable living, role they can play in implementation in government schemes.

Title: Search on for techie after coracle capsizes in Karnataka
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Rescue personnel search for Sachin Machaiah (inset), who’s suspected to have drowned after he ventured into th... Read More

BENGALURU: A techie is suspected to have drowned after he fell into Kalkere Lake in the early hours of Saturday. He and his friend had partied till late night before they ventured into the water body on a coracle .

Sachin Machaiah, 27, was employed with a private company in Manyata Tech Park and lived in Electronics City. He fell into the lake around 3am when the coracle capsized after the duo lost balance. His friend Ullas, a resident of Ramamurthynagar, escaped by swimming to the shore, police said.

Swimmers and rescue personnel were deployed to trace Sachin, but couldn’t make any breakthrough till evening. The search operation will resume on Sunday, police said.

Preliminary investigations revealed Sachin and Ullas were good friends for several years and were colleagues till six months ago when Ullas moved to a new job. They had partied near the lake several times in the past and sat down to chat on Friday night as well. After midnight, they sneaked inside the lake area through the rear gate by hoodwinking security guard Rajesh Erappa, who was stationed at the front gate.

Based on Ullas’ statement, police said the two decided to go for a boat ride and picked up a coracle that was lying nearby. Though there were no paddles around, the two sailed for a few feet in the water when the coracle rocked. While Ullas swam to safety and raised an alarm, Sachin did not make it to the shore. Earappa rushed to the spot and alerted police.

A senior officer from the fire and emergency department said the coracle could have capsized as Sachin weighed more than Ullas. “There should be a balance of weight in the coracle. Gathering from Ullas’ statements, we assume Sachin was sitting on the right corner. As the coracle moved, it tilted to the right and capsized,” an officer said. Sachin hailed from Virajpet in Kodagu and had got married last year.

Title: Union minister assures all help to seafood sector
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Minister of state for commerce and industry Som Parkash at the Multispecies Aquaculture Complex at Vallarpadam... Read More

KOCHI: All help will be provided to the seafood sector by the central government to make India the number one exporter, said minister of state for commerce and industry Som Parkash. India occupies fourth position now.

He was addressing the 22nd India International Seafood Show in Kochi on Saturday. The minister stressed the importance of “working together with a new vigour with all the stakeholders, including the state governments and the Marine Products Export Development Authority (MPEDA)”.

Acknowledging that the sector was facing a plethora of problems in achieving the production and export targets without compromising on quality and environment, the minister said that the government was willing to address each issue as it would contribute to the country’s overall economic development besides improving employment opportunities. At present, the sector provides employment to about 14.5 million people in the country.

The newly-instituted MPEDA chairman’s award for Most Responsible Exporter of the Year 2018-19 was given to Gadre Marine Products Pvt Ltd, Ratnagiri, Maharashtra. The Lifetime Achievement Award, another new initiative, went to Abraham J Tharakan , chairman and managing director of Kerala’s Amalgam Group.

State fisheries minister J Mercykutty Amma sought liberal financial assistance from the Centre for upgradation of the fishing industry in Kerala, including for replacement of the kerosene engine by more environment-friendly engines and for expansion of inland aquaculture . “Finance from the Centre was required also for implementing the state’s plan to popularize deep sea fishing,” she said.

The seafood exporters emphasized that the government should also ensure that the Chinese market remained open to India, particularly in view of the fact that the neighbouring country had become a net importer. A plea was also made to relook at policy matters relating to primary producers and exports.

It was also pointed out at the meet that Andhra Pradesh and a few other states had taken a march over Kerala in shrimp aquaculture and advised the producers to be extremely cautious on environmental issues.

Title: Trail of 17 boats and ideas keep hopes of clean Gomti afloat
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Residents enjoy the boat trail in the city on Saturday

LUCKNOW: Once considered as an agent of salvation and lifeline of Lucknow, Gomti is now neither clean nor sacred. Rather, one may contract disease just by stepping into its shallow waters.

To highlight the importance of the river, Lucknow chapter of Indian National Trust for Art and Cultural Heritage (INTACH) organised a boat trail ‘Nadi Mein Naadswar’, from Shaheed Smarak to Kudia Ghat, on Saturday.

Amid reverberations of old Bollywood songs and with more 120 residents on 17 boats, the trail covered city’s skyline of domes and minarets, followed by an intricate discussion on regulatory interventions that may be adopted to contribute towards a cleaner Gomti.

Convener of INTACH Vipul B Varshney said, “The need for this programme was felt when helmsmen at Shaheed Smarak refused for a boat ride stating that nothing can pass through the river due to blockage by water hyacinth and garbage. Several solutions were suggested by city-based environmentalists and professors of IIT-Kanpur.”

The measures included mapping and demarcation of the entire Gomti floodplain from the source to confluence with river Ganga. The silt which has been deposited in the riverbed along major settlements in Lucknow, Jaunpur, Sultanpur and 11 other districts should be removed.

According to experts, sugar factories and distilleries located along the river in Sitapur and upstream should be strictly monitored as they are known for discharging major pollutants in the river.

Later, speaking during panel discussion experts said no construction work should be allowed on 250km stretch along river Gomti, and a river garden should be developed along it.

They said significant incentives for afforestation along the river banks for next 10 years should also be announced by the government. The river garden should create a micro-ecosystem for birds, insects, flora and fauna, they added.

City-based historian Yogesh Praveen said Gomti should be declared the state river of Uttar Pradesh.

He said to revive the river, city’s drainage system should be improved and dumping of solid waste in the river should be prohibited.

“Nawab Wajid Ali Shah used to organise cultural festivals on the river banks while other nawabs owned steam vehicles for pleasure rides. Chhatar Manzil would be lit up and dance and music on various boats would go all night. It could have been Seine or Thames of Lucknow, but sadly it is nothing near that now. A concrete plan has to be chalked out by the government to revive it before it becomes invisible from the map of Lucknow in future,” said Praveen.

Title: After Madhya Pradesh govt rejects UPSC panel, DGP VK Singh meets CM Kamal Nath
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Madhya Pradesh chief minister Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: Director general of police V K Singh had a lengthy closed room meeting with chief minister Kamal Nath on Saturday, a day after Madhya Pradesh government rejected a panel of three IPS officers sent by UPSC for director general of police on the grounds that it overlooked “willingness” of one of them.

Though Singh passed it off as a routine affair, insiders say he expressed his displeasure over certain issues and put forth his views in the meeting with the CM. This one-to-one meeting between the CM and DGP has taken place after a gap of almost a month.

Those named in the panel sent by UPSC were senior IPS officers V K Singh, Vivek Johri and Maithli Sharan Gupt.

In a letter to the UPSC secretary, MP home secretary Rajesh Kumar Jain wrote that Johri (1984 batch) has not given his ‘ willingness ’ for the post of DGP in writing, so naming him in the panel is against the mandate of UPSC’s guidelines for selection.

It is now being said that Johri, is ready to give his willingness. “If he gives his willingness, the panel stands, and DGP would have to be finalized from the same list,” said an officer wishing anonymity. He also said that there is no system of giving willingness in writing. “If there is non-willingness, the officer concerned is supposed to give a letter citing reasons,” he said.

MP home secretary had informed UPSC that their recommendation has been rejected and sought a fresh meeting of the selection committee. “State government will send a new proposal to the commission on the matter at the earliest,” Jain wrote.

Title: ‘Pakistan’ in Gujarat child’s birth papers leaves parents worried
Content:
Sarfaraz Khan, great grandfather of the child (L), Shaleha Bibi Pathan, grandmother of the child

AHMEDABAD: Even as concerns and insecurity about proof of one’s nationality are rife in the wake of protests raging over Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and National Register of Citizens (NRC), imagine if your birth certificate has ‘Pakistan’ in your address line!A family in Vatva area of the city is highly distressed after the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) issued birth certificate for their 18-month old son with residence address mentioning ‘Pakistan railway crossing’.Mohammed Uzerkhan, the 18-month-old son of Arbazkhan Pathan and Mahekbanu Pathan, was born on October 1, 2018 at VS hospital. Pathan family is resident of Char Maliya Society near Vatva railway crossing.Shaleha Bibi Pathan, grandmother of the child and mother of Arbazkhan, collected his birth certificate from a civic centre on February 3. However, when the family read the certificate carefully they were shocked as the resident address line mentioned ‘Near Pakistan Railway Station’ as a landmark.Talking to TOI, Shaleha Bibi Pathan said, “After the enactment of CAA and talks of NRC, we are making frantic efforts to get our records in place. Four days ago, we went to the AMC to get the certificate and were shocked by this address. We tried to get it rectified at the civic centre but nobody paid any heed to our pleas. So we rushed to the office of the Danilimda Congress councillor Badruddin Shaikh.”Shaleha fears that mention of ‘Pakistan railway crossing’ in the birth certificate of her grandson may lead to difficulties in getting an aadhaar card or even PAN card. She expressed concern that the child may also be denied admission in a school.Sarfaraz Khan, great grandfather of the child and father of Shaleha said that this is a grave mistake as the references to the area in local parlance has got reflected in the official record.The crossing in the area is informally referred to as ‘Pakistan crossing’ as it is near a Muslim-dominated locality housing around 2,200 families referred as ‘Chhota Pakistan’. The area is officially named ‘Vasant Gajendragadkar Nagar EWS Housing’ named after the state’s first general secretary of the Jan Sangh Party in Gujarat.In Vatva, there are other localities too named after south-east Asian countries. For instance, the neighbouring Sadbhavana Nagar and Khushabahu Thakre Colony which is mostly Hindu-dominated is known as ‘Hindustan’.Shyama Prasad Mukherjee Colony with 992 housing units is nicknamed ‘Sri Lanka’. An EWS cluster has been recently nicknamed ‘Africa’.Activists say that local references getting reflected in official records is a serious lapse and should be rectified.Badruddin Shaikh, who is also former opposition leader in the AMC, said, “This is a criminal offence and the AMC should get the papers for this 18-month-old boy who even does not know what a birth certificate is.”Shaikh has written to the municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra, urging him to get the mistake rectified.Bhavin Joshi, who is in-charge of Registrar of Birth and Death, said, “We have checked the child’s records and found that our official record mentions the same address that was entered in the VS Hospital register. The record show that the father of the child has even signed the register attesting the records. They should have raised objection at that time.”He however, said that the parents have been called on Monday and after verifying their documents, due correction would be made.

Title: CM Ashok Gehlot vows to make public welfare-centric budget
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

CM Ashok Gehlot

JAIPUR: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Saturday said farmers, livestock rearers, dairy associations have a significant contribution to the state’s GDP and economy while adding that the government will prepare a ‘ public welfare-centric budget ’.

Gehlot said the feedback given by voluntary organisations, social workers and civil society have an important role in the implementation of government schemes and policies at grassroot level.

The chief minister was addressing a pre-budget interactive session with voluntary organisations, farmers, consumer forums here. The representatives of the Divyang community also put forward their demands with regard to giving the status of BPL category to their families, as mentioned in the manifesto of the party, and nominate the persons with disability to the post of a parshad and members in the municipal and panchayat bodies.

He said it was an effort of his government to include important suggestions of various social organisations in the preparation of the ‘public welfare budget ’ so that the benefits of the budget can reach every section of the society.

He said the suggestions made by voluntary organisations have been instrumental in formulating laws like Right to Information, Food Security Act and Right to Education. Gehlot said the role of NGOs and social workers is important to maintain harmony in the society.

He said the government realises that even after running various welfare schemes and programmes, there is a lot of scope for optimistic improvement of farmers’ lives.

Title: In Madhya Pradesh, Congress alarmed by BJP’s bid to count tribals as Hindus
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Madhya Pradesh chief minister Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath is concerned by reports in sections of media that RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat wants tribal community members to be counted as Hindus in the 2021 census .

Bhagwat was in Bhopal last week for a meeting of Sangh leaders from Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh. Both states have huge tribal populations — MP over 21% and Chhattisgarh nearly 32%. The state BJP insists tribals are the “first and original Hindus”.

“They have been living on this soil for thousands of years. For us, Hindutva is a way of living and tribals are 100% Hindus. They are the first line of Hindus. If you disassociate them, the community becomes soft target for missionaries and conversions,” said state BJP spokesman Hitesh Vajpayee. “By keeping them with a separate identity, Congress is indirectly helping missionaries,” he claimed.

Amid reports that RSS will launch a campaign to persuade tribals to identify themselves as Hindus, sources say, CM Nath has ordered senior officials to keep a watch on RSS activities in the 89 tribal blocks of MP. “CM will never allow anyone to play with the sentiments of tribals,” said PCC media department chairperson Shobha Oza.

“RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat was the person who advocated ending of reservations. RSS, which wants to end reservation for deprived classes, now wants to identify tribals as Hindus. Tribals have a different identity, they have a separate culture. Why does RSS want tribals to be marked as Hindus?” asked Oza.

Law minister P C Sharma said, “RSS claims it is a cultural organization, but its agenda is primarily based on religion and their motive is to divide the nation. BJP does exactly as the Sangh says. In the Constitution, every citizen has the right to expression. RSS cannot make that choice of religion for a citizen.”

Higher education minister Jitu Patwari argued, “For thousands of years, diversity has been the identity of this country. Tribals have a traditional way of living. In the Andamans, the government spends massive amounts of money to ensure that tribals can live their traditional life. The Constitution gives equal rights to everyone. I am a Hindu, so I identify myself as Hindu. If you force someone to identify otherwise, it is a sheer violation of Fundamental Rights.”

State BJP spokesman Rajneesh Agarwal, however, argued, “If Congress party, under pressure from separatists, tries to divide society, it will prove to be dangerous. Provisions under NPR and law is sufficient to conduct the census. Encouraging tribals to give false identity will keep them outside the purview of development.” Leader of opposition Gopal Bhargava went so far as to allege that CM Nath wants tribals to be converted to Christianity on instructions from AICC president Sonia Gandhi.

“CM Nath has threatened action on RSS — an organization that wants to bring tribals of Madhya Pradesh and rest of the country into mainstream Sanatan Dharma. Kamal Nath should first study the background, history and culture of tribals. Tribals have been an integral part of Sanatan Dharma and there is no need to prove it. Lord Rama tasted berries offered by Shabari, a tribal. From Treta Yug to Dwapar Yug, tribals have played a major role. To now say that tribals are not Hindus and threatening action is very unfortunate,” LoP Bhargava said on Saturday.

“There have been instances of playing with sentiments of Hindus before. I know this is happening with instructions from Congress national president Sonia Gandhi and Christians. CM Nath wants to convert tribals to Christianity from Chhindwara onwards. But RSS will never let Congress’ conspiracy succeed,” Bhargava said.

Title: Cash-strapped KWA gets Rs 675 crore
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state budget has allocated Rs 675 crore for the cash-strapped Kerala water authority ( KWA ).

Hinting at a probable hike of water tariffs, finance minister TM Thomas Isaac said that the gap between cost of production of water and revenue should be reduced. “The average cost of one kilo litre of water is Rs 23.72, but the average price of water is Rs 9.50. A fundamental restructuring is inevitable to bridge this gap,” Isaac said.

He said that the bottled water from KWA will be made commercially available by this financial year. The budget has announced sanctioning of Rs 2 crore for completion of the bottled water project at Aruvikkara. Already, Rs 16 crore has been spent on the project.

The budget has allocated Rs 864 crore for irrigation. The minister said that Rs 1,051 crore has been spent on Muvattupuzha Valley irrigation project, which was commissioned in 1974, with an estimated cost of Rs 21 crore. tnn

Title: Three killed as car rams into truck in Chittorgarh
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Jaipur: Three people were killed and as many injured on Saturday in an accident in Chittorgarh district, police said.

The accident occurred near the Jalia checkpost when a car coming from Neemuch in Madhya Pradesh rammed into a stationary truck .

Two people died on the spot while one more succumbed to injuries while undergoing treatment at a hospital, said assistant sub-inspector Ghisulal of the Nimbahera police station.

He said three people injured in the accident were referred to Udaipur.

Two of the deceased were identified as Saurabh and Abdul from Dhulia in Maharashtra, the official added. PTI

Title: McKinsey top recruiter in Cluster I
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Ahmedabad: The first of three clusters of PGP 2020 placements completed on Friday at Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad (IIM-A). Consulting firm McKinsey emerged as top recruiter with 27 offers including pre-placement offers, followed by The Boston Consulting Group (BCG) with 23.

The first cluster comprised of four cohorts of investment banking & markets, management consulting, advisory consulting and private equity, venture capital & asset management. Some of the recruiters included Accenture Strategy, Kearney, Avendus, Bain & Co., Citi, Credit Suisse, Goldman Sachs, HSBC, JP Morgan, KPMG, McKinsey & Company, Monitor Deloitte, Matrix Partners, Multiples, Nomura, Oliver Wyman, & The Boston Consulting Group among others. Several new recruiters including Blackstone Group and Strategy also participated this year, said IIM-A officials.

Among finance firms, Avendus was the top recruiter with 10 offerstnn

Title: Artificial Intelligence could help in arbitration in globalised era, says CJI
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

File photo

NEW DELHI: A fortnight after making it public that judiciary is exploring use of artificial intelligence to speed up justice delivery, Chief Justice S A Bobde on Saturday said traditional methods of arbitration in India could be augmented by use of AI to achieve international standards.

Speaking at an International Conference on ‘Arbitration in the Era of Globalisation’, organised by Indian Council of Arbitration and FICCI, the CJI said, “As we conceptualise international arbitration in a globalised era, we must also be cognisant of the synergistic opportunities available for international arbitration through utilisation of disruptive technologies.”

“Artificial Intelligence could provide immense benefits for the arbitration process and its users. By augmenting human cognitive abilities, AI powered services could assist lawyers in drafting, identification of better authorities, reviewing documents etc. It is also well placed to assist arbitral tribunals in preparation of award, simultaneous judicial review, streamlining case management etc. AI-based analytics system could be used to predict costs, duration and possible resolution including proposing a range of settlement based on analysis of previous arbitrations of similar size and complexity. AI-assisted arbitration holds immense promise for the arbitration community,” he said.

On January 24, CJI Bobde had said he was looking to employ AI, which reads one million characters per second, in judiciary to help judges get gist of voluminous petitions quickly and propel the pace of case disposal.

With the three-tier justice delivery system crawling under the heavy load of nearly three crore cases, he had said, “The AI systems we are currently looking to employ in courts, possesses reading speed of one million characters per second. I can imagine a system similar to this can be used to read and extract all relevant facts, compute tax effect and assist in a myriads of new ways to propel the pace of decision-making.”

Speaking at the 79th Foundation Day function of Income Tax Appellate Tribunal (ITAT), he had said, “Understanding the nature of the matters decided by the Tribunal, artificial intelligence can play a very significant role in docket management and decision-making.”

On use of AI by other jurisdictions, the CJI said, “I find it reassuring to discover that more nations are taking steps towards experimenting and implementing AI in their respective justice delivery systems. This goes to say that we are doing and must continue to do everything in order to tackle with the workload in judicial process. AI, as I see, brings new hope to drive the public faith in our (judicial) institutions.”

Title: VNIT help sought to solve Sadar flyover traffic mess
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nagpur: The National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) and city traffic police have sought help from Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology (VNIT) to decongest traffic at the landing of the newly constructed Y-shaped Sadar flyover near Kasturchand Park.

The flyover, which was inaugurated by city MP and Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari on January 9, is causing a bottleneck on the side of its landing between Vidhan Bhavan Square and LIC Square on the busy Wardha-Kamptee Road.

Though traffic police have blocked the road at the flyover’s landing for vehicles coming from Samvidhan Square and moving towards LIC Square by installing barricades, it has increased violations at the flyover. Most two-wheeler riders and autorickshaws can be seen taking a U-turn from the flyover.

Traffic police have also urged the NHAI to extend the existing divider at the landing of the flyover near Kasturchand Park. “Subsequently, we will extend the divider by almost 500 metre,” said a senior NHAI official.

In a joint study conducted by NHAI and traffic police, they had shortlisted two solutions — installing traffic signals at the landing and restricting vehicles going toward LIC Square from Samvidhan Square. No signals have been installed there and instead, traffic police diverted the vehicles from beneath the Sadar flyover. They were either taking the Shriram Towers road or using the Liberty Square road to move towards Kamptee Road.

An NHAI official said during a spot visit, the VNIT team suggested getting more space at the landing of the flyover by acquiring MSEDCL sub-station land near Kasturchand Park. “It will not be feasible as Kasturchand Park metro station is also being constructed there. If we accept this move, it may further add to the chaos,” the official said.

He said that they are also studying MahaMetro’s proposal to treat Kasturchand Park as traffic rotary and declare all the three roads along it as one-way.

Title: ‘The Shoes’ shines by polishing child poverty before worldSlug: Crushed Childhood
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nagpur: Contemporary cinema beautifully highlights the emotional and hidden aspect of our society in the shortest time possible and the Roshan Bhondekar-directed short film, ‘ The Shoes ’, which narrates the story of a child in search of happiness, is a fresh example of it.

Bhondekar, a film maker and director who hails from Tumsar, a small town in Maharashtra, made this film in association with Envision Film Studio, a production house. This film has won the prestigious ‘Award of Recognition’ for liberation, social justice and protest from the ‘The Accolade Global Film Competition’.

‘The Shoes’, a three-minute, four-second film, released on June 29, 2019. It has an exceptional storyline. It’s about a child in search of happiness while looking at other children on the streets. The film gives a social message about poverty-ridden children who are deprived of basic needs like food, water, shelter and even a shoe. It brings out the pain of children, who lives miserable lives while growing up.

The film was shot is Madrid (Spain) with child artistes from the same country playing key roles. The societal and emotional content of the film, which struck a chord with the audience, clinched the Accolade Global Film competition award in San Diego (California) on May 29, 2019.

Before its release, the film was screened at various film festivals. It was also broadcast on Spanish TV channels. “It was a life-changing experience for me to shoot a film on child poverty. The prestigious award is a result of immense hard work and teamwork,” said Bhondekar.

“It’s a surreal feeling when people from different parts of the globe appreciate your film. We will keep doing our best to put the best talent on the screen. It’s an honour to share the stage with Oscar-winning production projects,” added Roshan.

The award recognizes the exceptional craft and creativity of media professionals from the world of films, television and videography who produce standout content to bring about a positive change in the society. The entries are judged by noted personalities from the industry. “We never expected this honour to come our way,’ said Roshan.

Alicia Cornide, Valentina Ortiz, Iria Gonzalez, Carla Bote and Adriana Segador are the child artistes from Spain who played different roles in the film which was produced by Sahra Ardah of Spain.

More than the award, Bhondekar wants the film to spread the message of humanity and also to educate the audience about the plight of poor children.

Rick Prickett, who chairs The Accolade Global Film Competition, said, “Winning the award is not an easy task. We receive entries from all over the world, including big production companies and budding talent. The accolade helps set the standard for craft and creativity. The judges were pleased with the exceptional quality of the entries. The aim is to help winners achieve the recognition they deserve,” he added.

Title: Kamptee Rd flyover: Mohan Ngr residents to meet NHAI
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nagpur: Residents of Mohan Nagar and Gaddigodam will meet Naresh Wadetwar, regional officer of National Highways Authority of India (NHAI), on January 11 over Kamptee Road flyover issue.

NHAI has rejected MahaMetro’s revised plan to start the flyover near LIC Square and asked it to start construction in front of SFS Church. The residents strongly oppose this location as they fear for safety of their lives.

The residents led by Father Patrick Lemos of SFS Church met Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari and told him that MahaMetro had started construction opposite the church despite his assurance. Gadkari asked them to meet Wadetwar and Brijesh Dixit, managing director of MahaMetro.

Gadkari had earlier called up Dixit and asked him the reason for not changing the plan. Dixit told him NHAI had rejected the revised plan due to technical reasons.

The initial plan was to start the flyover opposite the church. When locals strongly opposed it and met Gadkari, he asked Dixit to prepare a revised plan. Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) passed a resolution in its general body for acquiring land near the new location.

MahaMetro then submitted a revised plan to NHAI for starting the flyover near LIC Square. Recently, NHAI rejected it without giving any reason.

Wadetwar told TOI that as the earlier design had been approved by technical section of NHAI head office, he had asked MAhaMetro to stick to the initial design. Only modification is that a ramp will be constructed between Kadbi Square and Indora Square, which is expected to reduce the traffic at SFS Church end by 70%.

Title: New cell-blocking kit promises early, better cancer diagnosis
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nagpur: Diagnosing diseases by looking at single cell or small clusters of cells is called cytology or cytopathology. It’s an important part of diagnosing some types of cancers. This was conveyed by a Nagpur-born professor of cytology, Dr Vinod Shidham, who heads the department of cytopathology at Wayne State University School of Medicine and Detroit Medical Center, USA.

He said this while addressing MACyCON 2020, the 3rd annual conference organized by Association of Cytologists of Maharashtra (ACM) at AIIMS, Nagpur, on Saturday.

He has developed a novel method of taking cellblock for cytology which is known as Shidham’s method. He also demonstrated his method of taking cellblock and slide viewing in front of 150 top pathologists from across the country.

He said cytopathology can be a step before biopsy in case of cancer. “Our method addresses most of the issues related to the qualitative and quantitative integrity of final cellblocks. But it needs special skill to perform this in laboratory. We have recently introduced ready-to-use kits. With this kits, this method can be adopted easily in any routine cytology laboratory,” Dr Shidham said.

“Cytology tests are used for both diagnosis and for screening. A diagnostic test is only used for people who have signs, symptoms. Screening test can detect people who might have a certain disease even before they develop symptoms,” he said.

Formal inauguration of the conference is scheduled to be held on Sunday at 9am at AIIMS, Nagpur. Padma Shri Dr Vikas Mahatme will be the chief guest. Under the guidance of AIIMS director Dr VIBHA Dutta, who is also a pathologist, organizing team of Dr Rasika Gadkari, Dr Nisha Meshram Dr Fatema Kamal from AIIMS along with VAPM office-bearers Dr Kishor Deshpande and Dr Manjit Kaur Rajput are coordinating this conference which is first national academic event on the new premises of AIIMS in MIHAN.

….

Better Cell block technique now in Nagpur:

Cell-block is a method of preparing cytological material

It can provide diagnostic information of cancer, thyroid etc

Dr Shidham’s method of taking cellblock addresses most of issues related to qualitative and quantitative integrity.

But performing this method in individual laboratory is labour intensive and relatively non-reproducible due to skill related issues.

So, Dr Shidham has recently introduced ready-to-use kits

These kits allow preparation of qualitatively and quantitatively enhanced cellblocks from any specimen

Kits are available in AIIMS and doctors here were trained in its use on Saturday

Title: nCov scare: Chinese restaurants face heat over imported ingredients
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: “Are you using made-in-China doubanjiang (a spicy broad bean paste)?” asked a guest before placing an order for Hunan chicken at an East Asian restaurant in a city luxury hotel. The front-line order taker, without batting an eyelid, said no. Before the guest could ask a follow-up question, he said, “All ingredients used in our dishes are made in India or are brought in from Singapore.” The restaurant employee knew where the guest was headed with the question. Since the outbreak of the deadly Novel Coronavirus, which originated in China’s Wuhan region, upscale restaurants serving Chinese food have seen a number of inquiries about the source of their ingredients.

Some restaurateurs also say people are avoiding Chinese cuisine—the most popular foreign fare in India—for fear of getting infected by the virus, which causes a pneumonia-like illness.

Food importers have turned cautious. “People have halted their food shipments from China and are avoiding travelling there. It may have a long-term ripple effect and prices may shoot up in the near future,” said Amit Lohani, founder-director, Forum of Indian Food Importers.

Some Chinese restaurants confirmed they have stopped placing fresh orders for made-in-China products and have started to look for alternative sources. “Lots of ingredients come from China. We buy them through distributors. But all supplies are approved by the food regulator. Right now, we don’t foresee any issues but there will be a crunch in supplies in the coming months.
