We will have to use alternatives wherever possible and may have to make some dishes unavailable from the menus till supplies resume,” said chef Sharad Dewan, regional director-food production, The Park Hotels, which runs 22 properties in the country.

Chefs at Chinese restaurants, though, ruled out any shortage as “they usually have buffer stocks and there would not be any need for import in immediate weeks”. “Anyway, most of our items are sourced from Thailand and Hong Kong. But we are still checking with suppliers and vendors so that there is no issue in the coming weeks,” said chef Yongliang Wong of Ano Tai, a Chinese restaurant at Jaypee Vasant Continental hotel in New Delhi.

Some are avoiding Chinese, certain restaurateurs admitted. “Due to the hype on media platforms, guests are restricting themselves from visiting Chinese restaurants,” said Wong.

But at another fine-dine outlet in a five-star hotel in Goa, it was business as usual as people had queued up for a taste of chicken in hot garlic sauce and crispy vegetable roll, said its executive chef.

Anjan Chatterjee, chairman and managing director of Speciality Restaurants, echoed the view. “There has been zero impact on business.” Speciality Restaurants owns Mainland China and Asia Kitchen by Mainland China, the largest chain in this segment.

Chatterjee said, “At our restaurants, most products, for instance, noodles, are of Indian make. Only 10% of ingredients, specifically sauces, are imported. But those too are brought in from Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia. Kwong Cheong Thye and Lee Kum Kee, the brands we use, have manufacturing facilities in these regions.”

A 2019 report by National Restaurant Association of India (NRAI) highlighted that 27% of the respondents surveyed called Chinese their top favourite cuisine after North Indian fare. India’s food service industry, estimated to be Rs 4 lakh crore in fiscal 2019, is expected to reach nearly Rs 6 lakh crore in financial year 2023, NRAI had said.

Mumbai’s executive health officer Dr Padmaja Keskar said as long as food was cooked well and long enough, there can be no risk of infection. “The only problem is with fomites (objects such as clothes and utensils that could carry infection),” she said.

Indonesia plans to ban live animals and certain foods and beverages from China. Many countries, including the UK, are reporting a drop in sales of Chinese food. German Federal Institute for Risk Assessment has said given the virus’s transmission methods, infection from food exported from China is unlikely. Doctors said the fact that WHO has not mentioned Chinese food at all indicates the low risk associated with it.

Title: ‘I am ready to become a martyr to save India’
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Nagpur: 89-year-old Leelatai Chitaley , a freedom fighter and staunch Gandhian, is ready to sacrifice her life to ‘restore the Constitution’. Having been to the lock up for raising anti-British slogans in Akola at the age of 12, Leelatai stressed that this nation’s foundation was laid on the ideology of ‘Bapu-Baba’ (Gandhi and Babasaheb Ambedkar) and not Hindutva alone.

Leelatai hails from a family that has always put the nation’s cause above self. Her father resigned from the railways in protest and her elder brother was jailed by the Britishers. She feels that an ‘all-party delegation’ can find a way out of the ‘disturbing political scenario’ which is prevailing in the country.

Excerpts...

Q. You stepped out to participate in a protest against the citizenship issue. Are you ready to fight for justice once again?

A. Yes. I’m ready to face the first bullet against the citizenship issue on the lines of ‘Baalidan in Satyagraha’ (sacrificing self to embrace the truth) but my only condition is that the young generation should march along with me. Like many others, I do not have birth-related documents to prove my citizenship. So, am I at fault? The government did not maintain public records. It is their fault.

Q. Is the alleged marginalization of Muslims justified?

A. Not at all. Mohd Ali Jinnah wanted Pakistan, but a sizeable number of people from his community chose India. Whoever is born and brought up here will stay here. This government came into existence a few years ago and now, they want to send the same people who voted for them out of the country. Today, political parties who did not play a role in framing the Constitution are now trying to attain power on the lines of religious ideology. The Constitution clearly states that religion is a personal affair and needs to be safeguarded. But it cannot be a national diktat. This country has humanity flowing in its veins and not religion. The incumbent government is following an outdated ideology which does not fit into any scheme of things in today’s society.

Q. You were also a student activist in the British era. In the recent past, students were targeted in agitations like JNU and Jamia. Do you see any hidden agenda?

A. I was picked up by the British police at the age of 12 when I was urging students of a college in Akola to refrain from pursuing education in English. I was only following a call given by Gandhiji. The police released me before sunset as I was a woman and under-age as well. Under the Constitution, students are free citizens. They are the future citizens who are being mistreated. You must listen to their grievances and try to resolve them and not insult them. A mature government will always have a dialogue with them.

Q. You have been participating in marches and agitations since the 1940s. Do you see any difference in crowd agitations of your time and now?

A. Today, the mob is being misled by some politically and power-hungry parties which should not be the case. This society will agitate against anything which is not acceptable. If the same agitation had been spearheaded by Gandhiji then he would have led it on the lines of ahimsa (non-violence) and charted the course of ‘Satyagraha’. In Satyagraha, it is a fight within oneself rather than the enemy in front of you. The vision is to bring about a change in the heart and mind of the enemy through tolerance and non-violence. In our days, we used to take out ‘Prabhat pheris’.

Q. What is your assessment of the agitation against the Citizenship Act and whether it will last?

A. The current scenario is the third major ‘emergency’ in the country after the British era and Indira Gandhi’s regime. Our society is very mature and potent enough to eject the present government out of power. The situation is gradually moving in that direction. If our lawmakers in legislative bodies are not responding then our citizens must raise the issues on international platforms. This government seems to be bringing back the British era’s ‘divide and rule’ policy. Differences of vision and opinion are needed for peace and balance in the society. Without peace, one cannot expect development.

Q. What is your solution to the agitations in the country against the Citizenship Act?

A. The government must encourage an ‘all-party’ delegation. This body should meet all the aggrieved parties and have a dialogue with them to accommodate their points of view. After that, a debate should take place in Parliament to ensure that the changes suggested by different sections of the society are accommodated. There is no point in insulting protesting groups or sections of the society by labelling them with derogatory expressions like ‘tukde tukde gang’. Talk responsibly and with dignity.

Q. You also had attended a programme to felicitate the police commissioner for his pro-women measures. Do you feel women in today’s society are unsafe?

A. In the past, assaults on women and their dignity took place within the four walls of the house. Today, women are facing a similar situation in the public domain as they are stepping out in more numbers. The onus of women’s security lies with both genders. If a man is targeting a woman, then he must also feel comfortable with someone else doing the same with his family members.

Q. Do you feel today’s women draw undue attention because of their bold and extrovert lifestyle?

A. When the Constitution is guaranteeing equality and equal treatment to all then why think on discriminatory lines. Everyone is trying to avail equal opportunities guaranteed by the Constitution. Why not enjoy just being ‘yourself’ which is more dignified.

Title: Helmet for pillion rider to be mandatory in city soon
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Among the measures being taken in the city to reduce road accidents and fatalities in such accidents, the city police are now launching a drive against those riding pillion on two-wheelers. Thus those used to riding pillion helmetless must be aware.

M Ramesh Kumar, ADCP (traffic) said, “We are going to impose traffic violation cases against the rider, if their pillion is not wearing a helmet . In some of the recent road accidents involving two-wheelers, we noticed that pillion riders are worse affected than the riders themselves.”

Other officials of the department informed that in the last 11 accidents involving two-wheelers, six people riding pillion had died and five had suffered serious injuries.

Echoing the sentiment of these officials, Ramesh Kumar asserted, “It is time to take action against pillion riders so that they too use helmets.”

On December 3, 2019 TOI reported that the Visakhapatnam police are planning such a drive. The plan was made after the city’s traffic police, according to its own claim, managed to convince bikers to wear helmets with relative success. The cops are now taking strict action against errant riders riding without helmets.

Discussing how compliance with traffic rules has improved in the Port City in the recent past, a senior traffic police official told TOI, “Even a few months ago, hardly any riders in the city used to wear helmets. But over the last five months, we have started severe drives against riders riding without helmets and are slapping fines on them.”

“The results of the drives have been positive and over 70 per cent riders in the city have started using helmets,” the official added.

On average, around 600 ‘driving without helmet’ cases are lodged in a day. The police had registered 5,55,683 traffic violations in 2018. In 2019, the figure went up to over seven lakh.

Traffic police officials said that they are also trying to rope in the district education wing to create awareness with regard to helmet rules. They said that they have brought up the issue in meetings with the Visakhapatnam road safety committee as well.

“In a recent meeting, we decided that police personnel found riding without helmets will not be allowed to attend to their duty for the day. In was the same meeting where we had decided to take up the issue of pillion riders,” another traffic official informed.

Title: Civic body prepares online TDR databank for greater transparency
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC) has started establishing online databank of TDRs (transferable development rights) in a bid to improve transparency in issuing TDRs and helping landowners sell their TDRs.

As per official data, the city’s civic body has issued 2,644 TDRs since 2007 to landowners as compensation for developing roads and other amenities.

As part of the creation of the online TDR databank, the GVMC has already digitally validated around 450 TDRs in the last few days. The process is expected to be completed by February 15.

The databank will contain all the details pertaining to TDRs such as, number of TDRs issued and utilisation of TDRs. Once completed, the portal will also be linked to the Andhra Pradesh Development Permission Management System of the department of municipal administration and urban development.

TDRs are issued by urban local bodies (ULBs) in lieu of the land surrendered by owners or private developers when ULBs are not in a financial position to provide monetary compensation.

The TDR will entitle the owner of the land, in the form of a development rights certificate (DRC), which can used by the owner or be transferred. Essentially, the development rights certificate empowers the DRC holder to go for extra floor space on their residual property or transfer the DRC in the name of another person. The DRC provides the certificate holder the four times the floor space of the area lost.

TDRs are generally issued as compensation for land taken from owners for development of green spaces, playgrounds, water bodies, parking lots, city-level facilities, road widening and drainage systems.

Town planning officials of the GVMC said that the online databank of TDRs will help prevent duplication in sale of TDRs. “We will complete the process over the next week as per the instructions of the state government,” a town planning official said.

Title: Understand CAA before reacting: VP
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) does not discriminate between Indian citizens, but seeks to provide citizenship to those who are persecuted on religious grounds in neighbouring countries, Vice-President M Venkaiah Naidu said on Saturday.

“When our people, who are originally Indians, are discriminated, it is our duty to take care of them. There is no mention of discrimination against any Indian citizen in the Act. But unfortunately, a lot of misinformation campaign is being carried out by some vested interests. I appeal to the public to fully study and understand the Act before reacting,” he said during a book release function at Gitam University.

Venkaiah also expressed his concern over the recent happenings in certain legislatures and Parliament with members coming to blows and resorting to acrimonious behaviour. “I am perturbed by the vitriolic language used by members against their opponents. They all should understand that they are only political rivals, not enemies. As the chairman of Rajya Sabha, I often hang my head in shame before the students and others sitting in the gallery during these disturbing sessions,” he said.

Exhorting students to love their mother tongue, he said mother tongue is like our eyes while other languages are like eyeglasses. “Without having eyesight, what is the use of wearing glasses? The foundation of education must be done in one’s mother tongue. But students must learn as many languages as they can,” he said.

Earlier, the Vice-President visited the Eastern Naval Command (ENC) and interacted with navy officials. He also visited the indigenously built stealth frigate INS Sahyadri.

Title: City police commissioner promoted to ADG rank
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The state government issued promotion orders for several IPS officers in Andhra Pradesh on Saturday. City police commissioner Rajeev Kumar Meena, an IG (inspector general) rank officer was promoted as additional director general of police (ADG).

Along with him, Atul Singh, who is on deputation in central services at the moment, was also promoted to the ADG rank.

Four DIG rank officers— Ch Srikanth, AS Khan, J Prabhakar Rao and Dadi Nagendra Kumar were promoted to the IG rank.

Moreover, IPS officers Dr Kolli Raghurami Reddy, Ake Ravi Krishna, Sarvashresth Tripati, R Jayalakshmi were promoted to the rank of DIG.

Conferred IPS officers GVG Ashok Kumar, G Vijay Kumar, S.Harikrishna, M Ravi Prakash, SV Rajasekhar Babu, KV Mohan Rao, and PHD Ramakrishna were also promoted as DIGs.

Ch Srikanth, who has been promoted to the rank of IG is now heading the SIB— the anti-Maoist intelligence wing and is also in-charge of Octopus— the anti-terrorist wing.

Title: Int’l Baccalaureate prog in city school
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Oakridge International School, Visakhapatnam, has become the first school in Andhra Pradesh to offer International Baccalaureate Diploma Programme (IBDP).

The two-year diploma programme is offered by International Baccalaureate Organisation (IBO) based in Geneva (Switzerland), and is considered a premium and challenging course in the world.

The programme provides an internationally-accepted qualification for entry into higher education and is recognised by many universities across the world.

IBDP is known to develop skills that organisations, such as the World Economic Forum, say are most needed in the coming years — critical thinking, collaboration, cognitive flexibility and complex problem solving.

In India, the Association of Indian Universities, Delhi, recognises IBDP as an entry qualification to all universities, provided the applicant includes a document from the IBO detailing percentage equivalency.

Title: 35-year-old dies while walking out of court
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A man suffered a cardiac arrest while coming out of the Anakapalli court premises on Saturday. 35-year-old V Sattibabu of Mutturdhi village in Chodavaram mandal had gone to the court to pay a fine.

Sources said that Sattibabu was caught driving under the influence of alcohol a few days ago. The cops at Chodavaram circle had counselled him and asked him to attend court.

Witnesses said that as Sattibabu was walking out of the court area he collapsed upon suffering a cardiac arrest.

People immediately gathered near him but the man breathed his last before he could be shifted to a hospital. Sattibabu is survived by his wife and three daughters.

Title: Despite efforts, natural farming doesn’t find many takers in AP
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Visitors take a look at terrace garden plants at a 3-day Organic Farm Mela in Visakhapatnam

Visakhapatnam: While efforts are on to make Andhra Pradesh a national leader in zero-budget natural farming ( ZBNF ), ground-level progress shows that online 3 per cent of farmers are practising pesticide-free farming, according to data from the state agriculture department.

According to officials of the state agriculture department, there are nearly 60 lakh farmers in the state with around 80lakh hectares under cultivation. At present, only around 1.6 to 2 lakh farmers in the state are practising ZBNF. Karnataka and Madhya Pradesh seem to be surging ahead in terms of adoption of the practice.

However, during a three-day ‘Organic Farm Mela’ in the city, Sankar Lingala from Rythu Mitra, said in his address that ZBNF has found subscribers in north-coastal Andhra Pradesh, where more people have taken it up than in other districts.

Speaking to TOI, Lingala said, “Awareness among people, efforts by NGOs in encouraging farmers has led to the progress in adoption of natural farming in Visakhapatnam, Vizianagaram and Srikakulam.”

GSNS Leelavathi, joint director of the Visakhapatnam agriculture department said that apart from farmers, consumers too are keen on procuring organic farm-based food nowadays.

“Consumers are ready to purchase organic products despite them being a bit pricey. The government is to achieve ZBNF in the next few years. Nearly 16,000 acres of farmland is under natural farming,” added Leelavathi.

Meawhile, environmentalist JV Ratnam said that since north-coastal Andhra Pradesh has vast tracts of Agency area, the practice of using natural fertilisers like cow dung, vermin compost and such other organic manure is more prevalent here than in other areas.

“Though natural farming may not give good produce initially, in the long run, the farms will yield desired results and improve soil fertility, thereby helping the environment,” Ratnam told TOI.

Title: Agri labourer electrocuted
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

A person died upon touching a live electric wire at Ramanujapuram in Dwaraka Tirumala mandal in West Godavari district on Friday. The deceased, identified as 38-year-old Mandapati Srinu was working as a coolie in a farm. Wild boars were damaging the crop at the field for some time. Consequently, he had set up an electric fence around the field.

On Friday morning, when he went to the field to remove the electric wire he slipped and was electrocuted. Srinu died on the spot. His body was shifted to Eluru General Hospital for post-mortem. Further investigation is on. tnn

Title: Anti-CAA meeting held in city
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Retired Bombay High Court Justice Kolse Patil said that CAA and NRC acts are very dangerous to the public of around 50 crore in the country. He said CAA would prove costly to not only Muslims but also Hindus. It would claim Hindus also intruders. He said around 24 crore population in the country do not have Aadhar cards and another 20 are not having birth certificates. So all these people would be in the detention camps.

Addressing the gathering at AP Civil Liberties Committee state meeting held here on Saturday, the Justice said around 19 lakh people of Assam have no identity cards following the implementation of NRC in that state. They were all put in the concentration camps. Out of 19 lakhs, only four lakh are Muslims and 15 lakh are Hindus.

Kolse Patil said that Rs. 20 is the daily income of around 45 crore peoples across the nation. All these people would become not Indians. AU Professor Satyapal, Law College Principal Prof. S Sumitra , Prof. KP Subba Rao and Telangana Civil Liberties Committee leader V Raghunath alleged that if the citizenship faces problems then what about primary rights of the people.

AP Civil Liberties Committee presdeint V Chittibabu and Secretary Chilaka Chandra Sekhar and Telangana committee leader Narayana Rao opposed the CAA and NRC. They said that civil rights activists faced many cases in the past and also facing now. They accused that Osmania University professor Kasim was illegally detained by the cops.

Title: Win for sustainable farming: Farmer duo grows corn that look like jewels
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Picture of the corn grown by the two farmers at their Hyderabad-based farm. They say that this corn is native ... Read More

VISAKHAPATNAM: When kernels of corn glimmered like rare jewels, Abhinav Gangumalla and Renu Rao rejoiced. After seven long years, these two farmers practising sustainable farming managed to harvest the glass gem corn which is native to North America at their farm in Hyderabad.

The duo was trying to crack the process since 2013, but has now managed to grow this rare species of corn. Since 2013, the duo was using trial and error to crack the production process of glass gem corn. They have also managed to harvest strawberry corn and purple corn.

Speaking to TOI, Abhinav Gangumalla, who did his BTech in civil engineering from Gitam University in Visakhapatnam , said that he was not happy with the corporate rat-race and therefore he decided to pursue sustainable farming.

Abhinav, who is now also a wellness coach, opened a store called ‘Hyderabad Goes Green’ in 2010. Then, in 2014, his partner Renu Rao and he bought 4.5 acres of land to practice sustainable agriculture.

Their farm— called ‘Beyond Organic’ is known for conserving native seeds and growing new varieties in a seasonal manner. This is where this corn variety was harvested. Stating that all the three varieties of corn were grown in sustainable ways, Abhinav said, “I was just short of tears when I finally saw the glass gem corn because we worked hard for it for seven years. Although we wanted to grow this beautiful corn, we failed consistently.”

“It was grown like normal corn but by using sustainable practices at the farm. After it was harvested, we cooked it and surprisingly, the colour remained,” added Abhinav.

He added that the glass gem corn tasted more authentic and also looked more beautiful with crystals adorning the crop.

Title: After FIR, 50 Mumbai Bagh protesters served notices
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Police oversee the 14th day of protest at Morland road in Nagpada

MUMBAI: A group of women sang Hum Honge Kaamyab Ek Din at Mumbai Bagh to protest against NRC-CAA , as others coming to join them were stopped by police on Saturday. Police told the women to sign notices, which few did. Police had filed an FIR against around 300 women sitting in protest on Friday night. The women, leading the protest, stated that they would not call it off till the Union government rolled back NRC.

In the last 14 days, 50 protesters, of which 11 are women, were issued notices under section 149 of CrPC. They stated that police had been telling protesters since January 26 not to continue as no permission was taken. “There could be a law and order problem. Traffic is affected and local residents are facing a problem. If something happens in the law and order situation, you will be held responsible and action will be initiated against you. This notice will be used as evidence against you in court,” the notice read. Police also noted down names and contact numbers of women going to the site.

A police team landed at the Marol residence of activist Feroze Mithiborwala and issued a copy of the notice to him too on Saturday morning. He said BMC was known for doing work slowly, and all of a sudden, it wanted to carry out work on that road.

Nagpada police had on Friday booked 300 women under section 341 (punishment for wrongful restraint) of IPC, sections of Criminal Amendment Act and BMC Act. BMC assistant commissioner Alka Sasaane, who lodged the complaint, said road construction was being done but due to the protest, there were obstacles in completing it. There were traffic issues and women seated on chairs have blocked the road, she said. Sections 313 and 314 of Mumbai Municipal Corporation Act, 1888, were invoked against the women. Section 313 states that no person shall, except with written permission of the commissioner, place upon any public place any chair, bench, box or other thing so as to form an encroachment, while section 314 gives power to remove it without notice.

BMC has undertaken concretization of roads and local corporator Rais Shaikh alleged it was ahead of time. BMC takes up major road repairs post-monsoon, and it is done till the next monsoon. During the four monsoon months, road work is put on hold.

“BMC lodged a complaint under police pressure. The road where women are protesting was constructed and only footpath work is left. I condemn this move by BMC, as road work in the area is ahead of time,” said Shaikh. Sasane did not respond to calls.

Title: ‘Denying women command posts will perpetuate discrimination’
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Countering the Centre’s stand on denying command posts to women in the Army on the ground of their physiological limitations and prevailing societal norms, the women officers have told the Supreme Court that it reflected a regressive mindset of the government , which will perpetuate gender discrimination.

Senior advocate Aishwarya Bhati, counsel for women officers seeking permanent commission and command posting in Army, said the Centre’s contentions are contrary to the records and statistics which show women officers have worked shoulder to shoulder with their male colleagues and performed extremely well- both in peace locations as well as hostile zones.

In a written note filed in the apex court on Friday, Bhati contended that the stand taken by the Centre was unfortunate and to deny command appointments to women officers would be an extremely retrograde step and pleaded the court to intervene to uphold the sacrosanct principles of gender equality as enshrined in the Constitution.

The Centre had cited male troops not yet being mentally conditioned to accept women officers in command units, greater family demands of women and dangers of them being taken prisoners of war as some of reasons to assert that women officers may not be suitable for command posts in the Army.

Questioning the government’s stand, Bhati said, “Indian Air Force and Indian Navy, having adopted the policy of complete equality for grant of permanent commission to women officers, it is extremely unfortunate that reasons of women lacking on various counts, prevailing societal norms and lack of combat exposure etc are being cited as lame excuses. It is submitted that women have been working shoulder to shoulder, with their colleagues in the Army. Even as SSC officers, they have been working as company commanders and leading soldiers from the front as per the ethos of the Army.”

“As young officers in the rank of Captain and Major, they have been in hostile and combat zone and displayed exemplary courage and bravery, acting exactly in the manner commensurate with the respect that the Indian Army commands, world over. To deny them command appointments would be an extremely retrograde step and will inflict irreparable injury to the dignity of these brave women,” she said in her note.

She said the Centre’s stand is contrary to the demonstrated fact that women officers have been serving in the 10 combat support arms for the last 27-28 years and have proven their mettle and courage under fire. “They have been found suitable by the organisation itself and have led platoons and companies of soldiers and men, both in peace locations as also hostile locations/operations, in the 10 Combat Support Arms. There has never been any occasion of soldiers/men having refused or not accepted the command of women on account of their perceived rural background, with prevailing societal norms,” she said.

The officers described as “misleading” the Centre raising the issues of national security, battlefield scenario, capture by enemy as the matter is not about allowing women officers to work in combat role.

Bhati also gave a list of decorated women officers, who showed exemplary courage in armed forces, to buttress her point that women are second to none in discharging their duty.

List of decorated women officers

1-Maj Mitali Madhumita—First lady officer to receive Sena Medal for showing exemplary courage during terrorist attack on Indian embassy in Kabul when she was posted as a leader of English language training team.

2 Sq Ldr Minty Agarwal—A fighter controller with IAF, she was part of team that guided Wing Commander Abhinandan to shoot down a Pakistani F-16 during air skirmishes post Balakot airstrike. She was awarded Yudh Seva Medal.

3 Capt Divya Ajith Kumar— At 21, she beat 244 fellow cadets (both men and women) to win the Best All- Round Cadet award and get the coveted “Sword of Honour”. She led an all-women contingent of 154 women officers and cadets during Republic Day parade in 2015.

4 Flt Officer Gunjan Saxena—During Kargil War, she made history by becoming the first woman IAF officer to fly in combat zone. Saxena flew dozens of helicopter sorties through the war zone to air-drop supplies to troops and evacuate injured soldiers. Became the first woman recipient of Shaurya Vir award.

5- Naval officers of Indian Naval Sailing Vessel (INSV) Tarini—The President awarded Nao Sena (aallantary) medal to six women crew members INSV Tarini, who circumnavigated the globe. Lt Cdr Vartika Joshi skippered the 194-day mission.

Title: Tamil Nadu governor holds key to Rajiv case convicts’ freedom
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

CHENNAI: One signature — that of Tamil Nadu governor Banwarilal Purohit — is now standing between the seven life convicts of the Rajiv Gandhi assassination case, and their freedom.

It is now the governor who shall sign their premature release warrant. The central government’s affidavit in Madras HC , in response to a habeas corpus petition filed by India’s longest serving woman prisoner, Nalini Sriharan, on Friday said it is the governor who shall take an appropriate decision on the matter. It even said the fate of convict A G Perarivalan’s mercy petition, pending before Purohit, too hinged on the governor’s “discretion”.

There are only three routes to clemency — by the President under Article 72 of the Constitution, by the governor under Article 161, and by the state government under Section 435 of CrPC.

The President has already rejected clemency multiple times and Tamil Nadu government’s bid to invoke 435 CrPC bombed after the Centre moved SC and got an order stating that “consultation” in respect of a case probed by central agencies would mean “concurrence”.

The Centre has rejected Tamil Nadu government’s early release proposal. It left only Article 161 available to the governor. Bitten once, the Tamil Nadu government adopted the Article 161 route on September 9, 2018 and recommended to the governor, who is sitting on it for more than 18 months.

Title: Navi Mumbai: 7 firemen suffer burn injuries in blasts after Seawoods tower blaze
Content:
Seven firemen sustained burn injuries during fire-fighting operations at a Nerul highrise after a major fire b... Read More

NAVI MUMBAI: Seven firemen, including two fire officers, sustained burn injuries during fire-fighting operations at a Nerul highrise after a major fire broke out in a duplex flat on the 20th and 21st floors, around 6.30am on Saturday. The incident occurred at Sea Homes Tower in Sector 44 of Seawoods in Nerul.The injured include assistant sub-fire officers G B Gade and V D Koli, leading fireman J D Joshi and firemen T J Thakare, M T Pawar, D M Jawale and J B Bhoye. They were injured after an LPG cylinder and air-conditioner compressor exploded in the 20th floor apartment, where the fire started in the electrical panel due to a short-circuit, Nerul fire officer Arun Bhoir said.The duplex owner, Chandrakant Bhansali (63), a builder, who is also the society’s chairman, and his five family members, including minors, quickly left the apartment. As the Bhansalis alerted others in the society, by ringing the fire alarm bell, residents too rushed downstairs. The blasts came after the duplex got engulfed in flames around 7.30am.Dr Sunil Keswani of National Burns Centre, Airoli, said, “All seven have sustained less than 20% burn injuries, which are patchy burns. Hence, there is nothing to worry as their vital signs are normal. But the depth of burns cannot be known on day one of treatment. Three of them are in the ICU, and the others are in the male ward.”Bhoir said, “Twenty fire engines, water browsers and mini-tenders from Vashi, Kopar Khairane, Nerul, CBD and Airoli, apart from the 68-foot Bronto Skylift from Vashi were pressed into service. As the fire hydrant system of the tower was not operational, we had to take water from the underground tank of a building on the opposite side. Water was filled in the fire engine, which was connected to the Bronto Skylift for fire-fighting operations. It took around eight hours to extinguish the fire in the five-room duplex.”Duplex owner Chandrakant Bhansali said, “I was in the kitchen with my wife when suddenly there was a power failure. Due to the smoke, water sprinklers in the flat got activated. Our family members ran out of the apartment and went downstairs.”In Video: Navi Mumbai: 5 firemen injured while battling highrise blaze

Title: Ex-CEC: VVPAT has made poll process transparent
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

NAGPUR: The process of holding free and fair elections in India has evolved over a period of time with ballet papers being replaced first by electronic voting machines (EVMs) and later by voter-verified paper audit trail ( VVPAT ) which is foolproof, said former chief elections commissioner ( CEC ) OP Rawat on Friday.

Delivering a speech on ‘India’s elections and electoral reforms’, organized by Maharashtra National Law University, Nagpur, he said VVPAT has transformed the process as voters can see for which candidate they have voted. The voting machines at poll booths are immediately replaced if there are reports of malfunctioning, he added.

Commenting on the repeated complaints of candidates exceeding the limit of expenditure as stipulated by the Election Commission, he said most of the political parties spend crores of rupees from the funds they get. In such a situation, it is very difficult to prove charges of over-expenditure by candidates in gross violation of rules, he added.

“Political parties have been increasingly using social media platforms for electioneering and there is no effective mechanism to curb such practices. This also saves money parties spend on campaigning,” he said. Short films and street plays are the other modes the political parties have adopted for election drive which does not require much money, he added.

Rawat lauded former CEC TN Seshan for ushering in electoral reforms and said he was the first bureaucrat who showed that the Election Commission has tremendous powers to curb illegal means political parties take recourse to.

It was during his regime the poll panel was feared by those using illegal means during elections. Seshan’s successors continued the high standards set by him to ensure transparency during elections, Rawat added.

It is very difficult to prove that a particular news is paid. This makes it difficult for the EC to calculate the exact expenditure by a candidate during campaigning. He also briefly spoke on the plans made by the EC to link ‘Aadhaar’ with election I-cards.

Rawat had an interactive session with the faculty and students in which he replied to various questions raised by them as regards the poll process, how the EC functions and many more.

(Reporting by Shivam Wagh)

Title: India keeps watch on TAR, troops on LAC
Content: Kolkata: Indian agencies are closely monitoring the situation in China’s Tibet Autonomous Region (TAR) that shares India’s northern border. The first case of coronavirus was detected in TAR in January. Since then, several cases have been confirmed from the Region.While restrictions have still not been imposed on trade across the Nathu La Pass in north Sikkim, the situation is being monitored closely, an official said. Indian troops are also posted along the LAC with China and the situation is being studied.“Russia has sealed its border with China. However, Wuhan is several thousands of kilometeres away from Lhasa. We should not jump to any conclusions and take drastic steps. If we get information of any serious problem in TAR, necessary steps will be taken. Our troops along the LAC are our primary concern. If necessary, they will be allotted protective equipment and an advisory will be released on how they should interact with their counterparts from across the LAC. There are routine Border Personnel Meetings with the People’s Liberation Army. The situation has improved along the LAC and we don’t want to raise an unnecessary scare,” an official said.Indian soldiers come in direct contact with their counterparts from China even during routine patrols.Trade with China along the historic Silk Route (through Nathu La) suffered in 2019 after the Doklam stand-off. Traders are worried that the coronavirus scare may affect trade in the days to come. There is also considerable concern regarding the Kailash Manasarov Yatra for 2020.While there are tours operated through Kathmandu in Nepal, the Chinese government had recently opened a route through Nathu La that is faster. India also promotes this route. Officials are worried that if the situation in China escalates, it may have an impact on the Yatra.“People have already started booking for the Yatra. We are worried of a situation where the situation in China gets worse and the Yatra has to be called off. We don’t want this to happen. People will be extremely disappointed but we can’t allow them to risk getting exposed to the virus. That is another reason why we are keeping a close watch on the situation. Indian states like Sikkim and Arunachal Pradesh in the eastern sector are also very close to China. We don’t want to take any risks,” another official added.

Title: Bengal assures help to seaman
Content: Malda: Bengal minister Gulam Rabbani has responded to an appeal from Binay Kumar Sarkar of North Dinajpur who is stranded on the Diamond Princess Rabbani, the minister of state for labour, dispatched district officials to Sarkar’s home in Hatipao village after the seaman appealed to PM Narendra Modi and CM Mamata Banerjee.“I have asked the district administration to send a report,” Rabbani told TOI. District magistrate Arvind Kr Meena said the block development officer had been sent to Sarkar’s house. “We will send the report to the state government. It can then be communicated to the external affairs ministry for communication with the Japanese government,” Meena said.Union minister of state Deboshree Choudhury, the local MP, has assured the family she will look into the matter. Mariners, though, said the quarantine was a standard operating procedure during an epidemic and pointed out that two ships had been similarly quarantined at Haldia.Sarkar, a hotel management graduate, had worked for a company in the US for three years before joining Diamond Princess eight months ago. “Initially, we heard the quarantine was for 14 days. Now, we aren’t sure when it will end,” he said.While Sarkar’s mother Chandi is spending sleepless nights, his elder brother Shyamal said: “He has not been infected yet. But he may catch the virus if he remains confined to the ship. We appeal to everyone to rescue him.”

Title: CID questions Ranaghat MP over MLA murder
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Kolkata: CID questioned Ranaghat’s BJP MP Jagannath Sarkar on Saturday about Krishnaganj MLA Satyajit Biswas’s murder last February.

This comes days after the Calcutta High Court granted Sarkar anticipatory bail till February 28. A division bench of justices Joymalya Bagchi and Suvra Ghosh, however, directed him to meet the investigating officer and fixed February 18 for final hearing of his case.

The Trinamool Congress MLA was killed amid murmurs that local BJP leaders had plotted his murder.

CID sources said Sarkar was questioned for around four hours and mostly “cooperated”. He was asked about whether he had links with the accused, his knowledge of the incident and whether his statements matched those of the others. Sarkar later said he had always complied with CID directives. “I will cooperate with the investigation in whatever capacity,” he said.

The victim’s family had lodged an FIR accusing 43 people. In the supplementary FIR, BJP leader Mukul Roy and Sarkar were included in the accused list and investigators had charged them with masterminding the crime. However, in the initial charge sheet filed by the investigators, their names were not included as the probe found inadequate evidence. But CID moved a plea before a Ranaghat court a few weeks later seeking permission to initiate a fresh investigation against them.

The investigators informed the court that after seizing the mobile phone of one accused, his conversations with Roy and Sarkar had been recovered, which is why fresh investigation against the duo was required. The Ranaghat court restrained the investigators from including their names in the charge sheet but let them continue the probe against the duo.

Apprehending arrest because of the fresh probe, Roy and Sarkar moved an anticipatory bail before the HC. The same division bench had earlier issued an interim order asking police not to arrest Roy at least till April and directed investigators to complete the probe by March.

Title: Kolkata: Books on CAA, NRC fly off the shelves
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

One of the books on the issue at the book fair.

KOLKATA: Niche publications that print books on current affairs and little magazines that usually struggle to survive are making the most of the spike in interest on the new citizenship law, the National Register of Citizens and National Population Register fuelled by the ongoing nationwide protests. Nearly all the publications have come out with issues focusing on these topics in December and January and these are flying off the shelves at the Kolkata book fair and at stores across the city.

The demand started picking up after the passage of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ) in Parliament on Dec-ember 11 and books and little magazines on these subjects have far outpaced those on other current affair topics.

Almost all the titles are priced between Rs 15 and Rs 50.

When all five copies of ‘The Saga of Assam’s National Reg-ister of Citizens ( NRC )’, a book that had been gathering dust on a shelf at Parchment Books in Kalighat for months, got sold within 48 hours of the passage of the CAA, the seller called the publisher to order more. But even the publisher had run out of copies.

“The interest on CAA, NRC, and NPR is so high that all the books that I had stocked, both in favour of CAA and against, got sold out,” said Phalguni Ghosh of Parchment Books.

At Dhyanbindu, a bookstore near College Square known for its rare titles on literature, art, music and politics, buyers are turning up even from the districts to pick up books on NRC, NPR and CAA.

“Books on these topics are moving rapidly off the shelves. People are also buying books on Kashmir, refugee politics and migration along with those on Syama Prasad Mukherjee and RSS,” said owner Subrata Sarkar. He added that all copies of a book on NRC in Assam got sold off in no time.

The scene is similar at Manik book stall and Big Byang café in Jadavpur, Sunilda’s book stall in Ultadanga, Read Bengali book store in Lake Market and Patiram in College Street.

People’s Study Circle, publisher of ‘The Saga of Assam’s National Register of Citizens (NRC)’, which has been the hottest selling book on the issue so far, has also come out with booklets on NRC, NPR, migration issues, refugee politics and the role of RSS in India’s Independence.

“The book on Assam NRC was our first and so far we have sold around 5,000 copies. Such was the response that we translated the book into English and Assamese. These too sold like hot cakes,” said Kasturi Bose, q senior member of People’s Study Circle. Another recent publication, ‘Nijer Deshe Refugee Hobo?’, a compilation of frequently asked questions on NRC, NPR and CAA, is on the verge of getting sold out.

“Affordability is a key criteria as the idea is to reach out to as many people as possible. These are issues that will create difficulties for ordinary people. So people are raising their voice nationwide. This has helped in the sale of the booklets which were published as a mass awareness tool,” said Dwaipayan Banerjee, another member of the publishing house.

Banking on the high interest, a number of book stalls at the Kolkata book fair have stocked up on these books. The December issue of several little magazines also focus on NRC and NPR.

“Little magazines like Aneek, Ekush Shatak have come up with writings on NRC and NPR in their December issue and they were a huge hit. Within 15 days, the first set of all these magazines (over 500 copies) were sold,” said Tapas Bhattacharya, owner of Patiram.

Bookstore owners said besides their regular customers, mostly students and researchers are buying these books.

Title: Valentine's Week: Happy Chocolate Day 2020: Images, Quotes, Wishes, Greetings, Messages, Cards, Pictures, GIFs and Wallpaper
Content: Without a shadow of a doubt, chocolates are a gateway to enter into the heart of your special ones. As you know the festival of love, Valentine's Day is just around the corner, we have a full week dedicated to celebrate the occasion. Each day of the week preceding the Valentine's Day has its own significance and February 9 is observed as Chocolate Day in Valentine's Week. Lovers across the world have already started preparing for this joyous occasion. Although there are a plethora of ways to share your feelings with your loved one but one of the best ways to express is by giving them scrumptious chocolates. In many ways, chocolate is indeed one of the most wonderful gifts to give your crush, lover or even friends. Chocolate is symbolic of never-ending love and affection shared between two people. Also, chocolates are considered a great source of cutting down stress and send a wave of sweetness in an individual’s body. It can be the best gift to cheer your loved ones up almost instantly.On the occasion of the chocolate day, sending your special one a memorable chocolate day wish accompanied by a box of favourite chocolates is indeed one of the sweetest things you can do to make his/her day. Not only the charm of chocolate day wishes can add bountiful sweetness in one's life but also it makes the relationship more cheerful and consolidated. Here we have compiled a list of heartfelt happy chocolate day messages, wishes, quotes and images that you can add with or without a box of scrumptious chocolates to make the day of your special one extra special.Chocolates are like true love. As soon as you taste it, you will feel the different dimensions in this existence. Wish you a very Happy chocolate day!On the occasion of Chocolate Day, I am sending you all my love, beautiful red rose, gifts, and yes, your favourite chocolates. Happy chocolate day, sweetheart!Life is easier and sweeter when you have a loving partner like you and a box of chocolates beside you. Wishing a happy chocolate day to my sweetheart!Sending across a box of chocolates that are but not half as sweet as you and your smile. Wish you a very Happy Chocolate Day my dear valentine.My heart is as delicate as scrumptious chocolate, I want you to sprinkle the fruits and nuts in it to make it sweeter. Sending you heartfelt Chocolate Day wishes!I searched many shops to buy the best chocolate for you but I didn’t find any chocolate sweeter than you and your smile. Happy Chocolate Day my sweetheart!Just like the Chocolate Day celebration is incomplete without chocolates, my life is incomplete without you. Wish you a very Happy Chocolate Day, my love!Today is chocolate day and I am looking forward to getting dipped in your sweet and passionate love. Wish you a Happy Chocolate Day my love!My dearest love, if you believe in Valentine's Day you must believe in Valentine's Week. If you believe in life, you must believe in heartbeats. If you believe in love, you must believe in you and me. Wish you a very Happy chocolate day!Just like the sweetness of chocolates, your smiling face gives me immense happiness. I wish you a Happy Chocolate Day, darling!In the book of life, few people will be very close to you, few will get away from you. But, life will become full of love, if you add the taste of chocolate in all those relationships. Wish you a Happy Chocolate Day 2020!You are my heartbeat sweetheart. If you are the chocolate then I am your wrapper No matter what, I will always be with you. Wishing you a Happy chocolate day 2020!

Title: TMC entry buzz as Chhatradhar meets Partha
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Jhargram: A meeting between Trinamool secretary general and state education minister Partha Chatterjee and Chhatradhar Mahato, the former leader of PCPA who was recently released from jail, sparked speculation on Saturday about the latter’s joining mainstream politics.

The meeting took place at Jhargram Rajbari. Chatterjee was in Jhargram to inaugurate Jhumur Utsav.

Mahato said: “We discussed the situation in Jangalmahal and the condition of the area and its people in the past. Jangalmahal has changed completely. Thanks to CM Mamata Banerjee, the tribal belt has witnessed a development spree. I myself can’t recognise many areas of Jangalmahal.”

Asked if he was considering joining Trinamool, Mahato said, “I have just got out of jail. I have not decided, but I will not sit idle.”

Chatterjee said: “He is an old friend. I called him for a meeting.” Asked if TMC wou-ld invite him to join the party, he added: “Let him get organised. He should be given time to decide on this. Ours (TMC’s) is a large family just as his is.”

Title: Speeding car kills cop checking rash driving in Bengaluru
Content:
The deceased, Dhananjaya Y (inset), and his colleague Uma Maheshwar were thrown towards the metal railing on ... Read More

BENGALURU: A speeding car ploughed into a traffic police team on Kempegowda International Airport Road on Saturday evening, killing a head constable and seriously injuring another.The impact was so severe that the two constables, Dhananjaya Y and Uma Maheshwar, from the Chikkajala traffic wing, were thrown towards the metal railing on the side of the road. They were rushed to a nearby hospital, but there was nothing doctors could do to help Dhananjaya, 40. He was declared brought dead. Uma was later shifted to a private hospital; his condition is said to be serious.The errant motorist, Kushal Raj M, who was headed to the airport in a white Hyundai i10, has been arrested. Police said tests had revealed that he was not driving under the influence, but he was travelling at a very high speed. Raj is a textile merchant from Gavipuram, Basavanagudi.The accident occurred around 5:30pm. Dhananjaya and Uma were attached to a speed interceptor vehicle, which was stationed near Chikkajala flyover, cracking down on airport-bound motorists driving too fast.Witnesses said the traffic team had stopped a few cars and was issuing challans when Raj's i10 appeared on the scene. The speeding car smashed into a stationary four-wheeler on the left side of the road before hitting the two constables."The i10 was being driven at a great speed. I don't think the driver spotted police personnel standing on the side of the road," said Vivek, who witnessed the accident. "Everything happened in a matter of seconds. It would have been a bigger tragedy had the car been in the right lane."Another passerby, Bheemappa, said the constables had no time to move away from the oncoming vehicle's path. "I use this route often. At times, drivers try to avoid police teams by speeding off. It's dangerous. No one should put lives at risk this way just to avoid a fine," he said.Police said Raj was in a rush as he had to catch a 7.10pm flight to Mumbai. Some people, in fact, were alarmed by the way he was driving."I noticed the vehicle when it went past my cab; it was jumping lanes and speeding. I was discussing how dangerous this was with the cab driver when the speeding car hit another vehicle and some police personnel," said Sandeep Sharma, who alerted traffic police about the accident on Twitter.Dhananjaya is survived by his wife Anusuyamma, who is a constable in Yelahanka New Town police station. The couple has two kids.In Video: Bengaluru: Speeding car ploughs into cops on highway duty, kills one

Title: Beijing scrambles to keep cities in lockdown fed
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

File photo

BEIJING: Communist leaders are trying to keep food flowing to crowded cities despite antidisease controls and to quell fears of possible shortages and price spikes following panic buying after most access to Wuhan was cut off January 23.

Food stocks in supermarkets ran low shortly after Beijing imposed travel curbs and extended the Lunar New Year holiday to keep factories, offices and other businesses closed and the public at home in an attempt to prevent the virus from spreading. That also kept trucks off the road, disrupting supplies of food.

This week, a cabinet official acknowledged vegetable supplies were uneven and some “daily necessities” were sold out. “These problems are being coordinated and resolved,” Lian Weiliang, deputy chairman of the National Development and Reform Commission, said on February 3.

Later that day, state TV announced the ruling Communist Party order local authorities nationwide to “ensure the supply of daily necessities”, including vegetables, meat, eggs, milk and grain. The following day, the agriculture ministry told officials to unblock transportation and “ensure normal operation” of livestock and feed production.

In Nanjing, a grocery store employee said, “Some people tried to buy a lot, but they are no longer doing it after seeing the abundant supply.“

Title: Bengaluru: Need Rs 1,400 crore to kickstart suburban rail project, says K-RIDE
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: The city’s longpending demand for suburban rail is unlikely to be fulfilled in the near future with Karnataka Rail Infrastructure Development Enterprises (K-RIDE), the special purpose vehicle mandated to execute the Rs 18,600 crore project, saying it requires at least Rs 1,400 crore to get the project started.

The development comes at a time when the Centre has made a paltry allocation of Rs 1 crore for the project this year. While K-RIDE said it’s in talks with financial institutions to fund the project, the railway ministry maintained there will be no delay. “We propose to invest 5% of the construction cost and 50% of the land cost in the first financial year (2020-21), which is around Rs 1,400 crore, for the project to take off,” said K-RIDE managing director Amit Garg on Saturday.

The project is funded 20% each by the state and Centre and 60% through external loans. It remains to be seen what amount that will be allocated in the state budget. Garg said they are in talks with financial institutions like World Bank, ADB, JICA, AIIB and Korea Eximbank (KEXIM).

Meanwhile, minister of state for railways Suresh Angadi said the project will not be delayed, but refused to provide a time frame.

Asked about the delay in getting clearance from the Cabinet Committee of Economic Affairs for the project that was announced in 2018-19 budget, he said, “Karnataka had a coalition government at that time. The Rs 1 crore allocated in the Pink Book is a token amount...The Karnataka CM has assured that a significant amount will be allocated in the state budget.”

Title: pipes on walking pavement
Content:

Title: BEWARE OF PAYTM FRAUD
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

I got a post on 8th Feb morning which contained a letter and a certificate and a coupon claiming that i have won Rs. 1 lakh but to redeem the same I have to deposit some fees in advance. I knew it was fake but i still called that number and asked them the procedure and he asked me to deposit some amount and when i informed him that I am calling the police he immediately disconnected the call. A request to all fellow citizens to be aware of such frauds and not fall prey to it

Title: Briton who joined IS loses bid to get back citizenship
Content:
This story is from February 9, 2020

LONDON: A UK woman who as a teenager ran away to join the Islamic State terror group lost a legal challenge on Friday aimed at restoring her citizenship, which was revoked on national security grounds.

Shamima Begum, who went to Syria in 2015 to join IS, resurfaced at a refugee camp in Syria last year and said she wanted to come home. Former home secretary Sajid Javid revoked her citizenship, but she challenged the decision.

She said she wasn’t the citizen of another country and the decision left her stateless. But the tribunal ruled in Javid’s favour. Judge Doron Blum said the decision didn’t breach the home office’s “extraterritorial human rights policy” and that she was “a citizen of Bangladesh by descent”, and therefore not rendered stateless.
